NORDWIND STEIN--Thekla. 08/08/38 - 09/12/13 Dear Tek, you left too soon. Happy Birthday. Love, Natash
LEVY--Arthur. February 27, 1930-August 8, 2007. We miss you so much darling. We love you. Barb

WENGROVER--Anita. It is with overwhelming sadness that we announce the passing of Anita Wengrover, wife of the late Bernard Wengrover, on August 5, 2014. Anita died peacefully in her home in Boca Raton, Florida. A devoted mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister and aunt, she loved and was loved by her children, 11 grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Anita was known for her beauty, strength, and zest for life. May her memory remain a blessing.

ROSENFELD--Gabriel Ira, known to everyone as Gabby, passed away at 11:59pm on the 6th of August 2014, his 89th birthday. Predeceased by his parents, Jacob and Josephine, his sister Saundre and his aunts Elsie and Fannie Smallin, he leaves behind his wife of 64 years, Louise, and his children and their spouses, Eric (Sally), Alison (Jim) and Leslie (Chuck). The family wishes to thank all his caregivers, especially Marilou. Former, 30 plus year Chairman of the New Castle Zoning Board of Appeals. On the Boards of Northern Westchester Hospital, Katonah Museum of Art, A-Home, Holocaust and Human Rights Education Center, Neighbor's Link, Chappaqua Women's Shelter. Long time supporter of the League of Women Voters and New Castle Democrats. Kind, funny, WWII combat vet, Purple Heart, Bronze Star, French Legion of Honor, ardent Democrat, Chappaqua, Chappaqua, Chappaqua, community service, Memorial Day Parade, motorcycle sidecar-ist, boat modeler, landscaper, Erasmus Hall, Cornell, chocolate, Adventurer's Club, Naval Order of the United States, Cautioneer, Rotary President and two-time Paul Harris Award winner, funeral director, stockbroker, business manager of The New York Cosmos, Bahamas, Westchester Municipal Planning Federation, National Maritime Historical Society, New Castle Historical Society, Southwest Harbor, corn, great laugh, noodles, people, fried clams, dogs, family, inspiration and influence to many. Services will be held at 1pm on Sunday, August 10th at Temple Beth El in Chappaqua NY. Come share your stories. (Interment will be earlier that morning at Westchester Hills Cemetery at 11am.) Contributions may be made in his honor to Northern Westchester Hospital or any of his organizations.

MURASE--Jiro. The Lauder family and The Estee Lauder Companies are deeply saddened by the loss of Jiro Murase, a valued and trusted counsel, mentor, and adviser to the Lauder family and the Company for more than 50 years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and many friends. With grace, friendship and humility, Jiro imparted immense wisdom and understanding to the Lauder family and to our Company. He will be greatly missed by so many for whom he was, and will continue to be, an inspiration. Leonard A. Lauder Chairman Emeritus William P. Lauder Executive Chairman Fabrizio Freda President and Chief Executive Officer Sara Moss General Counsel

KUNHARDT--Erich E.,The NYU community mourns the loss of Erich Kunhardt. Alumnus, teacher, scholar, provost of Polytechnic University, and key player in accomplishing the merger of NYU and Poly, his was a deeply valued and respected presence. His foresight, optimism, dedication, professionalism, and dignity were an example to us all. Whatever he turned his attention and efforts to, he made better, and we admired him for it. To his family and loved ones, we offer our deepest sympathies as we grieve with them over this sharp loss. David McLaughlin, NYU Provost Katepalli Sreenivasan, President of NYU's Polytechnic School of Engineering and NYU Dean of Engineering

GLAISTER--Christopher J.,urban designer, died in London on July 23, 2014. Chris was born in Carlisle, England on January 24, 1942 and educated at the Universities of Durham (B.A.) and London (M.A.), and at M.I.T. His long career included partnership in Design Development Resources/Eisenman Robertson Architects in New York, work on the design of the Shahestan Pahlavi Master Plan for Teheran and on Canary Wharf in London. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Sheiry Glaister. His friendship, intelligence, stoical sense of humor and passionate love of design are treasured by all who knew him.

GELBART--Marion, passed away peacefully at her home in New York City on August 6, 2014. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Karen (Peter) and Laurie (Larry). Grandmother of Julie, Ben and Jacob. Successful businesswoman. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue on Friday August 8th at 11:30am.

FLORIN--Esther, on August 7, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Loving mother of Mark and Linda; Joel and Jacalyn. Cherished grandmother of Daniella, Samuel, David, Michelle, Wyatt and Skylar. Devoted great-grandmother of Mollie. Forever loved and will always be missed.
FLORIN--Esther. A special lady who will be missed by all. Our love goes out the entire Florin family. Scott, Kelli and Rebecca

FAUER--Stanley, age 91, passed away on August 4, 2014 in Palm Beach, FL. Formerly of Woodmere, NY and Flint, MI. Beloved husband of Pat; loving father of Robert (Kristina), Stephen (Shari) and David. Cherished grandfather of Allie, Erin and Chase. Stanley served in World War II in Patton's Third Army and received The French Legion of Honor. He was Vice President of Hertz Truck Division, President of GMC Quality Truck Sales, Inc. and he was a Hadassah Associate. Funeral service to be held on Friday, August 8, 2014 at 11am at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY under the direction of I.J. Morris. Contributions in Mr. Fauer's memory may be made to Hadassah, 3545 S. Ocean Blvd, #

ELLSWORTH--Robert H.,The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Robert H. Ellsworth, a respected Benefactor of the Museum since 1977. One of the most extraordinary dealers of Asian art of his time, he was also a scholar and author, and amassed one of the world's greatest private collections of Chinese art, from furniture, jade, metalwork, and textiles, to painting and calligraphy of the 19th and 20th centuries. Many of these works are now in the collection of the Met, some acquired from Bob Ellsworth through purchase and nearly 500 more as generous gifts over two decades. He will long be remembered in his field and at the Met, where his important contributions will be seen and appreciated for generations to come. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President

DAVIDSON--Ralph P.,Ralph P. Davidson, beloved husband, devoted father and grandfather died on August 1, 2014 at his home in North West Washington. He would have been 87 on August 17th. He is survived by his wife Lou Hill Davidson and children Will, Ross, Scott, Sydney and Mary Elizabeth. He is also survived by ten grandchildren. He is predeceased by his son Dr. Andrew Davidson. Ralph Parsons Davidson was born on August 17, 1927 in Santa Fe, New Mexico to William Clarence Davidson and Doris Parsons Davidson. He served in the US Navy during World War II in the Pacific. He received a B.A. in international relations from Stanford University in 1950. Later, he worked in Europe for both the Marshall Plan and the US Central Intelligence Agency. He began his thirty-three year career at the illustrious publishing company Time Inc. as an advertising salesman for Life Magazine in 1954. He served as publisher of Time Magazine in the 1970's and became Chairman of the Board of Time Inc. in 1980. He was often quoted as saying, "Being Publisher of Time Magazine was the best job that anyone could have." Throughout his life, Mr. Davidson served on various boards supporting the arts, such as the New York City Ballet and the Shakespeare Theatre Company in Washington, DC. He also served as Chairman of the National Business Committee of the Arts. Following his retirement from Time Inc., Mr. Davidson was appointed Chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a position he served in from 1988-1990. Mr. Davidson was also an active supporter of higher education. He was co-chairman of the Independent Commission of the Future of the State University of New York and he served as Chairman of the Board of the American University in Bulgaria. His concern for human and environmental causes led him to serve on the boards of the National Urban League, Refugees International, World Wild Life Fund, Phoenix House and the National Council for Adoption. Mr. Davidson lived a life full of love and concern for others. He was admired for his constant pursuit of knowledge and for his lifelong spirit of adventure. His retirement years were spent in Washington D.C. and Vineyard Haven, MA, where he enjoyed time with his family and friends. They remember him as a renaissance man who read voraciously and would often recite passages from Shakespeare and Rudyard Kipling's Gunga Din. Mr. Davidson is loved by many and will be greatly missed by all who shared in his joy-filled life. Services to honor Ralph's life will be at the Arlington National Cemetery at a later date. Please contact Joseph Gawler's Sons LLC for information on the memorial service.

COHEN--Doris K.,beloved wife for nearly 53 years to the late Sheldon Cohen, devoted mother to Alison Cohen and Karen Caine, and mother-in-law to Cy Caine, adored Nana to Alex, Max, and Brian Caine, and Katelyn and Connor Jang, devoted sister to the late Betty Silverman, dear aunt and friend to many. Services will be held on Sunday, August 10th at 11:30am at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NY. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice.

CHEIT--Earl F. "Budd", died on August 2, 2014 at the age of 87 at home in Kensington, California. He was Edgar F. Kaiser Professor of Business and Public Policy Emeritus and Dean Emeritus of Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. Survived by his wife June, four children and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Haas School of Business or Cal Performances at the University of California.

CHAYEVSKY--Svetlana, 71, of Atlanta, passed away August 6, 2014. A loving mother and grandmother, she is survived by her son, Gene and his wife Lina; and grandchildren: Kirk, Liv, and William. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, www.alz.org. Funeral will be 1:15pm, Friday, August 8, at Nevsky Yablokoff Memorial Chapel. Burial will follow in Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

BROWN--Nona Baldwin. A pioneer among women professionals in journalism, Mrs. Brown died July 25, 2014 in Washington, D.C., aged 96. She was born May 11, 1918 to Helen Smitheman Baldwin and Allen Thomas Baldwin in Elizabeth, N.J., graduated from Vassar College in 1939, later receiving a master's degree from the Columbia School of Journalism, and 1940, joined the New York Times, where she was one of the first women reporters given a byline. Mrs. Brown took a leave of absence from the Times to serve in the U.S. Navy during World War II. In 1941 she met and married Lt. Cmdr. Clinton Bleecker Duma Brown of New York City. After the war, she returned to work at the Times and moved to Washington, D.C. with her husband, where she continued to write for the Washington bureau of the Times until she retired after 35 years. Her 2012 memoir, Through the Opening Door: My Pioneering Journey in Mainstream Journalism, recounts her experiences as a reporter. Mrs. Brown was preceded in death by her sister, Elizabeth Baldwin Montbach; her brother, Thomas Baldwin; and her husband, Clinton Brown. She is survived by 11 nieces and nephews; many great-nieces and nephews, and a multitude of great-grand-nieces and nephews. A memorial celebration will be held Sunday, August 10, at 2pm at her last residence, Grand Oaks, 5901 MacArthur Boulevard, Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that donations in Mrs. Brown's memory may be made to Vassar College, or to a local Humane Society.

BRAKMAN--William Henry "Bill", Jr.,passed away August 6, 2014. He was 86 years old and a resident of Port Washington, Long Island. Bill is survived by his wife of 57 years Joan; son and daughter-in- law, Hank and Charlott Brakman and daughter and son-in- law Sarah-Vaughan Brakman and James M. Youakim, and three grandchildren. Visiting hours at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY 11030 on Saturday, August 9, 2014 from 7 to 9pm and Sunday, August 10, 2014, 3 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, August 11, 2014 at 9:30am at St. Peter of Alcantara, 1321 Port Washington Blvd., Port Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the memory of Bill Brakman to St. Francis Hospital Foundation, 100 Port Washington Blvd., Roslyn, NY 11576 or to the Manhasset Bay Sailing Foundation/Brakman Fund at 455 Main Street, Port Washington, NY 11050.

BENNIS--Warren. The Antioch College community mourns the death of Warren Bennis, a distinguished graduate of the college, who was an educator, an honorary trustee of Antioch College, and a member of the "Antioch Review" advisory board. He was also a scholar whose pioneering work on leadership received international acclaim and led corporations from Cambridge to Calcutta to reshape their organizations. Throughout his life everyone sought his advice and were fortunate to receive it. Frances Horowitz, Chair of the Antioch College Board of Trustees Mark Roosevelt, President

YABLON--Lawrence, 86, of Boynton Beach passed away Tuesday, August 5, 2014. Formerly of West Hempstead, NY. Beloved husband of Babette for 62 years; devoted father of Dr. Jeffrey (Monique) Yablon and Bruce (Andrea) Yablon; cherished grandfather of Jeremy, Elizabeth, Lauren, and Michael; dear brother of Leon (Dana) Yablon and brother-in-law of Flora Rothman. Services and entombment were held in Boynton Beach, FL. Lawrence brought smiles to everyone and will be missed dearly by his family and all who knew him.

SIGETY--Charles E.,Charles E. Sigety, an entrepreneur, healthcare pioneer and New York Real Estate developer, died August 3 at 91. Born in the Bronx, Mr. Sigety graduated from Townsend Harris High School, Columbia University, Harvard Business School (HBS), and Yale Law School. Mr. Sigety served on the USS Fall River as an Ensign in the Navy Supply Corp during WWII. Upon graduating from Yale Law School, Mr. Sigety taught accounting at Pratt Institute and Yale University and became Assistant to the Commission on Federal Taxation at the American Institute of Accountants. Mr. Sigety served in the Eisenhower Administration as Deputy Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, and later returned to New York as a first Assistant Attorney General, and was also named the head of the NY State Housing Finance Agency. An HBS course called "The Management of New Enterprises," or entrepreneurship, would profoundly influence his business life. In the early 1950's he co-founded Video Vittles, Inc. with his wife, known professionally as Kit Kinne, who was the On Air Food Editor of NBC's early daytime TV show, The Home Show. He created Metropolitan Ski Slopes, bringing downhill skiing to New York City's Van Cortlandt Park in 1962, and founded Florence Nightingale Health Center in Manhattan in 1965. In 1982, he and his family purchased Professional Medical Products, Inc., a former medical device manufacturing subsidiary of Parke Davis Corporation headquartered in Greenwood, SC. He was also an active real estate developer, primarily in NYC and Bucks County, PA. Mr. Sigety's philanthropic interests focused around educational institutions, giving both his time and resources to the Navy Supply School Foundation, Townsend Harris Alumni Association, Cazenovia College, Delaware Valley College, The Harvard Business School Alumni Association and the National Association for Continence. He was also an active member of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, and Confrerie de la Chaine des Rotisseurs where he honed his love of fine food and wine, and was an avid collector of wine, art and historic memorabilia, particularly documents. He retired to Boca Raton, FL and is survived by his wife of 66 years, Katharine Snell Sigety; his brother Ernest F. Sigety of Alexandria, VA; five children: C. Birge Sigety, Kinne S. Yon, Robert G. Sigety, Cornelius E. Sigety, Elizabeth S. Marcus and 12 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Doylestown Presbyterian Church - Forward Together Fund (www.dtownpc.org); further information may be found at www.shellyfuneralhomes.com.

ROSENFELD--Gabriel Ira, known to everyone as Gabby, passed away at 11:59pm on the 6th of August 2014, his 89th birthday. Predeceased by his parents, Jacob and Josephine, his sister Saundre and his aunts Elsie and Fannie Smallin, he leaves behind his wife of 64 years, Louise, and his children and their spouses, Eric (Sally), Alison (Jim) and Leslie (Chuck). The family wishes to thank all his caregivers, especially Marilou. Former, 30 plus year Chairman of the New Castle Zoning Board of Appeals. On the Boards of Northern Westchester Hospital, Katonah Museum of Art, A-Home, Holocaust and Human Rights Education Center, Neighbor's Link, Chappaqua Women's Shelter. Long time supporter of the League of Women Voters and New Castle Democrats. Kind, funny, WWII combat vet, Purple Heart, Bronze Star, French Legion of Honor, ardent Democrat, Chappaqua, Chappaqua, Chappaqua, community service, Memorial Day Parade, motorcycle sidecar-ist, boat modeler, landscaper, Erasmus Hall, Cornell, chocolate, Adventurer's Club, Naval Order of the United States, Cautioneer, Rotary President and two-time Paul Harris Award winner, funeral director, stockbroker, business manager of The New York Cosmos, Bahamas, Westchester Municipal Planning Federation, National Maritime Historical Society, New Castle Historical Society, Southwest Harbor, corn, great laugh, noodles, people, fried clams, dogs, family, inspiration and influence to many. Services will be held at 1pm on Sunday, August 10th at Temple Beth El in Chappaqua NY. Come share your stories. (Interment will be earlier that morning at Westchester Hills Cemetery at 11am.) Contributions may be made in his honor to Northern Westchester Hospital or any of his organizations.

PERLE--E. Gabriel. of Greenwich, CT and formerly of Palm Beach, FL, one of the country's leading intellectual property authorities, died peacefully at home from complications from prostate cancer on August 8 at the age of 91. He was a son of the late Philip and Simmi Perle. A native of New York City, Gabe, as he was known, was an Eagle Scout and graduated from Queens College in 1943 where he was president of the Student Council, editor of the school's newspaper, and the first recipient of the Student Council Award for Distinguished Service to Queens College. He served as a Lieutenant in the amphibious forces in the Navy during World War II and was in command of landing craft during the initial assault waves in the invasions of Guam, Leyte, Luzon and Okinawa. After the war, Mr. Perle entered Yale Law School, where he was an editor of the Yale Law Journal and obtained his law degree in 1949. Mr. Perle began his legal career at the New York City firm of Cravath, Swain & Moore and spent many years as Corporate Vice President-Law at Time Inc. where he was responsible for the legal affairs of Time, Life, Fortune, Sports Illustrated, Money and People magazines as well as Time-Life Books, Home Box Office and Time Warner Cable. During his years at Time Inc., Mr. Perle became one of the country's leading authorities in intellectual property, copyright, publishing, computer, entertainment and communications law. In 1975, President Gerald Ford appointed Mr. Perle as a founding Commissioner of the National Commission on New Technological Works ("CONTU"), which drafted legislation enacted by Congress for the protection of computer programming and software. His pioneering work helped lay the foundation for all future discussions of copyright law. At the time of his death, Mr. Perle was Senior Counsel at the intellectual property law firm Ohlandt Greeley Ruggiero & Perle, in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Perle was a past President and Honorary Trustee of the Copyright Society of the U.S.A. and a two-time Chairman of the American Bar Association's Copyright Division/IP Law Section in addition to having been a Vice President and Member of the Board of Directors of the U.S. Trademark Association. Mr. Perle co-authored, along with attorney John Williams, the seminal two-volume work, Perle & Williams on Publishing Law. In addition, Mr. Perle was the Vice Chairman of the Big Apple Circus during its critical early phases. He was also a former director and secretary of the Baron de Hirsch Fund, of which he was an honorary Trustee. He was a member of the Century Association of New York City, and had been a member of Banyan Golf Club of Palm Beach, Sunningdale Country Club of Scarsdale and the Yale Club of New York City for many years. Brilliant, witty, and dynamic, Mr. Perle thoroughly enjoyed life, golf and a good martini. But most of all, he loved - and was dearly loved - by his family: his wife, Patricia Sinnott Perle; his daughter Elizabeth Anne Perle, son-in-law Steven Pressman and grandson David Perle McKenna of San Francisco; and his stepchildren Jo-Anne Sinnott of Larchmont, NY, Diane Sinnott of Tiburon, Cal. and William Sinnott of Norwalk, Conn. Mr. Perle was predeceased by his first wife, Ellen Carlotta Kraus of Philadelphia, and his brother Richard of New York City. At Mr. Perle's request, there will be no funeral service. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. The family wishes to thank Karen, Stacie and Claudette for their kindness, concern and care for Mr. Perle during his illness. Photo is by Alfred Eisenstaedt.

DAVIS--Alice Faye. Alice Faye Davis, 74, of Marietta, Georgia, passed away on August 2, 2014, after a long, fiercely fought battle with lung cancer. Born August 5, 1939, in Granville County, North Carolina, Mrs. Davis graduated from North Carolina A&T State University and earned Masters degrees from City College of New York and the College of New Rochelle. She was a devoted teacher and guidance counselor in the New York City public school system for more than 25 years. A woman of great faith, she also served as the First Lady of St. Paul Community Church in Harlem for 23 years. She was active in Jack and Jill of America and served on the board of the Greenwich Country Day School. After retiring to Georgia, she became a devout member, stewardess and missionary of Big Bethel AME Church in Atlanta. She is survived by her loving husband of more than 40 years, Rev. George Davis; daughter Alisha Davis (Michael Roberts); son Marc Davis; brother Joe Clark (Rita); sister Alma Wright; and many other loving family and friends. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

DAVIDSON--Ralph P.,Ralph P. Davidson, beloved husband, devoted father and grandfather died on August 1, 2014 at his home in North West Washington. He would have been 87 on August 17th. He is survived by his wife Lou Hill Davidson and children Will, Ross, Scott, Sydney and Mary Elizabeth. He is also survived by ten grandchildren. He is predeceased by his son Dr. Andrew Davidson. Ralph Parsons Davidson was born on August 17, 1927 in Santa Fe, New Mexico to William Clarence Davidson and Doris Parsons Davidson. He served in the US Navy during World War II in the Pacific. He received a B.A. in international relations from Stanford University in 1950. Later, he worked in Europe for both the Marshall Plan and the US Central Intelligence Agency. He began his thirty-three year career at the illustrious publishing company Time Inc. as an advertising salesman for Life Magazine in 1954. He served as publisher of Time Magazine in the 1970's and became Chairman of the Board of Time Inc. in 1980. He was often quoted as saying, "Being Publisher of Time Magazine was the best job that anyone could have." Throughout his life, Mr. Davidson served on various boards supporting the arts, such as the New York City Ballet and the Shakespeare Theatre Company in Washington, DC. He also served as Chairman of the National Business Committee of the Arts. Following his retirement from Time Inc., Mr. Davidson was appointed Chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a position he served in from 1988-1990. Mr. Davidson was also an active supporter of higher education. He was co-chairman of the Independent Commission of the Future of the State University of New York and he served as Chairman of the Board of the American University in Bulgaria. His concern for human and environmental causes led him to serve on the boards of the National Urban League, Refugees International, World Wild Life Fund, Phoenix House and the National Council for Adoption. Mr. Davidson lived a life full of love and concern for others. He was admired for his constant pursuit of knowledge and for his lifelong spirit of adventure. His retirement years were spent in Washington D.C. and Vineyard Haven, MA, where he enjoyed time with his family and friends. They remember him as a renaissance man who read voraciously and would often recite passages from Shakespeare and Rudyard Kipling's Gunga Din. Mr. Davidson is loved by many and will be greatly missed by all who shared in his joy-filled life. Services to honor Ralph's life will be at the Arlington National Cemetery at a later date. Please contact Joseph Gawler's Sons LLC for information on the memorial service.

von HOFFMANN--Ladislaus. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum mourn the death of Ladislaus von Hoffmann. SWARTZ--Barbara E.,died peacefully in New York on July 31, 2014 at age 69 after a long period of declining health. Formerly the director of the New York University Law School's clinic at Bedford Hills Prison, she later became a Distinguished Professor of Law at Touro College Law Center, Long Island, where she also created the school's human rights program in Berlin. A long-time human rights advocate, she served as a consultant to the World Health Organization and other international groups. Her passion later in life was mediation, helping people amicably resolve both domestic and workplace disputes. For several years, she served as a commentator on Court TV. She earned a J.D. from NYU and master's degrees in political science and public health from the Universities of Michigan and Columbia, respectively. Barbara was diagnosed with kidney disease at age 28 and spent 12 years on hemodialysis before receiving a kidney transplant, which sustained her life during the past 18 years. She demonstrated an indomitable will to live a full life and to act on her commitment to human rights in spite of the limitations imposed by illnesses, inspiring many by her example. Barbara loved to travel and developed lasting friendships worldwide. She met her husband, Knud-Erik Rosenkrantz, in Copenhagen 35 years ago. In lieu of a funeral, a celebration of Barbara's life will be held at a later time. Donations may be sent to: Compassion & Choices of New York, 244 Fifth Avenue, #

SOKOLSKY--Irving G.,97, on July 31, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Evelyne for 59 years. Adored father of Leslie (deceased), Bette, and sons-in-law Melvyn Minsky and Stephen Fiss. Proud grandfather of Jenifer Minsky (Gary Frankel), Adam and Teresa Fiss, and David Fiss. Cherished great-grandfather to Emma, Dara and Brady Frankel, and Lance and Juliana Fiss. Treasured uncle to innumerable nieces and nephews. He was a WWII Navy veteran, executive at h.i.s. men's clothing for 25 years, held the position of President of Sands Point Condominium Association in Tamarac, FL, and capped off his professional career with Township Tennis Club in Coconut Creek, FL for which he served as a valued employee for over 30 years. Those fortunate enough to have known him are truly blessed.

SOBEL--Gerson, 104, died peacefully in his home in Rockville Centre. Gerson graduated Syracuse University where he was captain of the water polo team. After college, he sailed the Caribbean until returning to Manhattan to go into the stationery business. A great storyteller, his stories about New York and New Yorkers were a source of fascination and laughter to everyone who heard them. When he retired, he resumed competitive swimming and was inducted into the Metropolitan Hall of Fame in 2012. Preceded in death by his wife, Pearl, and son James, he is survived by his daughter Judith, son Tom (Marge), grandchildren Paul, Erik, Lisa, David and Daniel and by his great-grandchildren, Hawkins and Macy. A celebration of Gerson's life will be announced and held later. The family requests no flowers.

Children Dana, Fara and Richard, Scott and Eileen, Russell and Cheryl; grandchildren Jessica and Jeff, Rebecca and Eric, Lindsay and Jeff, Ali and Brett, Brett, Danny, Kayla, Leslie, Stephanie; great-grandchildren Sophia, Molly and Lily.

SIGETY--Charles E.,Charles E. Sigety, an entrepreneur, healthcare pioneer and New York Real Estate developer, died August 3 at 91. Born in the Bronx, Mr. Sigety graduated from Townsend Harris High School, Columbia University, Harvard Business School (HBS), and Yale Law School. Mr. Sigety served on the USS Fall River as an Ensign in the Navy Supply Corp during WWII. Upon graduating from Yale Law School, Mr. Sigety taught accounting at Pratt Institute and Yale University and became Assistant to the Commission on Federal Taxation at the American Institute of Accountants. Mr. Sigety served in the Eisenhower Administration as Deputy Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, and later returned to New York as a first Assistant Attorney General, and was also named the head of the NY State Housing Finance Agency. An HBS course called "The Management of New Enterprises," or entrepreneurship, would profoundly influence his business life. In the early 1950's he co-founded Video Vittles, Inc. with his wife, known professionally as Kit Kinne, who was the On Air Food Editor of NBC's early daytime TV show, The Home Show. He created Metropolitan Ski Slopes, bringing downhill skiing to New York City's Van Cortlandt Park in 1962, and founded Florence Nightingale Health Center in Manhattan in 1965. In 1982, he and his family purchased Professional Medical Products, Inc., a former medical device manufacturing subsidiary of Parke Davis Corporation headquartered in Greenwood, SC. He was also an active real estate developer, primarily in NYC and Bucks County, PA. Mr. Sigety's philanthropic interests focused around educational institutions, giving both his time and resources to the Navy Supply School Foundation, Townsend Harris Alumni Association, Cazenovia College, Delaware Valley College, The Harvard Business School Alumni Association and the National Association for Continence. He was also an active member of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, and Confrerie de la Chaine des Rotisseurs where he honed his love of fine food and wine, and was an avid collector of wine, art and historic memorabilia, particularly documents. He retired to Boca Raton, FL and is survived by his wife of 66 years, Katharine Snell Sigety; his brother Ernest F. Sigety of Alexandria, VA; five children: C. Birge Sigety, Kinne S. Yon, Robert G. Sigety, Cornelius E. Sigety, Elizabeth S. Marcus and 12 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Doylestown Presbyterian Church - Forward Together Fund (www.dtownpc.org); further information may be found at www.shellyfuneralhomes.com.

REEVES--Jennifer Wynne. New York artist, Jennifer Wynne Reeves, 51, died of a brain tumor on June 22. Jennifer spent much of her childhood curled up on her grandmother's sofa drawing pictures. Her love of making art led to a life of making paintings. Jennifer's work, a combination of abstraction and realism, was shown consistently since 1998 in New York and abroad. She received a Guggenheim Fellowship in 2012. Her provocative discourses about art and philosophy ignited fierce discussion in the art world. She was open and generous with aspiring artists, pushing them to guard their integrity in a world where imitation is often rewarded over innovation. An exhibition featuring Jennifer's work will be held at BravinLee Gallery opening Thursday, September 4, 6-8pm. A memorial celebration is set for September 6 at St Mark's Church 131 East 10th St., NYC.

PERLE--E. Gabriel. of Greenwich, CT and formerly of Palm Beach, FL, one of the country's leading intellectual property authorities, died peacefully at home from complications from prostate cancer on August 8 at the age of 91. He was a son of the late Philip and Simmi Perle. A native of New York City, Gabe, as he was known, was an Eagle Scout and graduated from Queens College in 1943 where he was president of the Student Council, editor of the school's newspaper, and the first recipient of the Student Council Award for Distinguished Service to Queens College. He served as a Lieutenant in the amphibious forces in the Navy during World War II and was in command of landing craft during the initial assault waves in the invasions of Guam, Leyte, Luzon and Okinawa. After the war, Mr. Perle entered Yale Law School, where he was an editor of the Yale Law Journal and obtained his law degree in 1949. Mr. Perle began his legal career at the New York City firm of Cravath, Swain & Moore and spent many years as Corporate Vice President-Law at Time Inc. where he was responsible for the legal affairs of Time, Life, Fortune, Sports Illustrated, Money and People magazines as well as Time-Life Books, Home Box Office and Time Warner Cable. During his years at Time Inc., Mr. Perle became one of the country's leading authorities in intellectual property, copyright, publishing, computer, entertainment and communications law. In 1975, President Gerald Ford appointed Mr. Perle as a founding Commissioner of the National Commission on New Technological Works ("CONTU"), which drafted legislation enacted by Congress for the protection of computer programming and software. His pioneering work helped lay the foundation for all future discussions of copyright law. At the time of his death, Mr. Perle was Senior Counsel at the intellectual property law firm Ohlandt Greeley Ruggiero & Perle, in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Perle was a past President and Honorary Trustee of the Copyright Society of the U.S.A. and a two-time Chairman of the American Bar Association's Copyright Division/IP Law Section in addition to having been a Vice President and Member of the Board of Directors of the U.S. Trademark Association. Mr. Perle co-authored, along with attorney John Williams, the seminal two-volume work, Perle & Williams on Publishing Law. In addition, Mr. Perle was the Vice Chairman of the Big Apple Circus during its critical early phases. He was also a former director and secretary of the Baron de Hirsch Fund, of which he was an honorary Trustee. He was a member of the Century Association of New York City, and had been a member of Banyan Golf Club of Palm Beach, Sunningdale Country Club of Scarsdale and the Yale Club of New York City for many years. Brilliant, witty, and dynamic, Mr. Perle thoroughly enjoyed life, golf and a good martini. But most of all, he loved - and was dearly loved - by his family: his wife, Patricia Sinnott Perle; his daughter Elizabeth Anne Perle, son-in-law Steven Pressman and grandson David Perle McKenna of San Francisco; and his stepchildren Jo-Anne Sinnott of Larchmont, NY, Diane Sinnott of Tiburon, Cal. and William Sinnott of Norwalk, Conn. Mr. Perle was predeceased by his first wife, Ellen Carlotta Kraus of Philadelphia, and his brother Richard of New York City. At Mr. Perle's request, there will be no funeral service. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. The family wishes to thank Karen, Stacie and Claudette for their kindness, concern and care for Mr. Perle during his illness. Photo is by Alfred Eisenstaedt.

LOVE--James Spencer, Jr.,businessman and entrepreneur, died peacefully at home on August 2, in Delray, FL. Born 1926 in Burlington, NC, Mr. Love, eldest son of James Spencer Love and Sara Elizabeth Love Appleget, raised his family in Greenwich, CT. After graduating from Woodberry Forest, Davidson College (1947), and Harvard Business School (1949), and serving in the Navy, Mr. Love was Deputy to the Secretary of Commerce under Kennedy. He worked in textiles and Wall Street before starting businesses in solar energy and media. His great passions were tennis and bridge, authoring a Bridge primer. His wife, Meredith Morgan Love, is deceased, previously married to Nancy Sullivan Reynolds, Joan Howell Citron and Christie Coon. He is survived by six siblings, Robert Love, Julian Love, Charles Love, Martin Love, Cornelia Spencer Love, and Lela Love; seven children, J. Spencer Love III, Rachel Cornelia Love Lorentzen, Lisa Love, Michael Love, Nancy Love, Peter Love, and Wynne Love; and thirteen grandchildren. His Memorial Service will be August 23 at 2pm, St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Delray, where he was a member.

LEAHY--David G.,born in Brooklyn NY on March 20th, 1937 passed away after a year long illness on August 7th, 2014. He is survived by his sister, Mary Jane Dickas and his four children, Christopher, Genevieve, Aimee and Timothy, thirteen grandchildren and one great-grand child. D.G. Leahy as he was known professionally, or Dave as his friends knew him, graduated St. Peter's College and Fordham University and went on to teach classics and religion at NYU, C.W. Post, Brooklyn College and Loyola College Maryland. He wrote a series of philosophy books published by various university presses and founded New York Philosophy Corporation where he continued to teach graduate students until last year. He will be missed and remembered. Wake at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn, NY, Monday 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass 10am, Wednesday St. Patricks Church 4th Ave and 96th Street in Brooklyn.
LASSMAN--Vivian Kheel, 86 on July 22, 2014, beloved wife to Joseph, mother to David and Carol, grandmother to Cheryl, Andrew and Sara.

KERR--Barbara Wendell, died peacefully at home on July 9, 2014. She was 103 years old. Born in Boston, MA, her parents were Barrett Wendell and Barbara Higginson Wendell. She was a graduate of Milton Academy and attended the Sorbonne in Paris. During World War II, she worked in the Office of War Information, where she was named the Historian of the Department by Elmer Davis. She published a "War Atlas for Americans." She had a long and distinguished career in journalism, holding positions with Time, Inc., Colliers, and the Woman's Home Companion. She spent many years as the Managing Editor of Mademoiselle. She also worked at Seventeen and finished out her career as Executive Editor of Essence, when it was founded. As a free lance researcher and editor, she worked with such authors as George Ball, Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr., and A. Alvarez. She also served as an Associate Producer for CBS News Views the Press with Charles Collingwood. She was married twice, once to Horace Soule, and once to Chester B. Kerr. Both marriages ended in divorce. She is survived by two sons, Christopher W. Soule and Alexander Kerr, three grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and The Century Association. A Memorial Service will be held at St. James Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street, New York, NY on Thursday, August 28, 2014, beginning at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Century Association Archives Foundation, 7 West 43rd Street, New York, NY 10036.

KAMALNATH--Dr. Jacintha Fatima. Dr. Jacintha Fatima Kamalnath, 62, passed away following a heroic battle with endometrial cancer. She was born in Madras, India and immigrated to the United States at 25. Jacintha worked as a physician in India, Texas, Michigan, Illinois, New York and California, board-certified in internal medicine, geriatrics, and endocrinology. She co-founded Medical & Behavioral Consultants, Inc. She graduated from Madras Medical College '75, Albert Einstein College of Medicine '80 and Baylor College of Medicine '82. She won awards for highest marks in Anatomy, Clinical Medicine, and Orthopedics. She won the 1978 Hugh M. Mahoney Award for her research in thyrotoxic periodic paralysis. She was an Assistant Professor at Baylor College of Medicine and the University of California, Davis. Jacintha was a talented artist, accomplished competitive hurdler, tender gardener, loving mother, devoted wife, and world-class doctor. She will forever be remembered for her exceptional charm, infectious humor, great beauty and compassionate nature. She had unconditional love for her family, friends, patients, and flowers, especially California wildflowers. Jacintha is survived by her husband Prakash, daughters Anthea and Agnes, and son Andrew

HICKS--Mary Louise Yoder, 90, died August 4, 2014 in Newton, MA. From 1987 2013, Mary Louise lived in Williamsburg, VA, with her husband of 50 years, Harry L. Hicks, Jr. Prior to that, they lived on Shelter Island, in Manhasset, and in New York City. Born November 14, 1923 to Lesse Blosser and Joseph D. Yoder, Mary Lou attended Mamaroneck High School, Syracuse University, and the Yale School of Music. Mary Lou was known as a talented pianist and piano teacher and was an active volunteer and community member. She is survived by Lisa Hicks and Elliot Swan of Wellesley, MA; Tom Hicks and wife Susan of Port Washington, NY; Jon Hicks and wife Julie of Chicago; by step-daughter Andrea Sato and husband Tom of Wilton, CT; and by nine grandchildren. Mary Lou was pre-deceased by her husband, parents and brothers Joe Yoder, Jr. and John Yoder. A Memorial Service will be held on September 13, 2014 on Shelter Island, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Shelter Island Friends of Music, P.O. Box 193, Shelter Island, NY 11964.

GLAISTER--Christopher J.,urban designer, died in London on July 23, 2014. Chris was born in Carlisle, England on January 24, 1942 and educated at the Universities of Durham (B.A.) and London (M.A.), and at M.I.T. His long career included partnership in Design Development Resources/Eisenman Robertson Architects in New York, work on the design of the Shahestan Pahlavi Master Plan for Teheran and on Canary Wharf in London. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Sheiry Glaister. His friendship, intelligence, stoical sense of humor and passionate love of design are treasured by all who knew him.

GALLAGHER--Mary E.,departed this earth 1 August 2014 at home. As one of the first female licensed chiropractors in New York State, she was fierce advocate for promoting health, wellness and the arts. She will be mourned but not forgotten.
FRIEDMAN--Edith C.,89, July 27, 2014. Survived by daughters Janice and Laura, grandchildren, Matt and Shana, son-in-law, Michael.

FLORIN--Esther, on August 7, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Loving mother of Mark and Linda; Joel and Jacalyn. Cherished grandmother of Daniella, Samuel, David, Michelle, Wyatt and Skylar. Devoted great-grandmother of Mollie. Forever loved and will always be missed.

ELLSWORTH--Robert H.,The National Art and Antique Dealers Association of America mourns the death of our esteemed long time member Robert Hatsfield Ellsworth. He was one of the greatest dealers of Asian art of the 20th and 21st Centuries. He also had a superb private collection of Asian and European art and antiques. An elegant and generous man, he will be sorely missed. James McConnaughy, President

DAVIS--Alice Faye. Alice Faye Davis, 74, of Marietta, Georgia, passed away on August 2, 2014, after a long, fiercely fought battle with lung cancer. Born August 5, 1939, in Granville County, North Carolina, Mrs. Davis graduated from North Carolina A&T State University and earned Masters degrees from City College of New York and the College of New Rochelle. She was a devoted teacher and guidance counselor in the New York City public school system for more than 25 years. A woman of great faith, she also served as the First Lady of St. Paul Community Church in Harlem for 23 years. She was active in Jack and Jill of America and served on the board of the Greenwich Country Day School. After retiring to Georgia, she became a devout member, stewardess and missionary of Big Bethel AME Church in Atlanta. She is survived by her loving husband of more than 40 years, Rev. George Davis; daughter Alisha Davis (Michael Roberts); son Marc Davis; brother Joe Clark (Rita); sister Alma Wright; and many other loving family and friends. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

DAVIDSON--Ralph P. The directors, staff, and clients of Phoenix House mourn the loss of Ralph P. Davidson, who died at his home in Washington D.C. on August 1. A leading figure in the golden age of American magazine journalism, he served as the publisher of Time magazine, chaired the board of Time, Inc., and later was chairman of Washington's Kennedy Center. A devoted member of the Phoenix House Foundation's Board of Directors for more than two decades, he was a thoughtful advisor and generous friend, deeply committed to our mission. We will miss his style and grace, his humor and kindness. Howard P. Meitiner, President and CEO Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D., Founder

DAVIDSON--Ralph P.,Ralph P. Davidson, beloved husband, devoted father and grandfather died on August 1, 2014 at his home in North West Washington. He would have been 87 on August 17th. He is survived by his wife Lou Hill Davidson and children Will, Ross, Scott, Sydney and Mary Elizabeth. He is also survived by ten grandchildren. He is predeceased by his son Dr. Andrew Davidson. Ralph Parsons Davidson was born on August 17, 1927 in Santa Fe, New Mexico to William Clarence Davidson and Doris Parsons Davidson. He served in the US Navy during World War II in the Pacific. He received a B.A. in international relations from Stanford University in 1950. Later, he worked in Europe for both the Marshall Plan and the US Central Intelligence Agency. He began his thirty-three year career at the illustrious publishing company Time Inc. as an advertising salesman for Life Magazine in 1954. He served as publisher of Time Magazine in the 1970's and became Chairman of the Board of Time Inc. in 1980. He was often quoted as saying, "Being Publisher of Time Magazine was the best job that anyone could have." Throughout his life, Mr. Davidson served on various boards supporting the arts, such as the New York City Ballet and the Shakespeare Theatre Company in Washington, DC. He also served as Chairman of the National Business Committee of the Arts. Following his retirement from Time Inc., Mr. Davidson was appointed Chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a position he served in from 1988-1990. Mr. Davidson was also an active supporter of higher education. He was co-chairman of the Independent Commission of the Future of the State University of New York and he served as Chairman of the Board of the American University in Bulgaria. His concern for human and environmental causes led him to serve on the boards of the National Urban League, Refugees International, World Wild Life Fund, Phoenix House and the National Council for Adoption. Mr. Davidson lived a life full of love and concern for others. He was admired for his constant pursuit of knowledge and for his lifelong spirit of adventure. His retirement years were spent in Washington D.C. and Vineyard Haven, MA, where he enjoyed time with his family and friends. They remember him as a renaissance man who read voraciously and would often recite passages from Shakespeare and Rudyard Kipling's Gunga Din. Mr. Davidson is loved by many and will be greatly missed by all who shared in his joy-filled life. Services to honor Ralph's life will be at the Arlington National Cemetery at a later date. Please contact Joseph Gawler's Sons LLC for information on the memorial service.

CHEIT--Earl F. "Budd", died on August 2, 2014 at the age of 87 at home in Kensington, California. He was Edgar F. Kaiser Professor of Business and Public Policy Emeritus and Dean Emeritus of Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. Survived by his wife June, four children and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Haas School of Business or Cal Performances at the University of California.

CASTELNUOVO-TEDESCO--Lisbeth Stone, of New York, NY, died on Friday, August 1st, 2014 after a long illness. She was 78. Lisbeth was born in Belmont, MA and received her BA from Smith College. She lived over the years in Florence, Los Angeles, Nash- ville and New York. She was married to the late Pietro Castelnuovo-Tedesco, the James G. Blakemore Professor of Psychiatry at Vanderbilt University. She was a scholar of medieval art history, having earned her PhD at the University of California Los Angeles, and was the co-author of "Italian Medieval Sculpture in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Cloisters" in 2010. She is survived by her daughters Diana and Costanza Castelnuovo-Tede- sco. A private memorial service will be held in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Lisbeth's memory to the Metro- politan Museum of Art. Please specify that the gift is in memory of Lisbeth Castelnuovo-Tedesco and include the additional instructions of "For the Department of Medieval Art."

BREMER--Rebecca (nee Lifson), 98. Beloved wife of the late Arnold and sister of Teddy and Sol. Loving mother of Regina (the late, Stephen) and Toby (Eugene). Cherished grandmother of Jeremy Warhaftig (Elise), Daniel Warhaftig (Julie) and Alexa Poritz. Great-grandmother of Andrew, Rachel, Ethan, Abby, Maya and Lindsay Warhaftig. Adored Aunt of Rachel, David (and the late, Paul) Spielvogel. Gone from our sights and forever in our hearts. Memorials in her honor to Temple Beth El of Manhattan Beach, Memorial Sloan Kettering, NephCure Foundation, or Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation

BENNIS--Warren. The Antioch College community mourns the death of Warren Bennis, a distinguished graduate of the college, who was an educator, an honorary trustee of Antioch College, and a member of the "Antioch Review" advisory board. He was also a scholar whose pioneering work on leadership received international acclaim and led corporations from Cambridge to Calcutta to reshape their organizations. Throughout his life everyone sought his advice and were fortunate to receive it. Frances Horowitz, Chair of the Antioch College Board of Trustees Mark Roosevelt, President

BATES--Charles Turner, age 82, of Irvington, NY and Clinton, CT, died of natural causes on August 1, 2014. Charlie was born in Tarrytown, NY to Harry Cole and Helen Turner Bates. Charlie attended Hackley School in Tarrytown and graduated from Hamilton College in 1953. After college he served two years in the United States Army's Ordnance Corps, serving as a translator in France. He graduated from Yale Law School in 1958, and began his legal career at Townley & Updike in New York. Charlie joined the law department at CBS in 1969, rising to the level of Secretary of CBS. Upon retiring in 1988, Charlie embarked on a second career, teaching high school level U.S. History at his alma mater, Hackley. With his second retirement in 1999, he stayed active with travel to all parts of the globe, and volunteering at the Irvington Historical Society and The Church of St. Barnabas, where Charlie, a lifelong member, sang in the choir from childhood until this year. He is survived by his brother, Robert P. Turner of Weston, CT, and eight nieces and nephews, who will miss his wide ranging knowledge and wit, including his clever predictions of next season's events on Downton Abbey. He was predeceased by his brothers David and Harry Bates, also Hackley and Hamilton alumni. A memorial service will be held at St. Barnabas, 15 N Broadway, Irvington, on Friday, August 15 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Hackley School or The Church of St. Barnabas, Irvington, NY.

ADLER--Carol Husin, of Yardley, PA, formerly of Smithtown, NY, on August 1, 2014. Beloved wife of 50 years to David, devoted mother of Rachel, loving and proud grandmother of Ilana, dear sister of Margo Call, cherished daughter of the late Irvin and Bernice Husin. Graduate of Syracuse University, teacher for 33 years in Hauppauge, NY. Memorial service on September 14, 2014. Details at caroladlermemorial@ gmail.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia, PA.

MAIDMAN--Jacqueline Lazrus. Jackie passed away on August 7, 2014, at age 52. She left us much too soon. KAPLAN--Lawrence Jay, on August 5, 2014. Beloved husband of Jeanne. Loving father of Harriet Trackman, Sanford S. Kaplan and Marcia Pavone. Cherished grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of five.

HOCHMAN--Stanley. The family of Stanley Hochman, a long-time and widely respected figure of the New York City book-publishing community, are saddened to announce his death from natural causes at age 89. Husband of Eleanor, father of David (Genie), grandfather of Daniel and Joel, Stan will be remembered as a wise and compassionate man, with exceptionally deep knowledge of American literature and considerable skill at translation from both French and Italian into English. In his career, he worked for major firms like McGraw Hill and smaller but well regarded houses like Frederick Ungar and Walker and Company. His translations and edited reference works, most of which were first published more than 30 years ago, are still in many major libraries today. A fuller professional resume is available from the family. There is to be no funeral service, though a memorial will be held in the autumn at approximately what would have been his 90th birthday. No cards or flowers, please. Contributions in Stan's memory may be made to the Coalition for the Homeless.

GUDEMAN--Dr. Joani, on July 25, 2014. Beloved wife of David McCarthy. Devoted mother of Jacob and Samuel. Services will be held on August 15, 2014 at 10am at Chicago Sinai Congregation, 15 W. Delaware Pl. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to Metastatic Breast Cancer Network, PO Box 1449, NY, NY 10159 mbcn.org

GLASSER--Allois Anne Livengood, born October 16, 1936 died in New York City on August 8, 2014. Loie was a great artist, a wonderful mother and grandmother, and a truly special spirit. Survived by Joanne, Michael, Max, Julian, Zoe, Ron and Joey, and many family and friends who loved her dearly.

DAVIDSON--Ralph P. The directors, staff, and clients of Phoenix House mourn the loss of Ralph P. Davidson, who died at his home in Washington D.C. on August 1. A leading figure in the golden age of American magazine journalism, he served as the publisher of Time magazine, chaired the board of Time, Inc., and later was chairman of Washington's Kennedy Center. A devoted member of the Phoenix House Foundation's Board of Directors for more than two decades, he was a thoughtful advisor and generous friend, deeply committed to our mission. We will miss his style and grace, his humor and kindness. Howard P. Meitiner, President and CEO Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D., Founder

COHEN--Arthur G. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member, Arthur and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Karen and the entire family. Board of Governors Michael Mann, President

COHEN--Arthur G. The Family of Arthur Levien is saddened by the sudden passing of our friend and business partner, an iconic genius in the real estate business. Our relationship spans over five decades. Condolences to Karen, his five daughters and their families.

COHEN--Arthur G. It is with overwhelming sadness that the family of Arthur G. Cohen announces his sudden and untimely passing on August 9th at the age of 84 in Kings Point, New York, his home for decades with the love of his life, Karen Bassine Cohen. Arthur and Karen recently celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary, a joyous occasion shared with their devoted daughters, Lauren, Susan, Debra, Rochelle and Kathy, nine wonderful grandchildren Allison, Hanni, Caroline, Jennifer, Charlie, Kate, William, Emily and Henry - who made him proud and brought him much joy, sons-in-law Jeffrey, Mark and Jeigh, grandson-in-law Matthew and other members of his extended family, who survive him and, with Karen, will miss the wisdom, boundless energy, generosity and love of their family patriarch. Arthur is also survived by his sister, Marilyn Davimos; his brother, Richard M. Cohen, predeceased him. For more than 50 years Arthur enjoyed an illustrious career as a builder, developer, investor, owner and manager of real estate throughout the United States and abroad, having earned a legendary reputation as a pioneer in revitalizing Times Square through his ownership interest in the iconic, landmarked Paramount Building at 1501 Broadway and his development of the 1500 Broadway office tower and the Crowne Plaza, Paramount and Michelangelo hotels. His foresight in recognizing the potential of the far west side of midtown Manhattan produced the Westyard office-warehouse facility at 450 West 33rd Street, around which an entire new community is now burgeoning, the Worldwide Plaza mixed-use complex at Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets on the site of the former Madison Square Garden and 888 Seventh Avenue, across from Carnegie Hall. Arthur's innovative ideas produced many other distinctive, high-profile projects such as the Peninsula Hotel and Olympic Tower in New York City and Aventura in North Miami, Florida. Though Arthur preferred to maintain a low profile, he often partnered with many of the most active and renowned developers, property managers and financial investors of the last 50 years and today, who consider him a trailblazer in creating new ways of structuring and financing real estate transactions. Born in Brooklyn, New York to Frances and L.D. Cohen, Arthur graduated from the University of Miami and New York Law School. Though he became an attorney admitted to the New York Bar and remained so for more than 50 years, he entered the real estate field in a small way shortly after completing law school, but moved rapidly to developing department store properties and retail centers and, in 1971 at the age of 40, to creating Arlen Realty & Development, then the nation's largest publicly-held real estate enterprise, with a vast portfolio of office buildings, hotels, single- and multi-family residential buildings and more than 250 shopping centers worldwide, as well as the E. J. Korvette department store chain. Always available to share his expertise and numerous real estate industry and financial market connections with both his contemporaries and the next generation of real estate and other business entrepreneurs, Arthur never ceased to enjoy the constant flow of potential worldwide projects brought to him by admirers of his "laser beam" analytical skills and remarkable physical stamina, which he also exhibited in his "scratch" golf game frequently on display at Old Westbury's Glen Oaks Country Club and the Palm Beach Country Club. But no diversion from his intense work ethic gave Arthur greater pleasure than sailing with his family on Long Island Sound in his cherished vintage sailboat "Les Girls", named to honor his wife and five daughters. In addition to Arthur's business and recreational pursuits, he was involved in numerous educational, professional and philanthropic activities, including guest lectureships at the Harvard Business School and the Wharton School of Business, directorships of Citicorp and the Home Title Division of Chicago Title Insurance Company and a trusteeship of the John Hancock Mutual Fund. His public service internationally included membership on the Special Mission to Israel under Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir and as Special Envoy to aid underprivileged nations under President Lyndon B. Johnson. Often recognized by his real estate industry peers and the broader business community, among his honors are having been named Man of the Year by the Anti-Defamation League and the City of Hope and having received the Tree of Life Award from the Jewish National Fund and an honorary degree from Long Island University. His memberships on Boards of Trustees have included Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, Brandeis University (Emeritus), New York Law School and Albert Einstein College of Medicine. The family requests that their wishes for a private funeral service and interment be respected. Donations may be made in memory of Arthur to the Anti-Defamation League, which he previously served as President.

SAMET--Seymour, on July 30, 2014 in New Jersey. He spent his professional life working for social and racial justice, opening and directing the American Jewish Committee's SE office from 1952-1963. He also served as the ED of the Community Relations Board of South Florida. In recognition of his leadership in civil rights, the Seymour Samet Human Relations Library of Dade County was established as a professional resource center. After passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Law he came to Washington to implement the Community Relations Service, serving under Former Governor Leroy Collins and later Roger Wilkins. He returned to the AJC in 1968 as Director of National Domestic Affairs, working on civil rights, urban affairs and community relations issues. He is survived by his wife Elaine, two daughters, Anita Samet Rechler and Roberta Samet, and grandsons Scott and Jeff Rechler, who shared with him his passion for justice and equality and love of travel, friends, family, music, dance, magic, and a joke well told.

Racanelli (and Eileen) and Luigi Racanelli, Jr., (and Jennie). Predeceased by son Nicholas in 1971. A doting Nonno to Margherita, Luigi A., Luigi J. and Nicholas F. Bisnonno to Jennifer Rose. Friends and family may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St.), Tuesday 7-9pm and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of the Resurrection at St. Ignatius Loyola, Thursday 10am. The family requests that in lieu of flowers a donation be made to the Alzheimer's Association of NYC, 360 Lexington Ave., NY NY 10017 (646) 744-2900.

MARSHALL--Richard D. The Whitney Museum of American Art is greatly saddened by the loss of Richard D. Marshall, curator, art historian and dear friend to the Museum. A graduate of the Whitney's Independent Study Program, Richard's twenty-year tenure at the Museum began in 1973. During his prolific career at the Whitney he curated more than two dozen exhibitions including six co-curated Biennials as well as exhibitions of works by American masters from Isamu Noguchi, Alexander Calder and Louise Nevelson to Claes Oldenburg, James Rosenquist and Joel Shapiro. In particular, he will always be remembered for the seminal retrospectives of artists Alex Katz, Robert Mapplethorpe and Jean-Michel Basquiat and two historic exhibitions New Image Painting and American Art Since 1970 and The New Sculpture 1965-75: Between Geometry and Gesture (co-curated). In recent years Richard was the Curator of the Lever House Art Collection and he independently curated numerous international exhibitions by artists including Georgia O'Keeffe, Louise Bourgeois and Ed Ruscha. We will greatly miss his great "eye", enthusiastic support of artists and wonderful wit. Our most heartfelt condolences go out to his husband, the esteemed architect, Bill Georgis. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman, Board of Trustees; Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman; Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman; Neil G. Bluhm, President; Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director Ron Clark, Director, Independent Study Program

MARSHALL--Richard Donald. An independent curator, art historian and art consultant based in New York City and La Jolla, California died unexpectedly on August 8th at his home in La Jolla. Born in Los Angeles in 1947, and educated at the University of California, Irvine, he moved to New York City to enroll in the Museum Studies Program of the Independent Study Program at the Whitney Museum of American Art. A highly respected figure in the art world, he was known for his connoisseurship, prescience and kindness. His support of artists both emerging and established was legendary. Richard was a wise, dignified, modest and gentle man, unfettered by convention, who refrained from judgment. Worldly, innately elegant, well read and travelled, Richard's insatiable curiosity was manifested in diverse collections of contemporary art, Mexican silver, vintage pottery and post cards. He was a loving spouse, generous friend and bon vivant. For twenty years from 1974-1993 he was Curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art, where he organized numerous Biennial Exhibitions of contemporary art, and many seminal one-artist and group exhibitions including New Image Painting, Ceramic Sculpture, The New Sculpture 1965-75: Between Geometry and Gesture, American Art Since 1970, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Jonathan Borofsky, Alexander Calder, Alex Katz, Robert Kushner, Roy Lichtenstein, Robert Mapplethorpe, Louise Nevelson, Isamu Noguchi, Claes Oldenburg, James Rosenquist, Edward Ruscha, and Joel Shapiro, among others. Richard organized international exhibitions of Louise Bourgeois (Museo de Arte Contemporaneo, Monterrey, Mexico; and Contemporary Art Museum, Seville, Spain); Edward Ruscha (Museo Nacional de Arte Reina Sofia, Madrid); Alexander Calder (Japan Art and Culture Association, Tokyo); Robert Mapplethorpe (Mitsukoshi Museum, Tokyo); Jean-Michel Basquiat (Serpentine Gallery, London); Joan Mitchell (Instituto Valenciano de Arte Moderno, Valencia, Spain); Georgia O'Keeffe (Irish Museum of Modern Art, Dublin; and Vancouver Art Gallery, British Columbia); and Jack Pierson (Irish Museum of Modern Art, Dublin). Richard's books include, Ed Ruscha (Phaidon Press); Jack Pierson; Desire Despair (Rizzoli International); Georgia O'Keeffe; Nature and Abstraction (Skira Publishers); and Kenny Scharf (Rizzolli International), among others. He served as art editor of the Paris Review from 1975-1990. Since 2003, Richard served as Curator of The Lever House Art Collection -- a collection of works commissioned for display at the Lever House's outdoor plaza and glass-enclosed lobby, located at Park Avenue and 53rd Street, New York. The first commission was a neon installation by Keith Sonnier. Subsequent commissions included ambitious works by Jorge Pardo, John Chamberlain, Damien Hirst, Peter Wegner, Barnaby Furnas, Jeff Koons, E.V. Day, Sarah Morris, Folkert de Jong, Enoc Perez, Tom Friedman, Richard Dupont, Tom Sachs, Liza Lou, and Paula Hayes. In addition, Richard was a former member of the Authentication Committee of the Estate of Jean-Michel Basquiat and the Byzantine Fresco Foundation, The Menil Collection, Houston; and a member of the Advisory Board of the Alexander Calder Foundation, New York, and a Trustee of the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego. He is survived by his partner and spouse of twenty-five years William T. Georgis, a sister Shirley Capic, brother-in-law Stephen Capic, nieces Sarah and Megann Capic, aunt Donna Meagher and cousin Kathleen Meagher. A memorial service at the Whitney Museum of American Art and a memorial exhibition at the Lever House will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made in his honor to the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego for acquisitions.

LEVINE--Annette (nee Nagor) 87, beloved wife of the late Dr. Abraham, loving mother of Dr. Marc (Susan), Robin (David), Dr. Howard (Silvina), cherished grandmother of Rory, Eli, Anna, Joshua, Aaron, Nicole, Renee, died peacefully at home on August 10. The epitome of selflessness, a kind, humble role model who lived for her husband, children and grandchildren. KRAMER--Stephen Pendleton, 66, died August 8 in New York City at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center of complications from multiple myeloma. Loving husband for 40 years of Bonnie (Bonita Franklin, M.D.), his soul-mate, and adoring father of Jacob (Sara), Sarah and Alex Kramer, Steve was a constant and effervescent presence in the lives of his family and friends. Born in Washington, D.C. to Victor and Miriam Tickton Kramer, he attended The Choate School, Harvard College and The University of Pennsylvania Law School, after which he followed in the footsteps of his father in pursuing a career in the law dedicated primarily to public service. Upon graduation he threw himself into the George McGovern campaign for President, then joined the New York City Corporation Counsel where he was involved in environmental litigation and important policy matters, becoming Chief of the General Litigation Division. Mayor Ed Koch valued his wisdom and appointed him to fill an open seat on the bench as Judge of the Civil Court. Thereafter, he worked at Proskauer Rose LLC for several years before establishing a private practice dealing with New York City agencies. His last position, before the onset of his illness, was Chief of Staff and Special Counsel to the Commissioner of the New York Department of Buildings. Steve was known for mentoring young colleagues, many of whom went on to prominent careers with the City and in public service. Although born in Washington, D.C., Steve became the quintessential New Yorker, often riding his bicycle with Bonnie to all five boroughs, visiting frequently the Bronx and Brooklyn Botanical Gardens, Central Park, the City's many museums, attending theater, movies and musical events, a passion which engaged his entire family. Steve and Bonnie were pioneers in moving to Tribeca in 1983, and loved their loft and the community in their neighborhood. In addition to Bonnie and his children, Steve is survived by his sisters Ruth Kramer Ziony and Edie Kramer Wilairat. Steve was a constant source of intellectual energy and warmth to his many friends and his absence will be felt by all. Shiva will be at the Kramer/Franklin residence at 16 Hudson Street starting Monday from 5-8pm until Thursday. In lieu of flowers, donations in Steve's honor may be sent to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation (www.theMMRF.org).

HANKS--John L. The Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law community is deeply saddened by the loss of John L. Hanks, a member of Cardozo Law's founding faculty. John passed away at the age of 74 on August 9 after a brief, valiant battle against lung cancer. John had an illustrious professional career as professor of law and associate dean at Cardozo Law, where he was a founding faculty member. He also served the City of New York as director of franchises from 1988 to 1990, where he oversaw the growth of the cable industry; and he was appointed special master from 1980 to 1988, where he oversaw the financing, design and construction of two sewage treatment plants in New York City. A community park atop one of the sewage treatment plants alongside the Hudson River, serving the Harlem community, is a lasting testament to John's success in this role. He also served as board member of the Art Students League of New York, and owner of a long-term care facility, King James Care Center of Chatham, NJ. He held a B.S. and J.D. degree from Rutgers, and Master of Arts and Master of Laws degrees from Columbia. He leaves behind his beloved wife Fran Condon, his brother Dan, his sister Florence and a host of dear friends and colleagues who share a deep sense of sorrow with this loss. Cardozo Law extends its deepest sympathies to John's family and loved ones. Matthew Diller, Dean Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, Yeshiva University David P. Samson, Chair Cardozo Board of Overseers

COHEN--Arthur G. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Arthur Cohen, a supporter of the Museum for more than 30 years. With his wife, Karen--a Benefactor and Honorary Trustee of the Museum, as well as an avid collector and advocate of the Drawings and Prints Department whose gifts of works of art and funding have provided vital support for that department's galleries, acquisitions, and exhibitions--he donated generously to the departments of European Sculpture and Decorative Arts, Photographs, Paper Conservation, Editorial, and the Thomas J. Watson Library. In 1987 he also endowed a gallery that bears his wife's name. Campbell, Director and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President

COHEN--Arthur G. It is with overwhelming sadness that the family of Arthur G. Cohen announces his sudden and untimely passing on August 9th at the age of 84 in Kings Point, New York, his home for decades with the love of his life, Karen Bassine Cohen. Arthur and Karen recently celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary, a joyous occasion shared with their devoted daughters, Lauren, Susan, Debra, Rochelle and Kathy, nine wonderful grandchildren Allison, Hanni, Caroline, Jennifer, Charlie, Kate, William, Emily and Henry - who made him proud and brought him much joy, sons-in-law Jeffrey, Mark and Jeigh, grandson-in-law Matthew and other members of his extended family, who survive him and, with Karen, will miss the wisdom, boundless energy, generosity and love of their family patriarch. Arthur is also survived by his sister, Marilyn Davimos; his brother, Richard M. Cohen, predeceased him. For more than 50 years Arthur enjoyed an illustrious career as a builder, developer, investor, owner and manager of real estate throughout the United States and abroad, having earned a legendary reputation as a pioneer in revitalizing Times Square through his ownership interest in the iconic, landmarked Paramount Building at 1501 Broadway and his development of the 1500 Broadway office tower and the Crowne Plaza, Paramount and Michelangelo hotels. His foresight in recognizing the potential of the far west side of midtown Manhattan produced the Westyard office-warehouse facility at 450 West 33rd Street, around which an entire new community is now burgeoning, the Worldwide Plaza mixed-use complex at Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets on the site of the former Madison Square Garden and 888 Seventh Avenue, across from Carnegie Hall. Arthur's innovative ideas produced many other distinctive, high-profile projects such as the Peninsula Hotel and Olympic Tower in New York City and Aventura in North Miami, Florida. Though Arthur preferred to maintain a low profile, he often partnered with many of the most active and renowned developers, property managers and financial investors of the last 50 years and today, who consider him a trailblazer in creating new ways of structuring and financing real estate transactions. Born in Brooklyn, New York to Frances and L.D. Cohen, Arthur graduated from the University of Miami and New York Law School. Though he became an attorney admitted to the New York Bar and remained so for more than 50 years, he entered the real estate field in a small way shortly after completing law school, but moved rapidly to developing department store properties and retail centers and, in 1971 at the age of 40, to creating Arlen Realty & Development, then the nation's largest publicly-held real estate enterprise, with a vast portfolio of office buildings, hotels, single- and multi-family residential buildings and more than 250 shopping centers worldwide, as well as the E. J. Korvette department store chain. Always available to share his expertise and numerous real estate industry and financial market connections with both his contemporaries and the next generation of real estate and other business entrepreneurs, Arthur never ceased to enjoy the constant flow of potential worldwide projects brought to him by admirers of his "laser beam" analytical skills and remarkable physical stamina, which he also exhibited in his "scratch" golf game frequently on display at Old Westbury's Glen Oaks Country Club and the Palm Beach Country Club. But no diversion from his intense work ethic gave Arthur greater pleasure than sailing with his family on Long Island Sound in his cherished vintage sailboat "Les Girls", named to honor his wife and five daughters. In addition to Arthur's business and recreational pursuits, he was involved in numerous educational, professional and philanthropic activities, including guest lectureships at the Harvard Business School and the Wharton School of Business, directorships of Citicorp and the Home Title Division of Chicago Title Insurance Company and a trusteeship of the John Hancock Mutual Fund. His public service internationally included membership on the Special Mission to Israel under Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir and as Special Envoy to aid underprivileged nations under President Lyndon B. Johnson. Often recognized by his real estate industry peers and the broader business community, among his honors are having been named Man of the Year by the Anti-Defamation League and the City of Hope and having received the Tree of Life Award from the Jewish National Fund and an honorary degree from Long Island University. His memberships on Boards of Trustees have included Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, Brandeis University (Emeritus), New York Law School and Albert Einstein College of Medicine. The family requests that their wishes for a private funeral service and interment be respected. Donations may be made in memory of Arthur to the Anti-Defamation League, which he previously served as President.

BRANDEIS--Eric, passed away after a long illness on August 8, 2014 at his home which he loved. He was 89 years old, the only child of the late Dr. Martin Brandeis and Friedel Brandeis, and was raised in Mt. Vernon, NY and attending pre-med classes at Syracuse University at the time he was drafted to serve in World War II. As a member of the 345th Regiment of the 87th Infantry "Golden Acorn" Division, he was awarded a Bronze Star for gallantry in action while liberating a town during the Battle of the Bulge. After the war, he returned to the States where he obtained his law and accounting degrees and enjoyed a long and successful career in the field of legal publications, which culminated as a Senior Tax Editor with Research Institute of America. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Rene Leeser, his two sons and daughters-in-law, Clifford Brandeis and Sharon Schneier of New York, NY, and Charles and Katherine Brandeis of Arlington, VA, and his five grandchildren, Rachel, Henry, Aaron, Ben and Emma, all of whom he delighted endlessly whenever he exclaimed "Holy Smokes" in response to any of their exploits. He will be sorely missed and lovingly remembered.

BOYNTON--Dr. Willard Harold, "Doc," died August 3rd on Monhegan Island, ME, age 100. A graduate of Yale, MPH, and Tuffs University, MD, he practiced in Bethel, ME, prior to joining the State Department in public health. He worked for AID on four continents and built the medical school in Saigon. He then worked in world population control. He received the distinguished service award from Congress for his services.
