WILLIAMS--Robin. The Juilliard community is deeply saddened by the death of our distinguished alumnus Robin Williams. Robin's genius for comedic improvisation, which quickly surfaced in his studies at Juilliard, was matched by his deep understanding of the actor's art and how to touch his audience in meaningful ways. He was a generous supporter of the School's drama students through the Robin Williams Scholarship, which supported the tuition cost of a drama student each year. As an artist, he brought together a unique mix of traditional actor training with a creative spirit that set new standards for performance in cinema, television and live theater. His caring ways and effervescent personality will be missed by all who were touched by this special person. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President James Houghton, Richard Rodgers Director of the Drama Division

WARNER--Betsy. We mourn the loss of our beloved and esteemed colleague Betsy Warner. Betsy was a fixture at the Children's Museum of Manhattan for over 30 years and contributed greatly to the spirit of the Museum. She will be remembered for her dedication, astute observations and sense of humor. We offer our condolences to our dear friend Marcia Warner and to the Warner family. Halley Harrisburg, Board Chair; Laurie Tisch, Honorary Chair; Andrew Ackerman, Executive Director and the CMOM Board and staff

WARNER--Betsy. July 19, 1955 August 11, 2014. Betsy passed away peacefully on August 11 at the age of 59. Her optimism, kindness and courage, as well as her love and care for family and friends touched many people. She brought smiles, warmth and joy to all who knew her, especially at the Children's Museum of Manhattan (CMOM) where she worked for over thirty years. Betsy was the beloved wife of her late husband Michael Ettelson, cherished daughter of her late father Bob and mother, Marcia, sister to Jim and Steve, sister-in-law to Priscilla and Jennifer, and aunt to five nephews and nieces. She was a devoted friend to Shella Rivers, who shared in Betsy's many triumphs. Betsy's graveside service will take place at King David Cemetery in Putnam Valley, NY at 2pm on August 13. The family will sit shiva at Jim and Priscilla Warner's home at 56 Prospect Avenue, Larchmont, NY at 6:30pm following the service. A celebration of Betsy's life and memorial service will be held this fall at CMOM. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to CMOM, 212 West 83rd Street, NY 10024.

SUNG--Posoon Park, professor, philosopher, and prominent fine artist whose paintings and drawings explored life's spiritual journey, evolution, and transformation, died on August 8 in Seoul, Korea. She was 67. The cause was breast cancer, her family said. In addition to representation at June Kelly Gallery in SOHO, New York City, Park Sung was an artist-in-residence at Gana Art Gallery in Seoul. She was a fine arts professor at the University of Tampa and Incheon Catholic University, Seoul where she taught and inspired countless students. Throughout her life she exemplified courage, strength, dignity and immense principle as she carried on as a breast cancer survivor for twenty-three years with grace. For this and more, she was a role model to many. Park Sung lived and worked out of Seoul, South Korea, New York City, and Tampa, Florida. She received a BFA from Hong-Ik University, College of Art in Seoul and an MFA from The Pennsylvania State University. Park Sung has participated in numerous one-person and group exhibitions throughout the United States, Japan, and South Korea. Her work is represented in many corporate and private collections, including the Ottchelli Museum, Tongyeong, South Korea; Gana Art Center, Seoul, South Korea; the University of Tampa; Benihana Corporation, Miami; Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, New York; Jinmyeong Girls' High School, Seoul, and Avon Product Research Development Center, Suffern, New York. Park Sung is survived by her loving husband, Myung-Hak Sung, who resides in Seoul and Tampa, Florida and by her two devoted sons Peter and Matthew Sung, both who reside in New York City.

Racanelli (and Eileen) and Luigi Racanelli, Jr., (and Jennie). Predeceased by son Nicholas in 1971. A doting Nonno to Margherita, Luigi A., Luigi J. and Nicholas F. Bisnonno to Jennifer Rose. MARSHALL--Richard Donald. An independent curator, art historian and art consultant based in New York City and La Jolla, California died unexpectedly on August 8th at his home in La Jolla. Born in Los Angeles in 1947, and educated at the University of California, Irvine, he moved to New York City to enroll in the Museum Studies Program of the Independent Study Program at the Whitney Museum of American Art. A highly respected figure in the art world, he was known for his connoisseurship, prescience and kindness. His support of artists both emerging and established was legendary. Richard was a wise, dignified, modest and gentle man, unfettered by convention, who refrained from judgment. Worldly, innately elegant, well read and travelled, Richard's insatiable curiosity was manifested in diverse collections of contemporary art, Mexican silver, vintage pottery and post cards. He was a loving spouse, generous friend and bon vivant. For twenty years from 1974-1993 he was Curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art, where he organized numerous Biennial Exhibitions of contemporary art, and many seminal one-artist and group exhibitions including New Image Painting, Ceramic Sculpture, The New Sculpture 1965-75: Between Geometry and Gesture, American Art Since 1970, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Jonathan Borofsky, Alexander Calder, Alex Katz, Robert Kushner, Roy Lichtenstein, Robert Mapplethorpe, Louise Nevelson, Isamu Noguchi, Claes Oldenburg, James Rosenquist, Edward Ruscha, and Joel Shapiro, among others. Richard organized international exhibitions of Louise Bourgeois (Museo de Arte Contemporaneo, Monterrey, Mexico; and Contemporary Art Museum, Seville, Spain); Edward Ruscha (Museo Nacional de Arte Reina Sofia, Madrid); Alexander Calder (Japan Art and Culture Association, Tokyo); Robert Mapplethorpe (Mitsukoshi Museum, Tokyo); Jean-Michel Basquiat (Serpentine Gallery, London); Joan Mitchell (Instituto Valenciano de Arte Moderno, Valencia, Spain); Georgia O'Keeffe (Irish Museum of Modern Art, Dublin; and Vancouver Art Gallery, British Columbia); and Jack Pierson (Irish Museum of Modern Art, Dublin). Richard's books include, Ed Ruscha (Phaidon Press); Jack Pierson; Desire Despair (Rizzoli International); Georgia O'Keeffe; Nature and Abstraction (Skira Publishers); and Kenny Scharf (Rizzolli International), among others. He served as art editor of the Paris Review from 1975-1990. Since 2003, Richard served as Curator of The Lever House Art Collection -- a collection of works commissioned for display at the Lever House's outdoor plaza and glass-enclosed lobby, located at Park Avenue and 53rd Street, New York. The first commission was a neon installation by Keith Sonnier. Subsequent commissions included ambitious works by Jorge Pardo, John Chamberlain, Damien Hirst, Peter Wegner, Barnaby Furnas, Jeff Koons, E.V. Day, Sarah Morris, Folkert de Jong, Enoc Perez, Tom Friedman, Richard Dupont, Tom Sachs, Liza Lou, and Paula Hayes. In addition, Richard was a former member of the Authentication Committee of the Estate of Jean-Michel Basquiat and the Byzantine Fresco Foundation, The Menil Collection, Houston; and a member of the Advisory Board of the Alexander Calder Foundation, New York, and a Trustee of the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego. He is survived by his partner and spouse of twenty-five years William T. Georgis, a sister Shirley Capic, brother-in-law Stephen Capic, nieces Sarah and Megann Capic, aunt Donna Meagher and cousin Kathleen Meagher. A memorial service at the Whitney Museum of American Art and a memorial exhibition at the Lever House will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made in his honor to the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego for acquisitions.

MANGEL--Glenn, died on August 7. He is survived by his mother Elaine Mangel, girlfriend Christa Bean, sister Kathe Cobb (Alan), niece Klee Miller (Andrew) and their two children Bret and Brooke. He will be remembered always.

LEVINE--Annette (nee Nagor) 87, beloved wife of the late Dr. Abraham, loving mother of Dr. Marc (Susan), Robin (David), Dr. Howard (Silvina), cherished grandmother of Rory, Eli, Anna, Joshua, Aaron, Nicole, Renee, died peacefully at home on August 10. The epitome of selflessness, a kind, humble role model who lived for her husband, children and grandchildren. Donations may be made in her memory to the Family Respite Program at the Samuel Field YMHA or Cure Alzheimer's Fund.

KAFFE-ROSENBERG, Dr. Sara. It is with great sadness that the family of Dr. Sara Kaffe-Rosenberg announces her passing at age 75, on August 12, in New York City. A child survivor of the Holocaust, she went on to become one of a small group of women admitted to her medical school class in Jerusalem, a dedicated pediatrician and geneticist, and a loving and devoted mother to her children, Yuval and Anat Rosenberg. Sara was until the end a woman of fierce intellect, sharp wit and boundless love for her family. She is survived by her children; her former husband, Dr. Vladimiro Rosenberg; her brother, Israel Kaffe; and her two recently born grandchildren, Leo and Ella. Funeral services will be in Israel, and a memorial service will be held in New York in November. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association and to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

HOROWITZ--Floyd. The entire Antioch College community sends its most heartfelt condolences to our esteemed alumna and chair of the Antioch College Board of Trustees Frances Degen Horowitz over the loss of her beloved husband and life partner Floyd Horowitz. Floyd was a renowned scholar, talented writer, inspiring academic and devoted civil rights advocate. May his memory be for a blessing.

HANKS--John L. The Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the loss of John L. Hanks, a member of the school's founding faculty. As a professor of law he taught contracts and torts for over 20 years. He also served as director of Admissions and associate dean for Academic Affairs. John worked tirelessly to build Cardozo School of Law's reputation in its early years, and played a vital role in its growth. The Cardozo community offers our sincere condolences to his family and loved ones. Matthew Diller, Dean Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, Yeshiva University David P. Samson, Chair Cardozo Board of Overseers

HANKS--John L.,74, of New York, NY and Rumson, NJ, passed away on August 9, 2014, at his home in Rumson, NJ, after a brief, valiant battle against lung cancer. He leaves behind his beloved wife Fran Condon, his brother Dan, his sister Florence and a host of dear friends and colleagues. Born in Staten Island, NY, and raised on the West Coast, John had an illustrious professional career spanning significant public service for the City of New York; as an educator through his tenure as Professor of Law and Associate Dean at the Yeshiva University Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, where he was a Founding faculty member; as his volunteer service as a Board member of the Art Students League of New York, and as a successful business leader and owner of a long-term care facility, King James Care Center of Chatham, NJ. John holds a B.S. degree from Rutgers University's College of Engineering; a J.D. Degree from Rutgers University School of Law, where he was Research Editor of the Rutgers Law Review; a Master of Arts degree in Economics from Columbia University's Graduate School of Arts and Sciences and a Master of Laws degree from Columbia University School of Law. Among the many accomplishments during his public service career, John served as Director of Franchises for the City of New York. In that capacity, he provided testimony to the US Senate regarding the affects of vertical and horizontal integration and consolidation that was then taking place in the cable industry. Of particular note is John's service as Special Master from 1980-1988, appointed by Federal District Court Judge Robert L. Carter to oversee the financing, design and construction of two sewage treatment plants in New York City. This complex project was managed on time and under budget. A community park atop one of the sewage treatment plants alongside the Hudson River, serving the Harlem community, is a lasting testament to John's success in this role. John is the author of numerous publications in Franchising Law and the Regulation of Cable Television. He is also the author of the publication "On a Just Measure of the Efficiency of Law and Governmental Policies". After his service to the City of New York and Cardozo Law School, John focused on ensuring the highest quality of care at the King James Care Center of Chatham and his life-long passion as an artist. John's generosity with his friends and family expressed itself most importantly in his capacity to listen, analyze and advise. Most sadly he leaves behind his wife, best friend and business partner, Fran Condon. The love and life they shared together was an inspiration to all of their friends. A wake will be held at Thompson Memorial Home, Red Bank, NJ on August 13 from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Service to be held at Church of the Nativity, Fair Haven, NJ on August 14 at 11am. Donations, in lieu of flowers, should be made to the New York Botanical Garden where a bench will be dedicated in John's name. Contact Lisa Sifre at lsifre@nybg.org for details on how to give.

GUDEMAN--Dr. Joani, on July 25, 2014. Beloved wife of David McCarthy. Devoted mother of Jacob and Samuel. Services will be held on August 15, 2014 at 10am at Chicago Sinai Congregation, 15 W. Delaware Pl. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to Metastatic Breast Cancer Network, PO Box 1449, NY, NY 10159 mbcn.org

GREENOUGH--Doris, born January 14, 1916 in Decker Township, IN, passed away peacefully on August 5, 2014 at her summer home in Leland, MI. She survived the deaths of her husband, William Croan Greenough (the former Chairman of TIAA-CREF) and her son David. She is survived by her son Walter and his wife Nan, of Winnetka, Il, by their son, Alex, and by her daughter, Martha, of New York City, and by her children, James and Katharine Pitt. Services will be private. Memorials may be directed to The Leelanau Conservancy, P.O. Box 1007, Leland, MI 49654. Please share memories with Doris' family online at: www.martinson.info

GOGOL--Daniel F.,Ph.D., of Dobbs Ferry, New York died July 25, 2014. Gogol was born August 12, 1943, in the Bronx, New York, of immigrant parents. A Ph.D. in Mathematical Symbolic Logic, he attended The Bronx High School of Science, the City College of New York, and Yeshiva University. He published extensively on mathematics including "On the Switches Paradox" and "Formulas with Two Generalized Quantifiers." He became Vice President at General Reinsurance in Stamford, Connecticut. Gogol is survived by his wife, Miriam S. Gogol; daughter, Ariella Gogol; sister, Sheila Gogol of Amsterdam, Holland; and in-laws, David C. Sahatdjian, Victoria Moilan, and Nicholas Kabir of New York City. A memorial service will be held at 12 noon on Friday, August 15, at Irvington Presbyterian Church, 21 North Broadway, in Irvington, New York.

GILLESPIE--Edward A. On August 9, 2014 shortly before his 95th birthday. He will be greatly missed by his wife, family, friends and members of the many genealogical societies to which he belonged. Visitation Thursday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY. Funeral Service Friday 9:30am at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Restoration of Fraunces Tavern, 54 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10004.

GELFAND--Ruth, peacefully at home. Dear wife of the late Hyman. Beloved mother of Michael (Diana) Gelfand and Harriet "Ricky" (Steven) Cosenza. Adoring grandmother of Elizabeth (Jay) Rankin, John (Melissa) Gelfand, Kathryn Gelfand, Nicole (Anthony) Nardella, and Michael (Selene) Cosenza. Loving great-grandmother of Matt, Tommy, Alex, Will, Harrie, Luke and Will. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Services of New York Hospice Program and Temple Ansche Chesed.

FIGUR--Arthur. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital deeply mourns the passing of our long-standing and devoted friend, mentor and colleague. Dr. Figur came to Mount Sinai in 1955, training generations of students and residents in Hematology and in the Art and Science of Medicine. He served as AAS President from 1983-1984 and remained on the Board of Directors, playing an active role in constant support of the Mount Sinai physicians. In 1996, he received the prestigious Jacobi Medallion for his outstanding contributions to the institution. An avid cyclist, swimmer and steadfast champion of health and physical fitness, he traveled the world in pursuit of greater athletic and cultural endeavors. We salute his loyalty and legacy, and extend our sincere condolences to his family and many friends. Eric Neibart, MD, President Mark Reiner, MD, 1st Vice President Louis DePalo, MD, 2nd Vice President Harold Bronheim, MD, Secretary/Treasurer Amy Weinstein, Administrator

FIGUR--Arthur, MD. We, at the Mount Sinai Health System, are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend, mentor, and longtime colleague, Arthur Figur, MD. During his nearly six decades of service to The Mount Sinai Hospital and Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, he had many accomplishments as an internist and hematologist, holding key administrative posts as Chief of Outpatient Hematology, President of the Association of the Attending Staff, President of the Medical Board, and Medical Director. He was cherished as a wonderful and devoted teacher, role model, and mentor for medical students; an insightful administrator; and a physician sought by many for his wise counsel. A lifelong athlete, in his 60s and 70s he climbed Mount Kilimanjaro, biked cross-country, and won the 75-79 age division title in the U.S. Masters Swimming One-Mile Open Water National Championships, inspiring us all. We extend deepest condolences to his five children, grandchildren, other family members, and his beloved friends and colleagues. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD, Chief Executive Officer and President, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System David L. Reich, MD, President and Chief Operating Officer, The Mount Sinai Hospital
FIGUR--Arthur, passed away on August 9, 2014 at the age of 83. Beloved son, husband, father, grandfather and partner. Services Wednesday 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76 St., and Amsterdam Ave.

FEINBERG--Alice, beloved wife of the late Jerome E. Feinberg, passed away August 10. A respected occupational therapist, she is survived by a devoted daughter, Margie, and a son, Richard. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. Services Thursday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
DONOHUE--Rosemary, born in Queens, NY, died August 11, 2014 at Ocean Medical Center, Brick, NJ. She was 85.

CORROON--Rosemary Bradley, age 90, after a long illness. She leaves her husband of 67 years, John A. Corroon, daughters Rosemary Martin and Margaret Sheridan, sons John A. Jr., Richard A. and Thomas B., ten grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Her sister, Jeanne Gerwig, of Naples, FL also survives her. Rosemary had an avid interest in decorative arts, studied and trained at the Isabel O'Neil School for Painted Finishes and Conservation. She did volunteer work at the Cooper Hewitt Museum where she was an in-house decorative arts conservator. She was also a member of the Cooper Hewitt Advisory Council before the Museum became part of the Smithsonian. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Thursday, August 14th, at 11:00am at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, New York.
COONEY--Nancy. We love you forever and miss you like crazy. Barbara, Jordan, and Brewster.

COONEY--Nancy, on August 12, 2014. Beloved daughter of Elaine and the late Francis D. Cooney, Jr. Devoted sister of Susan, Maureen (Michael), Frank, Michael (Jocelyn), Kathleen and Shannon (Phillips). Loving aunt of Bridget, Michael and Charlotte. She will deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Memorial service: Thursday, August 14, 10:30am, Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th St., NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to The School of The Holy Child, Rye, NY. 914-967-5622.

COHEN--Arthur G. To my Uncle Arthur--cool under pressure, able to pause any meeting for a good laugh, a role model father, eternal husband--who is now looking down from the loftiest heights with his little brother, my father Richard, both with their piercing, intelligent blue eyes. Whether near or distant geographically, you are always close to my heart. Your nephew Andy Cohen
COHEN--Arthur G. To Karen and family, my sister Barbara Kurland and I were proud lifetime partners with Arthur. We extended our sincere condolences. Michael Lipstein

COHEN--Arthur G. We mourn the loss of Arthur Cohen. I was a young professional in the years that I knew Arthur, principally in the 1970s and 1980s. I knew Arthur to be a person of extraordinary intellect and refinement. My wife, Joan, interacted with Karen in our community in terms of care and well-being of our then respective young children. Arthur, in those years, was a leading luminary in the real estate and finance community. For a young professional, he was an object of awe. His passing represents the passing of a generation. Our sympathies to Karen, his daughters and their families. Joan and David Mandel

BROWN--Francis C.,Jr. With heavy hearts the family of Francis C. Brown Jr. announce his passing on August 11th at the age of 78. By his side was his devoted wife, Nancy L. Brown, whom he loved with all his heart from the moment he laid eyes on her as a teenager. Married for 54 years, they raised four children - Caroline, Buck, James, and Jennie - and he was a constant presence in their lives and those of his nine grandchildren, as well as that of his sister, Margaret. We loved him for his wit, tenacity, entrepreneurial spirit, high standards, intellectual curiosity, and devotion to family. For the last 15 years, he handled the symptoms of Parkinson's Disease with grit and grace. Born in Washington, DC, he graduated from Princeton University and Harvard Law School, and practiced law in New York as a sole practitioner for most of his professional life. He served on the Board of Regents of Georgetown University, and the Boards of The Convent of the Sacred Heart and the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. Contributions may be made in his memory to any of the above institutions or a charity of your choice. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday August 16th, 10:30am at St. Joseph's Church, 404 East 87th St.

ALTSHULER--Robert Louis. Died August 11, 2014, age 91. Husband of the late Sheila (Kaplan) Altshuler, Father of Ivie Rader and Adam Altshuler. Father-in-law of Bruce Rader, grandfather of Danielle Rader and Rochelle Rader, brother of the late Jack Altshuler, dear friend of Lois Rich. Born in Boston, MA to Israel and Ida Altshuler on January 13, 1923. Graduated Boston English High (1940) and Boston University School of Management, Cum Laude (1947). President of Class, Honorary Societies: Beta Gamma Sigma, Scarlet Key, Scabbard and Blade. Served during WWII in infantry combat as a Captain with the 7th Inf Regt, 3rd Inf Division. Decorated with the Silver Star, Bronze Star, Purple Heart and Combat Infantry Badge. Successful career in wholesale men's apparel business in Boston, New York and Los Angeles. Bob was a generous, kind and honorable man who will be dearly missed and lovingly remembered. Private burial in Sharon, MA.

WOLKOFF--Martin, passed away on August 12, 2014 at the age of 96. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn Wolkoff. Loving father of Allan, Harvey, and Neal and father-in-law of Claire, Susan, and Janet. WILLIAMS--Robin. The Juilliard community is deeply saddened by the death of our distinguished alumnus Robin Williams. Robin's genius for comedic improvisation, which quickly surfaced in his studies at Juilliard, was matched by his deep understanding of the actor's art and how to touch his audience in meaningful ways. He was a generous supporter of the School's drama students through the Robin Williams Scholarship, which supported the tuition cost of a drama student each year. As an artist, he brought together a unique mix of traditional actor training with a creative spirit that set new standards for performance in cinema, television and live theater. His caring ways and effervescent personality will be missed by all who were touched by this special person. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President James Houghton, Richard Rodgers Director of the Drama Division

WARNER--Betsy. July 19, 1955 August 11, 2014. Betsy passed away peacefully on August 11 at the age of 59. Her optimism, kindness and courage, as well as her love and care for family and friends touched many people. She brought smiles, warmth and joy to all who knew her, especially at the Children's Museum of Manhattan (CMOM) where she worked for over thirty years. Betsy was the beloved wife of her late husband Michael Ettelson, cherished daughter of her late father Bob and mother, Marcia, sister to Jim and Steve, sister-in-law to Priscilla and Jennifer, and aunt to five nephews and nieces. She was a devoted friend to Shella Rivers, who shared in Betsy's many triumphs. Betsy's graveside service will take place at King David Cemetery in Putnam Valley, NY at 2pm on August 13. The family will sit shiva at Jim and Priscilla Warner's home at 56 Prospect Avenue, Larchmont, NY at 6:30pm following the service. A celebration of Betsy's life and memorial service will be held this fall at CMOM. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to CMOM, 212 West 83rd Street, NY 10024.

VINE--Ruth Josephson April 2, 1927 - August 11, 2014. Beloved wife of Irvin, mother of Anthony, Brent and Stephen, grandmother of Carolyn and Vera, and great grandmother of Olya Cecile. In lieu of flowers, donations to Chabad Lubavitch of the Hamptons or Temple Israel of the City of New York.

SCHWARTZ--Irene. The Baruch College Fund and the entire Baruch College community is saddened by the death of distinguished alumna, Irene (Zanderer) Schwartz '48. Irene is the beloved wife and lifelong partner of Bernard Schwartz '48, Baruch College benefactor and Trustee Emeritus of the Baruch College Fund. Their support of Baruch, both Irene and Bernard's Alma Mater, was unprecedented in the history of The City University of New York. FRIEDMAN--Victor Stanley, died August 12th, at the age of 81, after a courageous five year struggle with cancer. He was surrounded by family and loved ones. Victor was born to Rose and Harry on May 9, 1933 in New York City. In 1941, the family moved to Los Angeles, where he attended Beverly Hills High and was an accomplished member of the debate squad. After graduating from Harvard in 1954, he attended Yale Law School, where he was elected to the editorial board of The Yale Law Journal. Shortly after law school, Victor joined the Civil Rights Division at the Justice Department in Washington D.C. In 1961 he returned to NYC to work as an anti-trust litigator for the law firm Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. He made partner at the age of 33, and soon became a leading attorney in his field. In 1974 he successfully argued before the US Supreme Court in the case of Dunhill vs. Cuba. He remained at Fried Frank, a job he loved, until his retirement in 1999. After retirement Victor, volunteered his time as a mediator and as a math tutor to high school students. He devoted much of his time to his many passions, including the piano, travel, scrabble, duplicate bridge, reading, and his loving nine children and grandchildren. Victor's intellectual curiosity, passion for life, and deep love for his friends and family will be missed. He is survived by his loving wife of 30 years, Victoria Schonfeld; his first wife, Sara Ann Friedman; his five beloved children Eric, Diana, Michael, Jared, and Remi; and his four adored grandchildren Naomi, Jordi, Ilan, and Liza. Services at 11:30am, Thursday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to the Southern Poverty Law Center or the Tutoring Star Learning at Goddard Riverside Community Center.

FIGUR--Arthur. We express our deepest sympathies for the family of our beloved Arthur Figur. No truer friend could we have had in our lives for over 60 years. A man who not only kept us healthy and alive with his medical expertise but kept us in stitches with his humor, his zest for life and, most of all, his kind and decent heart. After a distinguished career at Mt. Sinai and then as its Chief Medical Officer, he served his patients and legions of students with distinction. As an Ironman tri-athlete he showed age had few boundaries in sport. He fled Austria and the Nazis as a boy and returned to carry the United States flag at the Macabi Games in 2011. He will be missed. Herbert and Ann Burger Robert and Judith Bases

BROWN--Francis C.,Jr. With heavy hearts the family of Francis C. Brown Jr. announce his passing on August 11th at the age of 78. By his side was his devoted wife, Nancy L. Brown, whom he loved with all his heart from the moment he laid eyes on her as a teenager. Married for 54 years, they raised four children - Caroline, Buck, James, and Jennie - and he was a constant presence in their lives and those of his nine grandchildren, as well as that of his sister, Margaret. We loved him for his wit, tenacity, entrepreneurial spirit, high standards, intellectual curiosity, and devotion to family. For the last 15 years, he handled the symptoms of Parkinson's Disease with grit and grace. Born in Washington, DC, he graduated from Princeton University and Harvard Law School, and practiced law in New York as a sole practitioner for most of his professional life. He served on the Board of Regents of Georgetown University, and the Boards of The Convent of the Sacred Heart and the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. Contributions may be made in his memory to any of the above institutions or a charity of your choice. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday August 16th, 10:30am at St. Joseph's Church, 404 East 87th St.

BACCALL--Lauren. Jamie Bernstein, Alexander Bernstein and Nina Bernstein Simmons, along with the Leonard Bernstein Office, Inc., are very sad to have lost the Bernstein family's longtime friend, Lauren Bacall. Betty's appearance at the back door of the Bernstein apartment at the Dakota was always a welcome delight -- even if she was complaining about the piano noise. We send love to her entire family.

ALTSHULER--Robert Louis. Died August 11, 2014, age 91. Husband of the late Sheila (Kaplan) Altshuler, Father of Ivie Rader and Adam Altshuler. Father-in-law of Bruce Rader, grandfather of Danielle Rader and Rochelle Rader, brother of the late Jack Altshuler, dear friend of Lois Rich. Born in Boston, MA to Israel and Ida Altshuler on January 13, 1923. Graduated Boston English High (1940) and Boston University School of Management, Cum Laude (1947). President of Class, Honorary Societies: Beta Gamma Sigma, Scarlet Key, Scabbard and Blade. Served during WWII in infantry combat as a Captain with the 7th Inf Regt, 3rd Inf Division. Decorated with the Silver Star, Bronze Star, Purple Heart and Combat Infantry Badge. Successful career in wholesale men's apparel business in Boston, New York and Los Angeles. Bob was a generous, kind and honorable man who will be dearly missed and lovingly remembered. Private burial in Sharon, MA.

WALLACE--William E.,died peacefully surrounded by his family on Tuesday, August 12, 2014, in New York City. He was 92 years old. Bill was born in Philadelphia and was a long-time resident of Maple Shade, New Jersey. Bill served as a cryptanalyst in the 2nd Signal Intelligence Battalion of the US Army during World War II. He was the President for many years of the Federation of Telephone Workers of Pennsylvania, which became Local 13000 of the Communications Workers of America, and was later an International Vice President in that union. After his retirement, he remained active in community affairs, serving as head of the Maple Shade Planning Board, a volunteer mediator for the Burlington County Superior Court and a lector at Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Maple Shade. He was also active in local politics. Bill loved to travel and photograph the world; he enjoyed the Walnut Street Theatre and the Philly Pops; he was a devoted Philadelphia sports fan, attending the Phillies spring training each year; and he looked forward to spending time with his family in Avalon, New Jersey, and East Hampton, New York. Bill's beloved wife of 50 years, Rosemary, passed away in 2000. He was the beloved father of Nora Ann Wallace (Jack Nusbaum), Bill Wallace (Phyllis Wallace) and Rob Wallace (Susan Schlegel), and grandfather of Claire Wallace and Andrew Wallace. He was the brother of Georgina Meehan and the late Edward Wallace. Friends and family are invited to attend his viewing on Sunday, August 17, from 7:00pm to 9:00pm and on Monday, August 18, from 9:00am to 10:00am at Inglesby/Givnish of Maple Shade, 600 East Main Street. His Funeral Mass will follow at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Main Street and Fellowship Road, Maple Shade, New Jersey. Interment will be at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Cheltenham, Pennsylvania. www.snovergivnish.com

SWARTZ-WALDBAUM--Joyce Doris, 89, of Boca Raton, FL died peacefully August 12, 2014. Joyce passed away at home comforted with loving care from her sons, her friend and aide Merceline Smith and hospice protocol. Joyce was predeceased by her husband Michael Edward Swartz. Joyce was the loving mother of Steven and James, proud grandmother of Rhiana, Emily and Lora, and adoring great-grandmother of Wa-Ha-Yen-Tah Sheila Smoke. Joyce is survived by her brother Alan Waldbaum of Melville, NY. Joyce was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. Joyce raised her family in Little Neck and Roslyn, NY. Joyce was a past member of Temple Sinai, Roslyn, NY and Old Westbury Golf & Country Club, Old Westbury, NY. Joyce enjoyed traveling, dancing, spending time with her family and spending time at her summer home on Martha's Vineyard. Joyce worked in the family business, as a volunteer at North Shore hospital and a saleslady at A&S in Manhasset, NY. A gathering will be held August 19 at 1:00-1:30pm at Star of David, West Babylon, NY, 631-454-9600. A Graveside Service will be held August 19 at 2:00pm at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Lindenhurst, NY, 631-957-2277. In lieu of flowers or tributes, donations can be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1-800-633-2577.

STRASSFELD--Rabbi Meyer. SPANAKOS--William M.,April 11, 1928--August 11, 2014. With great sadness, the family of William (Bill) Michael Spanakos, of Bayside Queens, announces his passing. William was a practicing attorney for over fifty years and had an office in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. The eldest of seven sons born to Michael Basil Spanakos, and Stella (Katsorhis) Spanakos, passed away in Queens, NY, on Sunday night. He was surrounded by his family. William attended the U.S. Naval Academy at Annapolis, MD, in the late 40's; Graduated St. John's Law School, 1953; Served honorably for two years in the US Army, and was admitted to practice law in New York in 1955. William practiced law throughout the City, specializing in Criminal law and Commercial Transactions in the Restaurant Industry. He maintained a practice in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn for fifty eight years, along with his beloved brother and partner, John Spanakos, who sadly predeceased Bill by just over one year. William maintained the practice after the loss of his brother, and continued to work until his own passing. His sense of honesty and integrity served him, his firm, his family, and his clients honorably. He was a sought after advocate and had a fondness for representing the underdog. During his long and illustrious career he had the opportunity to be involved with many infamous legal cases. He represented individuals involved in the sensational Sentry Armored Car heist case in Astoria, and individuals involved in the notorious Claus von Bulow case. William took great pride in his successful appeal before the United States Supreme Court in the Athens case. He was known for his charitable works, and in 1990 established a scholarship fund in honor of his parents which served to assist financially challenged individuals of Greek descent to pursue and obtain their degrees in Medicine. William's father Michael was a prominent business man and restaurateur. He and his wife Stella, operated the "Paramount" located at 584 Court Street from the 1920's- 1950's. Stella, because of her charitable work in the community, went on to become New York State's Mother of the Year, after her husband had passed. Michael and Stella were proud Greek immigrants who settled and raised their family in Red Hook, Brooklyn. They instilled in their sons strong values of integrity, family, faith and a hard work ethic. William honored those values all the days of his life; and he sought to instill those values in his children, grandchildren, nieces and nephews. He was very proud of the fact that he had nine practicing attornevs in the family, and of all of those of the next generation who went on to become professionals. He was also very proud of each of his brothers, including those who achieved national and international athletic acclaim in the sport of Boxing for competition in the National Golden Gloves, Pan American Games and the Olympics. William was also predeceased by his brother Ernest and his wife Helen, his brother Charles and his wife Effie, his sister-in-law Mary, wife of John, and his son in law and friend Paul Kitsos. William is survived by his soulmate, Sheila Silverstein, his beloved children Michael Spanakos, Stella Spanakos, Lillian Spanakos, Helen Spanakos-Weitman, (Allen), Athena Spanakos-O'Riordan, (Eion); his beloved brothers George Spanakos, Peter Spanakos and Nick Spanakos, and each of their wives, his devoted long time secretary and friend, Helena Luchau, his grandchildren John, Michael, Paul, Nicholas, Jenna, Matthew, Andrew, and many nieces and nephews. William was a patriarch, father, brother, grandfather, uncle and friend. He was highly intelligent, witty and fearless, a tough gentleman. He was a true Renaissance man. He was hard but not hardened. He took great pride in himself and his appearance, and was an absolutely impeccable dresser. He was quick to laugh and to make others laugh. He was a very interesting character, with enormous depth and dimension. He was the kind of person anyone would want in their corner. He will be remembered for these many things. YIA SOU BILL! For further information please contact Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home 718-359-6300.

GEITHNER--Deborah Moore. Died peacefully at home in Orleans, MA on August 12, 2014, after a long journey with pancreatic cancer. Born June 6, 1938, to Charles F. Moore, Jr. and Adeline Nichols Moore. Graduated Smith College 1960. Survived by her husband of 54 years, Peter Franz Geithner, who spent much of his career at the Ford Foundation and with whom she lived in Zambia, Zimbabwe, India, Thailand, and China; her siblings, Jonathan Moore, Lydia Moore DuPertuis, Benjamin Moore; her son Timothy and his wife Carole; her daughter Sarah and her husband Andrew, her son Jonathan and his wife Debora; her son David and his wife Christine; and her grandchildren, Elise, Benjamin, Kaiya, Lincoln, Peter, Clare, Caroline, Piya and Malee. Pianist, teacher, force of nature, she loved Chopin, performed for her friends at Weil Recital Hall, New York, and founded and played with the Cove Chamber Players of Cape Cod. Her absence leaves a profound space in the lives of her family, friends and students. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Broad Reach Hospice & Palliative Care, the Lower Cape Outreach Council, or any other cause that reminds you of Deborah.

ALTSHULER--Robert Louis. Died August 11, 2014, age 91. Husband of the late Sheila (Kaplan) Altshuler, Father of Ivie Rader and Adam Altshuler. Father-in-law of Bruce Rader, grandfather of Danielle Rader and Rochelle Rader, brother of the late Jack Altshuler, dear friend of Lois Rich. Born in Boston, MA to Israel and Ida Altshuler on January 13, 1923. Graduated Boston English High (1940) and Boston University School of Management, Cum Laude (1947). President of Class, Honorary Societies: Beta Gamma Sigma, Scarlet Key, Scabbard and Blade. Served during WWII in infantry combat as a Captain with the 7th Inf Regt, 3rd Inf Division. Decorated with the Silver Star, Bronze Star, Purple Heart and Combat Infantry Badge. Successful career in wholesale men's apparel business in Boston, New York and Los Angeles. Bob was a generous, kind and honorable man who will be dearly missed and lovingly remembered. Private burial in Sharon, MA.

SUSSER--Mervyn W.,on August 14, 2014 at age 92. The faculty of the Gertrude H. Sergievsky Center at Columbia University mourn the passing of its founding director, Professor Mervyn W. Susser. Dr. Susser was a brilliant leader in the field of perinatal epidemiology and helped to launch the career of many. His profound impact on critical thinking and causality set the framework for modern epidemiology. His earlier work as a community physician and human rights advocate inspired all of those who knew him. We know that his legacy will live on. Richard Mayeux, MD, Sergievsky Professor and Director Gertrude H. Sergievsky Center at Columbia University

STRASSBERG--Bernard, on August 14, 2014 at age 87. Beloved father of Michael and Mitchell (Gale). Loving Grandfather of Erin (Les) and Shane (Sophia). Dear Great- grandfather of Madeline and Bridgette. Longtime companion of Judy Dean. Cousin of Jules. WWII Army Veteran, 9/11 Survivor, Collector of African Art and Music aficionado of Jazz and Blues. Former Gallery owner and painter. Funeral Service, Monday 11am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 Second Avenue, NYC. Interment to follow at Washington Memorial Park Cemetery, Mt. Sinai, NY.

SIMMONS--Harold Ralston Jr.,Harold Ralston Simmons, Jr. 1939--2014. Internationally noted interior designer Harold R. Simmons, Jr. died peacefully at his home in East Hampton, Long Island, New York on August 12, 2014. The son of Harold R. Simmons and Frances Caffey Simmons, he was born in Clarksdale, Mississippi on December 8, 1939. After his early education in the Clarksdale schools, Simmons graduated cum laude from the University of Mississippi, Oxford in 1961. Immediately upon graduation, he joined Kimbrough-Goldate, Inc., then the leading interior design firm in Memphis, Tennessee. Having majored in applied arts and art history at Ole Miss, after one year with Kimbrough-Goldate, Inc. he elected to continue his education at Parsons School of Design in New York City. Specializing in the study of Interior Architecture, he graduated with honors from Parsons in 1965 and began working for the architectural firm Alfred Easton Poor in Manhattan. In 1966, Simmons joined the decorating firm of Mrs. Henry Parish II in New York City working as the personal assistant to Albert Hadley. When Parish and Hadley formed their world-renowned firm, Parish-Hadley, Inc., Simmons was named Senior Vice President in charge of the architectural department where he nurtured the careers of several widely-recognized architects. He remained with the firm until 1987. The first week Simmons came to New York City in 1962, he was introduced to Peter J. van Hattum who played several major roles in the American musical theater. The two men entered into a relationship that lasted over fifty years, having residences in Manhattan and East Hampton. They were married on September 7, 2011. When Simmons left Parish-Hadley, Inc. in 1987, he and van Hattum formed the decorating firm Van Hattum and Simmons, Inc. which flourished until its closure in 2013. Over the twenty-five years they were in business together their projects included embassies in Argentina and Venezuela as well as residences in New York, London, Washington, D.C. and country estates on Maryland's Eastern Shore. Their work was featured on many occasions in both the Kips Bay Decorator Show House in New York City and in the Southampton Decorator Show House. Simmons and van Hattum have been loyal supporters of the East Hampton Historical Society. Simmons is survived by his spouse, Peter J. van Hattum, and by his sister Frances Simmons Keesee and her husband M. John Keesee. Funeral Service will be held on September 7th, 3:00pm at St. Lukes Episcopal Church, East Hampton, NY. Memorial gifts in honor of Harold Simmons may be made to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY, 11978.

SCHWARTZ--Tibbie, 95, died from a heart attack on August 14, 2014. She was a kind and devoted wife to Martin, her husband of over 72 years. She is survived by her loving children, son, Peter Schwartz, daughter Barbara Annis, grandson Andrew Schwartz, and daughter-in-law, Ellen Sherman. She was a wonderful mother and grandmother. She loved working in the world of antiques while also passionate about golf and bridge in which she participated enthusiastically in Palm Beach and at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, New York where she was a member for over forty years. She will always be loved and missed by the many who knew and appreciated her kind soul.

ROWE--George, Jr. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our heartfelt sympathy at the passing of George Rowe, Jr., a long-time friend of the Hospital. Through his generous support as an officer and director of The Ambrose Monell Foundation, Mr. Rowe played a critical role in advancing the Hospital's mission to improve the lives of all those affected by musculoskeletal disease and injury. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and fellow officers and directors of The Ambrose Monell Foundation. Richard L. Menschel, Chairman, Emeriti; Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery

READING--Charmian Sproule. Peacefully on August 14, 2014 at age 83. Photographer and artist. Mother of Sandra Chaplan, Rebecca Chaplan, Margaret Goldberg and Janet Pew. Loving grandmother of Aaron, Daniel, Jonathan and Benjamin Nathan; Nikolas, Matthew, and the late Alexander Goldberg; William, James and Henry Pew; and Remy Eggers. Mother-in-law of Chuck Eggers, David Nathan, Bill Goldberg and Layng Pew.

PERNICK--Bruce. It is with profound sadness that the American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel notes the untimely passing of board member and dear friend Bruce Pernick, who served as President of the Committee from 2005 until April, 2014. An Honorary Shenkar Fellow and member of the Board of Governors, Bruce's commitment to Shenkar was heartfelt, generous and unwavering. His kindness was felt and appreciated by the students who met with him on his frequent visits to the college, and who benefited from the many scholarships he provided. In recognition of Bruce and his family's substantial support, the main campus building at Shenkar and the faculty of Engineering were both named in their honor. An engineering graduate of the University of Rochester, Bruce would go to become President of the Monarch Machine Knitting Corporation, a very successful family business. His leadership at Monarch would sustain its reputation as the premier supplier of circular knitting machinery in the world. Our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Susan, who serves as our President; his children Craig and Jessica; his sister Jill Friedman (Mitchell); his grandchildren Trent and Olivia; nieces, nephews and the entire Pernick family as well as his many friends and colleagues. For those who had the opportunity and privilege to know Bruce, his presence and counsel will be sorely missed. Ivan Helfand, Executive Director Charlotte Fainblatt, Executive Director Emeritus

PERNICK--Bruce. Bruce Pernick, of Stamford, Connecticut and Bal Harbour, Florida passed away at home surrounded by his loving family on August 14th, 2014 at the age of sixty five. The cause was cancer. He grew up in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn and graduated from the University of Rochester with a degree in Aeronautical Engineering. He attended Leicester Polytechnic College and University to study textiles. He was CEO of Monarch Knitting Machinery Corporation and the American president of Shenkar College. He traveled all over the world for adventure and business. He was an avid golfer, a pinball champ, and captain of the squash team. He was a lover of nature and a student of the cosmos. Bruce was incredibly devoted to his family. He had a wonderful sense of humor and was adored by anyone fortunate enough to have known him. He is survived by his wife Susan, son Craig, daughter Jessica, beloved grandchildren Olivia and Trent, and sister Jill Friedman. He was predeceased by his parents, Frances and David Pernick. A service in celebration of his life will be held at their home on Sunday, August 17th at 11am. The family requests that donations in his memory be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital, Cancer and Wellness Center in Mt. Kisco, NY.

MROZ--John Edwin. Remarkable energy, vision and passion were the hallmarks of John Edwin Mroz, an individual whose formidable talents were dedicated to reducing international conflict and bringing together in rational discourse otherwise hostile adversaries. As dear friends and ardent admirers for over 30 years, we mourn the loss of a major figure of our time. We extend our sympathy to Karen, Jonathan, Jessica and Jeffrey and we hope they find strength and joy in the memory of this good man. Daniel and Joanna S. Rose

MARSHALL--Richard D. The Board of Directors of the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation notes with sadness the loss of Richard D. Marshall, gifted curator, writer, and art historian. Richard became an expert in the work of Robert Mapplethorpe and collaborated with the artist on the 1986 publication "Fifty New York Artists." Richard subsequently created with the artist, the groundbreaking retrospective exhibition of the artist's works installed at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 1988. Richard continued to collaborate with the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation to develop other projects and has contributed significantly to the expansion and elevation of the artist's legacy and the understanding of his work. Richard's writings, his keen eye, and his sharp wit combined to make him one of the great curators of our time. Our sympathy is extended to his partner of many years, William Georgis, and to his family and many friends around the world. Michael Ward Stout, President Dimitri Levas Burton G. Lipsky Stewart Shining Eric R. Johnson

LARIMER--Robert. We mourn the devastating loss of Bob Larimer on August 14th of cardiac arrest at age 85. A brilliant musician, lyricist and advertising genius, Bob served in Korea then began his career at McCann Erikson in the 1950's. He moved to Benton & Bowels where he was a creative director on Post Cereals. In 1964 he and Arch Nadler founded Nadler&Larimer which grew into a thriving advertising agency handling accounts such as Austin Nichols and Faberge. Bob created the highly- acclaimed Brut TV commercials -- interviews with athletes Joe Namath, Willie Mays and Jimmy Connors. The agency was sold to Mickleberry in 1980. He later joined his wife, Riki Kane, in her housewares company, Metrokane inc. Together they built a multi-million dollar business focusing on wine accessories, specifically the Rabbit and Houdini brands. The key to the company's success was Bob's advertising expertise. The Rabbit brand became famous world-wide and was advertised consistently in The New York Times Magazine and The New Yorker. Beyond his stunning career in advertising and marketing, Bob's first love was musical theater. Over the years he created several off-broadway and one broadway show, "But Never Jam Today" directed by Vinette Caroll. He wrote the music and lyrics for the last song recorded by Marlene Dietrich, "The World Goes Rolling On." This past June, he completed a concept album "Maxie's" an original jazz musical featuring vocalists Billy Porter, Jason Alexander, Heather Headley, Shirley Jones, Ruben Studdard, John Schneider and Jennifer Holliday. Much of Bob's music can be heard on his website..www.songsby boblarimer.com. A true renaissance man, Bob was a voracious reader, devouring books on politics and history. In Watermill, his favorite pastime was reading on his deck overlooking the lake and enjoying beautiful sunsets. In New York, his favorite pastime was composing music and playing his grand piano for hours on end. On Tuesday nights, he loved playing poker with his cronies. When he was younger he loved tennis. When they were hitting, he loved the Yankees. But most of all, he loved his wife and partner in life, Riki Kane Larimer. Their relationship spanned over five decades; they simply adored each other. In addition to his wife Riki, he leaves his son Neil (Kathy) daughter Cheryl (Jaime) granddaughters Heather, Vanessa and Gabriela; grandsons Alan and Robby, great-grandson Carter, brother-in-law Michael Kane of Los Angeles and his adorable puppy Miki who will miss snuggling up with him under the covers every night. Bob lived his life to the fullest and died with his boots on. Services to be held Monday August 18 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 1076 Madison Ave at 11:30am. The family will be receiving friends at home in New York Monday after 6pm.

KUST--Henrietta Logan, Died in New York City, August 11, 2014, age 94. Wife of the late Leonard E. Kust. Born May 6, 1920 in Pittsburgh, PA. Graduated University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill 1941. Served in the Women's Army Corps 1943-45. Worked in New York at Time Inc. as Research Librarian for National Affairs 1946-51. Survived by her daughters, Alice K. Harding of Crofton, MD and Andrea L. Kust of New York City; sons-in-law David S. Harding and Stephen E. Shapiro; granddaughter Jennifer L. Harding; sisters Alice Logan of Chapel Hill, NC and Georgia Henderson of Lexington, KY. Donations in her memory may be made to the Church of the Heavenly Rest, New York City.
KEATING--Charles. Dear friend for fifty years. Extraordinary actor, bawdy storyteller, tuneful balladeer, handsome gracious gentleman. We loved him dearly and will miss him forever. Maggie and Don

FRIEDMAN--Victor. AJC mourns the passing of Victor Friedman, beloved husband of our chief operating officer, Victoria Schonfeld. A Yale Law School graduate, Victor was a distinguished attorney with a lifelong commitment to the pursuit of justice. He was also an accomplished classical pianist, an avid bridge and tennis player, and a volunteer tutor in public schools. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, five children and four grandchildren. May the memory of this erudite, compassionate, courageous and dignified man always be for a blessing and an inspiration. Stanley Bergman, President Richard Berkman, Chair, Bd. of Governors David Harris, Exec. Director
FRIEDMAN--Alva. The Koch family mourns the loss of our Auntie Alva. No friend ever added more fun and laughter to our lives. It's comforting to know you will be keeping the whole gang smiling!

BURROUGHS--Davis "Chip" III, Davis "Chip" Burroughs III, Asbury Park resident and renowned chef, dies at 63. Chip passed away on August 9, 2014 while surrounded by family at the Jersey Shore University Medical Center in Neptune, NJ. "Chip" is survived by his life partner Betsy Old; his daughter Elizabeth B. Doerr; son Davis C. Burroughs IV; sister Bunny Krueger and her son Jamie Jordan; brother Peter Burroughs and his son Jeffrey Burroughs and daughter Lauren Burroughs; son-in-law Michael Doerr; step-son Forrest R. Old III and his fiance Lauren Sewell; and his beloved cat, Leroy. Chip's parents, Davis C. Burroughs Jr. and Jean K. Weidlein preceded him in death. In addition to his culinary degree, Chip earned a BA from Ohio Wesleyan University in Technical Theatre and a BA from Housatonic College in Computer Science. He was a Certified Microsoft Engineer. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, Chip was unusually gifted and multi-talented. Known for his spirited wit, ebullience, generosity, kindness and expansive creativity, Chip was a true Renaissance man. Accomplished in diverse fields, his passion and renown was as an Executive Chef. He trained at the Culinary Institute of America, and owned a successful catering company in Fairfield, CT for 20+ years. In 2011, Chip and Betsy founded The Asbury Ocean Beach Inn, an award-winning bed and breakfast in Asbury Park, NJ. Chip was a member of the Rotary Club of Asbury Park and donated his services to numerous charitable events. Chip's legacy includes memories of him delivering culinary masterpieces to his friends when testing new recipes. A legendary and colorful personality, Chip was a devoted and beloved father, husband and friend who will remain in hearts forever. To celebrate Chip's love of the sea, a memorial service will be held on Asbury Park Beach S on Saturday, August 16 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, and to honor Chip's love of animals, the family requests donations be made to: Rescue Ridge P.O. Box 223 Spring Lake, NJ 07762 www.rescueridge.com.
