WALLACE--William E.,died peacefully surrounded by his family on Tuesday, August 12, 2014, in New York City. He was 92 years old. Bill was born in Philadelphia and was a long-time resident of Maple Shade, New Jersey. Bill served as a cryptanalyst in the 2nd Signal Intelligence Battalion of the US Army during World War II. He was the President for many years of the Federation of Telephone Workers of Pennsylvania, which became Local 13000 of the Communications Workers of America, and was later an International Vice President in that union. After his retirement, he remained active in community affairs, serving as head of the Maple Shade Planning Board, a volunteer mediator for the Burlington County Superior Court and a lector at Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Maple Shade. He was also active in local politics. Bill loved to travel and photograph the world; he enjoyed the Walnut Street Theatre and the Philly Pops; he was a devoted Philadelphia sports fan, attending the Phillies spring training each year; and he looked forward to spending time with his family in Avalon, New Jersey, and East Hampton, New York. Bill's beloved wife of 50 years, Rosemary, passed away in 2000. He was the beloved father of Nora Ann Wallace (Jack Nusbaum), Bill Wallace (Phyllis Wallace) and Rob Wallace (Susan Schlegel), and grandfather of Claire Wallace and Andrew Wallace. He was the brother of Georgina Meehan and the late Edward Wallace. Friends and family are invited to attend his viewing on Sunday, August 17, from 7:00pm to 9:00pm and on Monday, August 18, from 9:00am to 10:00am at Inglesby/Givnish of Maple Shade, 600 East Main Street. His Funeral Mass will follow at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Main Street and Fellowship Road, Maple Shade, New Jersey. Interment will be at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Cheltenham, Pennsylvania. www.snovergivnish.com

SWARTZ-WALDBAUM--Joyce Doris, 89, of Boca Raton, FL died peacefully August 12, 2014. Joyce passed away at home comforted with loving care from her sons, her friend and aide Merceline Smith and hospice protocol. Joyce was predeceased by her husband Michael Edward Swartz. Joyce was the loving mother of Steven and James, proud grandmother of Rhiana, Emily and Lora, and adoring great-grandmother of Wa-Ha-Yen-Tah Sheila Smoke. Joyce is survived by her brother Alan Waldbaum of Melville, NY. Joyce was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. Joyce raised her family in Little Neck and Roslyn, NY. Joyce was a past member of Temple Sinai, Roslyn, NY and Old Westbury Golf & Country Club, Old Westbury, NY. Joyce enjoyed traveling, dancing, spending time with her family and spending time at her summer home on Martha's Vineyard. Joyce worked in the family business, as a volunteer at North Shore hospital and a saleslady at A&S in Manhasset, NY. A gathering will be held August 19 at 1:00-1:30pm at Star of David, West Babylon, NY, 631-454-9600. A Graveside Service will be held August 19 at 2:00pm at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Lindenhurst, NY, 631-957-2277. In lieu of flowers or tributes, donations can be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1-800-633-2577.

SUSSER--Mervyn W.,on August 14, 2014 at age 92. The faculty of the Gertrude H. Sergievsky Center at Columbia University mourn the passing of its founding director, Professor Mervyn W. Susser. Dr. Susser was a brilliant leader in the field of perinatal epidemiology and helped to launch the career of many. His profound impact on critical thinking and causality set the framework for modern epidemiology. His earlier work as a community physician and human rights advocate inspired all of those who knew him. We know that his legacy will live on. Richard Mayeux, MD, Sergievsky Professor and Director Gertrude H. Sergievsky Center at Columbia University

SUSSER--Mervyn, on August 14, 2014, 92 years old. The Columbia Mailman School of Public Health mourns the passing of Mervyn W. Susser, whose pathbreaking career as an epidemiologist, physician, and human rights advocate inspired generations of scientists, policymakers, and healthcare workers to understand the inextricable links between health and equality. Born in South Africa, Susser and his wife, Zena Stein, developed one of the first community based clinics to provide care for non-white South Africans and contributed a pioneering study of healthcare in the developing world. Joining the Columbia School of Public Health in 1965, Susser went on to found the PhD program in Epidemiology and the Gertrude H. Sergievsky Center, also at Columbia. Beloved husband of Zena Stein for 65 years. Loving father of Ida, Ezra and Ruth, and of adoptive son, Elie Valencia. Devoted grandfather of nine.

SUNDELL--Nina, passed away on August 3, 2014, peacefully and at home, her son and daughter, Margaret and David Sundell, both of New York City, at her side. She is also survived by her daughter, Marianne Sundell of Wendall, MA, her cousin, Marieve Rugo, of Boston, three grandchildren, Lillian and J.H. Sundell-Thomas and Tomas Laddaga, and her son-in-law Reinaldo Laddaga. She was the widow of Michael Gordon Sundell, whom she met in her junior year of college; they were, in her words, "life-long best friends." Nee Nina-Giulia Antonia Matilda Krauss Castelli, she was born July 22, 1936, in Vienna, and spent her first years in Paris. She emigrated to New York during World War II, accompanied by her beloved nanny Frances Grundy and her parents, Leo Castelli and Ileana Sonnabend, renowned dealers and champions of post-war avant-garde art. A visionary curator, Sundell shared her parent's passion and worked to introduce contemporary art to audiences throughout the United States at a time when its exhibition was largely restricted to New York. In 1968, she co-founded, with Marjorie Talalay, The New Gallery, later renamed the Museum of Contemporary Art Cleveland. Having moved to Washington D.C. in 1973, she then joined forces with Susan Sollins from 1975-1978 to establish Independent Curators Incorporated (ICI), which organized ambitious and artistically challenging exhibitions and is now known as Independent Curators International. From 1984 to 1990, Sundell served as director of the art gallery of Lehman College, CUNY, in the Bronx. She spent her final decades supporting her husband's work as president of the artist and writer's colony, Yaddo, traveling with family and close friends, and authoring a novel entitled The Dallek Touch. Witty, wise, and wide-ranging in her knowledge and love of the arts, she will be sorely missed not only by family but also by her many friends and associates. The family is grateful to Dr. Leslie Boyd, MD and her staff at NYU Langone Medical Center and Dorien Spelbrink and her staff at Heaven Can Wait, LLC for their care and support during her last years. A memorial, to be announced, is planned for the fall. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial contributions to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

SUNDELL--Nina Castelli. We mourn the death of our dear friend Nina Castelli Sundell. We will miss her sorely, but will remember with joy the excitement of experiencing new works of art together and the many extraordinary conversations filled with laughter. Wickedly witty and endlessly curious, Nina was voracious in her literary readings, and in her ability to absorb vast amounts of information about the arts in general, and contemporary art in particular. To look at art of any era with her always brought forth new and unexpected insights. We were privileged to join Nina in supporting and starting projects like Independent Curators International(ICI). And the many wonderful and enlightening journeys abroad with her will never be forgotten. In our sadness and loss, we offer condolences to Nina's three children and extended family. Agnes Gund and Susan Sollins

STRASSBERG--Bernard, on August 14, 2014 at age 87. Beloved father of Michael and Mitchell (Gale). Loving Grandfather of Erin (Les) and Shane (Sophia). Dear Great- grandfather of Madeline and Bridgette. Longtime companion of Judy Dean. Cousin of Jules. WWII Army Veteran, 9/11 Survivor, Collector of African Art and Music aficionado of Jazz and Blues. Former Gallery owner and painter. Funeral Service, Monday 11am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 Second Avenue, NYC. Interment to follow at Washington Memorial Park Cemetery, Mt. Sinai, NY.

SMITH--Lily Nixon Leopold, born 1934 in New York City, died August 15th near her home in Old Chatham, New York. A lifelong New Yorker, she loved the theater, the Yankees and all things New York. Lily's husband, James A. Smith predeceased her. She is survived by her children Palmer of New York City, Sanford of Sydney, Australia and Elizabeth of Portland, Oregon; and seven grandchildren. Memorials will be held at a later date.

SIMMONS--Harold Ralston Jr.,Harold Ralston Simmons, Jr. 1939--2014. Internationally noted interior designer Harold R. Simmons, Jr. died peacefully at his home in East Hampton, Long Island, New York on August 12, 2014. The son of Harold R. Simmons and Frances Caffey Simmons, he was born in Clarksdale, Mississippi on December 8, 1939. After his early education in the Clarksdale schools, Simmons graduated cum laude from the University of Mississippi, Oxford in 1961. Immediately upon graduation, he joined Kimbrough-Goldate, Inc., then the leading interior design firm in Memphis, Tennessee. Having majored in applied arts and art history at Ole Miss, after one year with Kimbrough-Goldate, Inc. he elected to continue his education at Parsons School of Design in New York City. Specializing in the study of Interior Architecture, he graduated with honors from Parsons in 1965 and began working for the architectural firm Alfred Easton Poor in Manhattan. In 1966, Simmons joined the decorating firm of Mrs. Henry Parish II in New York City working as the personal assistant to Albert Hadley. When Parish and Hadley formed their world-renowned firm, Parish-Hadley, Inc., Simmons was named Senior Vice President in charge of the architectural department where he nurtured the careers of several widely-recognized architects. He remained with the firm until 1987. The first week Simmons came to New York City in 1962, he was introduced to Peter J. van Hattum who played several major roles in the American musical theater. The two men entered into a relationship that lasted over fifty years, having residences in Manhattan and East Hampton. They were married on September 7, 2011. When Simmons left Parish-Hadley, Inc. in 1987, he and van Hattum formed the decorating firm Van Hattum and Simmons, Inc. which flourished until its closure in 2013. Over the twenty-five years they were in business together their projects included embassies in Argentina and Venezuela as well as residences in New York, London, Washington, D.C. and country estates on Maryland's Eastern Shore. Their work was featured on many occasions in both the Kips Bay Decorator Show House in New York City and in the Southampton Decorator Show House. Simmons and van Hattum have been loyal supporters of the East Hampton Historical Society. Simmons is survived by his spouse, Peter J. van Hattum, and by his sister Frances Simmons Keesee and her husband M. John Keesee. Funeral Service will be held on September 7th, 3:00pm at St. Lukes Episcopal Church, East Hampton, NY. Memorial gifts in honor of Harold Simmons may be made to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY, 11978.
SIGETY--Charles E. "The Wednesday Ten" mourns the loss of our esteemed friend and member, who graced 50+ years of dinners combining camaraderie, fun, and important issues.

SHAKTMAN--Sandra, 74, on August 7, of a heart attack. Sandy was a steadfast and loving mother, a loyal and supportive sister, sister-in-law and aunt, a tireless friend, and an ardent liberal. Her keen intelligence, curious mind, wit, and cheerful, independent spirit will be missed.

SCHWARTZ--Tibbie, 95, died from a heart attack on August 14, 2014. She was a kind and devoted wife to Martin, her husband of over 72 years. She is survived by her loving children, son, Peter Schwartz, daughter Barbara Annis, grandson Andrew Schwartz, and daughter-in-law, Ellen Sherman. She was a wonderful mother and grandmother. She loved working in the world of antiques while also passionate about golf and bridge in which she participated enthusiastically in Palm Beach and at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, New York where she was a member for over forty years. She will always be loved and missed by the many who knew and appreciated her kind soul.

SCHWARTZ--Irene. We mourn the loss of our dear Irene, friend of many years. Steadfast, genuine and loving. Her direct and elegant way blessed us all with her intelligence, warmth and humor. We extend our deepest, heartfelt sympathies to her beloved husband, Bob, to her daughters Karen and Francesca, and to her grandchildren, Jessica, Alexandra, Nicolas and Tess. Gene and Maryan

SCHWARTZ--Irene Zanderer. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Irene Zanderer Schwartz, beloved wife of Bernard Schwartz. We extend our condolences to Irene's husband; her daughters, Karen and Francesca; her grandchildren; and her entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

SCHWARTZ--Irene. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of WNET, we note with deep sadness the passing of Irene Schwartz, cherished wife of WNET Trustee Bernard Schwartz. Her support of WNET reflected her deep commitment to education and the arts and we are grateful to have been touched by her. Our thoughts are with Irene's family and we join them in mourning her passing. James S. Tisch, Chairman Neal Shapiro, President & CEO

SCHWARTZ--Irene. The Trustees and Staff of the New-York Historical Society express great sympathy and sadness on the passing of Irene Schwartz, beloved wife of our treasured trustee, Bernard Schwartz, and generous supporter of our Irene and Bernard Schwartz programs. We feel fortunate to have known Irene, a warm and exceptionally intelligent woman, extraordinarily devoted to her family and friends. Our hearts go out to Bernard, Karen, Fran and the grandchildren. Pam B. Schafler, Chair Richard Reiss, Vice Chair Roger Hertog, Chair of the Executive Committee Louise Mirrer, President & CEO

SCHWAB--Martin J.,died at the age of 91 on August 12, 2014. Beloved husband of Betty Brand who predeceased him. Loving brother of Elizabeth Fuld. Loving father of Jeffrey, Sally and Steven. Devoted grandfather of Jay, Julie Alex, Katie and Adam. Father-in-law to Susan, Sam and Shoko. Loving companion of Barbara. World War II veteran. Former CEO of United Merchants & Manufacturers. 50+ year member of Quaker Ridge Country Club, past Board Member of Montefiore Medical Center. He will be greatly missed.

ROWE--George, Jr.,died August 14, 2014 at the age of 92, following a long illness. He was the senior partner of the law firm of Fulton Rowe & Hart LLP and was the longtime President of The Ambrose Monell Foundation, Inc. and of The G. Unger Vetlesen Foundation, Inc. Mr. Rowe graduated from Yale University in 1943 where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. After graduation, he served in the United States Navy until 1946 aboard the U.S.S. Birmingham (CL 62) in the South Pacific, where he rose to the rank of lieutenant. After the War, he attended Columbia University Law School, and graduated in 1948. While at Columbia Law, he was recognized as a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, and was elected an editor of the Columbia Law Review for the 1947-1948 term. Following law school, he joined the firm of Fulton, Walter & Halley (now Fulton, Rowe & Hart LLP). Mr. Rowe served as president and director of Stanrock Uranium Mines Limited and as a director of its successor, Denison Mines Limited. Mr. Rowe also served as a director of International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Foster Wheeler Corporation and Axe Houghton Mutual Funds. He served for many years as a director and as the Vice President and Secretary of the van Ameringen Foundation, Inc. He is survived by his wife, Joyce C. Rowe, and their daughter Zoe X. Rowe, and also by his three children by a prior marriage, John G. Rowe, Julia T. Rowe and Katharine F. Rowe.

READING--Charmian Sproule. Peacefully on August 14, 2014 at age 83. Photographer and artist. Mother of Sandra Chaplan, Rebecca Chaplan, Margaret Goldberg and Janet Pew. Loving grandmother of Aaron, Daniel, Jonathan and Benjamin Nathan; Nikolas, Matthew, and the late Alexander Goldberg; William, James and Henry Pew; and Remy Eggers. Mother-in-law of Chuck Eggers, David Nathan, Bill Goldberg and Layng Pew.

PROSKAUER--Paul F.,Ph.D., son of the late Dr. Curt and Erna Proskauer and brother of the late Henry G. Proskauer passed away on August 9th. He was born in Breslau, Germany in 1921 and attended a humanistic Gymnasium (Johannesgymnasium) (Latin, French, Greek) for 7 ++ years until November 9, 1938 (Kristallnacht). In June 1939 he had to leave Germany with his parents and went to Italy to await there the issuance of the immigration visas to USA. From September 1939 until May 1940 he lived in Rome. Since his father who was a dentist in Breslau where he had published in 1926 the first pictorial history of Dentistry Iconographia Odontologica' and had also had from 1926 to 1933 in Berlin position of Director of the Research Institute for History of Dentistry Forschungsinstitut fur Goschichte der Zahnheilkunde - because of this and because of his personal acquaintance with the dentist of Pope Pius XII: Dr. A Piperno - he received permission to do research work in the Vatican Library in the field of history of dentistry. And it was the Vatican Library - possibly Cardinal Tisserant - who asked the Italian Steamship Company to reduce the fare from Italy to New York by 50% thus enabling the Proskauer family to leave Italy before Italy entered the war. His parents and Paul arrived in New York on May 23rd, 1940 and his brother Henry already in April 1940 - coming directly from Zurich to Naples and then to New York. His brother Henry had attended the ETH (Eidgebossische Technische Hochschule) in Zurich, Switzerland from 1935 until 1940 where he had studied architecture - where Prof. Salvisberg had been an outstanding architect and Henry's Professor. Paul attended in New York at first for eight months George Washington High School at night and took the Regents exams in English, American History and American Government in June 1941. In September 1941 he was admitted to attend the School of Business and Civic Administration of the College of the City of New York (now Baruch College) and graduated in 1945 "cum laude". He then worked for an export company for a few years, to earn money and began graduate studies in German Literature in 1959: he received a Master's Degree from Hunter College and his Doctorate (Ph.D.) in 1966 from the Department of Germanic Languages at Columbia University. He taught full time German Language and Literature courses at Hunter College, then Hunter College in the Bronx which was named eventually Lehman College for nearly 30 years and retired as Professor Emeritus. He is not survived by any member of his family. His grandmother on his father's side: Selma Proskauer was distantly related to Federal Appeal Court Judge Jacob Trieber was killed in an extermination camp and his uncle (his mother's brother). Dr. Willy Cohn - a specialist in the Hohenstuffen-era - was shot with his wife and two small daughters in Lithuania November 1941. His father's sister Ella Brinnitzer was killed in Auschwitz with her husband. When Paul was an undergraduate he was accepted by the College Honorary Society Sigma Alpha and after graduation by the National Honorary Society for students of Business Colleges 'Beta Gamma Sigma' (the scholastic equivalent of Phi Beta Kappa). His father Dr. Curt received shortly before his death in 1972 the Order of Merit from the German Government. 'Das Grosse Bundesverdienstkreuz'. Paul and his brother had decided to donate their book - and art collection to the Kantons - Library in Schwyz, Switzerland. Henry had already given three works of German Expressionism an Oil by Otto Mueller and two watercolors by Erich Heckel to the Brucke Museum in Berlin and had previously donated an architectural drawing by Poelzig to the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Both Henry and Paul were members if Modern Art for more than 50 years. During the last few years of his life Paul was happy when he could attend symphony and chamber music concerts in Carnegie Hall which he tried to support in his way. Paul was especially grateful for the personal interest and kindness of the three Rodriguez sisters: Rachel, Jennifer and Cindy who in their twenties had also known Henry and were good friends and companions. It was Paul's special wish to express to Dr. Jerry Gliklich and his wonderful secretary Ms. Joan how grateful he was for the extraordinary care and personal interest Dr. Gliklich had for many years shown to both brothers. Memorial services Tuesday, August 19 at 9am at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St.)

PERNICK--Bruce. It is with profound sadness that the American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel notes the untimely passing of board member and dear friend Bruce Pernick, who served as President of the Committee from 2005 until April, 2014. An Honorary Shenkar Fellow and member of the Board of Governors, Bruce's commitment to Shenkar was heartfelt, generous and unwavering. His kindness was felt and appreciated by the students who met with him on his frequent visits to the college, and who benefited from the many scholarships he provided. In recognition of Bruce and his family's substantial support, the main campus building at Shenkar and the faculty of Engineering were both named in their honor. An engineering graduate of the University of Rochester, Bruce would go to become President of the Monarch Machine Knitting Corporation, a very successful family business. His leadership at Monarch would sustain its reputation as the premier supplier of circular knitting machinery in the world. Our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Susan, who serves as our President; his children Craig and Jessica; his sister Jill Friedman (Mitchell); his grandchildren Trent and Olivia; nieces, nephews and the entire Pernick family as well as his many friends and colleagues. For those who had the opportunity and privilege to know Bruce, his presence and counsel will be sorely missed. Ivan Helfand, Executive Director Charlotte Fainblatt, Executive Director Emeritus

PERNICK--Bruce. Bruce Pernick, of Stamford, Connecticut and Bal Harbour, Florida passed away at home surrounded by his loving family on August 14th, 2014 at the age of sixty five. The cause was cancer. He grew up in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn and graduated from the University of Rochester with a degree in Aeronautical Engineering. He attended Leicester Polytechnic College and University to study textiles. He was CEO of Monarch Knitting Machinery Corporation and the American president of Shenkar College. He traveled all over the world for adventure and business. He was an avid golfer, a pinball champ, and captain of the squash team. He was a lover of nature and a student of the cosmos. Bruce was incredibly devoted to his family. He had a wonderful sense of humor and was adored by anyone fortunate enough to have known him. He is survived by his wife Susan, son Craig, daughter Jessica, beloved grandchildren Olivia and Trent, and sister Jill Friedman. He was predeceased by his parents, Frances and David Pernick. A service in celebration of his life will be held at their home on Sunday, August 17th at 11am. The family requests that donations in his memory be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital, Cancer and Wellness Center in Mt. Kisco, NY.

NORTHROP--David D, of Dobbs Ferry, born in Philadelphia, PA, died after an illness on August 15 at age 66, surrounded by his loving children Jessica and Daniel and close friends and family. He was deeply grieved by the loss of his dear wife Abby in 1993, and retired from his executive position at Merrill Lynch in 1998 to become a full-time dad to Jess and Dan, to whom he was devoted. In his early career he worked for the Legal Aid Criminal Defense Division in the Bronx, where he made many life-long friends. He was an avid fan of his home town Phillies and Eagles, an enthusiastic amateur scholar and admirer of Abraham Lincoln, and a devotee of the music of the Beatles. Friends may call Sunday from 4 to 8pm at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Funeral service Monday 1pm at South Presbyterian Church, 343 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY. www.edwardsanddowdle.com

NEWKIRK--Rudolph H.,born December 24, 1913 in Frankfurt-am-Main, died peacefully at 100 years of age. He moved to New York in 1934 and became a United States citizen. A successful businessman, he was a music lover, a supporter of the Metropolitan Opera and a Senior Master bridge player. He leaves behind his loving wife of 62 years, three devoted children, Thomas, James and Joyce, six loving grandchildren and seven wonderful great-grandchildren. Services private.

MROZ--John Edwin. Remarkable energy, vision and passion were the hallmarks of John Edwin Mroz, an individual whose formidable talents were dedicated to reducing international conflict and bringing together in rational discourse otherwise hostile adversaries. As dear friends and ardent admirers for over 30 years, we mourn the loss of a major figure of our time. We extend our sympathy to Karen, Jonathan, Jessica and Jeffrey and we hope they find strength and joy in the memory of this good man. Daniel and Joanna S. Rose

McNALLY--Sr. Virginia (St. Edward), RSHM, 85, Tarrytown, NY, August 12, 2014. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary (RSHM) 61 years. Taught at Marymount College, Tarrytown, NY; Marymount College, Boca Raton, FL; Marymount Manhattan College and Academy of the Sacred Heart of Mary, Manhattan, NY. Served in the RSHM Generalate, Rome; in province leadership and formation programs in New York; in Cormaria Retreat House, Sag Harbor, NY, and in Zimbabwe. Preceded in death by brothers, John and Richard McNally. Survived by sister Mary Alice Githens of Point Pleasant, NJ, and sister-in-law Sally Greeley McNally of Bronxville, NY. Services Marymount Convent, 32 Warren Avenue, Tarrytown, NY. Wake Wednesday, August 20, 3:00-7:30pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, August 21, 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to RSHM, 50 Wilson Park Drive, Tarrytown, NY, 10591.

MARSHALL--Richard D. The Board of Directors of the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation notes with sadness the loss of Richard D. Marshall, gifted curator, writer, and art historian. Richard became an expert in the work of Robert Mapplethorpe and collaborated with the artist on the 1986 publication "Fifty New York Artists." Richard subsequently created with the artist, the groundbreaking retrospective exhibition of the artist's works installed at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 1988. Richard continued to collaborate with the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation to develop other projects and has contributed significantly to the expansion and elevation of the artist's legacy and the understanding of his work. Richard's writings, his keen eye, and his sharp wit combined to make him one of the great curators of our time. Our sympathy is extended to his partner of many years, William Georgis, and to his family and many friends around the world. Michael Ward Stout, President Dimitri Levas Burton G. Lipsky Stewart Shining Eric R. Johnson

MANDEL--Jules. The founder of Glenmore Chrome Company and Dinettes at Discount has died at age 94. Beloved husband of Elinor. Devoted father of David (Jill), Jodie Turner, and Erica Gentile (Joe). Cherished grandpop of Jamie, Benjamin, Scott, Corinne, and Brian. Loving brother of the late Milton, Estelle, and Bette Bloom. A World War II Veteran of the United States Navy Seabees and furniture entrepreneur for more than 40 years. For more info: www. jewish-funeral-home.com
LEE--Flora B.,died Monday, August 11 at home surrounded by her children. She traveled the world but loved New York. Memorial August 30, St. Thomas Aquinas, Palo Alto, CA.

LARIMER--Robert. We mourn the devastating loss of Bob Larimer on August 14th of cardiac arrest at age 85. A brilliant musician, lyricist and advertising genius, Bob graduated from Carnegie Mellon, served in Korea then began his career at McCann Erikson in the 1950's. He moved to Benton & Bowels where he was a creative director on Post Cereals. In 1964 he and Arch Nadler founded Nadler&Larimer which grew into a thriving advertising agency handling accounts such as Austin Nichols and Faberge. Bob created the highly-acclaimed Brut TV commercials -- interviews with athletes Joe Namath, Willie Mays and Jimmy Connors. The agency was sold to Mickleberry in 1980. He later joined his wife, Riki Kane, in her housewares company, Metrokane inc. Together they built a multi-million dollar business focusing on wine accessories, specifically the Rabbit and Houdini brands. The key to the company's success was Bob's advertising expertise. The Rabbit brand became famous world-wide and was advertised consistently in The New York Times Magazine and The New Yorker. Beyond his stunning career in advertising and marketing, Bob's first love was musical theater. Over the years he created several off-broadway and one broadway show, "But Never Jam Today" directed by Vinette Caroll. He wrote the music and lyrics for the last song recorded by Marlene Dietrich, "The World Goes Rolling On." This past June, he completed a concept album "Maxie's" an original jazz musical featuring vocalists Billy Porter, Jason Alexander, Heather Headley, Shirley Jones, Ruben Studdard, John Schneider and Jennifer Holliday. Much of Bob's music can be heard on his website..www.songsby boblarimer.com. A true renaissance man, Bob was a horticulturist and a voracious reader, devouring books on politics and history. In Watermill, his favorite pastime was reading on his deck overlooking the lake and enjoying beautiful sunsets. In New York, his favorite pastime was composing music and playing his grand piano for hours on end. On Tuesday nights, he loved playing poker with his cronies. When he was younger he loved tennis. When they were hitting, he loved the Yankees. But most of all, he loved his wife and partner in life, Riki Kane Larimer. Their relationship spanned over five decades; they simply adored each other. In addition to his wife Riki, he leaves his son Neil (Kathy) daughter Cheryl (Jaime) granddaughters Heather, Vanessa and Gabriela; grandsons Alan and Robby, great-grandson Carter, brother-in-law Michael Kane of Los Angeles and his adorable puppy Miki who will miss snuggling up with him under the covers every night. Bob lived his life to the fullest and died with his boots on. Services to be held Monday August 18 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 1076 Madison Ave at 11:30am. The family will be receiving friends at home in New York Monday after 6pm.

KUST--Henrietta Logan, Died in New York City, August 11, 2014, age 94. Wife of the late Leonard E. Kust. Born May 6, 1920 in Pittsburgh, PA. Graduated University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill 1941. Served in the Women's Army Corps 1943-45. Worked in New York at Time Inc. as Research Librarian for National Affairs 1946-51. Survived by her daughters, Alice K. Harding of Crofton, MD and Andrea L. Kust of New York City; sons-in-law David S. Harding and Stephen E. Shapiro; granddaughter Jennifer L. Harding; sisters Alice Logan of Chapel Hill, NC and Georgia Henderson of Lexington, KY. Donations in her memory may be made to the Church of the Heavenly Rest, New York City.

KLEIN--Charles "Chuck", May 1, 1925-August 2, 2014 Born and raised in Newark, NJ. Graduated from NYU. He was a long time resident of New York, where he was a much admired and respected sales rep. for several national toy companies until his retirement at the age of 75. He passed away peacefully at Woodland Care Center in Reseda, CA from complications of Alzheimer's. He is survived by his devoted wife of 61 years Phyllis Cooper Klein, loving daughters Lyn Klein, Ann Klein Fraser, and Nina Klein Troha, son-in-law Frank Troha, beloved grandchildren Dana and Dean Fraser, and sister Anita Straussberg. He was a sweet and generous man with a well appreciated sense of humor and will be sorely missed by many people who dearly loved him. A private memorial ceremony will be held by the family on Saturday, September 6, 2014. In lieu of flowers, any donation to the Alzheimer's Association will be appreciated.
KEATING--Charles. Dear friend for fifty years. Extraordinary actor, bawdy storyteller, tuneful balladeer, handsome gracious gentleman. We loved him dearly and will miss him forever. Maggie and Don

KAFFE-ROSENBERG, Dr. Sara. It is with great sadness that the family of Dr. Sara Kaffe-Rosenberg announces her passing at age 75, on August 12, in New York City. A child survivor of the Holocaust, she went on to become one of a small group of women admitted to her medical school class in Jerusalem, a dedicated pediatrician and geneticist, and a loving and devoted mother to her children, Yuval and Anat Rosenberg. Sara was until the end a woman of fierce intellect, sharp wit and boundless love for her family. She is survived by her children; her former husband, Dr. Vladimiro Rosenberg; her brother, Israel Kaffe; and her two recently born grandchildren, Leo and Ella. Funeral services will be in Israel, and a memorial service will be held in New York in November. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association and to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

HOWSE--Gary. It is with overwhelming sadness and a deep sense of loss that we announce the passing of Gary Alan Howse on August 3, in New York City. Gary was the beloved newlywed of Philip Pares, a trusted business partner to Manuel Benevich, son to George and Helen Howse, brother to Larry, Julie and Dave, an uncle, mentor and friend. Gary's inspiration and passion was shared with thousands of people over the arc of his life. As a philanthropic leader in his community and the professional beauty industry, Gary personally poured his time, energy and love into causes such as Lifelong AIDS Alliance and the Puget Soundkeeper Alliance. Gary co-founded Gary Manuel Salon with Manuel Benevich. Together they sought to elevate the expectation of the salon experience from technical skills to guest service. When asked what Gary meant to his team, Manuel Benevich stated, "He was light in our sky and the shoes on our feet." Gary is survived by his husband Philip, brother Dave, sister Julie, nephews Cooper, Travis, and Matthew, nieces Melissa, Bailey and Morgan, great-niece Brooklyn, countless salon clients and a beloved team.Memorial contributions may be made to Lifelong AIDS Alliance, Puget Soundkeeper Alliance and Metropolitan Community Church of New York.

HOROWITZ--Floyd. The entire Antioch College community sends its most heartfelt condolences to our esteemed alumna and chair of the Antioch College Board of Trustees Frances Degen Horowitz over the loss of her beloved husband and life partner Floyd Horowitz. Floyd was a renowned scholar, talented writer, inspiring academic and devoted civil rights advocate. May his memory be for a blessing.

HART--William James Jr.,of Redding, CT and formerly of Westport, CT died on July 29, 2014. Beloved husband of Barbara Hart. Loving father of William J. Hart III, Elizabeth Menikheim, Angela Katherine Hart, Margaret Hart and Mary Ellen Hart Campbell. Two Step Daughters; Priscilla Hancock and Pamela Kinsey. Eleven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Donations may be made to the Food Science Dept. at the University of Massachusetts.

GROSSMAN--Fred, former editor of the Daily Racing Form, beloved husband of Arlene (Gurshman), father of Paula Joffe and Ellen Lieber, grandfather of four, sister Eileen Yasgur, passed away on July 6, 2014. He was 86. Loving, caring, intelligent, one-of-a-kind. He will be terribly missed.

GOLFINOS--Andromache Giannakou. Deeply cherished wife, mother and grandmother, passed away peacefully in her home in Manhattan on August 8, 2014 at the age of 84. A devoted wife of 60 years to her late husband, Dr. Argyrios John Golfinos, she is survived by three loving children, all Princetonians, Terina A. Golfinos (husband Robert Lisi), Dr. Anastasia G. Daifotis (husband Christopher) and Dr. John G. Golfinos (wife Stephanie), and six adored grandchildren (Alexander, Helen and Christine Daifotis and Jason, Chloe and Phoebe Golfinos), three of whom have also matriculated at Princeton. Born in Ioannina, Greece in 1929, she emigrated to the United States in 1955 to pursue an advanced degree at Teachers College, Columbia University. Known affectionately as "Mrs. G," she touched countless lives, young and old, with her genuine warmth, insightful mind and zest for life. From her favorite local hot dog vendor to Queen Frederika of Greece, for whom she sang as a young student, she made every person whose path she crossed feel as if they were the center of her universe. She will be remembered as a voracious reader, a marathon walker, a puzzle-a-day solver and an intrepid beachcomber, but, most of all, as a passionate advocate for each child's right to be healthy, happy and strong. She will remain an inspiration to her family and friends as the personification of grace under pressure and of pure unconditional love. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Making Headway Foundation at www.makingheadway.org.

GIMMA--Licia. The Licia Albanese-Puccini Foundation Officers and Board of Directors pay tribute to the legendary Diva Licia Albanese who was an exceptional and gifted human being admired and respected for her energy and commitment to others, especially for her devotion to young artists. Her achievements on and off stage were remarkable. No one who heard Licia sing will ever forget her. Many others who never met her, but felt they knew her, will remember her. She will be sadly missed and has a place in our hearts forever. Sachi Liebergesell, President Stephen De Maio, Artistic Director Licia Albanese-Puccini Foundation

GIMMA--Licia Albanese. We mourn the death of our beloved Licia who thrilled opera lovers throughout the world with her fiery interpretations. She was a great artist and mentor to so many young aspiring opera singers. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her son Joseph and his wife Maria. With the help of Cleo, they saw that Licia received all the tender loving care she needed. No mother could have wanted for more. Robert J. Campbell MD Cesare L. Santeramo

GIMMA--Licia Albanese. I've lost my dearest friend. For many years we ate and we laughed as we travelled the world together. Truly our friendship was blessed by the Gods. I will love you forever. My darling Licia, Rest In Peace. Evelyn Kupin
FRIEDMAN--Alva. The Koch family mourns the loss of our Auntie Alva. No friend ever added more fun and laughter to our lives. It's comforting to know you will be keeping the whole gang smiling!

FRANK--Claire W. With great sadness and love, the family of Claire W. Frank announces her passing away peacefully in her home on August 15, 2014. Predeceased by her cherished husband of more than fifty years, Tom, and by her treasured son Tommy. She was adored for her love of life, her unwavering optimism and her unbounded generosity. With these extraordinary qualities, she lit our lives and inspired us. Her daughters, Mary Frank and Kathryn Frank; her son-in-law, Jim Blume; her grandchildren, Marisa Frank and Zach Blume; and her great grandchildren, Cooper and Jack Conkling; and the many dear friends and relatives whose lives she touched will miss her beyond words. We will hold her in our hearts forever. The family would like to thank all the wonderful people who so devotedly have cared for and helped our beloved Nana across long years. Contributions can be made in Claire W. Frank's memory to New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Weill-Cornell Division of Geriatrics and Palliative Medicine, at 525 E. 68th St., Box 123, New York, NY 10065 in honor of Dr. Ronald Adelman. A memorial gathering will take place at a future date to be announced.

FIGUR--Arthur. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital deeply mourns the passing of our long-standing and devoted friend, mentor and colleague. Dr. Figur came to Mount Sinai in 1955, training generations of students and residents in Hematology and in the Art and Science of Medicine. He served as AAS President from 1983-1984 and remained on the Board of Directors, playing an active role in constant support of the Mount Sinai physicians. In 1996, he received the prestigious Jacobi Medallion for his outstanding contributions to the institution. An avid cyclist, swimmer and steadfast champion of health and physical fitness, he traveled the world in pursuit of greater athletic and cultural endeavors. We salute his loyalty and legacy, and extend our sincere condolences to his family and many friends. Eric Neibart, MD, President Mark Reiner, MD, 1st Vice President Louis DePalo, MD, 2nd Vice President Harold Bronheim, MD, Secretary/Treasurer Amy Weinstein, Administrator

DEANS--Robert Barr, Jr. passed away peacefully on August 13th, 2014 at Glen Cove Hospital. Bob was born on April 9, 1925 in Buffalo, New York. He was the son of Robert B. Deans ("Sheriff") and Lucy Bemis Pomeroy Deans. His younger sister, Lucy Pomeroy Deans Hanes predeceased him in 1977. He grew up in New York City and Aiken, South Carolina and attended The Buckley School in New York and Aiken Preparatory School in South Carolina. In 1939, he entered St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire as a member of the Third Form and he graduated in 1943. Following his graduation from St. Paul's, he enlisted in the United States Navy V-12 officer training program in Rochester, New York and served on the west coast until the end of World War II. At the conclusion of the war, he enrolled at Yale University under the G.I. Bill and graduated in 1947 with a degree in economics. After his graduation from Yale, Bob worked for New York Trust Company, Fiduciary Counsel, and Lehman Brothers until 1951 when he enlisted in the United States Marine Corps. In 1952, he married Elisabeth DeBoeck Prickett in Wilmington, Delaware and started working for Chase National Bank. Bob and Elise spent several years in Vienna, Zurich, and Beirut where Bob was on loan to various foreign banks while working for Chase. They traveled extensively, had many extraordinary experiences, and made many long-standing friends. During this time, Bob and Elise were accompanied in their travels by their oldest daughter, Mary, and their two sons who were born abroad (Rob in Zurich in 1954 and Gil in Beirut in 1956). Bob and Elise returned to New York in 1957 and took up residence in Mill Neck on Long Island at "Turbillon" where he lived until his death. Upon returning to New York in 1957, Bob joined Van Strum & Towne and, while working there between 1957 and 1967, he earned an M.B.A. from New York University and had two more children (Nick in 1957, Elisabeth in 1960). In 1967, Bob and several close friends and colleagues founded Inverness Counsel. He worked there as Chairman/CEO until, in 2011, he assumed the role of Chairman Emeritus. Even in his role as Chairman Emeritus, Bob never stopped actively consulting with his fellow partners and advising his long-time contacts. His memberships included The Racquet and Tennis Club, The Creek, Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club, the Boone and Crockett Club and, for a short time, the Colony Club. In 1963, Bob and his long-time neighbors and friends William T. Dunn, Jr. and Leonard L. Marshall, Jr. founded the North Shore Wildlife Sanctuary in Mill Neck and he served on the Executive Committee until his death. His first wife, Elise, pre-deceased him in 2001 and Bob was fortunate to spend his final years with his second wife, Shirley Blakeley of Livingston, Montana, whom he married in 2008. Bob is survived by his five children Mary L. C. Flood, Robert Barr Deans III (Janet), William Prickett Deans (Wendy), Nicholas Wyeth Deans (Barbara), and Elisabeth Suzanne DeBoeck Mooney. He is also survived by his grandchildren Caroline Whitney Deans and Robert Barr Deans IV (children of Rob and Janet), Katharine Hale Mooney (daughter of Elisabeth), and Jeremy Luke Frazier (step-son of Nicholas). He is also survived by an enormous extended family of friends and relatives with whom he interacted actively throughout his life. A private interment will be held at Valley Forge Memorial Chapel. A memorial service is scheduled for October 10, 2014 at 11:00am at Christ Church in Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers, Bob has requested that donations be made to North Shore Wildlife Sanctuary (P.O. Box 214, Mill Neck, NY 11765).

CORT-VAN ARSDALE--Diana, Died August 16, 2014, age 79. Loving mother of Hayley Cort, M.D. and Daniel G. Cort, on whom she shone, and who gave her infinite joy. Mother-in-law of Julia Cort, her much loved daughter-in-law. Proud grandmother of Amanda Cort, Meredith Cort and Genevieve CortGrasso. She knew they would grow up to be outstanding women. Sister of Phyllis Newman, her best friend, with whom she wrote the book Transitions A Woman's Guide to Successful Retirement. They knew how to laugh together. She was a therapist who touched numerous people in her professional and personal life. Memorial service at 3:00pm on Tuesday, August 19, 2014, Riverside Memorial Chapel, NY, NY.

COHEN--Arthur G. It is with overwhelming sadness that the family of Arthur G. Cohen announces his sudden and untimely passing on August 9th at the age of 84 in Kings Point, New York, his home for decades with the love of his life, Karen Bassine Cohen. Arthur and Karen recently celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary, a joyous occasion shared with their devoted daughters, Lauren, Susan, Debra, Rochelle and Kathy, nine wonderful grandchildren Allison, Hanni, Caroline, Jennifer, Charlie, Kate, William, Emily and Henry - who made him proud and brought him much joy, sons-in-law Jeffrey, Mark and Jeigh, grandson-in-law Matthew and other members of his extended family, who survive him and, with Karen, will miss the wisdom, boundless energy, generosity and love of their family patriarch. Arthur is also survived by his sister, Marilyn Davimos; his brother, Richard M. Cohen, predeceased him. For more than 50 years Arthur enjoyed an illustrious career as a builder, developer, investor, owner and manager of real estate throughout the United States and abroad, having earned a legendary reputation as a pioneer in revitalizing Times Square through his ownership interest in the iconic, landmarked Paramount Building at 1501 Broadway and his development of the 1500 Broadway office tower and the Crowne Plaza, Paramount and Michelangelo hotels. His foresight in recognizing the potential of the far west side of midtown Manhattan produced the Westyard office-warehouse facility at 450 West 33rd Street, around which an entire new community is now burgeoning, the Worldwide Plaza mixed-use complex at Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets on the site of the former Madison Square Garden and 888 Seventh Avenue, across from Carnegie Hall. Arthur's innovative ideas produced many other distinctive, high-profile projects such as the Peninsula Hotel and Olympic Tower in New York City and Aventura in North Miami, Florida. Though Arthur preferred to maintain a low profile, he often partnered with many of the most active and renowned developers, property managers and financial investors of the last 50 years and today, who consider him a trailblazer in creating new ways of structuring and financing real estate transactions. Born in Brooklyn, New York to Frances and L.D. Cohen, Arthur graduated from the University of Miami and New York Law School. Though he became an attorney admitted to the New York Bar and remained so for more than 50 years, he entered the real estate field in a small way shortly after completing law school, but moved rapidly to developing department store properties and retail centers and, in 1971 at the age of 40, to creating Arlen Realty & Development, then the nation's largest publicly-held real estate enterprise, with a vast portfolio of office buildings, hotels, single- and multi-family residential buildings and more than 250 shopping centers worldwide, as well as the E. J. Korvette department store chain. Always available to share his expertise and numerous real estate industry and financial market connections with both his contemporaries and the next generation of real estate and other business entrepreneurs, Arthur never ceased to enjoy the constant flow of potential worldwide projects brought to him by admirers of his "laser beam" analytical skills and remarkable physical stamina, which he also exhibited in his "scratch" golf game frequently on display at Old Westbury's Glen Oaks Country Club and the Palm Beach Country Club. But no diversion from his intense work ethic gave Arthur greater pleasure than sailing with his family on Long Island Sound in his cherished vintage sailboat "Les Girls", named to honor his wife and five daughters. In addition to Arthur's business and recreational pursuits, he was involved in numerous educational, professional and philanthropic activities, including guest lectureships at the Harvard Business School and the Wharton School of Business, directorships of Citicorp and the Home Title Division of Chicago Title Insurance Company and a trusteeship of the John Hancock Mutual Fund. His public service internationally included membership on the Special Mission to Israel under Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir and as Special Envoy to aid underprivileged nations under President Lyndon B. Johnson. Often recognized by his real estate industry peers and the broader business community, among his honors are having been named Man of the Year by the Anti-Defamation League and the City of Hope and having received the Tree of Life Award from the Jewish National Fund and an honorary degree from Long Island University. His memberships on Boards of Trustees have included Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, Brandeis University (Emeritus), New York Law School and Albert Einstein College of Medicine. The family requests that their wishes for a private funeral service and interment be respected. Donations may be made in memory of Arthur to the Anti-Defamation League, which he previously served as President.

CHENEY--Kathleen Sprowl, died on August 10, 2014. The Trustees and staff of Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute, Inc., (FAMRI), express our deepest sorrow to the family of FAMRI Trustee Kathleen Sprowl Cheney on her death. A former Eastern Airlines Flight Attendant from 1968 to 1988, she committed her life to make the world a safer place. Kathie was born in Miami, FL and was a resident of Peachtree City, GA, for more than 20 years until her death. She is survived by her beloved husband, Kevin; her loving son, Patrick; her devoted step-son Tom Cheney; caring sisters, Patricia Pallon, Joann Anthony, Mary Mosley and Denise Bamonte and their husbands, as well as numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. Many enjoyed the pleasure of Kathie's company and are inspired by her enthusiasm. Her generosity, dedication and friendship will be sorely missed.

CARROLL--Tom. August 30, 1941 - August 12, 2014. Tom Carroll was a graduate of the University of Notre Dame and a former officer in the United States Navy. In his early career, he became a CPA and rose to partnership in the firm of KPMG. The next step in his career was as a senior managing partner at Credit Suisse, Bankers Trust and finally at Prudential Financial where he was a senior Vice-President. At Prudential, he was a respected figure in the executive branch. He was acknowledged for his leadership in diversity, and his recognition and incorporation of all branches of military service personnel. As a member of both the New York Yacht Club and the Larchmont Yacht Club, he pursued his passion for sailing with great success and reward as captain of "Siren Song." He ran nine New York Marathons coming once under four hours. He established the Patrick and Mary Carroll scholarship fund at the University of Notre Dame and served on the board of the William Holden Wildlife Foundation. He is survived by his son Tom Carroll Jr., daughter Cathy Locabucci, three grandchildren and his partner of fourteen years Stefanie Powers. Services will be held on Wednesday, August 20, 2014 at 11:00am a the Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel on the corner of E. 81st and Madison. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Patrick and Mary Carroll scholarship fund and the William Holden Wildlife Foundation are appreciated.

BROCK--Jill Schulman, 53, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of New York, passed away August 10th after a valiantly fought battle with Cystic Fibrosis. She was a beloved wife to George; loving and devoted mother to Erin Lesser and Kayla; adored mother-in-law to Matt. She was cherished "Mimi" to her granddaughter Riley. Jill leaves behind her parents, Natalie and Burton Schulman of Palm Beach Gardens; father-in-law Richard Brock; sisters Donna Schwartz (Robert) and Mindy Gorman-Plutzer (Edward) sister-in-law, Joanne Romano (Frank), six nieces and three great-nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her mother-in-law, Millie Brock. She was a cherished friend to many. Jill lived her life with grace and dignity, loyalty and compassion, and had the most enormous capacity for love. She will forever be an inspiration to all who were privileged to know her.

BACALL--Lauren. The American Academy of Dramatic Arts mourns the loss and celebrates the life of its revered alumna Lauren Bacall, a former recipient of Its Alumni Achievement Award, who gave so generously of her time to the Academy. In 2009, she pulled the switch to light up the Empire State Building in honor of its 125th Anniversary. On behalf of the Academy community, we extend our heartfelt condolences to her sons Sam Robards (Academy Trustee) and Stephen H. Bogart, her daughter Leslie Bogart Shiffmann and to all the members of her family. Michael Gardner Chairman, Board of Trustees

ARCEL--Stephanie, of New York, on August 8, 2014. Predeceased by her husband, and love of her life, legendary boxing trainer Ray Arcel and his daughter and son-in-law Adele and Clement Bloch. Survived by granddaughters Jill Bloch and Susan Bloch Molloy and her dear friends. Services were private.

ADAMS--Roy M.,age 74, died on August 11, 2014. Roy was a respected and admired writer, advisor and speaker in the areas of estate planning, trusts, public charities and family foundations. Over a lengthy career, he served as senior partner in the law firms of Sonnenschein Nath & Rosenthal, Schiff Hardin & Waite and Kirkland & Ellis. Roy taught for over 25 years at Northwestern University School of Law, where he was a Professor Emeritus of Estate Planning and Taxation. A member of ACTEC, Roy also authored numerous articles and books on estate planning and advising the wealthy, including "Wit and Wisdom The Best of Roy Adams." A caring friend to both people and animals, Roy is survived by his sons, Daniel Adams and Oscar Castro Adams, and by a half-brother, Glen Adams. Funeral services will be private.

YATES--Douglas T.,of New York City, on August 16, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Titus Yates, devoted father of Douglas T. Yates, Jr. (Mary Caryl) of New Haven, CT, Timothy T. Yates (Kay) of Rye, NY, and L. Randall Yates (the late Hope Lloyd) and Margaret Yates Thorne (Nate), of New York City. Adored grandfather of Nate and Nicholas Thorne, and Hope Starr, Lawrence Jr., Tim (Alexis), Chris (Angela), Ted, Katie, Doug (Kerri), Brian (Marci) and Scott (Mackenzie) Yates. Loving great-grandfather of Max, Charlie, Campbell, Jade, Summer, Dougie, Eddie, Gaby, Oscar and Lydia Yates. Doug was a graduate of Culver Military Academy and Williams College. He served his Country during World War II as a Major in the US Army Signal Corps, then was employed as the Executive Vice-President and Director of Republic Pictures Corp., Chairman of Seaboard Associates Inc., Partner at White, Weld and Co., and Vice-President at Merrill Lynch. Doug was a Trustee of The Buckley School, and was a Trustee and Founder of The Episcopal School in New York City. He also served as a member of the Vestry of St. James Church and the International Center for the Disabled, was a Trustee of the Hospital Chaplaincy and The General Theological Seminary, and was Chairman of the Board of Foreign Parishes of The Episcopal Church. He was a long-time Trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital, and was Chairman of The United Hospital Fund and Vice-Chairman of The Greater New York Fund of United Way. Doug was a Knight Hospitaller of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, and was proud to have received The United Hospital Distinguished Director Award for 28 years of Distinguished Service to Hospitals and the United Hospital Distinguished Trustee Award for Extraordinary Service to Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, NYC, Southward Ho C.C., Bay Shore, NY, and Gasparilla Inn Golf Club, Boca Grande, FL. A Memorial Service at St. James Church will be held at 11:00am on September 12, 2014. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street or The Episcopal School in New York City, 35 East 69th Street. Internment will be private.

SUNDELL--Nina Castelli. We mourn the death of our dear friend Nina Castelli Sundell. We will miss her sorely, but will remember with joy the excitement of experiencing new works of art together and the many extraordinary conversations filled with laughter. Wickedly witty and endlessly curious, Nina was voracious in her literary readings, and in her ability to absorb vast amounts of information about the arts in general, and contemporary art in particular. To look at art of any era with her always brought forth new and unexpected insights. We were privileged to join Nina in supporting and starting projects like Independent Curators International(ICI). And the many wonderful and enlightening journeys abroad with her will never be forgotten. In our sadness and loss, we offer condolences to Nina's three children and extended family. Agnes Gund and Susan Sollins

HASSENFELD--Sylvia. The Officers, Board, and global staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn with profound sadness the passing of Sylvia Hassenfeld, a world renowned Jewish leader. As the first woman President of JDC, Sylvia led the organization -- with vision, wisdom, and foresight -- through one of its historic periods. As communism fell in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, she oversaw the creation of JDC's vast services for the Jews of these regions, ensuring life-saving care for the poor and elderly and building a legacy of vibrant Jewish community life throughout the world. It was also during Sylvia's tenure, and through her skillful diplomacy and leadership, that thousands of Ethiopian Jews were brought to Israel to which Sylvia had an unwavering life-long commitment. This passion and enthusiasm for doing good extended into her extraordinary work on behalf of children and countless other causes to which she dedicated herself. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sylvia's daughter and JDC Board member, Ellen Block; her son, Alan Hassenfeld; and to their entire family. May Sylvia's memory be for a blessing and may we all be inspired by the unparalleled example she set. Penny Blumenstein President Dr. Irving A. Smokler Chairman of the Board Alan H. Gill Chief Executive Officer

HASSENFELD--Sylvia G.,The trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing Sylvia G. Hassenfeld, a dear friend and longstanding member of NYU Langone's Board of Trustees. A champion of children's causes, Mrs. Hassenfeld established the Stephen D. Hassenfeld Children's Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders at NYU Langone in 1990 and was a driving force in the development of our dedicated children's hospital, the Hassenfeld Children's Hospital, which is slated to open in 2017. With deep gratitude to our beloved trustee Sylvia for her extraordinary gift and vision, we will begin a new era of pediatric healthcare in New York and help ensure bright, healthy futures for generations of children. The Hassenfelds' devotion to children, particularly the most vulnerable, is a family tradition that stems from their business, Hasbro, Inc. In an early sign of the family's interest in children's healthcare, doctor and nurse kits were among the first toys Hasbro made. Mrs. Hassenfeld also served on the board of the Hasbro Children's Foundation, the company's generous philanthropic arm that was known for giving worldwide. We extend our deepest condolences to her children, Alan Hassenfeld and Ellen Hassenfeld Block; her grandchildren, Laurie Block, Michael Block and Susan Block Casdin, her great grandchildren, Kinsey and Blaisdell Casdin, and to all the members of the Hassenfeld family. Kenneth G. Langone, Chair, Board of Trustees, and Robert I. Grossman, MD, Dean and CEO

HASSENFELD--Sylvia K. (Kay), 93, international leader, human rights activist, and philanthropist, died August 15, 2014. She was the wife of the late Merrill L. Hassenfeld. Born in Pennsylvania, the daughter of Joseph and Sophie (Flieglman) Kay, she was a resident of Palm Beach, Florida. Mrs. Hassenfeld has been described as "one of the most significant leaders in the American Jewish community of the twentieth century." In her over 50 years of national and international humanitarian leadership, she served as the first woman president of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC). As president of the JDC, Mrs. Hassenfeld initiated the International Development Program (IDP), which provides non-sectarian aid in times of crisis. Begun in response to the needs engendered by the Armenian earthquake, the IDP continues to provide vital emergency aid throughout the world. Also during her tenure as president, she oversaw JDC's return to the former Soviet Union; the rescue of Jews and Muslims from Sarajevo, and Operation Solomon, which rescued over 14,000 Ethiopian Jews via airlift in just 36 hours. At the time of her death, Mrs. Hassenfeld was the President of the Hassenfeld Foundation, a trustee of the NYU Langone Medical Center (NYULMC), a member of the Executive Committee of the Board of the Israel Museum, a Director of the Society of the Four Arts in Palm Beach and a Board Member of Hospice of Palm Beach. A champion of children's causes, Mrs. Hassenfeld served on the Board of the Hasbro Children's Foundation and was instrumental in establishing the Stephen D. Hassenfeld Children's Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders at NYULMC. She was the driving force behind the current development of a dedicated children's hospital at NYULMC; the Hassenfeld Children's Hospital is slated to open in 2017. In addition, Mrs. Hassenfeld served as National Chair of the Women's Division of the United Jewish Appeal and Vice-Chair of the Jerusalem Foundation, as well as a number of other leadership roles at national and international Jewish organizations, including the Board of the United Israel Appeal and the Board of Governors of the Jewish Agency. Board Member Emeritus of Hasbro, Inc., Mrs. Hassenfeld served as a Director on the company's board for over 20 years. As a leader in academia, she served as Vice Chair of the Board at Brandeis University and on the Advisory Committee of the Hopkins-Nanjing Center, a program jointly administered by Johns Hopkins University and Nanjing University in Nanjing, China. She received an Honorary Doctorate in Humane Letters from Brandeis University in 1998. Mrs. Hassenfeld has been recognized internationally by numerous educational, cultural, and civic organizations for her diplomatic skills and her role in protecting human rights, promoting religious freedom, influencing social policy and assuring services to children in need. Among her many honors and awards, she was made an Honorary Citizen of Jerusalem in recognition for her life-long efforts on behalf of Jerusalem and its citizens. She was also made a presidential appointee to the United States Holocaust Memorial Council under three different presidents, awarded the Emma Lazarus Statue of Liberty Award by the American Jewish Historical Society for "contributions to improving the human condition," and honored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Mrs. Hassenfeld is survived by her two children, Alan Hassenfeld and Ellen Hassenfeld Block; three grandchildren, Laurie Block, Michael Block, and Susan Block Casdin; two great-grandchildren. Kinsey and Blaisdell Casdin; and Vivien Hassenfeld (wife of Alan) and Alexander Casdin (husband of Susan). She was predeceased by her husband, Merrill Hassenfeld and her son Stephen D. Hassenfeld. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 19th at 1:00pm at Temple Beth El, 70 Orchard Ave., Providence, with burial in Lincoln Park Cemetery, Warwick, Rhode Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Hassenfeld Children's Hospital at NYULMC, One Park Ave., 17th Floor, New York, New York 10016, Attn: Grace Ko. Shiva will be observed at the home of Alan and Vivien Hassenfeld on Tuesday and Wednesday, August 19th and 20th from 7-9pm. Shiva will also be observed at the home of Susan and Alexander Casdin, 131 East 66th St, New York City on Thursday, August 21st from 6-9pm and Friday, August 22nd from 11am to 2pm. For further information and condolences, please see www.Sugarman-Sinai.com.

DEANS--Robert Barr, Jr. passed away peacefully on August 13th, 2014 at Glen Cove Hospital. Bob was born on April 9, 1925 in Buffalo, New York. He was the son of Robert B. Deans ("Sheriff") and Lucy Bemis Pomeroy Deans. His younger sister, Lucy Pomeroy Deans Hanes predeceased him in 1977. He grew up in New York City and Aiken, South Carolina and attended The Buckley School in New York and Aiken Preparatory School in South Carolina. In 1939, he entered St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire as a member of the Third Form and he graduated in 1943. Following his graduation from St. Paul's, he enlisted in the United States Navy V-12 officer training program in Rochester, New York and served on the west coast until the end of World War II. At the conclusion of the war, he enrolled at Yale University under the G.I. Bill and graduated in 1947 with a degree in economics. After his graduation from Yale, Bob worked for New York Trust Company, Fiduciary Counsel, and Lehman Brothers until 1951 when he enlisted in the United States Marine Corps. In 1952, he married Elisabeth DeBoeck Prickett in Wilmington, Delaware and started working for Chase National Bank. Bob and Elise spent several years in Vienna, Zurich, and Beirut where Bob was on loan to various foreign banks while working for Chase. They traveled extensively, had many extraordinary experiences, and made many long-standing friends. During this time, Bob and Elise were accompanied in their travels by their oldest daughter, Mary, and their two sons who were born abroad (Rob in Zurich in 1954 and Gil in Beirut in 1956). Bob and Elise returned to New York in 1957 and took up residence in Mill Neck on Long Island at "Turbillon" where he lived until his death. Upon returning to New York in 1957, Bob joined Van Strum & Towne and, while working there between 1957 and 1967, he earned an M.B.A. from New York University and had two more children (Nick in 1957, Elisabeth in 1960). In 1967, Bob and several close friends and colleagues founded Inverness Counsel. He worked there as Chairman/CEO until, in 2011, he assumed the role of Chairman Emeritus. Even in his role as Chairman Emeritus, Bob never stopped actively consulting with his fellow partners and advising his long-time contacts. His memberships included The Racquet and Tennis Club, The Creek, Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club, the Boone and Crockett Club and, for a short time, the Colony Club. In 1963, Bob and his long-time neighbors and friends William T. Dunn, Jr. and Leonard L. Marshall, Jr. founded the North Shore Wildlife Sanctuary in Mill Neck and he served on the Executive Committee until his death. His first wife, Elise, pre-deceased him in 2001 and Bob was fortunate to spend his final years with his second wife, Shirley Blakeley of Livingston, Montana, whom he married in 2008. Bob is survived by his five children Mary L. C. Flood, Robert Barr Deans III (Janet), William Prickett Deans (Wendy), Nicholas Wyeth Deans (Barbara), and Elisabeth Suzanne DeBoeck Mooney. He is also survived by his grandchildren Caroline Whitney Deans and Robert Barr Deans IV (children of Rob and Janet), Katharine Hale Mooney (daughter of Elisabeth), and Jeremy Luke Frazier (step-son of Nicholas). He is also survived by an enormous extended family of friends and relatives with whom he interacted actively throughout his life. A private interment will be held at Valley Forge Memorial Chapel. A memorial service is scheduled for October 10, 2014 at 11:00am at Christ Church in Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers, Bob has requested that donations be made to North Shore Wildlife Sanctuary (P.O. Box 214, Mill Neck, NY 11765).

COSTELLO--RAdm John D. The officers and employees of McAllister Towing record with sorrow the passing of Rear Admiral (Ret) John D. Costello, on Friday, April 15, 2014. His distinguished lifetime career with the United States Coast Guard was highlighted by outstanding service on Yerba Buena Island, San Francisco, CA; Governor's Island, New York, NY; and the Coast Guard Foundation in Washington DC. Following his retirement from active duty Admiral Costello was a founder and the first CEO of MRSC (Marine Spill Response Corp.), a consortium of oil companies and workboat professionals dedicated to the quick deployment of trained responders to the sites of shipping disasters for the purpose of preventing oil pollution and protecting the environment. We express our condolences to his family.

Sister of Phyllis Newman, her best friend, with whom she wrote the book Transitions A Woman's Guide to Successful Retirement. They knew how to laugh together. She was a therapist who touched numerous people in her professional and personal life. Memorial service at 3:00pm on Tuesday, August 19, 2014, Riverside Memorial Chapel, NY, NY.

Part 14: Malala explains the biggest difference between Pakistan and Britain, where she lives now; and talks about the biggest discovery she made when she left Swat Valley.
Part 12: Malala explains the single message that she hopes people will take away from her story and her example.
Part 13: Malala reveals her favorite TV show and her favorite mobile apps, and talks about what American students can do to support education around the world.
Part 11: Malala explains what people don’t understand about Islam, and reflects on her impressions of the many world leaders she’s met.
Part 8: Malala explains what she thinks the first step should be to change the culture of education in Pakistan.
Part 7: Malala talks about her mother’s struggle with not knowing English, and describes how her mother’s newfound literacy has changed their family.
Part 6: Malala explains why the obstacles to girls’ education goes way beyond the personal attitudes of individuals, and describes the role she thinks Islam can play in promoting education.
Part 10: Malala reveals what she said to President Obama during their meeting at the White House, and explains how she thinks the United States could be doing a better job defeating terrorism.

Part 2: The education activist talks about the New York Times documentary that made her famous and explains why the situation in Swat Valley should give people hope.

YOUNG--Stuart B. The Board of Directors of Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design Jerusalem extends its heartfelt condolences to Toni and the entire Young family on the passing of Stuart, our beloved board member and esteemed friend.

YATES--Douglas T.,of New York City, on August 16, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Titus Yates, devoted father of Douglas T. Yates, Jr. (Mary Caryl) of New Haven, CT, Timothy T. Yates (Kay) of Rye, NY, and L. Randall Yates (the late Hope Lloyd) and Margaret Yates Thorne (Nate), of New York City. Adored grandfather of Nate and Nicholas Thorne, and Hope Starr, Lawrence Jr., Tim (Alexis), Chris (Angela), Ted, Katie, Doug (Kerri), Brian (Marci) and Scott (Mackenzie) Yates. Loving great-grandfather of Max, Charlie, Campbell, Jade, Summer, Dougie, Eddie, Gaby, Oscar and Lydia Yates. Doug was a graduate of Culver Military Academy and Williams College. He served his Country during World War II as a Major in the US Army Signal Corps, then was employed as the Executive Vice-President and Director of Republic Pictures Corp., Chairman of Seaboard Associates Inc., Partner at White, Weld and Co., and Vice-President at Merrill Lynch. Doug was a Trustee of The Buckley School, and was a Trustee and Founder of The Episcopal School in New York City. He also served as a member of the Vestry of St. James Church and the International Center for the Disabled, was a Trustee of the Hospital Chaplaincy and The General Theological Seminary, and was Chairman of the Board of Foreign Parishes of The Episcopal Church. He was a long-time Trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital, and was Chairman of The United Hospital Fund and Vice-Chairman of The Greater New York Fund of United Way. Doug was a Knight Hospitaller of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, and was proud to have received The United Hospital Distinguished Director Award for 28 years of Distinguished Service to Hospitals and the United Hospital Distinguished Trustee Award for Extraordinary Service to Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, NYC, Southward Ho C.C., Bay Shore, NY, and Gasparilla Inn Golf Club, Boca Grande, FL. A Memorial Service at St. James Church will be held at 11:00am on September 12, 2014. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street or The Episcopal School in New York City, 35 East 69th Street. Internment will be private.

Her numerous early ICI exhibitions set the standard of excellence for which we continue to strive.

Unger Vetlesen Foundation are deeply saddened by the passing of George Rowe, Jr.; our dear and esteemed colleague who for many years served as Director and President of both Foundations. NEWMAN--John E.,Jr., 87, died August 10, Norwalk Hospital. A resident of New Canaan, formerly of New York City, he graduated from Newark Academy, Princeton University '50 and served in the U.S. Navy during WWII and Korean War. He spent many years on Wall Street. Born September 24, 1928, son of the late John E. and Mary Ingersoll Newman, survived by brother Charles I. of Essex Fells, NJ; sister Eleanor N. Caulkins of Denver, CO., step-son Alexander G. Smith of New York City, wife Peggy and grandchildren, Charlotte and Oliver, and step-daughter, Victoria Sartorius of Rye, NY. He was predeceased by brother Bruce E. Newman. He spent many happy summers in Quogue, LI and winter visits to Vero Beach, FL. He spent his last 10 years "doting on his grandchildren". In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to New Canaan Volunteer Ambulance Corps., 180 South Ave., New Canaan, CT 06840.

MROZ--John Edwin, The EastWest Institute (EWI) mourns the loss of John Edwin Mroz, its visionary founder and CEO. EWI is an influential international security nonprofit, which addresses the seemingly intractable problems that threaten world stability. With John's inspirational leadership and tremendous energy, EWI's work has spanned the Cold War, the Israel-Palestinian conflict, and relations between the U.S. and China. The entire EWI family extends their deepest sympathies to his wife, Karen Linehan Mroz and children, Jonathan, Jessica and Jeffrey. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be given in John's name to his beloved EastWest Institute www.ewi.info/donate. James L. Creighton, Chief Operating Officer The EastWest Institute

MROZ--John Edwin. Remarkable energy, vision and passion were the hallmarks of John Edwin Mroz, an individual whose formidable talents were dedicated to reducing international conflict and bringing together in rational discourse otherwise hostile adversaries. As dear friends and ardent admirers for over 30 years, we mourn the loss of a major figure of our time. We extend our sympathy to Karen, Jonathan, Jessica and Jeffrey and we hope they find strength and joy in the memory of this good man. Daniel and Joanna S. Rose

LIGHT--Barry. May 26, 1946 - August 12, 2014; President, Battery Park City Authority (1982-1983); President, New York School Construction Authority (1993-1995). Barry Light spent his career in housing and planning, developing better communities for New York. A celebration of his life will take place at his apartment on September 21, starting 2pm.

LEVANDER--Seymour S.,of New York passed away Saturday at age 90. He was a great husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Born in the Bronx of immigrant parents, he graduated first in his class from James Monroe High School and then earned an electrical engineering degree in 1944 from Cooper Union where he also taught in the early years of career. Sy, as he was known to his family, friends and business colleagues, enjoyed more than 60 successful years owning and running sales engineering businesses, selling pumps and motors in the construction field. His work included such iconic structures as the Seagrams Building, the original World Trade Center twin towers, and the new Freedom Tower at One World Trade Center. He retired at age 89. Throughout his life, Sy supported many charities and civic organizations, especially in the areas of Israel, education and poverty. He and his wife Ellenore, who predeceased him two years ago after 65 years of loving marriage, helped to found the Pelham Jewish Center. Most of all, he was devoted to his family and reveled in their successes. He is survived by his daughter, Vicki Luftman, a retired doctor in Longmeadow, Massachusetts whose husband, Dr. Richard Luftman prematurely deceased five years ago; and his son Andrew J. Levander of New York, the chairman of the Dechert law firm who is married to Carol Loewenson, FAIA, who is a member of Mitchell/Giurgola Architects and the president-elect of the AIA New York Chapter; and four grandsons: Adam Luftman, the principal trumpet of the San Francisco Opera and the San Francisco Ballet, his wife, Reva, a senior business accountant for the Gap, and their daughter Reily; Dr. David Luftman, a resident at Stonybrook Medical Center, and his wife Leah, a consultant to the US Government on health issues; Samuel Levander, a graduate of Columbia Law School and currently a law clerk to the Honorable Cheryl Krause, a United State Court of Appeals Judge sitting in Philadelphia; and Benjamin Levander, a 2014 graduate of Dartmouth College, who has been admitted to Yale Law School. Sy loved them all. Any donations in his honor should be made to: National Kidney Foundation - www.kidney.org Cooper Union - www.cooper.edu/giving/today American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science - www.weizmann-USA.org/get-involved/donate/
