HASSENFELD--Sylvia. I was fortunate to call her my friend. She was an extraordinary woman known for her grace and beauty. Her brilliant mind was matched only by her charitable heart. My deepest condolences to her family. Diane Belfer

HASSENFELD--Sylvia. The Officers, Board, and global staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn with profound sadness the passing of Sylvia Hassenfeld, a world renowned Jewish leader. As the first woman President of JDC, Sylvia led the organization -- with vision, wisdom, and foresight -- through one of its historic periods. As communism fell in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, she oversaw the creation of JDC's vast services for the Jews of these regions, ensuring life-saving care for the poor and elderly and building a legacy of vibrant Jewish community life throughout the world. It was also during Sylvia's tenure, and through her skillful diplomacy and leadership, that thousands of Ethiopian Jews were brought to Israel to which Sylvia had an unwavering life-long commitment. This passion and enthusiasm for doing good extended into her extraordinary work on behalf of children and countless other causes to which she dedicated herself. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sylvia's daughter and JDC Board member, Ellen Block; her son, Alan Hassenfeld; and to their entire family. May Sylvia's memory be for a blessing and may we all be inspired by the unparalleled example she set. Penny Blumenstein President Dr. Irving A. Smokler Chairman of the Board Alan H. Gill Chief Executive Officer
HASSENFELD--Sylvia. A woman of grace, vigor, commitment, and utmost loyalty. A friend without borders. Joy and Erving & Family

Hassenfeld--Sylvia We mourn the loss of our friend and philanthropist, Sylvia Hassenfeld. Sylvia was a fierce champion of Jewish causes, an advocate for children and a voice for marginalized communities everywhere. She led with courage, passion and determination. She will be missed by all those who loved her, whose lives she bettered and who will be inspired to carry on her legacy. Lynn Schusterman and the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation
HASSENFELD--Sylvia. Elegant dynamo, respected and revered internationally, cherished matriarch, treasured friend. She was an extraordinary grace in this world. Phyllis, Jody & Josh

With her family, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. The beautiful qualities of her life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved her. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President

Our deepest sympathy to her daughter Ellen, son Alan and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier President Archbishop Khajag Barsamian Cardinal Theodore McCarrick Vice Presidents

HASSENFELD--Sylvia. The Board of Directors and staff of The Jerusalem Foundation deeply mourn the passing of Sylvia Hassenfeld. She was a dearly devoted friend, benefactor of Jerusalem and longtime Board Member whose generosity and spirit will live on in the projects she helped bring to life. Her support and deep commitment has enriched all the residents of Jerusalem. She was truly a woman of valor and grace. Our sincerest condolences are extended to Alan and Vivien Hassenfeld, Ellen Hassenfeld Block and the entire family. Sallai Meridor, Intl. Chairman Mark Sofer, President Moshe Fogel, Executive Director

HASSENFELD--Sylvia K. Sylvia K. (Kay) Hassenfeld, 93, international leader, human rights activist, and philanthropist, died August 15, 2014. She was the wife of the late Merrill L. Hassenfeld. Born in Pennsylvania, the daughter of Joseph and Sophie (Flieglman) Kay, she was a resident of Palm Beach, Florida. Mrs. Hassenfeld has been described as "one of the most significant leaders in the American Jewish community of the twentieth century." In her over 50 years of national and international humanitarian leadership, she served as the first woman president of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC). As president of the JDC, Mrs. Hassenfeld initiated the International Development Program (IDP), which provides non-sectarian aid in times of crisis. Begun in response to the needs engendered by the Armenian earthquake, the IDP continues to provide vital emergency aid throughout the world. Also during her tenure as president, she oversaw JDC's return to the former Soviet Union; the rescue of Jews and Muslims from Sarajevo, and Operation Solomon, which rescued over 14,000 Ethiopian Jews via airlift in just 36 hours. At the time of her death, Mrs. Hassenfeld was the President of the Hassenfeld Foundation, a trustee of the NYU Langone Medical Center (NYULMC), a member of the Executive Committee of the Board of the Israel Museum, a Director of the Society of the Four Arts in Palm Beach and a Board Member of Hospice of Palm Beach. A champion of children's causes, Mrs. Hassenfeld served on the Board of the Hasbro Children's Foundation and was instrumental in establishing the Stephen D. Hassenfeld Children's Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders at NYULMC. She was the driving force behind the current development of a dedicated children's hospital at NYULMC; the Hassenfeld Children's Hospital is slated to open in 2017. In addition, Mrs. Hassenfeld served as National Chair of the Women's Division of the United Jewish Appeal and Vice-Chair of the Jerusalem Foundation, as well as a number of other leadership roles at national and international Jewish organizations, including the Board of the United Israel Appeal and the Board of Governors of the Jewish Agency. Board Member Emeritus of Hasbro, Inc., Mrs. Hassenfeld served as a Director on the company's board for over 20 years. As a leader in academia, she served as Vice Chair of the Board at Brandeis University and on the Advisory Committee of the Hopkins-Nanjing Center, a program jointly administered by Johns Hopkins University and Nanjing University in Nanjing, China. She received an Honorary Doctorate in Humane Letters from Brandeis University in 1998. Mrs. Hassenfeld has been recognized internationally by numerous educational, cultural, and civic organizations for her diplomatic skills and her role in protecting human rights, promoting religious freedom, influencing social policy and assuring services to children in need. Among her many honors and awards, she was made an Honorary Citizen of Jerusalem in recognition for her life-long efforts on behalf of Jerusalem and its citizens. She was also made a presidential appointee to the United States Holocaust Memorial Council under three different presidents, awarded the Emma Lazarus Statue of Liberty Award by the American Jewish Historical Society for "contributions to improving the human condition," and honored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Mrs. Hassenfeld is survived by her two children, Alan Hassenfeld and Ellen Hassenfeld Block; three grandchildren, Laurie Block, Michael Block, and Susan Block Casdin; two great-grandchildren. Kinsey and Blaisdell Casdin; and Vivien Hassenfeld (wife of Alan) and Alexander Casdin (husband of Susan). She was predeceased by her husband, Merrill Hassenfeld and her son Stephen D. Hassenfeld. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 19th at 1:00pm at Temple Beth El, 70 Orchard Ave., Providence, with burial in Lincoln Park Cemetery, Warwick, Rhode Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Hassenfeld Children's Hospital at NYULMC, One Park Ave., 17th Floor, New York, New York 10016, Attn: Grace Ko. Shiva will be observed at the home of Alan and Vivien Hassenfeld on Tuesday and Wednesday, August 19th and 20th from 7-9pm. Shiva will also be observed at the home of Susan and Alexander Casdin, 131 East 66th St, New York City on Thursday, August 21st from 6-9pm and Friday, August 22nd from 11am to 2pm. For further information and condolences, please see: www.SugarmanSinai.com.

HAIDER--Bunyad, 78, born in Quetta, Pakistan, passed away on August 17th at his home in Tenafly, NJ. Dr. Haider was a Professor of Medicine at New Jersey Medical School UMDNJ with over 45 years of service, culminating as Chairman of Medicine from 2006 to 2012. He was the recipient of the NJMS Faculty's Distinguished Career Award in 2011 and the NJMS Department of Medicine's Distinguished Lifetime Achievement Award in 2012. Dr. Haider was deeply committed to his students, trainees, colleagues, and patients. Outside of the hospital he was known for his warmth, generosity, and compassion. In both his personal and professional life, Dr. Haider always put the needs of others before his own. He is survived by his devoted wife, Shama Haider; beloved children, Ali Haider and Noreen Haider; and loving siblings, Sajad Haider, Kausar Shah and Jawad Haider. Funeral services will be held at 10am, August 19th at Barrett Funeral Home in Tenafly, NJ.

HABERMAN--Vicki. Surrounded by her loving family, Vicki Kaplan Haberman peacefully passed away on Sunday, August 17th, after a valiant five year battle against ovarian cancer. She was an attorney, vintage clothing retailer, nurturing mother, adored wife, devoted daughter, caring sister, and loyal friend. Ever so selfless in nature, Vicki tirelessly promoted Celiac Disease and Ovarian Cancer research. Her courage, tenacity, strong family values, and generosity will forever be remembered. She is survived by her husband, Ross, children Jacob, Isabelle, and Emma, her parents, Annett and Simon Kaplan, and sister, Karyn Kaplan. A celebration of life will be held for all those she touched on Tuesday, August 19th at 11:00am at Temple Israel, NY. Donations may be made to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund or the Celiac Disease Center at Columbia University.

GIMMA--Licia Albanese. We mourn the death of our beloved Licia who thrilled opera lovers throughout the world with her fiery interpretations. GIMMA--Licia Albanese. I've lost my dearest friend. For many years we ate and we laughed as we travelled the world together. Truly our friendship was blessed by the Gods. I will love you forever. My darling Licia, Rest In Peace. Evelyn Kupin

GIMMA--Licia Albanese. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Licia Albanese, one of the company's major soprano stars from 1940 to 1966. She made her Met debut in the role with which she was most associated, Cio-Cio-San in Puccini's Madama Butterfly, and went on to sing more than 400 performances of 17 roles. She was particularly celebrated for the vulnerability and emotional immediacy of her portrayals of such tragic heroines as Cio-Cio-San, Mimi in Puccini's La Boheme, and Violetta in Verdi's La Traviata, a role she sang more frequently than any soprano in the Met's 131-year history. When she retired from the stage, she continued to pass on the traditions of Italian opera through teaching and her foundation for young singers, and for decades was a fixture at Met opening nights, enthusiastically joining in the traditional pre-performance singing of the national anthem. We offer our sincerest condolences to her family, friends, and the millions of opera lovers whose lives she touched over the past century. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

GIMMA--Licia Albanese. The Trustees and Staff of the Bagby Foundation for the Musical Arts mourn the loss of our beloved and esteemed Licia Albanese, who served tirelessly on the Foundation since joining it as a Trustee in 1960. We thank you, Licia, for your guidance, good humor, charm and impeccable taste. The operatic world has lost a giant, and we have lost a friend. We extend our deepest condolences to Licia's son, Joseph, and his wife, Maria. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman, Blanche Lark Christerson, President, and J. Andrew Lark, Executive Director.

GIMMA - Licia Albanese. Legendary opera star passed away peacefully in her Manhattan home surrounded by her family and devoted caretakers on August 15, 2014, at the age of 105. During her long and illustrious career she enchanted opera lovers throughout the world. Her success on the stage notwithstanding, her true legacy remains with the many young artists that she has encouraged and mentored over the years. She is survived by her son Joseph and his wife Maria, her granddaughter Theresa Denise and her husband Thomas, her grandson Marc and three great-grandchildren Andrew, Michael and Bailey. Visitation will be held on Wednesday, 20 August, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel (1076 Madison Avenue, New York City) from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A private burial will take place on Thursday. A public memorial is being planned for mid-September. We will always remember to celebrate her life.

D'AQUILA--John Sebastian, died at his home in Belle Terre, NY, on August 14, at the age of ninety one. He was the son of the late Sebastian and Agatha D' Aquila of Middletown, Connecticut. Born in Middletown on April 6, 1923, he was educated in Middletown schools and served as a Medic in the 11th Armored Division during World War II, under Gen. Patton. He was in the Battle of the Bulge and was the only surviving medic of the 11th Division at the end of the war. He received a Purple Heart and was a witness to the horrors of the death camp Mauthausen as a member of the liberating force. Following the war, John was graduated from Middlebury College, Middlebury, VT and from Catholic University of America School of Law in Washington, DC. He worked for many years as an attorney for U.S.F.&G. in New York City. He was an avid theatre goer, and was an opera and symphonic music lover. He enjoyed reading and discussing books, collecting art and was a talented master cook. He loved to travel, visited many countries and made livelong friends wherever he went. When he retired and moved to Belle Terre, he became absorbed in a new phase of his life. He was appointed to the board of directors of Theatre3, in Port Jefferson. The artistic director at Theatre3 wrote "From The Fires; Voices of the Holocaust" a play based in part on John's experiences at Camp Mauthausen and presented mostly in grade schools. John attended some presentations and answered questions after the play about what he had personally seen. He felt he needed to bear witness and share his experiences. John became a gifted public speaker, educating young people. Also, in his "retirement", John became active in Stony Brook University's OLLI (Osher Lifelong Learning Institute) program and a participant in a memoirs writing class, as well as continuing to enjoy opera and theatre in New York City. Most important, in 2012, he married his partner of fifty-five years, Dr. Myron Ledbetter, who survives him. He is also survived by a sister, Eleanor Fiducia, as well as by many devoted nieces and nephews and loving friends. He was a wonderful caring man and will be very much missed. A celebration of his life will be planned for a later date.

BERNSTEIN--Sidney B.,passed away on August 17th, 2014 from complications of an auto accident. Sid was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and City College of Engineering. He was an explosives developer at Picatinany Arsenal for 35 years. His wife Joan died in 2005. He is survived by his brother Richard Bernstein. Richard Bernstein

YOUNG--Stuart. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Stuart Young, beloved husband of Toni Young. He leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Stuart's wife, Toni; his children, Mitchel (Katka) & Ann Young Saban (Hanoch); his grandson; his siblings, Ronell Douglass (William) and H. Alan Young (Sharon); his mother-in-law, Claire Perlman; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

YOUNG--Stuart B. The entire community of the Delaware College of Art and Design profoundly mourns the loss of our friend, inspiration, advocate, and tireless leader, Mr. Stuart B. Young, following his sudden passing on August 15, 2014. A dedicated champion for the arts in Delaware, Mr. Young was the founding Chairman of DCAD's Board of Overseers from 2000-2010 and Chairman of the Board of Directors from 2002-2010. Mr. Young continued to act as Distinguished Chairman Emeritus of DCAD's board following his retirement in 2010. Stuart Young's unyielding dedication, support and guidance have been major factors in the growth and development of the College since its inception in 1997, leading to the establishment of the prestigious Stuart B. Young Scholarship Fund. We send our most profound condolences to his wonderful family: to Toni, Ann, husband Hanoch and Stuart's cherished grandson Gilad, and to Mitchell and wife Katka.

YATES--Douglas T.,of New York City, on August 16, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Titus Yates, devoted father of Douglas T. Yates, Jr. (Mary Caryl) of New Haven, CT, Timothy T. Yates (Kay) of Rye, NY, and L. Randall Yates (the late Hope Lloyd) and Margaret Yates Thorne (Nate), of New York City. Adored grandfather of Nate and Nicholas Thorne, and Hope Starr, Lawrence Jr., Tim (Alexis), Chris (Angela), Ted, Katie, Doug (Kerri), Brian (Marci) and Scott (Mackenzie) Yates. Loving great-grandfather of Max, Charlie, Campbell, Jade, Summer, Dougie, Eddie, Gaby, Oscar and Lydia Yates. Doug was a graduate of Culver Military Academy and Williams College. He served his Country during World War II as a Major in the US Army Signal Corps, then was employed as the Executive Vice-President and Director of Republic Pictures Corp., Chairman of Seaboard Associates Inc., Partner at White, Weld and Co., and Vice-President at Merrill Lynch. Doug was a Trustee of The Buckley School, and was a Trustee and Founder of The Episcopal School in New York City. He also served as a member of the Vestry of St. James Church and the International Center for the Disabled, was a Trustee of the Hospital Chaplaincy and The General Theological Seminary, and was Chairman of the Board of Foreign Parishes of The Episcopal Church. He was a long-time Trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital, and was Chairman of The United Hospital Fund and Vice-Chairman of The Greater New York Fund of United Way. Doug was a Knight Hospitaller of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, and was proud to have received The United Hospital Distinguished Director Award for 28 years of Distinguished Service to Hospitals and the United Hospital Distinguished Trustee Award for Extraordinary Service to Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, NYC, Southward Ho C.C., Bay Shore, NY, and Gasparilla Inn Golf Club, Boca Grande, FL. A Memorial Service at St. James Church will be held at 11:00am on September 12, 2014. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street or The Episcopal School in New York City, 35 East 69th Street. Internment will be private.

WREGE--Dr. Charles Deck, Adjunct Professor at the Kheel Labor-Management Documentation Center, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, since 1991, died Tuesday, August 19, 2014. Born in Newark, NJ, he lived in East Orange until moving to Spring Lake in 1969. The author of more than 100 articles on management history, he co-authored with Ronald G. Greenwood: Frederick W. Taylor: Father of Scientific Management:; Myth and Reality, 1991, author of: Fact and Fallacies of Hawthorne: A Historical Analysis of the Hawthorne Illumination Tests and The Hawthorne Studies, in 1986. He also wrote: Spring Lake, An Early History, published in 1976. He served in the US Air Force in the South Pacific in WWII, as a photographer with the 35th Photographic Technical Unit. Dr. Wrege attended New Mexico Highland University, Las Vegas, NM in 1950, Upsala College, 1950 1955, earning a M.A. Concurrent with attending the New School, he enrolled in New York University, earning a M.B.A. in 1956 and a Ph.d in 1961. From 1956 to 1961, Dr. Wrege was on the faculty of the School of Commerce of New York University. In 1961, he joined Rutgers Universtiy, retiring from the School of Business in 1991, when he joined Cornell. Dr. Wrege was predeceased by his wife Beulah ("B") Marion-Cippel Wrege, born in Newark, NJ, who passed away on December 23, 2002. In 2003, he published a book on their 1950 romance: A Romance in Watercolors: Painting by Chuck Wrege for "B" Wrege. Interment will be in Atlantic View Cemetery, Manasquan, NJ. Visiting will be Friday, from 10am until the service is offered at 12 noon at the O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Hwy 35 Wall, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Jersey Shore Animal Shelter, 185 Brick Blvd., Brick, NJ 08723. For more information and to send condolences, visit www.obrienfuneralhome.com.

PEASE--Deborah S.,age 70 of Boston, formerly of New York City, on August 12th, 2014 following a brief illness. Deborah wrote Real Life, a novel, plus a number of collections of poetry. She was the publisher of The Paris Review from 1982-1992, and a supporter of A Public Space, Poets House and Poetry Society of America among other literary organizations. She leaves behind her loving brother Roland, and his wife Lori, niece Marianna, and nephew Nathaniel, and her Aunt Sally Willis and her husband Dudley, and numerous cousins and many loving friends. To share a memory or offer a condolence visit: www.concordfuneral.com Concord Funeral Home, Concord, MA, 978-369-3388.

NEWMAN--John E.,Jr., 87, died August 10, Norwalk Hospital. A resident of New Canaan, formerly of New York City, he graduated from Newark Academy, Princeton University '50 and served in the U.S. Navy during WWII and Korean War. He spent many years on Wall Street. Born September 24, 1928, son of the late John E. and Mary Ingersoll Newman, survived by brother Charles I. of Essex Fells, NJ; sister Eleanor N. Caulkins of Denver, CO., step-son Alexander G. Smith of New York City, wife Peggy and grandchildren, Charlotte and Oliver, and step-daughter, Victoria Sartorius of Rye, NY. He was predeceased by brother Bruce E. Newman. He spent many happy summers in Quogue, LI and winter visits to Vero Beach, FL. He spent his last 10 years "doting on his grandchildren". In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to New Canaan Volunteer Ambulance Corps., 180 South Ave., New Canaan, CT 06840.

MROZ--John Edwin. The EastWest Institute (EWI) Board of Directors is deeply saddened by the loss of John Edwin Mroz, founder, CEO and visionary leader of the institute. We salute this exceptional man, a major international figure of our times, who has made a real difference in the world for over 30 years. John's inspiration, boundless energy and creativity gave birth to new ways of reducing conflict that have stood the test of time. John embodied the values that have made EWI successful by bringing diverse people together to solve seemingly unsolvable problems. John was the recipient of numerous international awards, including the Order of Merit from the Federal Republic of Germany, for the role he and EWI played in facilitating German reunification. He was also awarded the highest civilian awards given to non-citizens by the presidents of Slovakia and Romania. Early in his career, John contacted the Reagan Administration and received approval to conduct a series of clandestine conversations with the Palestinian leadership, as there were no formal talks permitted at the time because of the PLO's failure to recognize the state of Israel. He met with PLO leader Yasser Arafat more than 50 times over three years. Moving quickly after the fall of the Berlin Wall in October 1989, John opened a European headquarters in Prague. He reinvented the institute to deal with the full array of challenges associated with the post-communist transitions of Central and Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, including political and economic reform and new arrangements of international security. John later opened satellite offices in Warsaw, Budapest, Kiev, and Moscow. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, he advanced the Institute's reach to Central Asia and China, anticipating the shift in global power. EWI's work now includes efforts to establish a stronger US-China relationship. EWI is pioneering a rigorous focus on the international challenges of cybersecurity, holding the first worldwide summit in 2010 in Dallas. Additional work focuses on the challenges of food, water and energy. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Karen Linehan Mroz, President of the Middle East Children's Institute (MECI) and three children--Jonathan, Jessica and Jeffrey--and grandchild Noel Isabella Mroz. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be given in John's name to his beloved EastWest Institute www.ewi.info/donate. Ross Perot, Jr., Chairman of the Board The EastWest Institute

MROZ--John Edwin, The EastWest Institute (EWI) mourns the loss of John Edwin Mroz, its visionary founder and CEO. EWI is an influential international security nonprofit, which addresses the seemingly intractable problems that threaten world stability. With John's inspirational leadership and tremendous energy, EWI's work has spanned the Cold War, the Israel-Palestinian conflict, and relations between the U.S. and China. The entire EWI family extends their deepest sympathies to his wife, Karen Linehan Mroz and children, Jonathan, Jessica and Jeffrey. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be given in John's name to his beloved EastWest Institute www.ewi.info/donate. James L. Creighton, Chief Operating Officer The EastWest Institute

MOONIE--Clyde Wickliffe, of Greenwich, CT, and formerly of Palm Beach FL and Scarsdale, NY, passed away on August 14, 2014 at the age of 96 from complications resulting from an aortal aneurism. He was surrounded by his loving family at the end. Born in San Francisco in 1918, he graduated from the University of Chicago with an MBA in 1941. He joined the US Army the following year and became a finance officer, serving in northern Africa before being attached to the US Air Force in southern Italy. He retired after World War II with the rank of Captain. Mr. Moonie was a CPA licensed in California (where he received the Forbes gold medal from the California CPA Society for the highest score on the CPA exam) and in New York. From 1945-1958 he was an audit manager at Arthur Andersen & Co. in Chicago, San Francisco and Mexico City. From 1958-1965 he was administrative manager and controller at mining companies in Peru and Chile before being transferred to the parent company, Minerals & Chemicals Philipp Corp., in New York City as Controller. After several mergers, he retired from Phibro-Solomon Inc. (subsequently acquired by CitiGroup) in 1982 as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. From 1983-1986 he was the Executive Director of the Advisory Council to the Financial Accounting Standards Board. After leaving FASB and until recently, Mr. Moonie was a financial consultant to various companies and volunteered with the Greenwich Retired Men's Association and the Hill House Retired Residents in Old Greenwich. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Liana, of Greenwich, his son Gregory and daughter Barbara, both of North Stamford. CT, and many nieces and nephews around the country. His intelligence, wise advice, great love and wry sense of humor will be dearly missed by his family. Services will be private.

HASSENFELD--Sylvia. The Brandeis University family mourns the passing of Sylvia Hassenfeld. Sylvia was a true friend of Brandeis, and we benefited greatly from her vision, passion and determination. She served on our Board of Trustees since 1996, including as vice chair and most recently as a trustee emerita. Sylvia was unwavering in her family's shared commitment to our mission, which spanned three generations, dating back to 1950 with Henry Hassenfeld, Sylvia's father-in-law. In 1998, Brandeis awarded Sylvia an honorary doctorate in humane letters in recognition of her contributions to the university. We extend our sincerest condolences to her son, Alan, who is co-chair of the Board of Overseers at the Brandeis International Business School; her daughter, Ellen Hassenfeld Block, who is a former member of the Board of Overseers at the Heller School for Social Policy and Management; and to her entire family. May her memory be a blessing. Perry Traquina Chairman of the Board Fred Lawrence President Brandeis University
HASSENFELD--Sylvia. A woman of grace, vigor, commitment, and utmost loyalty. A friend without borders. Joy and Erving & Family

CARNEY--David, UN economist, died in Southampton, NY, on May 8, 2014. He earned five degrees, between 1945 and 1952. His early career included high school teacher, high school headmaster in Ghana, and statistician in the Nigerian government. He arrived in the U.S. in 1953, from Sierra Leone, for a professorship at Lincoln University. He also taught at Fairleigh Dickinson University, Franklin & Marshall and Antioch colleges; and earned a Ph.D. He returned to Sierra Leone as government Economic Advisor, starting in 1961. Between 1963 and 1984, he worked in West Africa, East Africa, and the West Indies, through the UN agencies of UNDP, WHO, and FAO. He authored several books on economics, philosophy, religion, and a literary memento mori to his wife Helen, after her death in 1976. He was a member of Beta Gamma Sigma, Rotary International, and lifetime member of the Royal Economic Society. He retired to Long Island, NY in 1985, to pursue many interests, including collecting books ranging from alternative medicine to philosophy. In this electronic age, Dr. Carney's personal mission was preservation of the written word. He was always ready with a word of advice for those close to him; writing regular letters to the editor, for those farther afield. He was predeceased by his second wife Ellen, and is survived by two children, and two grandchildren. A Celebration of Life will be held at the Bridgehampton Senior Center on August 28, 2014 at 11:00am. The family suggests donations to the Bridgehampton Senior Center in Bridgehampton, NY, the John Jermain Library in Sag Harbor, or UNICEF. Condolences may be posted on the obituary webpage of Yardley & Pino Funeral Home.

YATES--Douglas T.,The staff and trustees of Lenox Hill Hospital mourn the loss of long-time Trustee Douglas T. Yates. YANKELEWITZ--Rabbi Gershon. The Yeshiva University family and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) mourn the passing of a revered European rabbinic scholar, Rabbi Gershon Yankelewitz, ztl, its 104 year old faculty member who delivered daily lectures in Talmud and Jewish Legal Codes to college students and rabbinic students for nearly 60 years. Born in Lubcza, Poland he studied in the Radin Yeshiva until its founder, the world renowned Chofetz Chaim, ztl, died, and he continued at the Mir Yeshiva in Russia before fleeing from the Nazi onslaught at the start of World War II with the entire Yeshiva, to Kobe, Japan, before settling in Shanghai, China until 1946, after which he came to America where he was welcomed by the former Salanter Yeshiva in the Bronx as a teacher, then at Yeshiva and RIETS. He was a kind, gentle and warm lively personality who danced with his colleagues and students at the recent Chag HaSemikha Convocation in Washington Heights at the Wilf Campus. He gave a Talmud class at the Young Israel of Pelham Parkway Jewish Center and worshipped regularly at Congregation Sons of Israel in the Bronx and was an active member of the Vaad Harabonim of the Bronx. He was predeceased by his wife, Bluma, zl, several years ago and is survived by wonderful sons, all of whom serve in the Jewish community: Dovid, Yaakov, Yoel and Moshe and their spouses, and daughters, Devorah Fromowitz, Gity Lipsius and Perl Gross and their spouses and many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He will be buried in Israel. May the entire Yankelewitz family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem together with the faculty and hundreds of his students who revered their beloved colleague and teacher. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

TALARICO--Kathy. The Department of French of New York University mourns the loss of our longtime friend and colleague, Kathy Talarico. She retained her connection to NYU's department and continued her professional and personal rapport with us. We shall miss Kathy's warmth and gentleness. Our sincere condolences to members of Kathy's family.

SCHIRO--James J. The St. John's University family celebrates the life and mourns the passing of James J. Schiro (67CBA, 95HON), illustrious and accomplished alumnus, extraordinarily generous benefactor, and loyal, cherished friend. His great ability, strong work ethic, and high ethical standards enabled him to forge a remarkable career that made him a role model for thousands of our students. His enduring dedication to alma mater was evidenced by his almost two decades of service on the University's Board of Trustees, which named him trustee emeritus, and his leadership in significant initiatives such as St. John's 125th Anniversary Celebration and the annual President's Dinner. The James J. Schiro, Zurich Chair of Enterprise Risk Management, established in 2010 in partnership with Zurich Financial Services will link his name, always, with St. John's as it continues to enrich the education of students in the University's Peter J. Tobin College of Business. We shall remember him with great affection and gratitude always. Our thoughts and prayers go to his cherished wife Tomasina, his children, Justine and James, Jr., and his entire family in this time of sorrow. Peter P. D'Angelo Chair, Board of Trustees Conrado Gempesaw, Ph.D. President

OBIN--Julius Norman, son of Clara Chefetz and Isidore Obshatkin, died in New York City August 19, 2014 at the age of 94. Graduate of James Monroe High School and New York University, Korean War veteran, practiced and taught periodontics until his retirement in 1991. Loved golf, his violin and classical music. MROZ--John Edwin. The EastWest Institute (EWI) Board of Directors is deeply saddened by the loss of John Edwin Mroz, founder, CEO and visionary leader of the institute. We salute this exceptional man, a major international figure of our times, who has made a real difference in the world for over 30 years. John's inspiration, boundless energy and creativity gave birth to new ways of reducing conflict that have stood the test of time. John embodied the values that have made EWI successful by bringing diverse people together to solve seemingly unsolvable problems. John was the recipient of numerous international awards, including the Order of Merit from the Federal Republic of Germany, for the role he and EWI played in facilitating German reunification. He was also awarded the highest civilian awards given to non-citizens by the presidents of Slovakia and Romania. Early in his career, John contacted the Reagan Administration and received approval to conduct a series of clandestine conversations with the Palestinian leadership, as there were no formal talks permitted at the time because of the PLO's failure to recognize the state of Israel. He met with PLO leader Yasser Arafat more than 50 times over three years. Moving quickly after the fall of the Berlin Wall in October 1989, John opened a European headquarters in Prague. He reinvented the institute to deal with the full array of challenges associated with the post-communist transitions of Central and Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, including political and economic reform and new arrangements of international security. John later opened satellite offices in Warsaw, Budapest, Kiev, and Moscow. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, he advanced the Institute's reach to Central Asia and China, anticipating the shift in global power. EWI's work now includes efforts to establish a stronger US-China relationship. EWI is pioneering a rigorous focus on the international challenges of cybersecurity, holding the first worldwide summit in 2010 in Dallas. Additional work focuses on the challenges of food, water and energy. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Karen Linehan Mroz, President of the Middle East Children's Institute (MECI) and three children--Jonathan, Jessica and Jeffrey--and grandchild Noel Isabella Mroz. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be given in John's name to his beloved EastWest Institute www.ewi.info/donate. Ross Perot, Jr., Chairman of the Board The EastWest Institute

McGOVERN--Richard Gordon, 87, of South Kingstown, RI, passed away on Tuesday, August 19, 2014, at home. Long after retiring as president of Pepperidge Farm and Campbell Soup, Gordon McGovern straightened shelves of bread and soup cans in grocery stores, and hardly a visitor left his home without a bag of cookies. Born in Norristown, Pennsylvania in 1926 to James and Marion (Stritzinger) McGovern, Richard Gordon McGovern graduated cum laude from Brown University in 1948 and received his MBA from Harvard in 1950. Starting as a management trainee sweeping floors for Pepperidge Farm, McGovern was named president of the company in 1968. He became Chief Executive Officer of the parent company, Campbell Soup, in 1980, and retired in December 1989. At both companies McGovern gained national recognition for the introduction of innovative products, including the 100% Natural Soup line. McGovern's business drive was fueled by a voracious curiosity. He traveled far and wide, hitch-hiking cross-country as a high school student and leading his grandchildren through the countrysides of France and Ireland. He read just as widely, as happy to pick up People magazine as he would a history of World War II naval battles. (McGovern served as a navy radar officer during the Korean War and in later years was very proud to wear his USS Arnold J. Isbell hat). He would shop for groceries in towns he visited, often discussing products and displays with the store manager. He took great pleasure each day working the daily crossword puzzles with Judy, his wife of 59 years, looking up obscure clues in his vast array of almanacs and reference books. A strong believer in education, McGovern gave generous support to universities, libraries and schools. He received an honorary doctorate from Johnson and Wales University, was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Xi scholastic honor societies, was a member of the Delta Upsilon fraternity, and served on the boards of Wheaton College and the Wooster School. His family field trips and dinner table quizzes on geography and current events are remembered by his four children and their many school friends. Family croquet matches capped a life-long love of sports. McGovern was a state-ranked tennis player in high school, and was on the pitcher's mound at Williams College when VJ day was declared in 1945. A modest man of deep moral conviction, McGovern was proud of his record of never closing a production plant at Pepperidge Farm and Campbell Soup. For years, he folded his 6'4 frame into his beloved yellow Volkswagen beetle for his corporate commute. An avid vegetable gardener, McGovern liked to plant new crops to challenge his green thumb. Gordon McGovern died at his home in Green Hill Beach, Rhode Island, on August 19, cared for by Judy and by his children. He is survived by daughters Lucinda McGovern, Jennifer McGovern and husband Steve Unruhe, and Mindy McGovern and husband Mark Fuller, son Douglas McGovern and wife Galen McGovern, and ten grandchildren: Molly Thomson, Seth Procter, Katherine Mae Unruhe, Mark Procter, Rebecca Procter, Hannah Fuller, Michael McGovern, Matthew McGovern, Graham Fuller and Daniel McGovern. His death was preceded by the deaths of his brothers Lane and Bruce McGovern. The family will hold a private ceremony. Persons wishing to make memorial contributions are directed to the Rhode Island Food Bank, the South Kingstown Land Trust, Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island, or a charity of choice.

McFATE--Dr. Patricia. The Santa Fe Opera notes with sadness the death of Dr. Patricia A. McFate. Dr. McFate and her late husband Sidney Norman Graybeal, both opera lovers, moved to Santa Fe because of its opera company. It was not long until Dr. McFate joined the Opera Board of Directors, remaining a member until her death. During her tenure she was president of The Santa Fe Opera Foundation and chaired the nominating, endowment and finance committees of the Board. An avid and curious opera fan, she was fascinated by the role of the director, especially in contemporary and unusual works. As such, she underwrote the director's chair for a number of important premieres. The Santa Fe Opera is the grateful beneficiary of her dedication and generosity. She will be remembered as a gracious and cherished friend. Susan F. Morris, Chairman Susan G. Marineau, President Charles MacKay, General Director

We are grateful to Nick and Valerie for devoting their deeply Catholic values of charity and love to benefit our patients and their families. We extend sincere condolences to Valerie, and to the entire Mastronardi family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Board of Directors Steven J. Golub, Chairman, Calvary Fund Board of Directors Frank A. Calamari, President & CEO, Calvary Hospital Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director, Calvary Hospital Vincent J. Spinelli, Executive Vice President, Calvary Fund
MARMALSTEIN--Morris 4/17/34 He was married to his beloved wife Elizabeth for almost 50 years. In addition to us, he is survived by his brother Saul and his adorable granddaughter Sammy.

KEATING--Richard P.,MD, 91, August 3, 2014. Born and raised in Manhattan, a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University, Colum- bia University College of Physicians & Surgeons. Survived by Barbara, his wife of 66 years; brother Paul Keating, MD, five children, 11 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Served as Captain in the United States Army stationed in New Mexico at the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Practiced internal medicine for 33 years in Ridgewood, NJ and at the Valley Hospital and led the New York St. Luke's Hospital thyroid clinic. Past President of the Bergen County Medical Society. Retired to Truro, MA and served as Truro Board of Selectmen Chairman, Planning Board Chairman and Truro Public Library Trustee.

KALKINES--Ann. We are deeply saddened by the death of Ann Kalkines who passed away on August 18th. How lucky are we to have had Ann in our lives. The hallmark of her life was her deep and abiding love and affection for her family and friends. With unending devotion, intelligence and perceptiveness, generosity, and a wonderful sense of humor, she consistently brought joy to our lives. She is survived by her husband George Kalkines, her children Nikki and Alexander, sister Marsha White of Hawaii and Trudy Kay Miller of Chicago, cousin Barbara Borer of Fremont, Ohio and sister-in-law Georgia Kondogianis. True to her nature, she wanted to express this final message, "I have had a spectacular life. For all those who have been in my life, I thank you and love you."

HELLER--Caroline Watkins, died at home on Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, NY last Sunday night August 17th, 2014. She was surrounded by loved ones and had a chance to say goodbye to her grandchildren and children. Caro was a force of creativity and love. She was born in Paris where her father was a partner at JP Morgan, and from which she fled the War at age five. She attended Brearley, Garrison Forest, and earned a BA from Sarah Lawrence, Class of '56. She studied painting in Paris when she was twenty-one, and was a prolific and accomplished sculptor who had a successful exhibit at the Atlantic Gallery in 1982. She was the founder of the scholarship program at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights, and as its director worked tirelessly for many years to diversify the student body. She was a combat pistol shooter, earning certification from the Lethal Force Institute in New Hampshire. She worked for a private eye doing stake-outs. She and her husband, Lowell P. Beveridge, became adept at investigation, and worked pro bono to reunite over eighty birth families split apart by adoption. She was once hired by the FBI to bring in a fraud perpetrator and chased him through Connecticut in her old Volvo. She brought him in. She loved Haiti, where she visited often, and whose culture inspired much of her art. She created community wherever she went, and was a cherished mentor to many lost souls. She has been credited with saving several lives. She was a beautiful skier and rider, and loved to roller blade. In later years, she was wild about her six grandchildren who adore her beyond measure. They are Caila and Cammi French, Zoe Heller, Ines Manuel, and Rachel and Pierson Beveridge. She is also survived by her husband Pete Beveridge, her former husband John Heller, and their children Peter Heller, Leslie Heller-Manuel, and Callie French; by her stepson Jesse Beveridge; by her sons-in-law John French and JP Manuel; and by her daughters-in-law Kim Yan and Briana Beveridge; also by other family members Robby and Lisa French; and by the family's dear friend Marie St. Juste.

GIMMA--Licia Albanese. Licia, we mourn your not being with us anymore. You were a great singer who brought life to your roles through your unique style and artistry. You were always a great lady and a true friend. Your spirit will be with us and you will stay in our hearts forever. We extend our deep condolences to your beloved son Joe Gimma and his wife Maria and to all your family. We love you. Marjan Kiepura and Jane-Knox Kiepura

FABRICANT--Audrey, 68, of Port Washington, NY, passed away on August 19, 2014 from brain cancer. The funeral is 1pm today at Riverside Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Audrey is survived by her husband, Stanley; children: Ken, Francine, Rob, Mollena, Beth, Kier; grandchildren: Mason, Lindsay, Avery, Rebecca, Hayden, Sabrina, Logan; sister, Sandy. Donations to Fabricant Family Fund for the Neuro-Oncology Research Program at NYU Langone Medical Ctr.

CHENEY--Kathleen Sprowl, died on August 10, 2014. The Trustees and staff of Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute, Inc., (FAMRI), express our deepest sorrow to the family of FAMRI Trustee Kathleen Sprowl Cheney on her death. A former Eastern Airlines Flight Attendant from 1968 to 1988, she committed her life to make the world a safer place. Kathie was born in Miami, FL and was a resident of Peachtree City, GA, for more than 20 years until her death. She is survived by her beloved husband, Kevin; her loving son, Patrick; her devoted step-son Tom Cheney; caring sisters, Patricia Pallon, Joann Anthony, Mary Mosley and Denise Bamonte and their husbands, as well as numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. Many enjoyed the pleasure of Kathie's company and are inspired by her enthusiasm. Her generosity, dedication and friendship will be sorely missed.

BOGARDUS--Sully Reeves, of New York City and Sharon died at home on July 26th, 2014, leaving her sons Sidney Tuttle Bogardus Jr., Peter Livingston Bogardus, Andrew Lanark Bogardus; eight grandchildren; and her sister Lisa Bounetheau Martin of Carmel, California. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of fifty-four years, Sidney Tuttle Bogardus. She was born on May 21st, 1938 and was the daughter of Sarah (Reeves) and Joseph Haskell Marshall, M.D. of Charleston, S.C. She was a National Merit Scholar, graduating with highest honors from Ashley Hall and summa cum laude from Wellesley College as a member of Phi Beta Kappa. Starting after her children entered school, she had a long, successful career at Credit Suisse First Boston. Keenly intellectual and with a gentle grace, she was passionate about the arts while her first love was always family. Funeral service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church in Manhattan on August 25, at noon. Memorial contributions may be made to Christ Church Episcopal, 9 South Main St., Sharon, CT 06069; or VNSNY Hospice, 1250 Broadway, New York, NY 10001.

BENJAMIN--Walter, passed away on Friday August 15, 2014 in New York City surrounded by his family members. Walter was a beloved member of his community, a loving brother, uncle and a friend. He will always be remembered with all the beautiful memories. He is preceded with his siblings Valentine, Neli, Shamiran, Ramina, Hubert, Dr. Vallo Benjamin and his extended family. A wake will be held Thursday, August 21, 2014, 6-8pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., (at 81st Street) New York, NY 10028. Funeral services will be held on Friday, August 22, 2014, 10:30am-11:30am at Mar Mari Assyrian Church of the East 129 Buena Vista Ave Yonkers, NY 10701.

BELSKY--Melvin, passed away at age 88 on August 19. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte Belsky, devoted father of the late Howard Belsky and loving brother of the late Daniel Belsky. Melvin Belsky was an esteemed Professor of Biology at Brooklyn College and University of California Berkeley. Melvin heroically served his country in the Pacific during WWII. He was also a world-renowned mineralogist and established the Melvin '49 and Howard '79 Belsky Awards, which provide scholarships to outstanding biology and geology students at Brooklyn College. Melvin was a kind and generous man whose caring ways and effervescent personality will be missed by all who were touched by this very special man. Melvin is survived by his sister, Edna Bader, and many loving nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Memorial service: August 21, 11:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Melvin's memory may be made to fight childhood cancer to HUMCF for the Steven Bader Foundation, website: www.Hackensack UMCFoundation.org.

BARKER--George. It is with deep sadness that we announce the death of George Barker on August 19th. Visitation, August 21, at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, August 22, at 10am.

ARONOW--Doris K. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Doris K Aronow. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President

TEPERMAN--Marjorie. Marjorie Teperman passed away at home on August 20, 2014, leaving her sons Lewis, Bruce and Sheldon, daughters-in-law Helaine and Edythe and grandchildren Jacob, Carly, Alex and Miles. She was predeceased by beloved husband Joseph and her sisters Dorothy and Lorel. She was born in Manhattan on January 8, 1922 to William and Rose Friedman. Marjorie was an accomplished student, graduating in the first class of the High School of Music and Art in 1940, receiving a Bachelor of Arts and Master of Arts in music from New York University, and later completing a Master of Arts in education from Teachers College at Columbia University. She contributed to the war effort by working in a factory with her sister to manufacture parts for airplanes. She was a celebrated concert pianist, performing charity concerts for Hungarian orphans of the war and at venues including the Barbizon Hall, Steinway Hall, Carnegie Chamber and Town Hall. She was a devoted public school teacher for 25 years, working at Riverdale Junior High School and PS 122 in the Bronx, and a passionate private teacher of the piano throughout her life. We will miss you Mom you were the life of the party. The family requests that donations in her name be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund at the Riverdale Jewish Center.

SCHROEDER--Karl H.,94, passed away peacefully at home on August 17. Beloved, loving companion of Judy Cole for 40 years. Father of Lyn Terranova and Karl Schroeder, Jr. Grandfather of seven, great-grandfather of seven. Father-figure to Lindsey, David, and children. WWII Veteran. Bronze Starrecipient. Gifted actor. Kind and caring. We will always miss him. A celebration of Karl's life to be held later.

OBIN--Julius Norman, son of Clara Chefetz and Isidore Obshatkin, died in New York City August 19, 2014 at the age of 94. Graduate of James Monroe High School and New York University, Korean War veteran, practiced and taught periodontics until his retirement in 1991. Loved golf, his violin and classical music. Formerly a resident of Delray Beach, FL and Scarsdale, NY. Predeceased by his wife of 70 years, Ruth and sister Louise, he leaves behind his children Nancy Sukenik and Martin and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City, Friday August 22nd.

KATZ--Edward. All of us at Perelson Weiner extend our thoughts, prayers and deepest sympathies to the family of Ed Katz as we mourn the loss of our long-time friend and client. He was an astute observer of human behavior and a businessman of great vision. He will be missed by all those whose lives he touched. He bravely fought his illness for years with dignity and strength and remained as always, a loving husband, father and grandfather. We will dearly miss Ed, and sincerely hope that his family will be greatly comforted by their memories of him. Ed was a kind, generous and highly principled man who treasured his family. Please accept our respects.

KATZ--Edward. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend, colleague and Chairman Edward Katz and extend our warmest sympathies to his wife, Connie; his children, Michael, Randi, Nanci and Toni; their spouses Jackie, Steven, Craig and Darren and his 11 grandchildren. We also extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wonderful extended family and many friends. We will always remember him as the founder of Choice Logistics and for the support and guidance he provided to us over the past 50 years.

KATZ--Edward (Eddie). The family of Edward (Eddie) Katz, 82, is deeply saddened by his death on August 20, 2014. Loving, adoring husband of Connie, proud father of Michael and Jackie, Randi and Steven, Nanci and Craig, Toni and Darren and amazing grandfather of David, Richard, Evan, Jordan, Annie, Jake, Max, Harry, Karli, Sami, and Jessi, and older brother to Stanley and Judy. Everyone knew that there was nothing more important to Eddie than his family. He taught us all so many great lessons. He also touched many others with his wisdom about life and about people. Although he suffered greatly with his illness, he never stopped having a positive attitude. We are comforted by the fact that he is "just resting". Donations in Eddie's memory can be made to Boys Town Jerusalem: www.boystownjerusalem.org. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 10am, Friday, August 22nd, 180 W. 76th Street.

KALKINES--Ann. We are deeply saddened by the death of Ann Kalkines who passed away on August 18th. How lucky are we to have had Ann in our lives. The hallmark of her life was her deep and abiding love and affection for her family and friends. With unending devotion, intelligence and perceptiveness, generosity, and a wonderful sense of humor, she consistently brought joy to our lives. She is survived by her husband George Kalkines, her children Nikki and Alexander, sister Marsha White of Hawaii and Trudy Kay Miller of Chicago, cousin Barbara Borer of Fremont, Ohio and sister-in-law Georgia Kondogianis. True to her nature, she wanted to express this final message, "I have had a spectacular life. For all those who have been in my life, I thank you and love you."
INDURSKY--Anne. A very special lady. I will miss you and your phone calls. Your questions and your love. Janie

INDURSKY--Anne, age 97 of Parkland, Florida passed away peacefully on August 20. Beloved wife of the late David Indursky; loving mother of Arthur (Janie and the late Deanne) and the late Howard (Ellen); cherished grandmother of Blake, Amy and Michael (Camilla); adored great-grandmother of Benjamin, Danielle and Mona; and dear sister of the late Samuel Levine (Sylvia) and the late Abraham Levine (the late Dorothy).

HERMAN--Paula. Jewish Board of Family & Children's Services mourns the passing of Paula Herman, mother of longtime Trustee Erica Schwartz. We will miss Paula at our annual Ladies' Night Out event, which she supported every year. Our hearts and thoughts are with Erica and Paula's entire family and many friends.

HERMAN--Paula A. (Rosenfeld), peacefully at home on August 20. Beloved wife of 55 years to Stuart, mother of Erica (Eric) Schwartz and Dana (Joe) Covey, grandmother of Rebecca and Danny Schwartz and Rachel and Evan Covey. Sister of Herb (Rhea) and Mitchell (Terry) Rosenfeld, sister-in-law of Sandy (Dale) Elledge. Cherished aunt, great-aunt, cousin, colleague and friend. Paula grew up in Brooklyn and Queens. A 1960 graduate of Pratt Institute, she worked in advertising for more than 50 years in partnership with her husband. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to a fund in her memory.

YATES--Douglas T. The Board of Trustees of The Episcopal School in the City of New York is deeply saddened by the passing of Douglas T. Yates. Mr. Yates was a trustee and dear friend for more than fifty years. His leadership and support were extraordinary. We give thanks for his life, and offer our condolences to his daughter, Margaret Yates Thorne, and his grandsons Nate Thorne '88 and Nicholas Thorne '91 and all his family. Thomas E. L. Dewey, President, Board of Trustees Judith R. Blanton, Director of School and Trustee

WEINSTEIN--Max. Born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in 1920, he was a WWII veteran and lifelong educator. He graduated from Brooklyn College in 1941 and went overseas in the 2nd Air Commando unit of the U.S. Army Air Corps. After his discharge, he began teaching and in 1957 he was appointed principal of P.S. 10 in Harlem, the youngest principal ever to be appointed at the time. He was on the Advisory Committee of Bank Street College and Fordham University. First Lady Rosalyn Carter invited him to the White House to discuss the implementation of her education project. She visited his Harlem School, P.S. 180 which was built after the demolition of P.S. 10. At the time of his retirement in 1984, he was vice-president of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators. After retiring, he continued working for the NYC Board of Examiners. He will be mourned and greatly missed by his wife, Jacqueline to whom he was married for 67 years, his children, Betty Kaplan of New City, New York, Howard (Rena) Weinstein of Olney, Maryland, and Neal (Rebecca) Weinstein of Scarsdale, New York. He is survived by seven grandchildren and four cherished great-granddaughters.

We grieve for him but are proud of him as well. He was a true American and Ukrainian patriot who loved and supported both countries. He will be most deeply missed. The Paslawsky Family

KEZER--Valerie Vreeland, 83, of Bailey Island, ME, died August 20, 2014 at the family home. She was sitting on the porch, looking out on a cloudless Maine day and the sparkling water of Casco Bay when she was stricken with a fatal heart attack. Schooled in Caldwell, NJ, she attended the Parson School of Design in New York City. Forced by circumstances to support herself at any early age she was hired by Time, Inc. first as a page and later, because of her artistic abilities and her presentation skills, she worked in the promotion department of Life magazine. She was married on January 30, 1954 and lived in Athens, GA, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, Shrewsbury, NJ and finally, Brunswick, ME. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Richard, and four daughters; Sandra, Allison, Gail and Ann. A fifth daughter, Leslie died of leukemia at age 10. She is also survived by her grandchildren; Brian, Carolyn, Tom, Scott, Duncan, Allison, Jasper, Olivia, Oliver, Meg and John who each loved their Nana as she loved them. Because of two back operations several years ago her mobility was limited but, as with other challenges in her life, she rose above the challenge and brought joy and kindness into many lives. She loved to read, cook, travel the world, follow the successes of family members and stay in touch with old friends. Fittingly, when she died she was browsing through a copy of The Flavor of Maine looking for a recipe for dinner. Her passing leaves an enormous void in the lives of every member of her family and all her friends. No one who knew her could help but recall her smile, her sense of humor, her wisdon, her compassion and her good advice on matters large and small. A Memorial service will be private. Donations in Valerie's memory may be made to Camp Sunshine, a retreat for children with life threatening illnesses and their families, 35 Acadia Road, Casco Bay, ME 04015 or the Curtis Memorial Library, 23 Pleasant Street, Brunswick, ME 04011.
INDURSKY--Anne. A very special lady. I will miss you and your phone calls. Your questions and your love. Janie

INDURSKY--Anne, age 97 of Parkland, Florida passed away peacefully on August 20. Beloved wife of the late David Indursky; loving mother of Arthur (Janie and the late Deanne) and the late Howard (Ellen); cherished grandmother of Blake, Amy and Michael (Camilla); adored great-grandmother of Benjamin, Danielle and Mona; and dear sister of the late Samuel Levine (Sylvia) and the late Abraham Levine (the late Dorothy).

HOGAN--Robert J, (Captain NYPD Ret.) age 74, passed away in Port Washington NY, on Wednesday, August 20, 2014. Bob was born in St. Catherine of Alexandria parish in Borough Park, Brooklyn. He attended high school at LaSalle Academy on East 2nd Street in Manhattan and received his B.S. from Manhattan College on a full Police Department scholarship, graduating cum laude. He also earned an MBA from Manhattan College. He joined the N.Y.C. Police Department in 1963, and was appointed by Mayor Koch to serve as an assistant commissioner in the New York City Department of Transportation. He retired from the Police Department after twenty-two years to serve as the director of Public Safety at the then newly opened Javits Convention Center on the West Side of Manhattan. He later worked as an intelligence analyst for the Drug Enforcement Administration before retiring in 2002. Bob took up the bagpipes, joining the ranks of the Pipes & Drums of the New York City Police Department Emerald Society in 1968. He served in positions of administrative and musical leadership as Bandmaster, Assistant Bandmaster, and Pipe Major. Bob is the only member of the Band to serve both as Bandmaster and Pipe Major. During his tenure as pipe major, the Band produced its first long playing album and won two consecutive Father Donal J. O'Callahan trophies as the best bagpipe band in the New York City St. Patrick's Day Parade. In 1981, while completing work on an MBA at Manhattan College, he collaborated with Brother Kenneth Fitzgerald F.S.C. and they founded the Manhattan College Pipe Band, where he served as the director for 17 years. He was directed toward law enforcement by his unofficial adopted father, Aeneas B. Neligan. In the NYPD, he served for many years as an Emerald Society Delegate and a member of the Holy Name Society. He was a contributing member to the New York Irish American Historical Society, co-founder of the Emerald Society in the New York office of the Drug Enforcement Administration, and a member of the Manhattan Division 3 - Ancient Order of Hibernians. Being civic minded and driven to be impactful locally, Bob served in elected positions as Mayor to the Village of Plandome Manor and President of the Port Washington Estates Association. He also served as a reporter for the local newspaper. Bob is survived by his wife of 52 years, Rosemary, his children, Grace, Colleen, and Michael, his Sisters, Virginia Pitsios and Margaret Dove, and six grandchildren. Visitation will be held at the New Hyde Park Funeral Home 506 Lakeville Rd. New Hyde Park NY Saturday and Sunday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10am, Monday, August 25, at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City. Interment will be private. www.nhpfh.com. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions are welcome and should be directed to the Irish Guide Dogs for the Blind, which Bob supported, online at www.guidedogs.ie/iopen24/index.php, or by mail to Irish Guide Dogs for the Blind, National Headquarters & Training Centre, Model FarmRoad, Cork Ireland.

HERMAN--Paula A. (Rosenfeld), peacefully at home on August 20. Beloved wife of 55 years to Stuart, mother of Erica (Eric) Schwartz and Dana (Joe) Covey, grandmother of Rebecca and Danny Schwartz and Rachel and Evan Covey. Sister of Herb (Rhea) and Mitchell (Terry) Rosenfeld, sister-in-law of Sandy (Dale) Elledge. Cherished aunt, great-aunt, cousin, colleague and friend. Paula grew up in Brooklyn and Queens. A 1960 graduate of Pratt Institute, she worked in advertising for more than 50 years in partnership with her husband. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to a fund in her memory.

EDDA A LITTLE VALKYRIE’S FIRST DAY OF SCHOOL. Written and illustrated by Adam Auerbach. 32 pp. Christy Ottaviano/Holt. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 7) 
 
Edda’s home is in Asgard, “a land full of magic and adventure.” But Edda, the littlest Valkyrie, doesn’t have quite enough to do, until her father flies her “all the way to Earth for the first day of school.” The contrast between home and school is hard to get used to (in one, she can ride reindeer; in the other she gazes through glass at the classroom guinea pig). In his first picture book, Auerbach mingles the two worlds unapologetically. Children are likely to appreciate the joke.

TODMAN--Terence. The Cardozo community expresses heartfelt sadness over the passing of Terence Todman, beloved father of Terence Todman, Jr., (Terry) who served with distinction on Cardozo's Board of Overseers and as our esteemed Treasurer, and who also served with dedication on the Yeshiva University's Board of Trustees Audit Committee. THOMAS--Brooks John, of New York, NY and East Hampton, NY passed away on Saturday, August 16th 2014. He is survived by his son Taylor Brooks Thomas of Watermill, NY; his brother, Scott Thomas of St. Louis, MO; his sister-in-law, Jennifer (Costin) Thomas, his niece, Delaney Thomas and nephew, Tucker Thomas of St. Louis, MO; his ex-wife Genie Egerton-Warburton of Watermill, NY; and countless friends and colleagues, especially Ward Williams, who will miss him tremendously. Brooks was born in Rockville Center, New York to the late John Walter Thomas and Maleen Meyer Thomas of Naples, Florida. He was a graduate of Portsmouth Abbey School and Ohio Wesleyan University where he was a member of Phi Gamma Delta Fraternity. Brooks began his career in the fashion industry in the May Corporation Executive Training Program at Lord & Taylor and subsequently held posts at Tommy Hilfiger, Barneys New York, Ralph Lauren and Bergdorf Goodman where he served as Divisional Merchandise Manager of Men's Tailored Clothing and Sportswear, Furnishings and Accessories for over ten years. Most recently he served as Vice President, Menswear at Holt Renfrew in Toronto, Ontario, Canada while also maintaining his luxury consulting endeavor, Brooks Thomas Group. Brooks was an active mentor in the Council of Fashion Designers of America's Incubator Program, an avid supporter of the Natural Resource Defense Council and World Wildlife Fund, and a devoted volunteer to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Research. In his memory, donations can be made in his name to any of the above mentioned charitable organizations.

TEPERMAN--Marjorie. Marjorie Teperman passed away at home on August 20, 2014, leaving her sons Lewis, Bruce and Sheldon, daughters-in-law Helaine and Edythe and grandchildren Jacob, Carly, Alex and Miles. She was predeceased by beloved husband Joseph and her sisters Dorothy and Lorel. She was born in Manhattan on January 8, 1922 to William and Rose Friedman. Marjorie was an accomplished student, graduating in the first class of the High School of Music and Art in 1940, receiving a Bachelor of Arts and Master of Arts in music from New York University, and later completing a Master of Arts in education from Teachers College at Columbia University. She contributed to the war effort by working in a factory with her sister to manufacture parts for airplanes. She was a celebrated concert pianist, performing charity concerts for Hungarian orphans of the war and at venues including the Barbizon Hall, Steinway Hall, Carnegie Chamber and Town Hall. She was a devoted public school teacher for 25 years, working at Riverdale Junior High School and PS 122 in the Bronx, and a passionate private teacher of the piano throughout her life. We will miss you Mom you were the life of the party. The family requests that donations in her name be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund at the Riverdale Jewish Center.

TEICH--Eugene M.,MD, born in Brooklyn, NY died August 21, 2014 in Brookline, MA, at the age of 87. Eminent cardiologist, known as an astute clinician, auscultator and EKG reader, he was devoted to his patients. Possessed of a fierce forehand, a well-disguised dropshot and a baffling serve, he claimed to have won ten tournaments. The Open was his time of year. Skilled card player, in poker circles feared as "Ice," he was also a grandmaster of "Rock, Scissor, Paper." The Giants, "The Wild Bunch" and "Double Indemnity," and "Puns & Anagrams" were among his many passions. He is survived by his beloved family, dedicated wife of 61 years, Suzanne (Gottesman), children, Douglas, Jessica and Roger and their spouses Bettina, Michael and Maggie, and grandchildren, Felix, Hannah, Isabel, Maya, Isaac, Charlotte, and Margalo. He was larger than life, and will be missed.

TALARICO--Kathy. The Department of French of New York University mourns the loss of our longtime friend and colleague, Kathy Talarico. Kathy earned her Ph.D. from our department and went on to a successful career in academia as professor and department chair at the College of Staten Island. She retained her connection to NYU's department and continued her professional and personal rapport with us. We shall miss Kathy's warmth and gentleness. Our sincere condolences to members of Kathy's family.

SUNDELL--Nina Castelli. With sadness, we mourn the loss of Nina Castelli Sundell. She will be remembered with joy for her passion for art and her support of artists, particularly during her time at Yaddo when her husband, Michael G. Sundell, served as President. Nina knew what an artist's life was and how hard the struggle is to create in real life the vision in one's mind. She continued as a strong supporter of Yaddo's mission long after she and Michael retired. We offer condolences to Nina's children and extended family. The Members, Directors, and Staff of Yaddo.
