Schwartz, one of its founding members, past president and guiding lights. Howard was beloved by all who knew him for his many contributions that he made in both his professional and individual capacities. The world was made better by Howard's presence and he will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family.

SCHWARTZ--Howard L. The partners and staff of Tuchman, Korngold, Weiss, Liedman & Gelles, LLP extend our condolences to the family of our friend, beloved partner and guiding spirit, Howard L. Schwartz. He will be sorely missed but never replaced.

SCHWARTZ--Howard, The Board and Staff of Jewish Child Care Association mourn the loss of Howard Schwartz, our long-time Board member, a wonderful Board president and a great philanthropist helping children in need. Our heartfelt condolences to Phyllis and the entire family. Peter Hauspurg, Board President Richard Altman, CEO

SCHWARTZ--Howard L.,age 89, died peacefully at his home in the early morning of August 22. Diagnosed with Parkinson's disease in 2007, he suffered a stroke a few days prior to his death. Treasured husband of Phyllis (nee Rattner), adored father of Andy and of Laura Winkleblack and David Winkleblack, beloved grandfather of Nick and Ben Winkleblack and besotted greatgrandfather of Julius, Simone, and Theo Winkleblack. Howard grew up on the Lower East Side with his parents Harry and Rose Schwartz and younger sister Judith (Small). They lived above the family funeral home founded by his grandfather, Sigmund Schwartz. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Howard entered Penn State University at age sixteen; fraternity brother George Rattner introduced the young undergrad to his sister Phyllis, striking a spark of romance that would continue to glow and grow for a lifetime. In 1944, Howard enlisted in the Navy; promoted to Lieutenant (junior grade), he served in the South Pacific and the Aleutian Islands. At war's end, he earned his JD degree from Columbia Law School and joined Holtz & Schrier, specializing in tax certiorari and real estate. The firm prospered during Howard's halfcentury tenure and at age 75 he retired as a Senior Partner. He had a richly deserved reputation for scrupulous integrity, wise counsel, and being The Nicest Boss Ever. Throughout his life, Howard was optimistic, openminded, compassionate and loving. He was an exemplary husband and father, a wonderful friend, an enthusiastic and curious traveler. A lifelong Democrat, he had a remarkable memory for history and politics. He gave many years of service as a Trustee and Chairman of the Board of the Jewish Child Care Association, and lived his values in all his actions. Howard was deeply devoted to his family and friends. We will never forget his warmth, grace, humor, and intelligence. He leaves this world but remains in our hearts forever.

SCHEIN--Roslyn, Roz died on August 22, 2014 at the age of 90 leaving her daughter Lisa, grandsons Douglas and Zachary, brother Albert, nieces, nephews and many adoring friends. Roslyn taught voice, diction and drama to aspiring students during her 40 year career at the High S chool of Performing Arts, many of whom went on to become famous actors in stage and film. And Mrs. Schein, as she was known to her students, was the only teacher to be mentioned in the movie Fame. Hers was a wonderful and giving life that touched many. She will be greatly missed. Shiva Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, August 26-28, 2pm-7pm at Roslyn's Manhattan apartment. Donations to Alzheimer's Research.

RUSOFF--Marilyn Rapping, Age 80. Formerly of Peekskill, NY, died from heart and lung disease. Has resided in Manhattan since 1959. Survived by her brother, Dr. Lowell Rapping of Peekskill, and her beloved nieces and nephews. Graveside service and burial at King David Cemetery in Putnam Valley, NY on Sunday August 24 at 12 noon.

ROWE--George, Jr. The Rockefeller University mourns the passing of our longtime friend George Rowe. As President of The Ambrose Monell Foundation, he wisely guided the Foundation's philanthropic support for medical research, arts, education, and social services. Under his leadership, the Foundation generously supported the University's research and education initiatives. We are deeply grateful for his commitment to The Rockefeller University Hospital and to our recruitment of world-class biomedical investigators, thereby helping to advance scientific discovery and translational research. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Joyce; to his fellow Foundation directors; and to the entire Rowe family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair and Life Trustee Russell Carson, Chair Richard Furlaud, Chair Emeritus Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President

Rosenzweig--Sheila, 83, of Wyomissing, PA, formerly of Freeport, NY, died peacefully August 9, 2014 at The Highlands of Wyomissing. Born in Brooklyn, NY on November 12, 1930, she was the daughter of the late Justice Daniel and Mrs. Sally Albert. She graduated from Connecticut College for Women in 1951 and worked as a social worker prior to her marriage to her husband of almost 62 years, Dr. Leonard Rosenzweig. She was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother, and an avid and accomplished amateur golfer. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her children: Seth, husband of Barbara, of Wyomissing and Andrew, of Scottsdale, Arizona. She is also survived by her loving grandchildren, Dana, Michael, Jessica and Jillian. Funeral service was held privately on Long Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Olivet Boys and Girls Club, 1161 Pershing Blvd., Reading PA 19611

RITHOLZ--Gerald "Jerry". Gerald "Jerry" Ritholz, 81, passed away in his Las Vegas home on August 2, 2014. He was preceded by Ray Jarvis, his life partner; his parents Samuel J. Ritholz and Sylvia Silverstein Ritholz; and brother, Richard A. Ritholz. Among his surviving family members are his nephew, Jeffrey S. Ritholz, in New York, and niece, Susan K. Ritholz, in New York. Jerry also has several remaining cousins: Lois Neiman Kempner in New Jersey, Warren Neiman in Arizona, Arna Silvers Baker in Illinois, Alan Silvers in Georgia, Kenneth Silvers in New York, Jules Ritholz in Illinois, Robert Ritholz in Illinois, and Edward Bedno in Illinois. Born in Chicago on September 25, 1932, Jerry enjoyed a childhood fascination with Gilbert and Sullivan, whose work inspired him to perform puppet shows of his own for his friends. At age 11, Jerry's interest in the arts was fueled when his father's aunt introduced him to the Metropolitan Opera radio broadcasts. Inspired by these broadcasts, he began to develop miniature sets of his own and collect phonograph records. While attending Lakeview High School, Jerry's artistic interest grew to include music as he began to compose original scores. Encouraged by his music teacher and his father's gift of season tickets to the Chicago Symphony, Jerry soon aspired to become a set designer. After high school, Jerry briefly attended the University of Illinois at Navy Pier to study business education. His love for the theatre, however, took over when he accepted the opportunity to work with the University's drama department. With the realization that his life's work belonged in the arts, Jerry transferred to The Goodman Theater of Arts Institute of Chicago. After graduating from the Goodman Theater, Jerry's dream of becoming a professional set designer was soon realized, and his work was showcased by several famous dance companies, drawing rave reviews from Ruth Page, Claudia Cassidy and the Chicago Ballet Guild. Jerry's set design talent eventually led him to New York City, where he also began buying and selling artwork. When a new opera company in Chicago advertised for singers and dancers, Jerry seized the opportunity to present his portfolio. He was quickly hired and relocated back to Chicago by co-founder and former general manager of the Lyric Opera of Chicago, Carol Fox, and opera producer, Larry Kelly. Designing sets for Lyric Opera was Jerry's primary occupation and passion for many years. During his career with the Chicago Metropolitan Opera, Jerry brought his creative talent as set designer to "The Taming of the Shrew", "Aida", "Le Nozze Di Figaro" and "Fedora" just to name a few of many operas. He became lifelong friends with soprano, Maria Callas, world renowned opera singer who died at the age of 53. Jerry took a hiatus from the art world, however, to attend to the needs of his family when his father became ill. During this time, he worked very briefly for the family business, King Optical Company. His business travels led him to eight states as well as Ontario, Canada. On the side, Jerry continued to purchase artwork and graphics, frame them, and sell them to department stores in Chicago. Urged by his aunt and uncle to advertise his business venture in Decor Magazine, Jerry achieved success outside of the family business to the point where in 1970, he started a company of his own: Mixed Media, Ltd. With the support of his business and life partner Ray Jarvis, who suggested that they switch from black and white to color advertisements in their catalogue, Mixed Media, Ltd. became one of the most successful wholesale poster art distributors in the United States. Jerry met Ray Jarvis, in 1976 when Jerry accompanied his mother on the Royal Caribbean Nordic Prince cruise ship. At the time, Ray was the ship's assistant cruise director and was also a former acquaintance - Jerry and Ray met for the first time in 1956 at the Music Theater in Highland Park, Illinois. Jerry and Ray's relationship developed quickly and after four more cruises together, they decided to establish residence with one another in Chicago. Years later, in search of a better climate, the couple moved to Las Vegas, Nevada, where they ultimately sold their business and retired. Jerry and Ray enjoyed a deeply committed and loving relationship together for 33 years before Ray's passing in 2009. Jerry was a staunch supporter of the Smith Center for the Performing Arts in Las Vegas, as well as an active donor and member of the Golden Rainbow. He was surrounded by many close friends during his final years, which was a source of great joy, support, and comfort to him. His dying wish was to pass away peacefully in his home, which he did. The Ritholz family extends heartfelt gratitude to all of Jerry's friends who demonstrated their love, care and concern for Jerry throughout his life and until the time of his passing. Particularly, the family wishes to express their appreciation for the many years of devotion by long-time friend, and former employee, Wayne S. Weiswasser of Las Vegas. At Jerry's request, there will be a "Blast from the Past" party in Las Vegas. Those who knew Jerry may contact 702-731-1926 for additional information. Donations in Jerry's name may be made by calling The Smith Center for the Performing Arts at 702-749-2012, The Golden Rainbow at 702-384-2899, or Nathan Adelson Hospice at 702-733-0320. The interment will be private.

PEASE--Deborah S.,age 70 of Boston, formerly of New York City, on August 12th, 2014 following a brief illness. Deborah wrote Real Life, a novel, plus a number of collections of poetry. She was the publisher of The Paris Review from 1982-1992, and a supporter of A Public Space, Poets House and Poetry Society of America among other literary organizations. She leaves behind her loving brother Roland, and his wife Lori, niece Marianna, and nephew Nathaniel, and her Aunt Sally Willis and her husband Dudley, and numerous cousins and many loving friends. Services private. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to the Sherborn Library, 4 Sanger St., Sherborn, MA 01770. To share a memory or offer a condolence visit: www.concordfuneral.com Concord Funeral Home, Concord, MA, 978-369-3388.

OBIN--Julius Norman, son of Clara Chefetz and Isidore Obshatkin, died in New York City August 19, 2014 at the age of 94. Graduate of James Monroe High School and New York University, Korean War veteran, practiced and taught periodontics until his retirement in 1991. Loved golf, his violin and classical music. Formerly a resident of Delray Beach, FL and Scarsdale, NY. Predeceased by his wife of 70 years, Ruth and sister Louise, he leaves behind his children Nancy Sukenik and Martin and many nieces, nephews and cousins.

NEFF--Edwin J.,95, born in Richmond Hill, Queens, NY, with his daily "To Do List" in his pocket, died suddenly in his home on July 4, 2014. During WWII he served in the United States Army Air Force in Pakistan. A graduate of St. Francis Prep, he started working at 17 when his young father died after a long illness. He helped his mother provide for his younger brother and two sisters. While employed by the U.S. Air Force after the War, his young wife, Mary Edith Hogan, died in 1959. He never remarried. In spite of these challenging moments he never complained, never despaired. He forged a career in the new Aero Photo Reconnaissance Industry. His dedication led to corporate Sales Executive, and Marketing Vice President positions for leading corporations serving the U.S. Military. Having lived almost a century, Ed met reality with humor, perseverance and common sense. Never a bad word, always a smile with a helping hand. Although he was a member of numerous Trade Associations and Clubs, his favorites were The White House News Photographers Association and The New York Athletic Club. He is survived by his younger sister, Winnifred Faughnan of Oakland, CA; his son Edwin Neff Jr., and a granddaughter Adrienne Justine Neff, both of New York City. A private Veterans Service will take place in September at Cypress Hills Cemetery. Memorial gifts in his name may be sent to Catholic Charities or United Jewish Appeal.

MUNROE--George B.,who led the copper mining and manufacturing company Phelps Dodge Corporation from 1969 to 1987, died painlessly and peacefully in his sleep on August 19. Munroe led Phelps Dodge through a difficult period for the domestic copper mining industry, as it struggled to meet growing competition from abroad and new environmental requirements at home. Munroe continued to increase the company's production as a new hydro-metallurgical process was developed to reduce the need for smelting in the production process and Phelps Dodge, which had been the third largest United States copper producer, emerged as the domestic industry leader and one of the largest producers in the world. Before joining Phelps Dodge, Munroe practiced law in New York as an associate with Cravath, Swain and Moore and Debevoise, Plimpton and McLean and worked in the Office of the U.S. High Commissioner for Germany in the early 1950's, serving first in Bonn as a lawyer and later in Nuremberg as a justice of the U.S Court of Restitution Appeals of the Allied High Commission. Munroe was a trustee of Dartmouth College for 14 years and the chairman of its board for three years. He was also a trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, serving on several of it's committees for 25 years, and chairing the Museum's finance committee for 8 years. Other board memberships included the Henry Street Settlement, the YMCA of Greater New York and the Academy of Political Science, of which he was chairman for 10 years. He was a director of several major corporations, including the New York Life Insurance Company, the Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical banks, the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, Manville Corporation and New York Times Company and was a Public Governor of the New York Stock Exchange. His service in the Navy during World War II included duty as a combat information center officer on the battleship Maryland in the Pacific. The Maryland took part in the invasion of Okinawa in 1945, where it survived damage from Kamikazi plane attacks. As a young man, Munroe was an outstanding basketball player on three Ivy League championship teams at Dartmouth and led Dartmouth to the national championship game of the N.C.A.A. tournament in 1942. That year, he led the Eastern Intercollegiate League in scoring and was named to several All-America Teams. Later, while attending Harvard Law School, he played in the professional league for the St. Louis Bombers and Boston Celtics. Munroe graduated from Dartmouth College and Harvard Law School with honors and from Oxford University in England where he was a Rhodes Scholar. Munroe is survived by his wife of more than 45 years, Elinor Bunin Munroe, an artist and award-wining film maker, and by two sons by a previous marriage, Ralph of Orange, Virginia and Taylor of Atenas, Costa Rica and a grandson, Zachary. Mr. Munroe decided not to have a funeral or memorial service. Contributions may be made to the George B. Munroe Scholarship Fund at Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH 03755 or to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10021 in lieu of flowers or condolences.

MROZ--John Edwin. The EastWest Institute (EWI) Board of Directors is deeply saddened by the loss of John Edwin Mroz, founder, CEO and visionary leader of the institute. We salute this exceptional man, a major international figure of our times, who has made a real difference in the world for over 30 years. John's inspiration, boundless energy and creativity gave birth to new ways of reducing conflict that have stood the test of time. John embodied the values that have made EWI successful by bringing diverse people together to solve seemingly unsolvable problems. John was the recipient of numerous international awards, including the Order of Merit from the Federal Republic of Germany, for the role he and EWI played in facilitating German reunification. He was also awarded the highest civilian awards given to non-citizens by the presidents of Slovakia and Romania. Early in his career, John contacted the Reagan Administration and received approval to conduct a series of clandestine conversations with the Palestinian leadership, as there were no formal talks permitted at the time because of the PLO's failure to recognize the state of Israel. He met with PLO leader Yasser Arafat more than 50 times over three years. Moving quickly after the fall of the Berlin Wall in October 1989, John opened a European headquarters in Prague. He reinvented the institute to deal with the full array of challenges associated with the post-communist transitions of Central and Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, including political and economic reform and new arrangements of international security. John later opened satellite offices in Warsaw, Budapest, Kiev, and Moscow. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, he advanced the Institute's reach to Central Asia and China, anticipating the shift in global power. EWI's work now includes efforts to establish a stronger US-China relationship. EWI is pioneering a rigorous focus on the international challenges of cybersecurity, holding the first worldwide summit in 2010 in Dallas. Additional work focuses on the challenges of food, water and energy. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Karen Linehan Mroz, President of the Middle East Children's Institute (MECI) and three children--Jonathan, Jessica and Jeffrey--and grandchild Noel Isabella Mroz. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be given in John's name to his beloved EastWest Institute: www.ewi.info/donate. The EWI Family

MOLLMAN--John Peter, died on July 30, 2014, at his home in Carmel, CA. Peter is survived by his wife Carol of 16 years, his daughter Sarah Underhill (Robert) of Bronx- ville, NY; son Eric (Mary) of Winnetka, IL, and stepson David (Janet) Moga of San Mateo, CA, and by eight grandchildren: Molly and Sam Underhill; Maddy, Tim, Annie, and Ellie Mollman; and Zoe and Ava Moga. His marriage to Jane Kendall Mollman, in 1953, ended in divorce. Peter was born on February 8, 1931, in Belleville, IL. He earned his MA from Washington University in St. Louis in 1952. He spent his professional life in publishing in New York at Harper & Row and Random House, Inc., World Book in Chicago, and finally Microsoft in Seattle. In retirement, he channeled his immense creative energy into the design and development of an Italian food website: www.classicpasta.com. As Peter himself described it, one of the most delightful and memorable moments in his long publishing career was meeting Marcella and Victor Hazan and his subsequent role in the development of The Classic Italian Cookbook. Peter had signed up for an Italian cooking class with the Hazans in New York, in search of the food he had come to love in his travels; the authenticity of their food was nowhere to be found in American cookbooks at the time. A friendship and partnership were born, and the first edition of this seminal work on Northern Italian cooking was published by Peter at Harper's Magazine Press in 1973. His passions included art, music, travel, food and wine, and all things Italian, and his volunteer commitments reflected these interests. Peter had an exceptional zest for life, and his signature laugh was contagious. A celebration of his life will take place at his home in Carmel. Donations in Peter's honor may be made to the Carmel Public Library Foundation, PO Box 2042, Carmel, CA 93921-2042, (831)624-2881, http://carmelpubliclibrary foundation.org; or to Chamber Music Monterey Bay, PO Box 221458, Carmel, CA 93922, www.chambermusicmontereybay.org

MIRON--Tsipora. Our beloved mother Tsipora passed away on August 5, 2014 in her Upper West Side apartment, surrounded by her loving family. She is survived by her husband of 71 years, Issachar Miron, her daughters Ruth Schleider, Shlomit Aviram and Miriam Lipton, six grandchildren, and three great grandchildren. She was born in Kiev in 1923 and moved to Palestine in 1925. She was a gifted pianist and organist who performed, recorded, and coached pianists and vocalists. She worked closely with her husband Issachar, a famed composer of innumerable musical works including Tzena Tzena. The cherished memory of our beloved mother, and the legacy of our parents' extraordinary love and music, will always live on. Ruth, Shlomit and Miriam

MCKELVEY-SHAW--Judith Grant McKelvey-Shaw of Greenbrae, CA died on August 10 after an extended illness. Judith was Dean of Golden Gate University School of Law from 1974 - 1981, and only the second woman in the US to become dean of an ABA accredited law school. Judy is survived by her husband, Dr. Robert Shaw, by his four children, by two sisters, by several nieces and nephews, and by numerous beloved friends and colleagues whose loss is incalculable. Please see full obituary in San Francisco Chronicle.

MATTIN--Helen A.,89, died peacefully at home on August 23, 2014. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Helen was preceded in death by her parents, Harry and Edith Mattin and her younger brother, Henry Mattin. Helen was a proud graduate of Erasmus Hall High School, class of 1942, and Cornell College of Arts and Sciences of Cornell University, class of 1946. Helen worked for many years in publishing, where she made significant contributions in the editorial research and writing department for Colliers Encyclopedia. Helen often reminisced about her involvement in the Children's Garden Program at the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens, and she maintained her involvement at BBG through major donations in several areas of the Gardens, most notably the Helen Mattin Warm Temperate Pavilion. Helen was passionately involved in and donated significantly in several areas where she found personal meaning. She was an avid supporter of Women's Rights and organizations like Planned Parenthood, she supported Civil Rights through Public Citizen and Common Cause, the Environment and Animal rights through The Central Park Conservancy, National Wildlife Federation, and the Sierra Club, the Jewish Community through the JUF of NY and Dorot, and The Arts through Channel 13 and The Actor's Fund. Helen also believed in the values of the Democratic party and gave significantly to individual policitical candidates and causes. Helen's love of travel deepened her understanding of those who were less fortunate and she often traveled to places where she viewed her contributions in action. Helen was a true humanitarian, and believed in the Jewish value of "Tikkun Olam", to repair the world, and this value guided her life. Her generosity will live on in the many lives she touched. In her private life Helen was a quiet force for good, and a feisty personality. She loved her neighborhood and the City of New York, and relished the beauty of her terraces and the sweet companionship of her cat Mittens. Although initallly Helen reluctantly accepted the care she needed from others, she eventually forged strong bonds with her caregivers, Jane Shapiro, Carmen Crawford, Eartha Simpson, Franca Neptune and Gloria Simmons. Helen maintained her sense of humor and dignity until the very end of her life. Helen is survived by several relatives and many devoted friends. She will be sorely missed.

LYMUS--Evelyn J.,on August 18, 2014 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. The family mourns the loss of a beloved and extraordinary Matriarch. She was a loyal and trusted confidant to both family and friends, far and wide. She will be missed but her legacy will endure through the many lives she touched. Services entrusted to the L.H. Woodward Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Bethany Baptist Scholarship Council, 460 Marcus Garvey Blvd., Brooklyn, NY 11216.

LAUGHLIN--Henry R. February 13, 1960 August 6, 2014. Henry Laughlin has passed unexpectedly at his home in San Francisco. Growing up in Norfolk, Connecticut, with roots in Wyoming, he spent time in Argentina and Chile before settling in San Francisco with Carlene, his wife; and there they would later welcome the births of Walker and Amelia, their children. He was currently serving on the board of the Alta Ski Lifts Company in Alta, Utah, the Snake River Associates and Crystal Springs Ranch in Wilson, Wyoming. In Utah, the Andes of Chile and Argentina, the Tetons in Wyoming and the Sierras in California Henry was able to explore his passion for skiing. He enjoyed mountain-biking the trails of Wyoming and the Sierras as well as biking the beautiful roads of the Berkshires. Henry was an accomplished cabinetmaker. Alta benefited from his keen eye for design and perfectionist detail, and he contributed to the major elements in the buildings recently constructed at the Alta Ski Lifts Company. Henry is survived by his brother Paul Laughlin his wife Marian Gram Laughlin and their two sons James R. Laughlin and Hugh O. Laughlin, his sister Leila Laughlin Javitch her husband Daniel Javitch and their two daughters Arielle Javitch and Daphne Javitch. Above all, Henry was an immensely kind man, who gave generously his energy and enthusiasm to help others in need. Even a small gift of his latest discovery showed he had thought of you. So many will miss him not least his beloved dog, Bay. But Henry's own life was not easy. He suffered deeply from mental illness that would not allow him to support his own dreams, even as he supported the dreams of others. Now and in years to come, those who share mental illness such as Henry's will be helped not only by medication and therapy; but also by public awareness and discussion; open empathy with each individual patient, free of shame, prejudice, or judgment of any kind; and rigorous research. Carlene, Amelia, and Walker thank you deeply for contributions made in Henry's name to any organization you feel assists those who suffer from mental disease, such as the National Alliance on Mental Illness (www.nami.org), Bring Change 2 Mind (www.bringchange2mind.org) and ReachOn.org. A celebration in memory of Henry's life will be held at the Swedenborgian Church of San Francisco on September 26, 2014 at 4pm.

KEZER--Valerie Vreeland, 83, of Bailey Island, ME, died August 20, 2014 at the family home. She was sitting on the porch, looking out on a cloudless Maine day and the sparkling water of Casco Bay when she was stricken with a fatal heart attack. Schooled in Caldwell, NJ, she attended the Parson School of Design in New York City. Forced by circumstances to support herself at any early age she was hired by Time, Inc. first as a page and later, because of her artistic abilities and her presentation skills, she worked in the promotion department of Life magazine. She was married on January 30, 1954 and lived in Athens, GA, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, Shrewsbury, NJ and finally, Brunswick, ME. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Richard, and four daughters; Sandra, Allison, Gail and Ann. A fifth daughter, Leslie died of leukemia at age 10. She is also survived by her grandchildren; Brian, Carolyn, Tom, Scott, Duncan, Allison, Jasper, Olivia, Oliver, Meg and John who each loved their Nana as she loved them. Because of two back operations several years ago her mobility was limited but, as with other challenges in her life, she rose above the challenge and brought joy and kindness into many lives. She loved to read, cook, travel the world, follow the successes of family members and stay in touch with old friends. Fittingly, when she died she was browsing through a copy of The Flavor of Maine looking for a recipe for dinner. Her passing leaves an enormous void in the lives of every member of her family and all her friends. No one who knew her could help but recall her smile, her sense of humor, her wisdon, her compassion and her good advice on matters large and small. A Memorial service will be private. Donations in Valerie's memory may be made to Camp Sunshine, a retreat for children with life threatening illnesses and their families, 35 Acadia Road, Casco Bay, ME 04015 or the Curtis Memorial Library, 23 Pleasant Street, Brunswick, ME 04011.

KEATING--Richard P.,MD, 91, August 3, 2014. Born and raised in Manhattan, a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University, Colum- bia University College of Physicians & Surgeons. Survived by Barbara, his wife of 66 years; brother Paul Keating, MD, five children, 11 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Served as Captain in the United States Army stationed in New Mexico at the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Practiced internal medicine for 33 years in Ridgewood, NJ and at the Valley Hospital and led the New York St. Luke's Hospital thyroid clinic. Past President of the Bergen County Medical Society. Retired to Truro, MA and served as Truro Board of Selectmen Chairman, Planning Board Chairman and Truro Public Library Trustee.

KATZ--Edward. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend, colleague and Chairman Edward Katz and extend our warmest sympathies to his wife, Connie; his children, Michael, Randi, Nanci and Toni; their spouses Jackie, Steven, Craig and Darren and his 11 grandchildren. We also extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wonderful extended family and many friends. We will always remember him as the founder of Choice Logistics and for the support and guidance he provided to us over the past 50 years.

KATZ--Edward. All of us at Perelson Weiner extend our thoughts, prayers and deepest sympathies to the family of Ed Katz as we mourn the loss of our long-time friend and client. He was an astute observer of human behavior and a businessman of great vision. He will be missed by all those whose lives he touched. He bravely fought his illness for years with dignity and strength and remained as always, a loving husband, father and grandfather. We will dearly miss Ed, and sincerely hope that his family will be greatly comforted by their memories of him. Ed was a kind, generous and highly principled man who treasured his family. Please accept our respects.

KATZ--Edward (Eddie). The family of Edward (Eddie) Katz, 82, is deeply saddened by his death on August 20, 2014. Loving, adoring husband of Connie, proud father of Michael and Jackie, Randi and Steven, Nanci and Craig, Toni and Darren and amazing grandfather of David, Richard, Evan, Jordan, Annie, Jake, Max, Harry, Karli, Sami, and Jessi, and older brother to Stanley and Judy. Everyone knew that there was nothing more important to Eddie than his family. He taught us all so many great lessons. He also touched many others with his wisdom about life and about people. Although he suffered greatly with his illness, he never stopped having a positive attitude. We are comforted by the fact that he is "just resting". Donations in Eddie's memory can be made to Boys Town Jerusalem: www.boystownjerusalem.org. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 10am, Friday, August 22nd, 180 W. 76th Street.

HERMAN--Paula. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Paula Herman. She leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Paula's husband, Stuart; her children, Erica (Eric) Schwartz and Dana (Joe) Covey; her grandchildren, Rebecca and Danny Schwartz and Rachel and Evan Covey; her siblings, Herb (Rhea) and Mitchell (Terry) Rosenfeld; sister-in-law Sandy (Dale) Elledge; & the entire extended family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

HERMAN--Paula A. (Rosenfeld), peacefully at home on August 20. Beloved wife of 55 years to Stuart, mother of Erica (Eric) Schwartz and Dana (Joe) Covey, grandmother of Rebecca and Danny Schwartz and Rachel and Evan Covey. Sister of Herb (Rhea) and Mitchell (Terry) Rosenfeld, sister-in-law of Sandy (Dale) Elledge. Cherished aunt, great-aunt, cousin, colleague and friend. Paula grew up in Brooklyn and Queens. A 1960 graduate of Pratt Institute, she worked in advertising for more than 50 years in partnership with her husband. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to a fund in her memory.

HELLER--Caroline Watkins, died at home on Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, NY last Sunday night August 17th, 2014. She was surrounded by loved ones and had a chance to say goodbye to her grandchildren and children. Caro was a force of creativity and love. She was born in Paris where her father was a partner at JP Morgan, and from which she fled the War at age five. She attended Brearley, Garrison Forest, and earned a BA from Sarah Lawrence, Class of '56. She studied painting in Paris when she was twenty-one, and was a prolific and accomplished sculptor who had a successful exhibit at the Atlantic Gallery in 1982. She was the founder of the scholarship program at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights, and as its director worked tirelessly for many years to diversify the student body. She was a combat pistol shooter, earning certification from the Lethal Force Institute in New Hampshire. She worked for a private eye doing stake-outs. She and her husband, Lowell P. Beveridge, became adept at investigation, and worked pro bono to reunite over eighty birth families split apart by adoption. She was once hired by the FBI to bring in a fraud perpetrator and chased him through Connecticut in her old Volvo. She brought him in. She loved Haiti, where she visited often, and whose culture inspired much of her art. She created community wherever she went, and was a cherished mentor to many lost souls. She has been credited with saving several lives. She was a beautiful skier and rider, and loved to roller blade. In later years, she was wild about her six grandchildren who adore her beyond measure. They are Caila and Cammi French, Zoe Heller, Ines Manuel, and Rachel and Pierson Beveridge. She is also survived by her husband Pete Beveridge, her former husband John Heller, and their children Peter Heller, Leslie Heller-Manuel, and Callie French; by her stepson Jesse Beveridge; by her sons-in-law John French and JP Manuel; and by her daughters-in-law Kim Yan and Briana Beveridge; also by other family members Robby and Lisa French; and by the family's dear friend Marie St. Juste.

GUDAS--Eleanor Bogden, 89, of Syracuse, NY, on August 16, 2014. Beloved and caring wife of Albert J. Gudas for 67 years; proud mother of Dr. Lorraine J. Gudas (Dr. John Wagner) and Celeste Gudas (Stuart Kagel); adored grandmother of Gregory Wagner, and Eleanor, James, and Katherine Kagel. "Unable are the loved to die. For love is immortality ..." (Emily Dickinson). We love you and miss you, mom. Lorraine and Celeste Gudas

GIMMA--Licia Albanese. The Trustees and Staff of the Bagby Foundation for the Musical Arts mourn the loss of our beloved and esteemed Licia Albanese, who served tirelessly on the Foundation since joining it as a Trustee in 1960. We thank you, Licia, for your guidance, good humor, charm and impeccable taste. The operatic world has lost a giant, and we have lost a friend. We extend our deepest condolences to Licia's son, Joseph, and his wife, Maria. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman, Blanche Lark Christerson, President, and J. Andrew Lark, Executive Director.

FROMMER--Edith, died peacefully on August 22, 2014 at her home and in her 68th year. Daughter of the late Eleanor Jeannette and Barney Frommer, she is survived by her brothers Henry and Morris, her sisters-in-law Cheryl and Barbara, and her niece and nephews, Kate and David, Robert, Greg and Michael. She was a woman of valor, having fought her illness of multiple sclerosis for 46 years. Funeral services will take place on Monday August 25th at 9:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Ave.

FRITZE--Gunther E.A.,died August 21, 2014, age 78, while biking on Fishers Island. Beloved husband of Anita W. Fritze, devoted father of Mary E. F. Pollard, Johannes P. Fritze and Liese F. Brown, proud father-in-law of Chip, Camilla and Dave, "Papi" to seven grandchildren. Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, September 13th at 3pm, Church of the Redeemer, 379 Hammond Street, Chestnut Hill, MA 02467.

FRIEDMAN--Harry (Harold) K.,on August 7, 2014, of Boynton Beach, FL; formerly of the Bronx, NY, Cedarhurst, NY and White Meadow Lake, NJ. Born in 1923, Harold attended DeWitt Clinton High School and was a track star. Pearl Harbor was bombed while Harold was attending City College, and he immediately enlisted (needing his parents' permission because he was underage). Placing first in his class at Master Gunner School, he served as a Warrant Officer in the 9th Air Defense Command, 231 AAA Searchlight Battalion, specializing in reconnaissance. A problem solver, Harold single-handedly devised a mathematical solution to enable pilots to land at night. Previously, medium bomber pilots had been flying only daylight missions and there were heavy casualties. His solution saved hundreds and hundreds of lives of pilots who were now able to fly night missions without being seen by the enemy. After WWII, he married his sweetheart, Toby Nevins, the great love of his life for 53 years. President of A. Friedman & Co., a manufacturing jewelry firm in lower Manhattan, he was an exacting artist, taking pride in the craftsmanship of each piece. Harold was a brilliant raconteur and a light in the world, finding the humor in everything, lightening everyone's mood, refusing to say or hear anything negative about anyone. He loved music, especially from the big band era, sang in a choral group for many years, and was a wonderful dancer. He loved to laugh and to make others laugh, particularly at the bowling alley or over a spirited game of cards. Harold loved his family and was adored by them. He passed peacefully in his sleep, as gracefully as he lived. A unique man of warmth, integrity and humor, Harold has left a piece of himself in every heart that he touched through his long and loving life. He is reunited with his Toby. Harold is survived by daughters Lydia Jacobs (Jon) of Plantation, FL, and Nancy Friedman (Steve Posner) of Evergreen, CO; grandchildren Scott Golden, Melanie Golden (Glenn Hamburg), Jolie Portnoy (Bryan), Jay Jacobs (Kristin), Jared Jacobs, Daniel Friedman-Posner; and great-grandchildren Joshua, Isabella, Jeremy, and Jase.

FRIEDBERG--Maurice. Beloved father and grandfather died August 15, 2014 in Washington, DC at age 84. Born in Rzeszow, Poland, to Isaac and Ida (nee Jam) Friedberg. Preceded in death by loving wife Barbara (nee Bisguier) and dear brother Simon. Eminent scholar of Russian literature and Soviet culture at Indiana University and the University of Illinois. Legendary raconteur, proud Jew and Zionist. Survived by daughters Rachel (David Weil) and Edna (Stig Trommer), and grandchildren Ariel, Yoni, Tamar, Isaac, and Noam. Donations to Jewish Braille Institute or Leket Israel Food Bank.

DUBINER--Matthew. With great sadness and love, the family of Matthew announces his passing on August 20. Devoted husband to Madelyn, adoring father to Julie and Eric and "awesome" PopPop to Ben, Sam and Solomon. Above all, Matt was a caring educator to countless students. He inspired all who knew him. Services to be held at 12noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations may be made in Matt's memory to North Shore LIJ Lung Cancer Program, 125 Community Dr., Great Neck, NY 11021.
CONNOLLY--John P.,aged 67, died in Sausalito, CA. August 1. Founded Modern Sailing School. He is survived by Kevin, Cynthia and Brian.

CHENEY--Kathleen Sprowl, died on August 10, 2014. The Trustees and staff of Flight Attendant Medical Research Institute, Inc., (FAMRI), express our deepest sorrow to the family of FAMRI Trustee Kathleen Sprowl Cheney on her death. A former Eastern Airlines Flight Attendant from 1968 to 1988, she committed her life to make the world a safer place. Kathie was born in Miami, FL and was a resident of Peachtree City, GA, for more than 20 years until her death. She is survived by her beloved husband, Kevin; her loving son, Patrick; her devoted step-son Tom Cheney; caring sisters, Patricia Pallon, Joann Anthony, Mary Mosley and Denise Bamonte and their husbands, as well as numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. Many enjoyed the pleasure of Kathie's company and are inspired by her enthusiasm. Her generosity, dedication and friendship will be sorely missed.

CARNEY--David, UN economist, died in Southampton, NY, on May 8, 2014. He earned five degrees, between 1945 and 1952. His early career included high school teacher, high school headmaster in Ghana, and statistician in the Nigerian government. He arrived in the U.S. in 1953, from Sierra Leone, for a professorship at Lincoln University. He also taught at Fairleigh Dickinson University, Franklin & Marshall and Antioch colleges; and earned a Ph.D. He returned to Sierra Leone as government Economic Advisor, starting in 1961. Between 1963 and 1984, he worked in West Africa, East Africa, and the West Indies, through the UN agencies of UNDP, WHO, and FAO. He authored several books on economics, philosophy, religion, and a literary memento mori to his wife Helen, after her death in 1976. He was a member of Beta Gamma Sigma, Rotary International, and lifetime member of the Royal Economic Society. He retired to Long Island, NY in 1985, to pursue many interests, including collecting books ranging from alternative medicine to philosophy. In this electronic age, Dr. Carney's personal mission was preservation of the written word. He was always ready with a word of advice for those close to him; writing regular letters to the editor, for those farther afield. He was predeceased by his second wife Ellen, and is survived by two children, and two grandchildren. A Celebration of Life will be held at the Bridgehampton Senior Center on August 28, 2014 at 11:00am. The family suggests donations to the Bridgehampton Senior Center in Bridgehampton, NY, the John Jermain Library in Sag Harbor, or UNICEF. Condolences may be posted on the obituary webpage of Yardley & Pino Funeral Home.
BLOCK--Robert C. A thousand memories are embedded in our hearts. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend. Harriet and Larry Feldman and Family
BLOCK--Robert. Goodbye dear friend. I hope you remembered to take your fishing gear with you. Much Love, Bobby and Gunther

BLOCK--Robert Charles, age 83, of New York, NY. Son of Dorothy and Joseph Block, graduate of PS6, Horace Mann Lincoln and Wharton. With his late brother, Jay Block, he started the Block China Corporation. A devoted husband to Judith, father to Joshua and Andrew, father-in-law to Allison and Laura and proud grandfather of five. Known for his zest for life and sense of adventure combined with his loyalty to his friends and family. Avid angler who loved to fish the waters from Maine to the Florida Keys. A true gentleman, his passing will be felt by countless family, friends and business associates. The family will sit Shiva at 215 East 68th St on Monday and Tuesday between 5-8pm. Donations to the Westchester Reform Synagogue or charity of your choice.

BERNSTEIN--Sidney B.,passed away on August 17th, 2014 from complications of an auto accident. Sid was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and City College of Engineering. He was an explosives developer at Picatinany Arsenal for 35 years. His wife Joan died in 2005. He is survived by his brother Richard Bernstein. Richard Bernstein

BERLAND--Kenneth K. died on July 25th, 2014. He was 91. Ken is survived by his beloved wife of 69 years, Gloria; daughter, Elizabeth Anne Berland Dundov; son-in-law, Michael Dundov; and daughter-in-law, Laura Toups. He is preceded in death by his son, Alan Lance Berland; sisters, Martha, Mildred and Doris; and brothers, Oscar, and Seymour. For extended obituary and to sign the guest book go to www.legacy.com

RITTER--Anthony B. Sr.,of New York City owner of the Barbizon Lingerie Corporation and Jaunty Textiles. Beloved husband, father, friend and mentor passed away on August 22nd 2014 at the age of 87 in Manhattan. Mr. Ritter attended the Eaglebrook School, Phillips Academy Andover and graduated from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania where he made many lifelong friends. After Wharton, Tony joined his family business in New York City and Barbizon Lingerie became one of the most recognizable and respected labels throughout the United States. Mr. Ritter was a member of Old Oaks Country Club of Purchase, NY where he sat on the board and The Harmonie Club of Manhattan. Throughout his life Tony was known for his wit and humor. He will be missed by his loving wife Sherry Ritter, his son Anthony Ritter Jr. his daughter Elizabeth Samuelson and his two beloved Spinones, Vito and Luca. Services Tuesday 11:30am at the Riverside 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Interment at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, LI. Memorial contributions to NYU Cancer Institute, 160 E. 34th Street, NY. NY 10016. Attn: Dr. Abraham Chacho.

NUSSBAUM--Helen C.,(nee Coble) 86, died peacefully on August 23, 2014 in Delray Beach, Florida. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Helen was preceded in death by her devoted husband of 57 years, Dr. Arnold Nussbaum. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Ruth and Gerald Fogel of Bellmore, NY. A beloved mother to her children and their spouses, Jack and Jolie, Paul and Johnnie, Robert and Barbara, and Burt and Andrea and many loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Known for her love of music and teaching, she is fondly remembered as a wonderful second grade teacher for countless children in Mill Basin, Brooklyn. "Unable are the loved to die. For love is immortality" Emily Dickinson.

MUNROE--George B.,who led the copper mining and manufacturing company Phelps Dodge Corporation from 1969 to 1987, died painlessly and peacefully in his sleep on August 19. Munroe led Phelps Dodge through a difficult period for the domestic copper mining industry, as it struggled to meet growing competition from abroad and new environmental requirements at home. Munroe continued to increase the company's production as a new hydro-metallurgical process was developed to reduce the need for smelting in the production process and Phelps Dodge, which had been the third largest United States copper producer, emerged as the domestic industry leader and one of the largest producers in the world. Before joining Phelps Dodge, Munroe practiced law in New York as an associate with Cravath, Swain and Moore and Debevoise, Plimpton and McLean and worked in the Office of the U.S. High Commissioner for Germany in the early 1950's, serving first in Bonn as a lawyer and later in Nuremberg as a justice of the U.S Court of Restitution Appeals of the Allied High Commission. Munroe was a trustee of Dartmouth College for 14 years and the chairman of its board for three years. He was also a trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, serving on several of it's committees for 25 years, and chairing the Museum's finance committee for 8 years. Other board memberships included the Henry Street Settlement, the YMCA of Greater New York and the Academy of Political Science, of which he was chairman for 10 years. He was a director of several major corporations, including the New York Life Insurance Company, the Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical banks, the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, Manville Corporation and New York Times Company and was a Public Governor of the New York Stock Exchange. His service in the Navy during World War II included duty as a combat information center officer on the battleship Maryland in the Pacific. The Maryland took part in the invasion of Okinawa in 1945, where it survived damage from Kamikazi plane attacks. As a young man, Munroe was an outstanding basketball player on three Ivy League championship teams at Dartmouth and led Dartmouth to the national championship game of the N.C.A.A. tournament in 1942. That year, he led the Eastern Intercollegiate League in scoring and was named to several All-America Teams. Later, while attending Harvard Law School, he played in the professional league for the St. Louis Bombers and Boston Celtics. Munroe graduated from Dartmouth College and Harvard Law School with honors and from Oxford University in England where he was a Rhodes Scholar. Munroe is survived by his wife of more than 45 years, Elinor Bunin Munroe, an artist and award-wining film maker, and by two sons by a previous marriage, Ralph of Orange, Virginia and Taylor of Atenas, Costa Rica and a grandson, Zachary. Mr. Munroe decided not to have a funeral or memorial service. Contributions may be made to the George B. Munroe Scholarship Fund at Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH 03755 or to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10021 in lieu of flowers or condolences.

OLSON--Eric Scott, age 45, of Ridgewood, died August 23, 2014. Beloved husband of Angela, loving father of Andrew and Macrae and devoted son of Robert and Jane Olson. Eric was born in Vermont, raised primarily in Ringwood, NJ and a proud Ridgewood resident for the last 15 years. He was a 1991 graduate of Boston College, where he met Angela. Eric spent his entire career since college with Northwestern Mutual. He was the Managing Partner of the Olson Financial Group with Northwestern Mutual in Morristown, NJ. He was involved in many charities including The Stuttering Association for the Young, NJ SEEDS and the annual Far Hills Benefit. Visiting Thursday 2-4pm and 7-9pm, at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood. Friday services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Stuttering Association for the Young (www.say.org), 330 W. 42d St. 12th Flr., New York, NY 10036. www.feeneyfuneralhome.com.

MUNROE--George B. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of George Munroe, a treasured Trustee since 1975 and Trustee Emeritus since 1998. He was a valued leader, advisor, and colleague, whose varied and distinguished career in government service, law, and business, along with his sterling character and judgment, informed his participation in his many involvements at the Met. Over the years, he served as chairman of the finance and employee benefits committees, and was an active member of additional committees including those dedicated to investments, legal matters, and merchandising. He also chaired the newly formed business committee from 1977 to 1980. Together with his beloved wife Ellie, he supported generously the Museum's membership program and the Fund for the Met campaign. We will deeply miss George's integrity, humility, warmth, and friendship, and send condolences to Ellie and to his entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President

LICHTENSTEIN--Marjorie R. A most elegant lady passed away peacefully August 25th. Goodbye old friend. May you rest in peace. Paula, Fran & Betty

In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Wounded Warrior Project.

LANDIS--Donald M.,of White Plains, NY, born May 24, 1929 in New York, NY. Died peacefully on August 24, 2014. Son of Lucille (Neuman) and Aaron Landis; brother of the late Leonard R. Landis. Married for 56 years to Betsy Miller Landis. Adoring and adored father to Ellen Miller Landis and Lisa Thompson, Maggie Neuman Landis, and David Aaron and Becky (Chamberlain) Landis. Warm and witty grandfather of Ruth, Millie and Martin Landis. Practicing lawyer and businessman; more importantly, activist with many Jewish and community organizations. Past President of Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, Performing Arts Center of Purchase College, American Jewish Committee (Westchester) and Westchester Jewish Council. Long-time Executive Committee member of the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College. He is a past board member of American Friends of Tel Aviv Museum of Art, CLAL, and Westchester Jewish Community Services. Proud alumnus of Camp Winnebago, Phillips Academy in Andover, Harvard College and Law School. Officer for the US Air Force Judge Advocate General. In 1965, worked with Lawyers Constitutional Defense Committee as a civil rights attorney in Jonesboro, Louisiana. Funeral services will be at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains, NY on Tuesday, August 26 at 1:30pm. In his memory the family would appreciate contributions to Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, New Israel Fund and American Jewish World Service.

FLYER--Augusta. In memory of our beloved sister Augie. Arlene and Lester Pollack and Family

FERGUSON--Fred T. Fred T. Ferguson, journalist, editor, and public relations professional died on Friday at New York Presbyterian Medical Center. He was eighty-two. A graduate of New York Military Academy, Ferguson, a veteran newsman with wide experience, began his career as a stringer on Pacific Stars and Stripes during the Korean War covering the southern Japanese Islands. In 1956, Ferguson began at United Press International as a copyboy, and worked his way up through the ranks of reporter and editor at bureaus in Jackson, MS, Mineaola, NY, Trenton and Newark, NJ. He later served as Regional Executive for New Jersey, Eastern Pennsylvania and Delaware. One of his fondest memories was escorting former President Harry S. Truman on his daily walks. In 1980, Ferguson won the New York Press Association's News Feature Award for a series he wrote on the advent of robotics in the US. Twenty-seven years later, Ferguson went onto begin his second career in Public Relations. After eight years at DAY (now Olgivy PR), PR Newswire hired him to coach their clients writing press releases. Public speaking expert, Dorothy Sarnoff, trained Ferguson to speak across the country on "Writing press releases editors will notice." A favorite phrase of his was: "Now I'm a flack instead of a hack!" Never retiring, he went on to start his own consulting company: Fred-Editing Help, after leaving PR Newswire at the age of 77. To say he loved his work would be understatement. A great story teller, Ferguson spoke last spring at the National Hemophilia Foundation's Annual Soiree where he was honored for his work on the board. An energetic person, who continued to be motivated by his longtime girlfriend, Gloria Marti, Ferguson danced, skied, played tennis, ice skated, traveled extensively and was an avid opera and theater goer. He also raised his two children by himself, for the most part, at a time when that was not the norm. His son, Dr. Robert Ferguson of Paxton, MA survives him as well as his daughter, former Mayor, Lisa Uchrin of Lebanon, NJ, his granddaughter, Kyla Ferguson of Leeds, MA and his two grandsons, Zachary Ferguson of Boston, MA and George Uchrin, age 14. He was their beloved "Pop Pop." In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association. Visitation with the family will be held at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. on Friday, August 29, 2014 from 7-9:00pm.

BUNIS--Andrea, 57, peacefully after a 14 month battle with pancreatic cancer. Born and raised in the Bronx, she was a resident of Manhattan for the last three decades. Survived by the love of her life and companion of 42 years, Harvey Rudman. Beloved daughter of Joan and George, admired aunt to nephews Kris, Matt, Henry and niece Priya. Predeceased by her brother Stephen. She founded Andrea Bunis Management 30 years ago and grew it into one of New York City's leading residential management firms. Andrea was a senior real estate account executive with the Kriesel Company. Serving as a director and manager, she represented various sponsors, developers and investors. Andrea was the recipient of numerous industry awards, including Habitat Magazine's Management Award for Manager of the Year. She was admired for her energy, independence and strong will. Andrea achieved her Bachelor's in Business Administration from Lehman College-CUNY and attended New York University's Real Estate institute where, as a New York State licensed real estate broker, she shared her extensive knowledge as a senior staff instructor. She was a member of the Real Estate Board of New York (REBNY), Professional Women in Construction, (PWC) and Association of Real Estate Women (AREW). Andrea was a varsity athlete in volleyball and swimming and was the Shorehaven Club woman's paddleball champion for four consecutive years. She earned the PSAL's Louisa Wingate Underhill Award given to the most outstanding female athlete in New York City and was a devoted and loyal New York Giant's and Knicks fan. She enjoyed cooking and was great at it. She liked skiing Aspen, Vail and visiting Florida with her family. She also loved boating on the East End. She was a classic movie buff and enjoyed Broadway musicals and music. Andrea enjoyed driving her Landcruiser ever since a test drive 23 years ago. Andrea loved and was totally devoted to her family and staff. She was a beautiful soul and a once in a lifetime individual taken too early from her heartbroken family. Graveside service Wednesday, August 27, 11am at King David Cemetery.

BROADWIN--Stanley. It is with great sadness that the family of Stanley announce his death of AML on August 24, 2014. Devoted husband and best friend of Judith for almost 60 years. Very adoring and proud father of Dr. Beth (Dr. Robert) Belkin and Sharon (Harold) Lorman. Loving and beloved grandpa to Dr. Daniel, Samuel and Molly Belkin, and Hannah and Bess Lorman. Dear brother of Arlene (George) Toscano and dear brother-in-law of Peggy (Irwin) Lewis and Susan Barlow. Possessing a great sense of humor and making many friends everywhere, Stanley will be greatly missed. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, located at 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC on Tuesday at 11am. Interment 1pm at Beth David Cemetery. In memory of Stanley, donations may be made to T and V Synagogue or Calvary Hospital.

BERSON--Frances Grace (Fran). Beloved wife of Abe z"l, devoted mother of Tom and Andy, mother-in-law of Dorothy, grandmother, great-grandmother, and aunt to many. Fran loved Tranquillity Camp, friendsofty.org. Services Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, Tuesday, 12 noon.

BATTI--Gerard V.,73, of Naples, FL and Austerlitz, NY, formerly of Bedford, NY, passed away suddenly on August 22. Gerard was born to Nancy Leto and James Batti in the Bronx. He is survived by his wife Phyllis of 50 years and his three children; Lisa Muoio and her husband Frank, Dr. James Batti and his wife Holly, and Alaina Pratley and her husband Preston. He also has six grandchildren: Michael, Kevin, Noelle, Julia, Jack, and Luke. He is also survived by a brother, James Batti, Jr and his wife Rosemary of Wyckoff, NJ. Gerard will be dearly missed. Gerard worked for UMEX Company in Greenwich, CT, a division of Unilever for 27 years with the last 17 years serving as President. During his retirement, he enjoyed hunting, fishing, boating, and spending time with his loving family and friends. The family will receive friends on Monday, August 25 from 5:00-9:00pm at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11:00am on Tuesday, August 26 at St. Michael the Archangel RC Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. Entombment will follow at St. Mary's Mausoleum, Greenwich. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Cancer and Wellness Center, Northern Westchester Hospital, 400 E Main St, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549.

SLOANE--Virginia. The Trustees and Staff of the Heckscher Foundation for Children mourn the passing of their esteemed Trustee and President Emeritus, Virginia Sloane. Ginnie served as a Trustee for nearly 40 years, and as President from 1986. Her commitment to underserved children and families has helped tens of thousands realize their dreams for generations. We will miss her wisdom, judgment and leadership. Heckscher Foundation for Children

SLOANE--Virginia. Philanthropist and civic leader, died on August 24, 2014 after a lengthy illness. She was 91 and lived in Larchmont, New York and Manhattan. Virginia, known to all as "Ginnie", was elected President of the Heckscher Foundation for Children in 1986 and presided over its affairs for many years. In 2012, she became President Emeritus. Under her leadership the Foundation provided funding to many of the leading social service programs and cultural institutions in New York and elsewhere in support of its mission to level the playing field for underserved youth by providing access to education and experiences that make for a richer, more forward-reaching life. Grantees have included the Boy Scouts of America, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Central Park Conservancy, Citizens' Committee for Children, Citizen Schools, Community Service Society of New York, Coalition for the Homeless, Covenant House, De La Salle Academy, The Doe Fund, The Fresh Air Fund, Girls Educational and Mentoring Services, Harlem RBI, Henry Street Settlement, Jazz at Lincoln Center, National Dance Institute, NPower, New York City Center, New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, The New York Pops, Opportunities for a Better Tomorrow, Perez Art Museum Miami, The Public Theater, Prep for Prep, Reading Partners, Seedco, Success Charter Network, Taproot Foundation, Teach for America, Tipping Point Community, and Wounded Warrior Project. In 2003 she was honored by United Cerebral Palsy at its "Women Who Care Hall-of Fame" gala. She was an accomplished pianist and an avid tap dancer who studied under some of the leading figures in the arts, including Charles "Honi" Coles. As the Founder of the National Dance Institute, Jacques d'Amboise, said: "Virginia realized that children are everything, and they deserve the best that we can give them. Being with her, I felt the sunlight got a little bit brighter, and the shadows on the moon diminished." She is survived by her two children, Gail Sloane Meyers (Andrew Hall) and Peter Sloane (Jaar-mel Sevin Sloane), five grandchildren, Hilary Azrael, (Josh Gurewitsch), Kate Meyers (Jonathan Etra), Nessia Sloane Kushner (Taylor Kushner), Alex Sloane and Jake Sloane, and four great grandchildren, Zachary and Molly Azrael, and Lilly and Annabelle Etra. A private funeral will be held for family members. A memorial will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to an organization of the donor's choosing which serves the interests of children in need.

SIMSON--Walter A.,Jr., a long-time Westchester resident, died peacefully in Newton, MA on August 22, 2014 with his wife and daughter at his side. He was 95. He was born on July 6, 1919, graduated from Roosevelt High School in Yonkers and attended Colgate (class of 41) before enlisting. He served in the Army 4th Malaria Survey unit in the Philippines and New Guinea, seeing action in Leyte. He graduated from Columbia in 1949. He started Rolls Offset Printing Co. where he promoted roll-fed printing for magazine, book and direct mail uses. He obtained several patents for in-line gluing, converting and embossing. He was a talented violinist, and was founding president of the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester, performing with soloists such as Yehudi Menuin and Emmanuel Ax in concerts held at Mt. Vernon High School. He lost his sight to Retinitus but continued to live a full life, working into his mid-70's. He had season tickets to both the Metropolitan Opera and the Philharmonic. He also enjoyed recorded science lectures and working on his 1949 Plymouth and 1985 Mercedes. Despite his blindness, he had an amazing sense of direction and for years walked to his appointments in Manhattan unaided. His family finally convinced him to get a cane, which he habitually left on the train. This left friends wondering about the reaction of the Metro North lost and found department, which saw periodic build-ups of white canes in inventory. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Victoria; his son Walter (wife-Valerie); Daughter Nancy (husband-Brian) and four grandsons (Chip, Will, Teddy and Charlie) to whom he was a devoted and much-loved grandfather. He lived independently, with optimism, intelligence and great good humor until his last weeks. His ashes will be scattered in the surf at Montauk. http://www.nytimes.com/ 2009/12/06/automobiles/ collectibles/06EGO.html

ROSENBLUM--Beth, on August 24 of Fearrington, Pittsboro, NC formerly of Wyckoff, NJ. Wife of 50 years of R. Jerry Rosenblum, daughter of the late Jack and Betty Wieder, survived by daughters Jill and Lori (David), granddaughters Zoe and Isabella, brother Ronald (Laurie), brother-in-law Bill (Linda). A Hunter graduate, MS and Ed. D from Columbia, Active in the Jewish community, and a founder of Temple Beth Rishon, Wyckoff. Graveside services Wednesday, August 27th Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ at 11:30am.

ROBERTS--Florence, died peacefully at home on June 1, 2014. Beloved wife of Moss; adored and admired mother of Sean and Jenny. In her work over three decades as a Legal Services attorney and Family Law Unit Director, she represented indigent clients in domestic violence, custody, and divorce cases. She also did volunteer work with incarcerated women in family law. She fought for her clients based on a keen sense of justice and injustice and compassion for the cruelties that poverty inflicts on them. She was an inspiration to her children, both of whom pursued careers in law, and to her colleagues (veteran and junior), who turned to her for advice and who responded to her dynamic personality. She leaves a major legacy in the field of law, but also in the field of medicine, having participated in an epigenetic trial for the treatment of leukemia, to which she finally succumbed. A celebration of her life will be held on September 13, starting 11am, at the Kimmel Center of NYU, Rosenthal Hall. To honor her life's work, our family has established a fund in her name at the Women's Prison Association. The donation link is: http://www.wpaonline.org/ content/florence-roberts-memorial-fund

PACE--Michael. Extraordinary performer, founder of the singing group Gotham, composer - lyricist - playwright, graphic designer and teacher. Surviving partner of 25 years with Alan Alpert. Beloved sibling, godfather and fabulous friend to multitudes.

ORTEGA--Noel, 79, of Pawling, NY. Died August 10. Retired Professor of Spanish and Portuguese. Much loved by his students, friends, family and spouse. He was a beautiful man and a true gentleman. He had a remarkable life. Memorial service is planned. josephdconnors@yahoo.com

NEFF--Edwin J.,95, born in Richmond Hill, Queens, NY, with his daily "To Do List" in his pocket, died suddenly in his home on July 4, 2014. During WWII he served in the United States Army Air Force in Pakistan. A graduate of St. Francis Prep, he started working at 17 when his young father died after a long illness. He helped his mother provide for his younger brother and two sisters. While employed by the U.S. Air Force after the War, his young wife, Mary Edith Hogan, died in 1959. He never remarried. In spite of these challenging moments he never complained, never despaired. He forged a career in the new Aero Photo Reconnaissance Industry. His dedication led to corporate Sales Executive, and Marketing Vice President positions for leading corporations serving the U.S. Military. Having lived almost a century, Ed met reality with humor, perseverance and common sense. Never a bad word, always a smile with a helping hand. Although he was a member of numerous Trade Associations and Clubs, his favorites were The White House News Photographers Association and The New York Athletic Club. He is survived by his younger sister, Winnifred Faughnan of Oakland, CA; his son Edwin Neff Jr., and a granddaughter Adrienne Justine Neff, both of New York City. A private Veterans Service will take place in September at Cypress Hills Cemetery. Memorial gifts in his name may be sent to Catholic Charities or United Jewish Appeal.

MOREIRA--Marcio. McCann mourns the passing of Marcio Moreira, former Vice Chairman of McCann Worldgroup. He was a highly accomplished, much-honored industry leader, including being named Advertising Professional of the Century. His remarkable career began as a film projectionist for McCann in his native Brazil. He rose quickly to writer/producer posts in London, Lisbon, Copenhagen and Frankfurt, became Creative Director for all of Latin America and later for many years was McCann's Worldwide Chief Creative Officer, leading work on many of the agency's global accounts and winning hundreds of awards. In addition to his creative role, for four years he also headed McCann's Asia-Pacific operations. He then became Vice Chairman, Chief Talent Officer, a tribute to his understanding of the people and talent of the business. He retired in 2011 after 44 years. Elegantly fluent in several languages, he authored books of poetry in Portuguese and was a recorded lyricist, collaborating with top-notch jazz and bossa nova composers. He most recently served as Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Berlin School of Creative Leadership and as a lecturer-at-large at the Miami Ad School. He resided in Chatham, NJ and is survived by his wife Maria Moreira, daughter Eliana Moreira, son Joaquim Moreira, a grandson Lucas Moreira and granddaughter, Marina Moreira. A private Memorial Service will be held on September 4.

LOWENSTEIN--Ruth, 101, died at home on August 20th. She fled Germany at 25 arrived here and fell in love with NYC where she lived a long, active life. Loving wife of Harry, mother of Steven Hartman, amazing grand- mother to Dave and Gabbie, best ever mother-in-law!

LANDIS--Donald. The board of governors of the Reconstructionist Rab- binical College/Jewish Reconstructionist Communities mourns the death of long-time board member Don Landis, who helped to build the Reconstructionist movement in North America, Israel and at Congregation Bet Am Shalom. We extend condolences to Betsy Landis, their children Ellen, Maggie and David, and their families. Don's memory surely will be a blessing. David Roberts, Chair; Rabbi Deborah Waxman, President

LANDIS--Donald M.,of White Plains, NY, born May 24, 1929 in New York, NY. Died peacefully on August 24, 2014. Son of Lucille (Neuman) and Aaron Landis; brother of the late Leonard R. Landis. Married for 56 years to Betsy Miller Landis. Adoring and adored father to Ellen Miller Landis and Lisa Thompson, Maggie Neuman Landis, and David Aaron and Becky (Chamberlain) Landis. Warm and witty grandfather of Ruth, Millie and Martin Landis. Practicing lawyer and businessman; more importantly, activist with many Jewish and community organizations. Past President of Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, Performing Arts Center of Purchase College, American Jewish Committee (Westchester) and Westchester Jewish Council. Long-time Executive Committee member of the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College. He is a past board member of American Friends of Tel Aviv Museum of Art, CLAL, and Westchester Jewish Community Services. Proud alumnus of Camp Winnebago, Phillips Academy in Andover, Harvard College and Law School. Officer for the US Air Force Judge Advocate General. In 1965, worked with Lawyers Constitutional Defense Committee as a civil rights attorney in Jonesboro, Louisiana. Funeral services will be at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains, NY on Tuesday, August 26 at 1:30pm. In his memory the family would appreciate contributions to Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, New Israel Fund and American Jewish World Service.

JAMROG--Sandra, died on May 29, 2014. A memorial service was held at her home and she was cremated on June 1. She is survived by her husband Joe Jamrog, her children Jeff, Josh, Jennifer, and John, and her seven grandchildren. Ms. Jamrog was a childbirth, parenting, and movement educator, and practioner of Body-Mind Centering developed by Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen. A founder of the Childbirth Education Association New York, she studied dance with Eric Hawkins and Mary Anthony. Her love of horses led her to become a horse massage therapist and instructor and she found great joy in riding and training her horse. Her passion for learning continued until her last days. She was a well-known vessel of knowledge and helped many people with her advice and welcoming ear. She was deeply committed to her work, dearly beloved and is greatly missed by her family and friends.

HASSENFELD--Sylvia. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of it's esteemed member, Sylvia Hassenfeld, and extends sincere sympathy to her children, grandchildren and other members of her family. William L. Mack, President; Warren J. Spector, Secretary

GEIGER--David M.,88, of Fort Lee, NJ and Boynton Beach, FL, passed away on August 25th after a long illness. For many years, David was a director at Kee-Wah Camps in Wingdale, NY, owned by his parents, Adolph and Ida Geiger. David taught at New Rochelle High School, was a Professor of History at Herbert Lehman College, a dean in the Education Department at Fairleigh Dickinson University, and Chairman of the Social Studies Department at Fairlawn High School, NJ. A graduate of Cornell University, David earned his masters and doctorate from Columbia University, and also studied at the Sorbonne. A scholar and natural raconteur, David was admired by all for his knowledge on a wide range of subjects. His gift for seamlessly weaving his erudition into absorbing stories-- and always with a dollop of humor-- was reflected in his lively conversations, and also in the doggerel poems he wrote for many happy occasions. His gentle wit and personable manner endeared him to countless students, colleagues, friends, and family. David leaves behind his wife Arlene Warren Geiger, of Fort Lee, NJ and Boynton Beach, FL, his sister and brother-in-law, Skitz and Norman J. Nichols, his son, Jonathan Geiger and wife, Jan, his daughter, Miriam Glassman and husband, Steven, his stepdaughters Diane Reppert and husband Paul, Jodi Magen and husband, Burt, his stepson, Richard Eggert and wife Elizabeth, son-in-law, Tim Reppert, and grandchildren, Emily, Julia, Stephanie, Sophia, Jessica, Hayley, Elyse and Sarah. A gift in his name may be made to Na'Amat (561-738-4708).
