BRISKIN--Andrew. February 24, 1968 - August 27, 2012. A very special son who departed too soon. You're in my heart and my thoughts every minute of the day. Love Dad

YORK--Scott Roland, 85, peacefully at home on August 18 after an illness that lasted either a weekend or a decade. Beloved by his wife, Alix Kates Shulman; daughter, Gwill York; son-in-law, Paul Maeder; grandsons, Paxton and Walker Maeder-York; stepchildren, Theodore and Polly Shulman. Born in Cleveland, OH, he attended Duke on scholarship, captaining the basketball team. He served in the Navy 1951-1955, then attended graduate school at Harvard on the GI Bill, first the School of Design, then the Business School, earning an MBA. With his first wife he had two children, Gwill and Frederick. In 1983, divorced, he tracked down his 1950 sweetheart, Alix, and lived happily with her for three decades. A member of the Explorers Club, he scaled mountains on five continents. He retired from a career in finance in 1987 to pursue art, exhibiting his sculpture in New York, Maine, and Hawaii. Despite a 2004 traumatic brain injury with progressive dementia, he retained his sweetness, charm, and loving nature to the end.
SLOANE--Virginia. New York has lost its sweetest angel and I've lost a wonderful friend. Marlene Fanta Shyer

SLOANE--Virginia. The Trustees and Staff of the Heckscher Foundation for Children mourn the passing of their esteemed Trustee and President Emeritus, Virginia Sloane. Ginnie served as a Trustee for nearly 40 years, and as President from 1986. Her commitment to underserved children and families has helped tens of thousands realize their dreams for generations. We will miss her wisdom, judgment and leadership. Heckscher Foundation for Children

SLOANE--Virginia. Philanthropist and civic leader, died on August 24, 2014 after a lengthy illness. She was 91 and lived in Larchmont, New York and Manhattan. Virginia, known to all as "Ginnie", was elected President of the Heckscher Foundation for Children in 1986 and presided over its affairs for many years. In 2012, she became President Emeritus. Under her leadership the Foundation provided funding to many of the leading social service programs and cultural institutions in New York and elsewhere in support of its mission to level the playing field for underserved youth by providing access to education and experiences that make for a richer, more forward-reaching life. Grantees have included the Boy Scouts of America, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Central Park Conservancy, Citizens' Committee for Children, Citizen Schools, Community Service Society of New York, Coalition for the Homeless, Covenant House, De La Salle Academy, The Doe Fund, The Fresh Air Fund, Girls Educational and Mentoring Services, Harlem RBI, Henry Street Settlement, Jazz at Lincoln Center, National Dance Institute, NPower, New York City Center, New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, The New York Pops, Opportunities for a Better Tomorrow, Perez Art Museum Miami, The Public Theater, Prep for Prep, Reading Partners, Seedco, Success Charter Network, Taproot Foundation, Teach for America, Tipping Point Community, and Wounded Warrior Project. In 2003 she was honored by United Cerebral Palsy at its "Women Who Care Hall-of Fame" gala. She was an accomplished pianist and an avid tap dancer who studied under some of the leading figures in the arts, including Charles "Honi" Coles. As the Founder of the National Dance Institute, Jacques d'Amboise, said: "Virginia realized that children are everything, and they deserve the best that we can give them. Being with her, I felt the sunlight got a little bit brighter, and the shadows on the moon diminished." She is survived by her two children, Gail Sloane Meyers (Andrew Hall) and Peter Sloane (Jaar-mel Sevin Sloane), five grandchildren, Hilary Azrael, (Josh Gurewitsch), Kate Meyers (Jonathan Etra), Nessia Sloane Kushner (Taylor Kushner), Alex Sloane and Jake Sloane, and four great grandchildren, Zachary and Molly Azrael, and Lilly and Annabelle Etra. A private funeral will be held for family members. A memorial will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to an organization of the donor's choosing which serves the interests of children in need.

PRICEMAN--Mark, a long time resident of Larchmont, NY, died peacefully at 1:00 on August 23, 2014. Mr. Priceman is survived by his loving wife of 57 years, Alla, his son Eric (Kathleen), their three children Zachary (Kelly), Mark and Kristina (Christopher Weller), and two great-grandchildren, Ava and Nolan. He was preceded in death in 1997 by another son, Oliver. Mr. Priceman was born in 1914 in Bialystok, Poland. At a young age, his family moved to Berlin where he finished high school and then moved to Paris to obtain his degree in Philosophy and Sociology at the Sorbonne. In 1939 he came to the United States and was drafted in 1941. From 1943 until 1946 Mr. Priceman worked in military intelligence in the South Pacific and later in the Pentagon. Mr. Priceman was fluent in several languages and was sent by the Pentagon to be an observer and occasional interpreter at the Nuremburg trials. He was one of the pioneers of the use and application of simultaneous interpretation at the UN where he also held various other positions. In 1959, he left the UN for a career with IBM World Trade, managing language programs and later human resources. He retired in 1979. Mr. Priceman was an avid reader, writer and student of politics who enjoyed spirited debates with his friends and family. Much of his later years were devoted to this, and spending time with his devoted family. We miss his warmth and love.

PAPPAS--Susan. 1952 2014. At age 5 she wanted to be Annie Oakley. At 40 she celebrated her birthday as "Annie" complete with a live horse. At age 7 she set her sights on golf. At 35 she won her club championship. At age 16 she envisioned having her own business. At 25 she created that business and Pappas MacDonnell continues to accomplish great things today. Smart, driven and creative, she was a mentor to many. Above all, she was a lover of life of friends and family, her beloved dogs, her home on the water, music, architecture, art and so much more. She lived her dreams with style, with grace, and left huge footprints in the sand. When you look into the sky, the stars will twinkle with her love and wit. Donations may be made in Susan's name to the U.S. Fund for UNICEF (unicefusa.org) to provide girls around the world with the opportunities to survive and thrive.

He leaves behind a legacy of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Donald's wife, Betsy Miller Landis; his children, Ellen Miller Landis and Lisa Thompson, Maggie Neuman Landis, and David Aaron and Becky (Chamberlain) Landis; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

MOSS--Robert, 90, of Scarsdale, NY, passed away on August 27, 2014 at his home. He was predeceased by his parents, Benjamin and Theodora Moss. Bob, as he was known, attended Columbia Grammar School and The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1948. He was drafted into the Army in May of 1943 and served three years. He was a market maker on the floor of the American Stock Exchange for most of his professional career. Bob is survived by his loving wife Eleanor, his sons, Stephen, Michael, Lawrence and Andrew, daughter-in-laws Barbara, Daryl, Leah, and Michelle, and his seven grandchildren. They were everything to him. He was a kind and gentle man who either coached or attended almost all his children's sporting events. He will be missed. Shiva to be held on Friday from 1:00pm to 5:00pm and Monday from 4:00 pm to 9:00pm at 258 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. As an expression of sympathy, memorial contributions may be sent to SPARC, Inc., 3045 Gomer St. Yorktown Heights, NY 10598.

KREISMAN--Dolores 83, died August 20, 2014. As Senior Advisor on Government and Policy Affairs at NYS Psychiatric Institute, she spent over 30 years as a powerful advocate for mental health research funding. She was also a faculty member of the Columbia Department of Psychiatry, studying the effects of schizophrenia on family dynamics and friendships. Predeceased by beloved husband Richard Christie and stepson Lance Christie; survived by stepdaughters Gail and Rebecca Christie and Margaret Christie Kellogg, five grandchildren, four great-grandchildren and a large extended family to whom she was extremely devoted. Her warmth, wisdom and generosity touched all who knew her. She will be greatly missed. Memorial gifts to the Dolores Kreisman Internship Fund at Barnard College. Memorial service info dkreismanmemorial@gmail.com
FARRELLY--James J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James J. Farrelly, associated with The New York Times from October 21, 1961 until retiring on March 1, 1980.

DALY--Margaret Vennum, on August 21. Beloved sister, stepmother, grandmother, friend, colleague, neighbor and congregant of Grade Church in NYC. Always the smartest person in the room; with gentle wit, delightful irreverence, an open mind and compassionate soul she will be deeply missed by all who loved her. Margie was born in Minneapolis, MN. She attended Northrup Collegiate School and was a graduate of Vassar College. Margie had retired from a long career as an Editor of Better Homes and Gardens Magazine and was enjoying church, international travel, hosting dear friends, theatre and walks throughout NYC. A 56 year resident of the East Village; Margie had been all over the world and made life-long friends wherever she visited. Margie is irreplaceable and unforgettable.

BRONSTEIN--Elaine Abrams. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the passing on Monday, August 25th of Elaine Abrams Bronstein, beloved mother of our friend and partner Richard J. Bronstein. We express our deepest sympathies to Rick, Eileen and all other members of the Bronstein family.

BEARD--Reginald Anthony. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Reginald Anthony Beard, associated with The New York Times from June 13, 1955 until retiring on December 31, 2001. He was a noted pioneer in the use of satellite communications for journalists.

BABYATSKY--Mark, MD. The Mount Sinai Health System is deeply saddened by the loss of our long-time colleague and friend Mark Babyatsky, MD, a highly respected mentor, educator, researcher, and clinician. Dr. Babyatsky, former Chairman of the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine at the Mount Sinai Health System, also served as Program Director of the Internal Medicine Residency Program and Vice Chair of Education for the Department of Medicine at Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. As a researcher, he was credited for making novel discoveries in gastrointestinal inflammation. As an educator, he was among an elite group of leaders in residency training. The Mount Sinai community extends heartfelt condolences to his family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, the Mount Sinai Health System; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, CEO and President, the Mount Sinai Health System; and Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, the Mount Sinai Health System.

AEILLO--Sister Marilda Joseph, SC (Theresa Mary) (1916-2014) died at the Convent of Mary the Queen, Yonkers, on August 26th, 2014. She entered the Sisters of Charity of New York on February 2, 1943. From 1945-2006 (61 years) Sister Marilda Joseph held various positions at the New York Foundling Hospital. She is survived by her sister, Vera Sayers, her niece Patricia O'Toole and nephew, William Baumann. Wake and Funeral Mass will be held at the Convent of Mary the Queen. Wake: Thursday, August 28th, 2014 2:00-8:00pm. Vigil Service at 6:30pm. Mass: Friday, August 29th, 2014 at 10am. Burial: St. Joseph Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity of New York.

ZITTELL--Ruth Rosalind "Roz" Born July 22, 1922, Brooklyn NY; passed away peacefully in San Rafael, CA on Saturday, August 23, 2014. Educator, catalyst for special needs integration, community volunteer. Survived by children, Philip, Teddy and Bari, and Andrew and Mia. Grandma to Naomi and Jared; Miriam and John; Benjamin; and Zachary. Great-grandmother to Henry, Jack and Zelda. Predeceased by her loving companion and active debating partner, Chaim Friend z"l. Donations in Roz's memory may be made to Brooklyn College Foundation/Alumni Association, Congregation B'nai Israel of Rossmoor, Chabad of Contra Costa, or the charity of your choice. May her memory be for a blessing.

WHITE--Arthur H. It is with profound regret and sadness that we announce the passing on August 25, 2014 of Arthur H. White who served with distinction on the Community Service Society's Board of Trustees from 1991 until his resignation in August 1998. Mr. White, an accomplished businessman, founder of Jobs for the Future and co-founder of Reading is Fundamental (RIF), left the CSS Board to accept an appointment to then-President Clinton's Federal Prison Industries Commission. A dedicated and resolute voice in support of enhancing education and job-training opportunities for working people and the unemployed, Mr. White played a pivotal role in CSS's growth and development as a preeminent anti-poverty organization. He will be missed as a friend and a mentor. David R. Jones, Esq. President & CEO Community Service Society

WALDNER--Danny David, passed away peacefully at the age of 101 on August 26, 2014. He lovingly devoted his life to his late wife Mae, and is survived by his sons, Stephen and Jeffrey, daughters-in-law Linda and Diane, four grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. Grandpa Danny will be dearly missed.

SWEENEY--Donald E. Donald E. Sweeney, 88, a dedicated educator who achieved breakthroughs in the integration of intellectually challenged children into the Kingston, New York school system, died Sunday at his residence in Los Angeles surrounded by family. A native of White Plains, New York and graduate of White Plains High School, Mr. Sweeney enlisted in the United States Marine Corps at the age of 17, serving as a corporal in the Second Marine Division during WWII in the Central Pacific. He was a forward observer in Saipan, Tinian, The Marshalls, Guam, and Okinawa. He also served as an MP in Nagasaki, service that initiated a lifelong interest in the Japanese people and culture. Mr. Sweeney was a member of the Second Marine Division Association and the Veterans of Foreign Wars. After his military service, Mr. Sweeney earned his Bachelor's degree in education from SUNY Oswego in 1952 and his Masters of Science Degree in Education from Syracuse University in 1954. He received a Certificate of Advanced Study in Education from SUNY New Paltz and completed post-graduate work at New York University and SUNY Albany. He began his 38-year career in education as a teacher in the Baldwinsville, New York Central School and then as a principal at Hudson Jr. High School in Hudson, New York. He continued his career as an elementary school principal at the #

SLOANE--Virginia. The Trustees and Staff of the Heckscher Foundation for Children mourn the passing of their esteemed Trustee and President Emeritus, Virginia Sloane. Ginnie served as a Trustee for nearly 40 years, and as President from 1986. Her commitment to underserved children and families has helped tens of thousands realize their dreams for generations. We will miss her wisdom, judgment and leadership. Heckscher Foundation for Children
STOPOL--Phil. How fortunate we were to share his life. We will always love him and continue to be inspired by him. Connie, Richard, Carolyn, Carol, Larry, Jonathan, Melissa and Evan

SLOANE--Virginia. Philanthropist and civic leader, died on August 24, 2014 after a lengthy illness. She was 91 and lived in Larchmont, New York and Manhattan. Virginia, known to all as "Ginnie", was elected President of the Heckscher Foundation for Children in 1986 and presided over its affairs for many years. In 2012, she became President Emeritus. Under her leadership the Foundation provided funding to many of the leading social service programs and cultural institutions in New York and elsewhere in support of its mission to level the playing field for underserved youth by providing access to education and experiences that make for a richer, more forward-reaching life. Grantees have included the Boy Scouts of America, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Central Park Conservancy, Citizens' Committee for Children, Citizen Schools, Community Service Society of New York, Coalition for the Homeless, Covenant House, De La Salle Academy, The Doe Fund, The Fresh Air Fund, Girls Educational and Mentoring Services, Harlem RBI, Henry Street Settlement, Jazz at Lincoln Center, National Dance Institute, NPower, New York City Center, New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, The New York Pops, Opportunities for a Better Tomorrow, Perez Art Museum Miami, The Public Theater, Prep for Prep, Reading Partners, Seedco, Success Charter Network, Taproot Foundation, Teach for America, Tipping Point Community, and Wounded Warrior Project. In 2003 she was honored by United Cerebral Palsy at its "Women Who Care Hall-of Fame" gala. She was an accomplished pianist and an avid tap dancer who studied under some of the leading figures in the arts, including Charles "Honi" Coles. As the Founder of the National Dance Institute, Jacques d'Amboise, said: "Virginia realized that children are everything, and they deserve the best that we can give them. Being with her, I felt the sunlight got a little bit brighter, and the shadows on the moon diminished." She is survived by her two children, Gail Sloane Meyers (Andrew Hall) and Peter Sloane (Jaar-mel Sevin Sloane), five grandchildren, Hilary Azrael, (Josh Gurewitsch), Kate Meyers (Jonathan Etra), Nessia Sloane Kushner (Taylor Kushner), Alex Sloane and Jake Sloane, and four great grandchildren, Zachary and Molly Azrael, and Lilly and Annabelle Etra. A private funeral will be held for family members. A memorial will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to an organization of the donor's choosing which serves the interests of children in need.

SILVERMAN--Harold, died August 26, 2014, at age 85. He was Rhoda's beloved husband of 22 years; father of Steven; brother of Stan; cherished stepfather and grandfather. Korean War veteran, Pitney-Bowes inventor, tennis nut, history maven, consummate gentleman. He brought happiness.
RUTLAND--Hiawatha. Teacher extraordinaire, died Monday, August 25, 2014. He lives on inside of us fortunate to have known him. The Lenzner Family

ROWE--George, Jr. The lawyers and staff of Fulton, Rowe & Hart LLP are deeply saddened by the passing of their colleague, friend and mentor George Rowe, Jr. His leadership, intellect and sense of humor will be missed by all. Our condolences to his wife Joyce and to his entire family.
LASTER--Lillian, passed peacefully surrounded by loving family. Missed by Robin Kriesberg and family.

HALBERSTAM--Jean Sandness, died August 25 at her home in Nantucket. Survived by her beloved daughter Julia, her son-in-law J. Ryan Harvey, and her grandson Owen David Harvey. Predeceased by her husband, David. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a contribution to Teach for America in the Mississippi Delta. Checks can be sent to TFA-MS's Jean Halberstam Memorial Fund, c/o CFNM, 315 Losher St, Suite 100, Hernando, MS 38632. For on-line guestbook, please visit: www.johnlawrencefuneral home.com

KREISMAN--Dolores 83, died August 20, 2014. As Senior Advisor on Government and Policy Affairs at NYS Psychiatric Institute, she spent over 30 years as a powerful advocate for mental health research funding. She was also a faculty member of the Columbia Department of Psychiatry, studying the effects of schizophrenia on family dynamics and friendships. Predeceased by beloved husband Richard Christie and stepson Lance Christie; survived by stepdaughters Gail and Rebecca Christie and Margaret Christie Kellogg, five grandchildren, four great-grandchildren and a large extended family to whom she was extremely devoted. Her warmth, wisdom and generosity touched all who knew her. She will be greatly missed. Memorial gifts to the Dolores Kreisman Internship Fund at Barnard College. Memorial service info dkreismanmemorial@gmail.com

EWERT--Alfred P.,of New York and Tuxedo Park, NY, died on August 23rd at the age of 80 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. He was born and raised in Detroit, MI, and graduated from the University of Michigan in 1955. He served as a 1st Lieutenant in the US Air Force in France from 1955 to 1957. On his return he entered George Washington University Law School and graduated in 1961. He became a member of the Virginia, DC, and New York Bar Associations. In 1964 he joined the patent law firm Morgan and Finnegan in New York, became a partner soon thereafter, and had a distinguished career in patent litigating until his retirement in 2003. His pro bono work included successfully representing the town of Tuxedo in preserving its environment against massive development. He was an expert skier and tennis player, and a member of The Tuxedo Club. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Tucker Ewert, two daughters, Caroline Ewert Jaenicke, of Wellesley, MA, and Alexandra Ewert Farnell, of Park City, UT, four grandchildren, his sister, Marge McGoff of Charlevoix, MI, and brother, Herb Ewert, of Vero Beach, FL. Services will be private.

CHALTIEL--Victor M.G. Victor M.G. Chaltiel was born in Tunis, Tunisia on September 8, 1941 and passed away peacefully on Sunday, August 24, 2014, surrounded by his family and loved ones. He is survived by his wife Toni and their three children, Oscar, Maxime and Sarah. He is also survived by his children Jean-Jacques (Sarah), Lionel (Serena), Edouard (Julia) daughter-in-law, May, his grandchildren Zachary, Ezra and Niko, and his sister Jacqueline along with his many nieces and nephews. Victor tragically was predeceased by his son Eric. As an active participant in the Las Vegas business and social communities, Victor had a love for national and local politics, and his love for Las Vegas led him to run for Mayor of Las Vegas in 2011. Despite his distinctive heavy French accent, which he never lost after living in the US for over 40 years, Victor was proud to say he was American by choice. Victor was an active philanthropist, donating to many charitable causes worldwide. He served as a Board member of The Las Vegas Sands Corporation and was appointed to the Board of the Nevada Governor's Office of Economic Development. Victor was a member of the Board of Directors of The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Adelson Educational Campus as well as numerous other charitable organizations, and he was a proud member of the Board of the Republican Jewish Coalition. Victor had over forty years of experience in the healthcare industry and until his passing served as Founder and Chairman of Redhills Ventures where he led and created HealthDataInsights, Inc., the industry leader in healthcare claims integrity which was formed and headquartered in Las Vegas. HealthDataInsights was sold in 2011 to HMS Holdings Corporation. Prior to moving to Las Vegas, Victor served as Chairman and CEO of Total Renal Care Holdings now Davita, the nation's second largest provider of renal dialysis services. He also served as Chairman, President and CEO of Total Pharmaceutical Care, now Apria, and as President, Chief Operating Officer and Director of Salick Health Care, a pioneering cancer treatment care company. Victor Chaltiel is a graduate of the Ecole Superieure des Sciences Economiques et Commerciales in Paris and holds a Master's Degree in Business Administration from Harvard Business School. After graduating from Harvard Business School, Victor began his career with Baxter International, where he quickly climbed through the ranks to lead their artificial organs division. He was instrumental in the successful development and worldwide commercialization of Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD), currently the leading home dialysis treatment. Victor was honored by the National Kidney Foundations of Northern and Southern California as well as those in New York and the Capital Area. The National Kidney Foundation annually awards the "Victor Chaltiel Young Investigator Grant of The National Kidney Foundation." Victor's love for life, gregarious sunny personality, and his boundless energy and generosity is known by all those who were fortunate to know him. He will be sadly missed by many, but most of all by his family and loved ones. The family requests that in lieu of flowers; please make a donation to a charity of your choice.

SLOANE--Virginia. The Trustees and Staff of the Heckscher Foundation for Children mourn the passing of their esteemed Trustee and President Emeritus, Virginia Sloane. Ginnie served as a Trustee for nearly 40 years, and as President from 1986. Her commitment to underserved children and families has helped tens of thousands realize their dreams for generations. We will miss her wisdom, judgment and leadership. Heckscher Foundation for Children

SLOANE--Virginia. Philanthropist and civic leader, died on August 24, 2014 after a lengthy illness. She was 91 and lived in Larchmont, New York and Manhattan. Virginia, known to all as "Ginnie", was elected President of the Heckscher Foundation for Children in 1986 and presided over its affairs for many years. In 2012, she became President Emeritus. Under her leadership the Foundation provided funding to many of the leading social service programs and cultural institutions in New York and elsewhere in support of its mission to level the playing field for underserved youth by providing access to education and experiences that make for a richer, more forward-reaching life. Grantees have included the Boy Scouts of America, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Central Park Conservancy, Citizens' Committee for Children, Citizen Schools, Community Service Society of New York, Coalition for the Homeless, Covenant House, De La Salle Academy, The Doe Fund, The Fresh Air Fund, Girls Educational and Mentoring Services, Harlem RBI, Henry Street Settlement, Jazz at Lincoln Center, National Dance Institute, NPower, New York City Center, New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, The New York Pops, Opportunities for a Better Tomorrow, Perez Art Museum Miami, The Public Theater, Prep for Prep, Reading Partners, Seedco, Success Charter Network, Taproot Foundation, Teach for America, Tipping Point Community, and Wounded Warrior Project. In 2003 she was honored by United Cerebral Palsy at its "Women Who Care Hall-of Fame" gala. She was an accomplished pianist and an avid tap dancer who studied under some of the leading figures in the arts, including Charles "Honi" Coles. As the Founder of the National Dance Institute, Jacques d'Amboise, said: "Virginia realized that children are everything, and they deserve the best that we can give them. Being with her, I felt the sunlight got a little bit brighter, and the shadows on the moon diminished." She is survived by her two children, Gail Sloane Meyers (Andrew Hall) and Peter Sloane (Jaar-mel Sevin Sloane), five grandchildren, Hilary Azrael, (Josh Gurewitsch), Kate Meyers (Jonathan Etra), Nessia Sloane Kushner (Taylor Kushner), Alex Sloane and Jake Sloane, and four great grandchildren, Zachary and Molly Azrael, and Lilly and Annabelle Etra. A private funeral will be held for family members. A memorial will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to an organization of the donor's choosing which serves the interests of children in need.

HICKS--J. Portis. Died August 27 at age 76 in New York City. Survived by his wife, Laura J. Corwin, of New York City; his children, Darcy Anne Hicks of Westport, Connecticut, and Tyler Portis Hicks of Nairobi, Kenya; his grandchildren, Eli, Theo and Henry Koskoff, and his son-in-law, Joshua Koskoff, all of Westport, Connecticut; his brothers, Irwin Hicks of Wilmette, Illinois, Hilary Hicks of Monrovia, California, and Carter Hicks of Bluffton, South Carolina. There will be a celebration of his life at The Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue, New York City, at 5:00pm to 7:00pm on September 7. Retired partner in Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittmann LLP and Volunteer Mediator at the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Judicial Department. Avid skier, theatergoer, cyclist and world traveler. Contributions to the Portis Hicks Memorial Fund may be made to the Detroit Public Schools Foundation, Fisher Building, Suite 1004, 3011 West Grand Boulevard, Detroit, MI 48202, The Fund will be used to benefit Nichols School, a public middle and elementary school in Detroit that Portis attended that is now in need of resources. Contributions may also be made to RISC (Reporters Instructed in Saving Colleagues) at http://www.risctraining.org or by sending a check to RISC, c/o The Half King, 505-507 West 23rd Street, New York, NY 10011.

COOPER--Nathan, 93 years old of Scottsdale, AZ, formerly of New York City and Hartsdale, NY, passed away on August 27, 2014. A selfless man full of dreams for his wife and family, his life lived with endless kindness, enormous empathy, and unconditional love. With Caryl, his wife of 64 years, he was a creator of opportunity in business, in the community, and for his family and friends. Nate was a decorated (Bronze Star) Veteran of WWII, an accomplished business executive, unparalleled wiz with letters and numbers, a superb coach and mentor; quick with both wit and wisdom. A priceless gem; husband (to Caryl); father (to Daniel, Andrew and John); father-in-law (to Wendy, Liz, and Rosa); grandfather (to Samantha, Kimberly, Alana, Natanya, Alexandra, Dylan); grandfather-in-law to Scott, Josh, and Matthew. His vision, counsel, love and patience are irreplaceable gifts. We love you Papa and miss you now and forever.

CHALTIEL--Victor M.G. Victor M.G. Chaltiel was born in Tunis, Tunisia on September 8, 1941 and passed away peacefully on Sunday, August 24, 2014, surrounded by his family and loved ones. He is survived by his wife Toni and their three children, Oscar, Maxime and Sarah. He is also survived by his children Jean-Jacques (Sarah), Lionel (Serena), Edouard (Julia) daughter-in-law, May, his grandchildren Zachary, Ezra and Niko, and his sister Jacqueline along with his many nieces and nephews. Victor tragically was predeceased by his son Eric. As an active participant in the Las Vegas business and social communities, Victor had a love for national and local politics, and his love for Las Vegas led him to run for Mayor of Las Vegas in 2011. Despite his distinctive heavy French accent, which he never lost after living in the US for over 40 years, Victor was proud to say he was American by choice. Victor was an active philanthropist, donating to many charitable causes worldwide. He served as a Board member of The Las Vegas Sands Corporation and was appointed to the Board of the Nevada Governor's Office of Economic Development. Victor was a member of the Board of Directors of The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Adelson Educational Campus as well as numerous other charitable organizations, and he was a proud member of the Board of the Republican Jewish Coalition. Victor had over forty years of experience in the healthcare industry and until his passing served as Founder and Chairman of Redhills Ventures where he led and created HealthDataInsights, Inc., the industry leader in healthcare claims integrity which was formed and headquartered in Las Vegas. HealthDataInsights was sold in 2011 to HMS Holdings Corporation. Prior to moving to Las Vegas, Victor served as Chairman and CEO of Total Renal Care Holdings now Davita, the nation's second largest provider of renal dialysis services. He also served as Chairman, President and CEO of Total Pharmaceutical Care, now Apria, and as President, Chief Operating Officer and Director of Salick Health Care, a pioneering cancer treatment care company. Victor Chaltiel is a graduate of the Ecole Superieure des Sciences Economiques et Commerciales in Paris and holds a Master's Degree in Business Administration from Harvard Business School. After graduating from Harvard Business School, Victor began his career with Baxter International, where he quickly climbed through the ranks to lead their artificial organs division. He was instrumental in the successful development and worldwide commercialization of Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD), currently the leading home dialysis treatment. Victor was honored by the National Kidney Foundations of Northern and Southern California as well as those in New York and the Capital Area. The National Kidney Foundation annually awards the "Victor Chaltiel Young Investigator Grant of The National Kidney Foundation." Victor's love for life, gregarious sunny personality, and his boundless energy and generosity is known by all those who were fortunate to know him. He will be sadly missed by many, but most of all by his family and loved ones. The family requests that in lieu of flowers; please make a donation to a charity of your choice.

BRONSTEIN--Elaine Abrams. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the passing on Monday, August 25th of Elaine Abrams Bronstein, beloved mother of our friend and partner Richard J. Bronstein. We express our deepest sympathies to Rick, Eileen and all other members of the Bronstein family.

BEATON--Shirley Ruth, (nee Sobelman). On August 28, 2014. Born August 19, 1925 in Bronx, NY to late David and Lena and last resided at The Osborn in Rye, NY. Devoted wife of the late Daniel for 65 years. Loving mother of Dr. Howard, Neal (Dr. Ann) and Dianne (Brian Heaps). Adoring grandmother of Joshua (Beth Stevens), Audrey (Mike Margarite), Eric (Rachel), Jessica, Kevin (Elisha), Gregory, Rachel, Nathan and Andrew. Proud great-grandmother of Jacob, Olivia and Leo. Graduate of Hunter College (B.S. Chemistry) at age 19. Active in the Sisterhoods, choirs and nursery school programs at Community Synagogue in Port Washington and Community Synagogue of Rye and many charitable endeavors. Services at Sharon Gardens on Sunday, August 31 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to charity in her memory. May her memory forever be a blessing.
