YORK--Scott Roland, 85, peacefully at home on August 18 after an illness that lasted either a weekend or a decade. Beloved by his wife, Alix Kates Shulman; daughter, Gwill York; son-in-law, Paul Maeder; grandsons, Paxton and Walker Maeder-York; stepchildren, Theodore and Polly Shulman. Born in Cleveland, OH, he attended Duke on scholarship, captaining the basketball team. He served in the Navy 1951-1955, then attended graduate school at Harvard on the GI Bill, first the School of Design, then the Business School, earning an MBA. With his first wife he had two children, Gwill and Frederick. In 1983, divorced, he tracked down his 1950 sweetheart, Alix, and lived happily with her for three decades. A member of the Explorers Club, he scaled mountains on five continents. He retired from a career in finance in 1987 to pursue art, exhibiting his sculpture in New York, Maine, and Hawaii. Despite a 2004 traumatic brain injury with progressive dementia, he retained his sweetness, charm, and loving nature to the end.

WINTHROP--Floreine J.,born June 14, 1918 in San Francisco, died August 27, 2014 in Glen Cove, NY. Widow of Robert Winthrop; mother of Charlene Townsend and Susan Mojonnier; grandmother of Lesley Duval, Julie Troyer, Adam Tyler; great-grandmother of Violet Duval. A private service was held at Church of the Advent in Westbury, NY on August 29. She was a member of Piping Rock Club, the Knickerbocker Club, and the Meadow Brook Club.

VAN BUREN--Robert, 89, Banker, Port Authority Commissioner, WW II Veteran and Philanthropist, on August 20th, 2014 in West Palm Beach, FL. A descendant of President Martin Van Buren, he was born in Plainfield, N.J. to Dorothy Way and William Benjamin Van Buren II. Mr. Van Buren married Ann Vanderveer Rapalje, a descendant of Joris Jansen Rapalje, the French Huguenot, and they were married sixty years until her death in 2006. Mr. Van Buren started his banking career at the Chemical Bank in New York City rising to Executive Vice President. After 20 years, he moved to Midlantic Bank in New Jersey, as President, then Chairman of the Board. He led Midlantic to become New Jersey's largest bank, and prior to his retirement helped orchestrate its sale to the PNC Financial Services Group. Mr. Van Buren oversaw the financing of Atlantic City's first casino, Resorts international, and became well-known through the company's innovative advertising campaign as "The Hungry Banker". He was appointed by Governor Thomas Kean as Commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, serving fifteen years. He also served on the Board of Directors of Champion Products, Inc., the Foster Wheeler Corp., MGM Grand Corp., Smith-Corona Corp., and was President of the Board of the Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield, where he and his wife established the Van Buren Intensive Care Unit. Mr. Van Buren is survived by his children Marcia Van Buren - Brown and her husband Thomas W. Brown; Cynthia Way Rapalje Van Buren, Esq.; Robert Scott Van Buren; brother William Benjamin Van Buren III, several nieces and nephews, and his companion Martha Janet Utterback of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. A memorial service will be held at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, 714 Watchung Ave., Plainfield NJ on Saturday, September 6th at 3pm. Services are being handled by Memorial Funeral Home in Fanwood, NJ (908-322-4350). For additional information or to sign the guestbook, visit: www.fanwoodmemorial.com.

TODD--Frances Starr, teacher and philanthropist, died at her home on August 28, 2014. Born May 28, 1941 to Louis and Abbey Starr, Fay graduated from Foxcroft School and Columbia University. An artist and opera devotee, she was committed to many community and cultural organizations, including the Metropolitan Opera, Lamington Presbyterian Church, Lower East Side Girls Club, Poets and Writers, Harlem Academy, and the River and Plains Society. Her husband, John R. Todd, and brother, Dillwyn Starr, predeceased her. She is survived by her son Christopher (Jesenia), daughter Mary Ganzenmuller (Peter), and five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the New Jersey Audubon Society, Lamington Presbyterian Church, or the Clarence Dillon Public Library.

SUSSNA--Dr. Stephen, son of Louis and Minnie Sussna, passed away on August 15, 2014. Steve served in the United States Navy on LST 1012 during Operation Dragoon in southern France which occurred on August 15, 1944, exactly 70 years earlier to the day. The LST next to his was blown up and Steve always said how lucky he was. In 2008 he wrote a book "Defeat and Triumph: The Story of a Controversial Allied Invasion and French Rebirth." It thoroughly analyzes the pros and cons of Dragoon and also provides a panoramic history of Operation Dragoon and related events in France, the United States, the Mediterranean and Germany from l940-l945. In June 2009, Steve received the French Legion of Honor at Les Invalides in Paris for his participation in this Invasion and for his book. He devoted his career to the city planning and zoning fields, both as a consultant and as a professor. (Professor Emeritus of Law at CUNY). He contributed significantly to periodicals in his field and lectured frequently. Steve graduated from CCNY and then received both an MPA and PhD at New York University, followed by a JD at Fordham. A loved and very devoted husband, father, and grandfather, he is survived by his wife of 59 years, Marian Frost Sussna; a son Alan Frost Sussna (Brenda); a daughter Dr. Amy Sussna Klein (Rob) and grandchildren Benjamin, Daniel, Jennifer Sussna, Sarah Klein, and his brother, Dr. Edward Sussna. Private graveside services will be held at the National Veterans Cemetery. Donations made be made to the VNSNY Hospice.

STREETER--Edward "Ted," Jr.,died Wednesday, August 20, 2014 at 92 years old at his home in Redding, CT. Ted was born on June 21, 1922 to Edward and Charlotte (Warren) Streeter in Great Neck, NY and was the second of four children. As the son of an author, Ted figured into the inspiration of many of Edward Streeter's titles, including "Father of the Bride." A WWII Veteran, Ted served in the 10th Mountain Division of the Armed Forces in Italy. He married Barbara Wood in 1953 in New York City. They lived in NYC until 1964 and then moved out to his beloved little house on the hill in Laurel Hollow, NY. After a long career in sales, Ted retired from Hedwin Corporation in 1987. His passions included music, cars, the stock market and a love of everything outdoors especially when it involved family and dogs. Ted is survived by his daughter, Claire (Streeter) Carlson of Ridgefield, CT; grandchildren, Brian, Sarah, Sam, Claire, Jack and Annie as well as many adored nieces, nephews and in-laws. He is predeceased by his wife, Barbara and his son, Edward "Dan" Daniel. There will be a private memorial celebration, details being determined. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to North Shore Animal League, 16 Lewyt Street, Port Washington, NY 11050.

STERN--Vivien C. February 26, 1947-August 22, 2014. Loving wife of Robert Stern. Beloved daughter of Mary Silverman and George Ungar. Devoted mother of Tracy Husted and Dana Schwartz. Adoring "Vivi" of Sarah, Will, and Jack Husted and Mallory and Tatum Schwartz. Miss Viv, Our hearts will be broken forever.

SPOKOJNY--Artur M. Artur M. Spokojny, MD, FACC, Husband, Father, Medical Pioneer Dies at 58. Dr. Artur Manfred Spokojny, alternative cardiologist and internist, died on January 7th in Los Angeles, after a long, brave battle with his illness. He was buried in Sfat, Israel on Thursday, January 9th, 2014, resting place of beloved teacher, Kabbalist Rav Berg. Words cannot convey the love and respect Artur had for Rav and Karen Berg, who changed the course of his life and illness when they met in 1993. Services coincided with the Kaddish for Artur's father, Sen. Julius Spokojny; the Creator's hand is evident in such timing. Donations may be made for Dr. Artur Spokojny to KCI at 1108 S. Robertson Blvd., Los Angeles, CA 90035 for The Tel Aviv Beshalach Project, the Torah portion of his departure in which he shared an affinity. The Zohar's commentary on the Prophet Elijah, resonate deeply with Artur's extraordinary longevity in the face of terminal illness. Diagnosed in 1991 with rare Smoldering T-Cell Leukemia Lymphoma, he was given seven years to live. Artur was born in Augsburg, Germany on May 10th, 1955, on Lag B'Omer, Hebrew holiday and death anniversary of R. Shimon Bar Yochai, author of the Zohar. His connection to Kabbalah which began at birth would manifest many years later as the principles of the Zohar became his foundation for life-changing paradigm. In 1961, at age six, Artur's academic brilliance shined, he completed reading his first year textbook that very day. In secondary school, he sat for two grades in 1971 and began medical studies in 1973 completing at Ludwig-Maximillian-University of Munich in 1979. Artur was awarded the 'Studiendstiftung de Duetschen Volkes' scholarship in 1975 then sat for the Medical examinations completing in 1979. After internships, he was granted his 'Approbation als Arzt'-- medical license--in November 1979, Dr. Spokojny became Chair I Research Assistant in "venous return" at the Institute of Physiology, University of Dusseldorf, just shy of his 25th birthday, then spent a year at Hadassah University Hospital, Jerusalem. He widely published medical research here and abroad. In 1983, Dr. Spokojny was the first foreign student ever to be accepted into residency at Beth Israel of Harvard University Hospital in Boston, MA where he performed ground-breaking research on laser treatment for coronary disease and heart infection. From Beth Israel, NY in 1985, Dr. Spokojny joined the faculty at New York Hospital Cornell Medical University in 1989 as Assistant Director of the Cardiac Catheterization Laboratory. After Artur's diagnosis, he looked for alternatives to create a new paradigm for healing. Meeting Rav and Karen Berg solidified both the change in his outlook on life and medicine. Artur credited their relationship and healing modalities of the Zohar with prolonging his life. In 1996, he left Cornell creating Whole Heart Center of New York as an alternative cardiologist and internist. The doctor who's every move was for the love of Science perceived disease in a whole new light discovering modern medical breakthroughs recorded in the Zohar over 2000 before. Artur then lectured worldwide on science and spirituality and kabbalistic consciousness and healing techniques serving as advisor and researcher on projects reducing radiation levels of nuclear waste around the world. Artur, a unique combination of intellectual prowess with a penchant for mischief and mayhem, loved a good party, good friends, fine food, wine and single malt scotch. Whether discussing nuclear science and radioactive waste solutions with President Bill Clinton, the CEO of one of Europe's largest Nuclear Power Companies, or the United States Department of Energy during the George W. Bush administration, Artur commanded the floor earning respect with seriousness, brilliance and unconditional care for the welfare our of world. Artur was a gentleman's gentleman; to know him was to love him. His laugh was infectious, his dry sense of humor, zest for wisdom irresistible. A voracious literarian of historical and science fiction fantasy, spiritual, scientific and medical tomes, he loved Jewish, new age and classical music as well as classic rock, enjoyed travel, appreciated good movies, delighted in chocolate and making a good cup of coffee. Above all, Artur was a dedicated and loving husband and father. Artur and Melissa were married by Rav Berg and sons on August 24th, 1995, nine months to the day of their first date. They welcomed first daughter, Rachael, in July 1999, and second, Miriam, in April 2001. Artur developed family property in Augsburg, called Zobelpark naming Julius-Spokojny-Weg for his late father. Dr. Artur Spokojny is also survived by parents-in-law, Barbara and Irving Orenstein, sister in-law Laurie, husband Ken Goeringer, children Zachary, Jonathan and Erin, all of New York. In Israel, Aunt Sala Mateles, cousin Tovy and husband Eldad Malkin, children Rona, Ori and Tal, cousin Zeev Chayut and children Maya, Dor and Omer, cousin Hadassah Eckshtien, children Iaron, Sharon and Orit. In Germany, Cousin Heinrich Spokojny and wife Petra, their daughters Helen and Linda, her son Morris. Dr. Spokojny, missed by his many patients for whom it was his honor to serve and by his Kabbalah Centre family, chevre and community around the world, who enriched his life beyond measure--especially Meir Yeshurun, who stayed with him to the end. Artur lives in the hearts and souls of all those he touched. We will always love you, dear Artur.

SOMMERFIELD--George J. Jr.,of New York City and North Dartmouth, MA passed away on August 26, 2014 at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale. Born in NYC to Dr. and Mrs. George J. Sommerfield Sr., Mr. Sommerfield attended George Washington High School (NYC) and Penn State University. A long time senior executive in the men's clothing industry. Mr. Sommerfield was the husband of the late Sally L. Sommerfield and for the past nine years cherished partner of Nina G. Epstein of Weston, MA and South Dartmouth, MA. George Sommerfield is predeceased by his son Andrew Neil and survived by his son Michael J. Sommerfield of NYC. Funeral service private. Family requests with great appreciation that donations be made to the Hebrew Home at 5901 Palisade Ave, Riverdale, NY 10471. Family will receive friends at Michael's residence Friday, August 29, 2014 from 5pm to 8pm.
SOMMERFIELD--George J Jr We extend our heartfelt condolences to Michael Sommerfield, devoted son, on the loss of his beloved father. Marjorie & Arthur Samuels Jr.

SLOANE--Virginia. The Trustees and Staff of the Heckscher Foundation for Children mourn the passing of their esteemed Trustee and President Emeritus, Virginia Sloane. Ginnie served as a Trustee for nearly 40 years, and as President from 1986. Her commitment to underserved children and families has helped tens of thousands realize their dreams for generations. We will miss her wisdom, judgment and leadership. Heckscher Foundation for Children

SLOANE--Virginia. Philanthropist and civic leader, died on August 24, 2014 after a lengthy illness. She was 91 and lived in Larchmont, New York and Manhattan. Virginia, known to all as "Ginnie", was elected President of the Heckscher Foundation for Children in 1986 and presided over its affairs for many years. In 2012, she became President Emeritus. Under her leadership the Foundation provided funding to many of the leading social service programs and cultural institutions in New York and elsewhere in support of its mission to level the playing field for underserved youth by providing access to education and experiences that make for a richer, more forward-reaching life. Grantees have included the Boy Scouts of America, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Central Park Conservancy, Citizens' Committee for Children, Citizen Schools, Community Service Society of New York, Coalition for the Homeless, Covenant House, De La Salle Academy, The Doe Fund, The Fresh Air Fund, Girls Educational and Mentoring Services, Harlem RBI, Henry Street Settlement, Jazz at Lincoln Center, National Dance Institute, NPower, New York City Center, New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, The New York Pops, Opportunities for a Better Tomorrow, Perez Art Museum Miami, The Public Theater, Prep for Prep, Reading Partners, Seedco, Success Charter Network, Taproot Foundation, Teach for America, Tipping Point Community, and Wounded Warrior Project. In 2003 she was honored by United Cerebral Palsy at its "Women Who Care Hall-of Fame" gala. She was an accomplished pianist and an avid tap dancer who studied under some of the leading figures in the arts, including Charles "Honi" Coles. As the Founder of the National Dance Institute, Jacques d'Amboise, said: "Virginia realized that children are everything, and they deserve the best that we can give them. Being with her, I felt the sunlight got a little bit brighter, and the shadows on the moon diminished." She is survived by her two children, Gail Sloane Meyers (Andrew Hall) and Peter Sloane (Jaar-mel Sevin Sloane), five grandchildren, Hilary Azrael, (Josh Gurewitsch), Kate Meyers (Jonathan Etra), Nessia Sloane Kushner (Taylor Kushner), Alex Sloane and Jake Sloane, and four great grandchildren, Zachary and Molly Azrael, and Lilly and Annabelle Etra. A private funeral will be held for family members. A memorial will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to an organization of the donor's choosing which serves the interests of children in need.

SILVERMAN--Hirsch Lazaar, Ph.D.,D.Sc., LL.D, D.H.L., Litt.D., and Poet, 99, of Chicago, Illinois, died on Friday, August 29, 2014 at The Self Help Home in Chicago, IL. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Dr. Silverman resided in Newark until 1965, then for 44 years in West Orange before moving to Chicago in 2009. By profession Dr. Silverman was a clinical and forensic psychologist. For over forty years, he was a leading educator in the fields of psychology, behavioral sciences, mental health and education. He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, Sigma Xi, Psi Chi, Mensa and a Diplomate and Research Fellow of the International Society of Philosophical Enquiry. He was a professor and Chairman of the Psychology Department at Yeshiva University, NYC from 1959-65, and then Professor and Chair of Educational Psychology at Seton Hall University, South Orange, NJ until 1980. He was also a member of multiple organizations, national and international, dealing with the science of psychology. He was the author of 23 books, including nine volumes of poetry. Dr. Silverman contributed articles to over 270 national and international journals. His achievements in literature included Fellow of the World Academy of Poets, member of the Academy of American Poets and past Trustee of the New Jersey Poetry Society. Dr. Silverman was a Founding Fellow of The International Academy of Poets, Member of The Royal Society of Literature, Benjamin Franklin Fellow of The Royal Society of Arts of England and Fellow of The World Poetry Society and the United Poets Laureate Academy. He was the recipient of the first annual Creative Leadership Award of Kappa Delta Pi of New York University. Dr. Silverman was predeceased by his wife of 61 years, Mildred Friedlander Silverman. He is survived by his children Hyla Susan Silverman of Los Angeles, CA, Dr. Morton Mayer Silverman and his wife, Kineret Jaffe, of Chicago, IL; and Stuart Edward Silverman, and his wife, Paula Silver, of Los Angeles, CA; his sister, Helen Lomazow of Monroe Township, NJ; his four grandchildren Ariana, Noah, Ethan, and Zoe Silverman; and his two great-grandchildren Micah Silverman and Rebecca Long. Services will be conducted on Tuesday, September 2, 2014 at 2:30pm at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union (Vauxhall), NJ. Interment at Oheb Shalom Cemetery, Hillside, NJ.

SAREMSKY--Leonard, passed away on August 29, 2014 at the age of 93. Beloved husband of the late Jean. Dear father of Carol Schwartz (Jesse) and Andrea Silver (Jeffrey). Loving grandfather of six, great-grandfather of six, and friend to all. Services Sunday, 11:15am, at "The Riverside," 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
RUTLAND--Hiawatha. Teacher extraordinaire, died Monday, August 25, 2014. He lives on inside of us fortunate to have known him. The Lenzner Family
ROSEN--Scott. A gentle soul, you left us too soon. You will be missed. Lorrie, Cliff, Sybilla, Harper and Bryan

ROSENHEIN--Elihu, on August 28 at age 100. Beloved husband of the late Beverly. Adored father of Larry, Jon (Ellen), and the late Debby (Gary). Cherished grandfather of Lindsay, Julie, Matthew, and Joanna. Devoted uncle to Lewis, and brother-in-law of Robert, Arthur, and Clara. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 14 Penn Plaza Suite 1710, NY NY 10122.

ROBSON--Margaret. The American Folk Art Museum records with sadness the loss of Margaret Robson. Margaret was passionate about and collected works by self-taught artists. She served on the Museum's Board of Trustees from 1998 to 2007, bringing her distinguished record of public service and professional experience to her role. Margaret is remembered for her strength, focus, elegance, and generosity. In addition to her position on the long-range planning committee, Margaret donated works of art and funded major exhibitions. Chief among her contributions was the creation of the Henry Darger Study Center Fellowship, which gave scholars unprecedented access to this archival resource while working with museum staff in a four-week program. The Board of Trustees and staff extend heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. Laura Parsons, Chairman Edward V. Blanchard, Jr., President Dr. Anne-Imelda Radice, Executive Director

ROBSON--Margaret Zuehlke, of Chicago, formerly of Santa Fe, NM, and Washington, DC. Beloved wife of John and devoted mother of sons, Matthew and Douglas, died on August 24, 2014. She was 82 years old. Margaret Z. Robson was born in St. Cloud, MN, on June 13, 1932. She received her B.B.A. degree from the University of Minnesota, and subsequently moved to Chicago. She left a pioneering career at Continental Illinois Bank, becoming one of its first female officers, to work for the 1960 Kennedy campaign and in anticipation of her impending marriage. She and her husband, John, met and were wed in Chicago, where they started a family. Over their 41 years together, John's career in government, business and academia took them to Chicago, Washington, DC, Atlanta, San Francisco, and Santa Fe, NM. Ms. Robson had a wide range of interests and made contributions to all. She spent many years in public service, primarily in the fields of health, art, and historic preservation. She served as a member of the Board of Directors of the American Folk Art Museum of New York; of the Santa Fe Art Institute; and the College of St. Benedict, St. Joseph, MN. She was a Regent for the Museums of New Mexico and a member of the Board of the Foundation for Self Taught Artists and the Vice President's Residence Foundation. She served on the President's Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, Defense Advisory Commission on Women in the Military (DACOWITS), and the President's Committee on Arts and Humanities. She was a member of the Board of Directors of the Northwestern Memorial Foundation in Chicago and a Trustee of Northwestern Memorial Hospital. From 1987-1990, Ms. Robson served as a Commissioner on the Georgia Boxing Commission. Ms. Robson's survivors include her son, Douglas Robson of San Francisco, CA; her sister, Mary Stevens of La Jolla, CA.; her brother, Tom Zuehlke of Salinas, CA.; and several nieces and nephews. Her husband, John, and her son, Matthew, predeceased her. She leaves behind countless friends and numerous Godchildren who will miss her dearly. In accordance with her wishes, a private graveside service will be held in September. In honor of her life and memory, contributions may be made to the Matthew Stone Robson Memorial Scholarship, Development Office, Colorado College, P.O. Box 1117, Colorado Springs, CO 80901-9897 at www.coloradocollege.edu/give or to the American Folk Art Museum, c/o Elizabeth Kingman, Development Director, 1865 Broadway, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10023, telephone: 212-265-1040, Ext. 113. Donations to either should indicate "In Memory of Margaret Robson."

ROBERTS--Florence, died peacefully at home on June 1, 2014. Beloved wife of Moss; adored and admired mother of Sean and Jenny. In her work over three decades as a Legal Services attorney and Family Law Unit Director, she represented indigent clients in domestic violence, custody, and divorce cases. She also did volunteer work with incarcerated women in family law. She fought for her clients based on a keen sense of justice and injustice and compassion for the cruelties that poverty inflicts on them. She was an inspiration to her children, both of whom pursued careers in law, and to her colleagues (veteran and junior), who turned to her for advice and who responded to her dynamic personality. She leaves a major legacy in the field of law, but also in the field of medicine, having participated in an epigenetic trial for the treatment of leukemia, to which she finally succumbed. A celebration of her life will be held on September 13, starting 11am, at the Kimmel Center of NYU, Rosenthal Hall. To honor her life's work, our family has established a fund in her name at the Women's Prison Association. The donation link is: http://www.wpaonline.org/ content/florence-roberts-memorial-fund

REDPATH--Jean. Jean Redpath was born in Leven, Kingdom of Fife, Scotland in 1937 into a musical family. Four years into her studies at University of Edinburgh, she was encouraged by her mentors to focus on her singing of traditional Scottish music. She came to California in 1961 and after migrating across the United States in a VW bus, made it to Greenwich Village, where she sang at Gerde's Folk City. An enthusiastic review in The New York Times helped to launch her concert and recording career. For over fifty years she traveled the world offering concerts and teaching workshops. She was artist in residence at Wesleyan University (1972-76), and taught Traditional Scottish Music at University of Stirling (1979-89). She has honorary doctorates from the Universities of Stirling, Glasgow, St Andrews, and the Royal Scottish Academy, and numerous honorary memberships in music and literary societies. She sang by invitation at the Queen's Silver Jubilee celebrations at Edinburgh Castle (1977), and in 1987 was awarded an MBE for her services to music. Her portrait hangs in the Scottish National Gallery. In 2011 Jean was artist in residence in the Department of Celtic and Scottish Studies at University of Edinburgh. In May 2014 she sang to standing ovations at her last performance, in Cambridge, New York. Her recorded music is her legacy.

PUGH--Margaret Ellen, of New York, New York passed away on June 23, 2014 at McAuley Hall Health Care Center, Watchung, NJ after a long illness. She was 79 years old. A Memorial Mass to celebrate her life will be offered at St. Malachy's R.C. Church, 239 W. 49th St., New York, NY on Saturday, September 6, 2014 at 11:00am. Services are being handled by the Codey & Jones Funeral Home of Caldwell, NJ. To view the full obituary, read words of remembrance, extend a condolence or share a memory, please visit www.codeyjonesfh.com.

PRIMOFF--L. Robert, New York attorney, passed away peacefully on August 16, 2014 in New York City. A memorial service will be held at the Harvard Club on September 23 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donors' contributions to the charity of their choice. "Go and catch a falling star, Get with child a mandrake root, Tell me where all past years are. Teach me to hear mermaids singing, And find what wind serves to advance an honest mind." John Donne. May you forever shine.

PINZUR--Michael, died peacefully on August 29 at the age of 76. Survived by his wife, Laura, his children Marilyn, Mark and Brad, daughter-in-law Amy, grandchildren, Kayla, Jenna and Maia and sister Ellen. Donations may be made to: One Kid One World, 3652 McLaughlin Ave., Los Angeles, CA. 90066

PAPPAS--Susan. 1952 2014. At age 5 she wanted to be Annie Oakley. At 40 she celebrated her birthday as "Annie" complete with a live horse. At age 7 she set her sights on golf. At 35 she won her club championship. At age 16 she envisioned having her own business. At 25 she created that business and Pappas MacDonnell continues to accomplish great things today. Smart, driven and creative, she was a mentor to many. Above all, she was a lover of life of friends and family, her beloved dogs, her home on the water, music, architecture, art and so much more. She lived her dreams with style, with grace, and left huge footprints in the sand. When you look into the sky, the stars will twinkle with her love and wit. Donations may be made in Susan's name to the U.S. Fund for UNICEF (unicefusa.org) to provide girls around the world with the opportunities to survive and thrive.

ORTEGA--Noel, 79, of Pawling, NY. Died August 10. Retired Professor of Spanish and Portuguese. Much loved by his students, friends, family and spouse. He was a beautiful man and a true gentleman. He had a remarkable life. Memorial service is planned. josephdconnors@yahoo.com

ORTEGA--Jose Corbin, 51, passed away on August 20 in New York City. He is survived by his partner Joseph Aubain from St. Thomas, VI, parents Jose and Laetitia Corbin Ortega, brother Frank Ortega, sister Lee Ortega, brother-in-law Julien Faure, nephews and nieces, godchildren and countless friends. A service will be held on Sunday, September 7 at 5pm at 2181 NE 27th Drive, Fort Lauderdale, Florida.

NISSEL--Frank R.,died August 28, 2014, at age 88. Beloved father of James Nissel (Barbara), Nancy Lewis (Wayne), Laura Shemanski (Joseph Figliolino, Jr.). Predeceased by his wife Bette. Memorial donations may be sent to The Hill at Whitemarsh, 4000 Fox Hound Dr., Lafayette Hill, PA 19444 in Frank's name for the Music Fund. Interment private.

MURNION--William E.,81, of Warwick, NY, passed away at home on Friday, August 22, 2014 surrounded by his cherished family. William was born in New York City to Frances (Canavan) and William E. Murnion. Dr. Murnion was a Professor of Philosophy and Religious Studies (Ramapo College), writer, teacher, and founder of PhilosophyWorks. He received his Ph.D in Philosophy Summa Cum Laude from Gregorian University, Rome, 1969. He was the author of Aquinas's Theory of the Act of Understanding. His main interests are Aquinas; Bernard Lonergan, on transcendental method and systematic theology, and the infrastructure of modern philosophy. Dr. Murnion was predeceased by his brothers, John Murnion and Philip Murnion. Bill was the beloved husband of Deborah, the devoted father of Cary and his wife Antoinnette and Gregory and his wife Annie; and the proud grandfather of Teddy; and the faithful brother of Rose Mary Gerdes. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to a charity of your choice that provides social justice for the poor. Log onto: www.sticklesolteszfuneralhome.com tribute wall to personally post your condolences, memories and photos.

MUNROE--George B. The Board of Directors and the staff of the Academy of Political Science, publisher of Political Science Quarterly, report with deep sadness the death on August 19th of our esteemed colleague and friend, George Munroe. George was a director of the Academy for the last 40 years, served faithfully and effectively as Chairman from 1996 to 2006, and as Chairman Emeritus from 2006 until his death. During his tenure as Chairman, the Academy doubled its financial reserves. George Munroe's keen judgment, wide experience, and gentle wit were always in the service of improving the Academy's and Quarterly's work. The respect and affection in which he was held by leaders in business, foundations, the not-for-profit world, and those in higher education allowed the Academy to recruit outstanding new members for its Board and to raise funds for special projects. George Munroe was a great man and a very good man. His intellectual, moral, and financial support of the Academy as well as his integrity and friendship will be greatly missed. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Ellie and their family. Peter John Goulandris, Chairman Demetrios James Caraley, President and Editor Conrad K. Harper, Secretary of the Board

MILLIS--Walter. December 26, 1932-August 25, 2014. Husband of Alison, father of Andrew, Peter and Robert and grandfather of Lily, he worked for NBC News in New York and London, covering stories in Iran, the former Soviet Union, India, Jordan, Afghanistan, Australia, Somalia and many places in the British Isles and Europe. An avid sailor, he kept a boat in Orient, New York and was active in the Orient Yacht Club. He is deeply missed by his family, friends and the Orient community. Donations may be made to the Oysterponds Historical Society.

MARKEWICH--Iris Alexandra, 87, died peacefully at home on August 30, 2014. Born in New York City, daughter of Milton and Anna Grass, Iris was preceded in death by the love of her life, her soul-mate and husband of sixty-two years, Robert Markewich. Iris will be missed, and lovingly remembered, by her five children and their spouses: Deborah Lazarus, Judith Stuchiner (Robert), Ida Lawrence (Geoffrey), Jeremiah Markewich (Deborah), and Eve Rachel Markewich, her seven grandchildren and their spouses: David Lazarus (Susan Verni), Matthew Lazarus (Mariecel Pilapil), Jacob and Emily Stuchiner, Andrew Lawrence, and Chloe and Tessa Markewich, and her baby great grandson James Richard Lazarus. Iris graduated from Wellesley College and, while raising her family, earned a masters degree from Teachers College and a doctorate degree at NYU, at the age of 60. Iris worked for many years as a rehabilitation counselor and administrator at the Post Graduate Center for Mental Health. Later in life, Iris taught numerous courses in psychology at Mercy College and at NYU. She was an inspiration to all, as an example of being able to have it all a spectacular family life and a fulfilling professional career. For funeral services, call Plaza Funeral Home, 212-769-4400.

LEONARD--Hugh Matthew, age 79, died on Tuesday, August 26, 2014 in Ridgewood, NJ. He was born in Paterson, NJ to Isabel and John Leonard. In 1979, Hugh was one of ten United States Trustees appointed by the Attorney General of the United States to test a bankruptcy pilot program created by the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978. Until 1989, he served as the United States Trustee for New Jersey, Delaware, and later Pennsylvania. He served as Chairman of the Advisory Committee for U.S. Trustees during his tenure with the Department of Justice. Prior to retiring in 2004, Hugh headed the Bankruptcy and Corporate Restructuring Department at Cole, Schotz, Meisel, Forman & Leonard, PA. He was a founder and former Master of the Bankruptcy Inn of Court. Hugh is survived by his wife Norma and daughter Nicole. Hugh was honorable, magnanimous and kind. He will live on through the many he inspired. Services by the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, www.vpfh.com.

KNEELAND--Yale. The Trustees and staff of the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, CT mourn the loss on August 25 of our esteemed trustee Yale Kneeland, whose friendship we hold in our hearts. We send our affection and sympathies to Judy, Tim, Anne and Juliette.

HICKS--J. Portis. Died August 27 at age 76 in New York City. Survived by his wife, Laura J. Corwin, of New York City; his children, Darcy Anne Hicks of Westport, Connecticut, and Tyler Portis Hicks of Nairobi, Kenya; his grandchildren, Eli, Theo and Henry Koskoff, and his son-in-law, Joshua Koskoff, all of Westport, Connecticut; his brothers, Irwin Hicks of Wilmette, Illinois, Hilary Hicks of Monrovia, California, and Carter Hicks of Bluffton, South Carolina. There will be a celebration of his life at The Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue, New York City, at 5:00pm to 7:00pm on September 7. Retired partner in Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittmann LLP and Volunteer Mediator at the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Judicial Department. Avid skier, theatergoer, cyclist and world traveler. Contributions to the Portis Hicks Memorial Fund may be made to the Detroit Public Schools Foundation, Fisher Building, Suite 1004, 3011 West Grand Boulevard, Detroit, MI 48202, The Fund will be used to benefit Nichols School, a public middle and elementary school in Detroit that Portis attended that is now in need of resources. Contributions may also be made to RISC (Reporters Instructed in Saving Colleagues) at http://www.risctraining.org or by sending a check to RISC, c/o The Half King, 505-507 West 23rd Street, New York, NY 10011.

KATZ--Stanley M.,The family of Stanley M. Katz is deeply saddened to announce his death at Yale New Haven Hospital on August 4, 2014, at age 96. A graduate of NYU, Stan was a highly respected business executive. During his career, he was a stockbroker and marketing executive, President and board member of Polycast, Inc. and in his eighties provided digital consulting services to Swissbank and Virgin Airlines. A decorated US Army Veteran of World War II, Stan was in counter intelligence and served on General Douglas MacArthur's staff. Later in life, he served a term as president of the Retired Officers Association of Connecticut. He is survived by his wife, Charleene B. Katz; children Barbara and Steven Katz; and a sister, Kit Dornbush and her children, Kathy A. Dornbush, Dr. Jeffrey Dornbush and family of Marblehead, Massachusetts.

HERSHAN--Stella K.,born in Vienna, Austria on February 7, 1915, died on August 22, 2014. She emigrated to New York City in 1939 during the Holocaust. Stella was an internationally known author and lecturer about women in history. Her first of 12 published books, "A Woman of Quality," was a collection of anecdotes about Eleanor Roosevelt. Stella was preceded in death by her parents, Lucy and Felix Kreidl and her husband Rudi. She is survived by her daughter Lisa; her grandchildren Larry (Ellen), Sheryl and great-granddaughters, Jylian, Dilyn, Sydnie and Lauren. Memorial donations in her name may be made to www.ERVK.org.

GROSSBERG--Jacob. The Bard College Studio Arts Program and Milton Avery Graduate School of the Arts mourn the loss of Professor Emeritus of Sculpture Jacob Grossberg, a vital member of the Art Department from 1969-96, a strong mentor to generations of students, and instrumental in developing the Avery Graduate School. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Diane Sisson Baldwin '66.

GRIFFIN--John T.,Esq., 60, died suddenly on July 28, 2014. A graduate of Don Bosco High School, '71, Columbia College with a B.A. in '75, earning the George William Curtis Medal in Gold for Public Orations. He also earned a JD degree at Case Western Reserve University while completing an MBA from Columbia College and being admitted to the bar in 1979. John founded the Griffin Realty Group in 1988. Beloved son of H. Barbara and the late Robert T. Griffin Sr., and cherished by his brothers, sisters, brothers and sisters-in-law, and many nieces and nephews. He will be missed but will be loved forever. Contributions in his memory to be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, 8th floor, NY, NY 10022 or www.centralparknyc.org

GLASSER--David T.,of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Manhattan. It is with great sadness that we mourn his passing on August 26, 2014. He was a beloved and devoted husband, father, grandfather, and friend. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Bettyann, his children Jennifer Glasser Barmash, Stephanie Glasser Callini, and Adrienne Glasser-Rosenfeld; His sons-in-law Igor Barmash Tony Callini and Win Rosenfeld; and his granddaughters Gabriella Barmash and Julia and Sabrina Callini. He will be remembered for his sense of humor, style, and Grace. He will be greatly missed and will live on in the hearts and memories of those who loved him and whose lives he touched.

FRIEDMAN--Leroy. Leroy Friedman, 93, of Queens, New York, passed away on August 19, 2014 at home, surrounded by his family. Leroy was born April 16, 1921 to Ilona and Herman Friedman of Brooklyn, NY. After graduating from the City College of New York with a degree in chemical engineering, he entered the Army Air Forces during World War II and in 1945 married June Sternberg of Queens, New York. Leroy was employed for many years at Columbia Records as the Director of Recording Operations before retiring in 1984 and joining his co-op's Board of Directors as a tireless and enthusiastic advocate for its residents. He is survived by his wife June, daughter Madge and her husband Mark, daughter-in-law Vivian, grandchildren Rebecca, David and wife Katie, Jeffrey and wife Tricia, great-grandchildren Hannah and Ethan, and several nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his son Paul. An ardent operagoer with a passion for all things musical, a voracious reader and incurable perfectionist, Leroy was a friend to all in his community and devoted beyond measure to his family. He will be in our hearts always.

EWERT--Alfred P.,of New York and Tuxedo Park, NY, died on August 23rd at the age of 80 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. He was born and raised in Detroit, MI, and graduated from the University of Michigan in 1955. He served as a 1st Lieutenant in the US Air Force in France from 1955 to 1957. On his return he entered George Washington University Law School and graduated in 1961. He became a member of the Virginia, DC, and New York Bar Associations. In 1964 he joined the patent law firm Morgan and Finnegan in New York, became a partner soon thereafter, and had a distinguished career in patent litigating until his retirement in 2003. His pro bono work included successfully representing the town of Tuxedo in preserving its environment against massive development. He was an expert skier and tennis player, and a member of The Tuxedo Club. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Tucker Ewert, two daughters, Caroline Ewert Jaenicke, of Wellesley, MA, and Alexandra Ewert Farnell, of Park City, UT, four grandchildren, his sister, Marge McGoff of Charlevoix, MI, and brother, Herb Ewert, of Vero Beach, FL. Services will be private.

CUMMINS--Ginette "Eugenie," died at home in Delray Beach, FL, on August 26th. Devoted wife of the late Seymour K. Cummins; beloved mother of Richard and Diane; adored grandmother of Bradley and Aaron.

COHEN--Eva Anne, New York City, passed away on August 17th in her 80th year. Eva was a passionate fighter for social justice, a committed Orthodox Jew and an ardent feminist. She was active in the anti-Vietnam war, civil rights, and women's rights movements. Eva was a loving wife to Gerry Cohen, who pre-deceased her, and a loving mother and grandmother. Eva is survived by her sons and daughters-in-law, Eric, Hugh, David, Judy and Susan, her grandchildren, Griffin, Sam, Lily, Holden, and Jeremy, and by her sister Bertha Kreisler and her family, and cousins. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Jewish World Service, The Abraham Joshua Heschel School, The Solomon Schechter School of Manhattan, or MJHS - Hospice and Palliative Care.

BUNIS--Andrea, 57, peacefully after a 14 month battle with pancreatic cancer. Born and raised in the Bronx, she was a resident of Manhattan for the last three decades. Survived by the love of her life and companion of 42 years, Harvey Rudman. Beloved daughter of Joan and George, admired aunt to nephews Kris, Matt, Henry and niece Priya. Predeceased by her brother Stephen. She founded Andrea Bunis Management 30 years ago and grew it into one of New York City's leading residential management firms. Andrea was a senior real estate account executive with the Kriesel Company. Serving as a director and manager, she represented various sponsors, developers and investors. Andrea was the recipient of numerous industry awards, including Habitat Magazine's Management Award for Manager of the Year. She was admired for her energy, independence and strong will. Andrea achieved her Bachelor's in Business Administration from Lehman College-CUNY and attended New York University's Real Estate institute where, as a New York State licensed real estate broker, she shared her extensive knowledge as a senior staff instructor. She was a member of the Real Estate Board of New York (REBNY), Professional Women in Construction, (PWC) and Association of Real Estate Women (AREW). Andrea was a varsity athlete in volleyball and swimming and was the Shorehaven Club woman's paddleball champion for four consecutive years. She earned the PSAL's Louisa Wingate Underhill Award given to the most outstanding female athlete in New York City and was a devoted and loyal New York Giant's and Knicks fan. She enjoyed cooking and was great at it. She liked skiing Aspen, Vail and visiting Florida with her family. She also loved boating on the East End. She was a classic movie buff and enjoyed Broadway musicals and music. Andrea enjoyed driving her Landcruiser ever since a test drive 23 years ago. Andrea loved and was totally devoted to her family and staff. She was a beautiful soul and a once in a lifetime individual taken too early from her heartbroken family.

BONOMO--Marilena. The international art world mourns the loss of a beloved gallerist. Marilena Bonomo was a pioneer, opening her legendary gallery in Bari, Italy in 1971. Her intellect, elegance and keen eye will be missed by her many followers. Heartfelt condolences to her devoted family, husband Lorenzo, and daughters Alessandra, Magda and Valentina. Pat Steir and Carol LeWitt
BOAL--Arthur M.,Jr., 87, August 18, 2014. Husband of Ariane Boal, father of five, stepfather of two, granddad of seven. Practiced law in New York, retired to Evergreen, CO in 1994.

BLUMENTHAL--Amy Michelle, passed away suddenly on Wednesday, August 27, 2014 at her residence in New York City at the age of 47. She is survived by her partner Susan Turner; her father, Lawrence Blumenthal of Kansas City; her brother and sister-in-law, Randall Blumenthal and Sabra Krock of New York City and her nephews, Max and Louis Blumenthal. She was predeceased by her mother Susan "Sudy" Zane of Houston, TX. Amy was an attorney and founding partner of Blumenthal and Gruber, LLC based in Dallas, TX. She was also a cherished friend, a teller of wonderful tales, a crossword maven, a generous giver to charities, a tennis nut and gift to all who knew her. She will be missed. Services Tuesday, 3pm at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BABYATSKY--Mark Warren, MD. Members and alumni of The Division of Gastroenterology, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, deeply mourn the passing of our dearest friend and colleague, Dr. Mark Babyatsky. A brilliant diagnostician, compassionate physician, fierce patient advocate and astute investigator, Mark applied these talents to train hundreds of young physicians in the ethical and humanistic care of all patients. We will miss his humor, intellect, wisdom, and smile, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Liz and his family. Bruce Sands, MD Steven Itzkowitz, MD Thomas Ullman, MD

ALSON--Elizabeth "Libby" Lee, 80, died on August 28, 2014. Born in Bronxville, she attended Horace Greeley and Radcliffe, worked for McCall's and Knopf, assisted director Joseph Mankiewicz, and curated at Caramoor museum. Libby loved the arts, travel, nature, animals, and people. She will be greatly missed by her husband Larry, daughter Kate, stepson Peter, son-in-law Jason, daughter-in-law Alice, sister Helen, stepsister Mary, sister-in-law Elaine, her grandchildren Eliot and Eden, and a legion of family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Pets Alive: petsalivewest.org A memorial will be held at Croton Point Park.

VAN BUREN--Robert, 89, Banker, Port Authority Commissioner, WW II Veteran and Philanthropist, on August 20th, 2014 in West Palm Beach, FL. A descendant of President Martin Van Buren, he was born in Plainfield, N.J. to Dorothy Way and William Benjamin Van Buren II. Mr. Van Buren married Ann Vanderveer Rapalje, a descendant of Joris Jansen Rapalje, the French Huguenot, and they were married sixty years until her death in 2006. Mr. Van Buren started his banking career at the Chemical Bank in New York City rising to Executive Vice President. After 20 years, he moved to Midlantic Bank in New Jersey, as President, then Chairman of the Board. He led Midlantic to become New Jersey's largest bank, and prior to his retirement helped orchestrate its sale to the PNC Financial Services Group. Mr. Van Buren oversaw the financing of Atlantic City's first casino, Resorts international, and became well-known through the company's innovative advertising campaign as "The Hungry Banker". He was appointed by Governor Thomas Kean as Commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, serving fifteen years. He also served on the Board of Directors of Champion Products, Inc., the Foster Wheeler Corp., MGM Grand Corp., Smith-Corona Corp., and was President of the Board of the Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield, where he and his wife established the Van Buren Intensive Care Unit. Mr. Van Buren is survived by his children Marcia Van Buren - Brown and her husband Thomas W. Brown; Cynthia Way Rapalje Van Buren, Esq.; Robert Scott Van Buren; brother William Benjamin Van Buren III, several nieces and nephews, and his companion Martha Janet Utterback of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. A memorial service will be held at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, 714 Watchung Ave., Plainfield NJ on Saturday, September 6th at 3pm. Services are being handled by Memorial Funeral Home in Fanwood, NJ (908-322-4350). For additional information or to sign the guestbook, visit: www.fanwoodmemorial.com.

STERN--Vivien C. February 26, 1947-August 22, 2014. Loving wife of Robert Stern. Beloved daughter of Mary Silverman and George Ungar. Devoted mother of Tracy Husted and Dana Schwartz. MARKEWICH--Iris Alexandra, 87, died peacefully at home on August 30, 2014. Born in New York City, daughter of Milton and Anna Grass, Iris was preceded in death by the love of her life, her soul-mate and husband of sixty-two years, Robert Markewich. Iris will be missed, and lovingly remembered, by her five children and their spouses: Deborah Lazarus, Judith Stuchiner (Robert), Ida Lawrence (Geoffrey), Jeremiah Markewich (Deborah), and Eve Rachel Markewich, her seven grandchildren and their spouses: David Lazarus (Susan Verni), Matthew Lazarus (Mariecel Pilapil), Jacob and Emily Stuchiner, Andrew Lawrence, and Chloe and Tessa Markewich, and her baby great grandson James Richard Lazarus. Iris graduated from Wellesley College and, while raising her family, earned a masters degree from Teachers College and a doctorate degree at NYU, at the age of 60. Iris worked for many years as a rehabilitation counselor and administrator at the Post Graduate Center for Mental Health. Later in life, Iris taught numerous courses in psychology at Mercy College and at NYU. She was an inspiration to all, as an example of being able to have it all a spectacular family life and a fulfilling professional career. For funeral services, call Plaza Funeral Home, 212-769-4400.

HICKS--J. Portis. Died August 27 at age 76 in New York City. Survived by his wife, Laura J. Corwin, of New York City; his children, Darcy Anne Hicks of Westport, Connecticut, and Tyler Portis Hicks of Nairobi, Kenya; his grandchildren, Eli, Theo and Henry Koskoff, and his son-in-law, Joshua Koskoff, all of Westport, Connecticut; his brothers, Irwin Hicks of Wilmette, Illinois, Hilary Hicks of Monrovia, California, and Carter Hicks of Bluffton, South Carolina. There will be a celebration of his life at The Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue, New York City, at 5:00pm to 7:00pm on September 7. Retired partner in Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittmann LLP and Volunteer Mediator at the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Judicial Department. Avid skier, theatergoer, cyclist and world traveler. Contributions to the Portis Hicks Memorial Fund may be made to the Detroit Public Schools Foundation, Fisher Building, Suite 1004, 3011 West Grand Boulevard, Detroit, MI 48202, The Fund will be used to benefit Nichols School, a public middle and elementary school in Detroit that Portis attended that is now in need of resources. FERNAINE--Antoine V. Lutheran HealthCare in Brooklyn, NY, mourns the passing of Antoine V. Fernaine, M.D., former co-chief of the Department of Cardiology, a cardiologist at Lutheran Medical Center since 1979, and a key member of the Medical and Dental Staff. Dr. Fernaine was a highly respected physician, peer and friend to many. His passion for his patients and expertise in cardiovascular disease built the foundation for Lutheran's significant expansion in cardiology and the creation of the May Ellen and Gerald Ritter Cardiology Center. He will be sorely missed. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, physicians and staff of Lutheran HealthCare, we send our sincere condolences to his wife and his entire family. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Antoine V. Fernaine Memorial Endowment at Lutheran HealthCare. A wake will be held at the McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home, 9620 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, on Monday, September 1 from 7pm to 9pm and on Tuesday, September 2 from 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Services will be held on Wednesday, September 3 at St. Mary's Church, 192 81st Street, Brooklyn, at 10am.

BLUMENTHAL--Amy Michelle, passed away suddenly on Wednesday, August 27, 2014 at her residence in New York City at the age of 47. She is survived by her partner Susan Turner; her father, Lawrence Blumenthal of Kansas City; her brother and sister-in-law, Randall Blumenthal and Sabra Krock of New York City and her nephews, Max and Louis Blumenthal. She was predeceased by her mother Susan "Sudy" Zane of Houston, TX. Amy was an attorney and founding partner of Blumenthal and Gruber, LLC based in Dallas, TX. She was also a cherished friend, a teller of wonderful tales, a crossword maven, a generous giver to charities, a tennis nut and gift to all who knew her. She will be missed. Services Tuesday, 3pm at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BELTRAMI--Michael. The officers, brokers and staff at Brown Harris Stevens will miss our colleague, who was a respected member of the Real Estate Community. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his family and friends.

ALSON--Elizabeth "Libby" Lee, 80, died on August 28, 2014. Born in Bronxville, she attended Horace Greeley and Radcliffe, worked for McCall's and Knopf, assisted director Joseph Mankiewicz, and curated at Caramoor museum. Libby loved the arts, travel, nature, animals, and people. She will be greatly missed by her husband Larry, daughter Kate, stepson Peter, son-in-law Jason, daughter-in-law Alice, sister Helen, stepsister Mary, sister-in-law Elaine, her grandchildren Eliot and Eden, and a legion of family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Pets Alive: petsalivewest.org A memorial will be held at Croton Point Park.

FREULER--Raymond, Sr & Jr, Dad, Chip, We thought our grief would lessen on the wings of time, but no. You touched both heart & soul with kindness, humor and generosity of spirit. You left us too soon and broken hearted. Karin & Richard

SIMON--Martin J.,age 94, died on August 30th with his loving family by his side. Survived by his wife of 73 years, Lillian, his three daughters, son-in-law, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. In 1942, he received his law degree from St. Johns University. He served in the US Army as a Lieutenant. In 1946, he started his own law firm. In 1955 he founded Simon Agency NY, now entering its 60th year. He was President of DWH Leukemia Foundation for 25 years. He served on the board of Brookdale Hospital where he received the Medal of Honor. He also was a longtime member of Seawane Country Cub and The Friars Club. For his 76th birthday he performed at a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall. He leaves this world but remains in our hearts forever.

ROSENTHAL--Hilda Davis, born on March 24, 1923, passed away September 1, 2014, at age 91, widow of George Rosenthal. Loving mother of Beth Rosenthal Finkel and son-in-law, Shelly Finkel; adoring grandmother of Genny Finkel, William and Wendy Perlmutter Finkel, and Steven and Lee Finkel Goldberg; great-grandmother of Ashley, Henry and Hannah; and devoted sister of Marilyn Davis Levine. Hildy gave her all for family, friends and community. For her official nieces and nephews and her 'adopted' ones, she truly loved you all. Donations may be made to the New York Common Pantry: nycommonpantry.org. Funeral to be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street, Manhattan on Tuesday, September 2, at 1pm. The family will be sitting shiva at the home of Beth and Shelly Finkel through sundown Monday. Remember her smiling on the dance floor....
ROBBINS--Irving M. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Milt. We express our deepest sympathy to Esther, his four children and the rest of the family. The Isaacson Family

POWELL--Jane Leigh, 80, of Ridgeland, formerly of Glen Cove, NY, died on Saturday, August 30th, 2014, peacefully, after a long illness. She was born in London on September 28, 1933, the daughter of the late Francis and Florence (Pratt) Powell. Jane was pre-deceased by her three sisters, Edie Papps, Anne Remsen and Sonia Powell and is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Lois and Charley Cheston (of Topsfield, MA) and nine nieces and nephews, Janie Bellenis, Fizz Papps, Elizabeth Papps, John Papps, Rick Remsen, Jay Remsen, Lita Remsen, Chip Cheston and Virginia Spencer. She graduated from Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, and Briarcliff College in New York. Jane was deeply involved in various organizations, including Roosevelt Hospital in New York City, the American Association of Birth Centers, The Hallelujah Singers of Beaufort, South Carolina, and Good Hope Corporation, Ridgeland, South Carolina where she served as President of the Board for the past 30 years. As a young woman she dedicated much of her time to the Frontier Nursing Service of Hyden, Kentucky, and this became a lifelong passion. She was an active and involved member of the Jasper County community. Jane's love of her home, the South Carolina Low Country, its flora, fauna and community, guided and enriched her life. She was an avid and talented gardener. Bird hunting - at various locations around the world - was her passion. Nowhere was this sport more loved or aggressively pursued than hunting turkey in the dawn woods at Good Hope Plantation. A celebration of Jane's life with her family and friends will take place at a later date. There is no service planned. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Frontier Nursing University, Box 528, Hyden, Kentucky 41749.

LANDAU--W. Loeber, died peacefully in his sleep at home on September 1. Loeber was a graduate of the Newman School in New Orleans, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Princeton University where he was valedictorian of his class, and a summa cum laude graduate of the Harvard Law School where he was the Developments Editor of the Law Review. After his service in the Office of the General Council of the Air Force he joined Sullivan & Cromwell where he spent his entire career and served on the managing committee. He served on several corporate boards but also made time to serve on the boards of many non-profit organizations. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Barbara Gordon Landau, son Gordon Loeber Landau, daughters Blair Trippe and Donna Hardiman and her husband John, and his adored grandchildren, Katherine and Elizabeth Hardiman and Victoria and Brian Trippe. The family will be receiving visitors at home on Thursday evening from 6-8pm. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Chapel Haven, a school for the developmentally disabled (1040 Whalley Ave., New Haven, CT 06510), Harvard Law School, or the charity of your choice.

JORQUERA--Humberto, 88, an electrical engineer whose career was principally focused on Latin America, died in Southampton, NY on August 16, 2014. Mr. Jorquera, a longtime resident of Greenwich, CT., was born in Santiago, Chile to the late Olga and Humberto Jorquera of Santiago. Mr. Jorquera was predeceased by his wife, Mary, and his brothers, Sergio Jorquera and Jaime Jorquera, both of Santiago, Chile. He is survived by his daughters, Christine Vickery of New York, New York and Sarah Jorquera of Pound Ridge, New York, his sons in law, Alan Vickery and David Kulowiec, his five grandchildren, William, Sarah and James Vickery, and Catherine and Peter Kulowiec, and his sister and brother in-law, Sylvia and Jaime Riquelme of Clemmons, North Carolina. Mr. Jorquera graduated from the Instituto Nacional in Santiago, Chile and the Universidad de Chile, Santiago, Chile from which he received his degrees in electrical engineering. Upon completion of his university education Mr. Jorquera was accepted into an electrical engineering internship program in Boston sponsored by the General Electric Company and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While in the internship program, he met his future bride Mary O'Malley and was married in 1955. The couple lived in Santiago, Chile for several years during which time Mr. Jorquera worked for the Compania Chilena de Electricidad, at that time a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company (EBASCO.) Mr. Jorquera was then asked to relocate to the United States to work for EBASCO International, headquartered in Manhattan, where he served as a vice president of EBASCO International and various subsidiary utilities in Latin America. Many years later, following the acquisition of EBASCO International by Boise Cascade Corporation, Mr. Jorquera joined EBASCO Services, the consulting arm of EBASCO. At the time of his retirement he was manager of international rates and client services of EBASCO Services. Following his retirement from EBASCO, he worked as an independent consultant to U.S., Latin American and Caribbean utilities. A Funeral Mass was held on August 23, 2014, at St. Mary's Church in Greenwich, CT.

HIRSCHFELD--Allison B. (nee Klugman), born July 22, 1931, died August 30, 2014, surrounded by her family. Beloved mother of Susan, Linda and Barbara, grandmother of Matthew, mother-in-law of Nicholas and Elliot, and dear sister of Eleanor. Avid golfer, lover of the arts, Allison was dedicated to charitable causes. Her sense of humor, generosity, thirst for learning and adventure, and indomitable independent spirit will long be remembered. At once a prankster and disciplinarian, sensible and generous, she was above all a proud mother and reliable friend. Burial private. Family will receive friends on September 2, between 4pm and 7pm at Indian Cove. Donations to The Alzheimer's Association will be greatly appreciated.

EISENBERG--Anita Joy, 81 and forever young, a Raving beauty with black hair, cherubic lips and green eyes, from Brooklyn who resided in Hewlett Harbor, NYC, San Miguel and Boca West; spicy, feisty, biting sense of humor, held an intangible expansive view of the Universe and got a kick out of saying "St00pid with 2 O's", has swept our hearts away with her as she journeys onward. Her sharp wit and passion for living, will be sorely missed but her essence will linger on like a perfume. She is survived by Cheri, Mark, Stacey, Brian, Jordan, Carley, Jason, husband Stanley and BFF Jackie. Hope your Birthday was festive Mom! Family and Friends please join us for Service and Celebration of her Vivacious Spirit on Sunday, September 7th, NYC, 1:00pm Honeymoon Suite. Contact Cheri or Mark for info.
DICHTER--Stanley. To my beloved brother with whom I shared many happy times, I will miss you forever. Bobbie

COHEN--Eva Anne, New York City, passed away on August 17th in her 80th year. Eva was a passionate fighter for social justice, a committed Orthodox Jew and an ardent feminist. She was active in the anti-Vietnam war, civil rights, and women's rights movements. Eva was a loving wife to Gerry Cohen, who pre-deceased her, and a loving mother and grandmother. Eva is survived by her sons and daughters-in-law, Eric, Hugh, David, Judy and Susan, her grandchildren, Griffin, Sam, Lily, Holden, and Jeremy, and by her sister Bertha Kreisler and her family, and cousins. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Jewish World Service, The Abraham Joshua Heschel School, The Solomon Schechter School of Manhattan, or MJHS - Hospice and Palliative Care.

WEINSTEIN--Joan Berry. 12/10/1927-9/3/2014 In loving memory Her Family

YATES--Douglas T.,of New York City, on August 16, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Titus Yates, devoted father of Douglas T. Yates, Jr. (Mary Caryl) of New Haven, CT, Timothy T. Yates (Kay) of Rye, NY, and L. Randall Yates (the late Hope Lloyd) and Margaret Yates Thorne (Nate), of New York City. Adored grandfather of Nate and Nicholas Thorne, and Hope Starr, Lawrence Jr., Tim (Alexis), Chris (Angela), Ted, Katie, Doug (Kerri), Brian (Marci) and Scott (Mackenzie) Yates. Loving great-grandfather of Max, Charlie, Campbell, Jade, Summer, Dougie, Eddie, Gaby, Oscar and Lydia Yates. Doug was a graduate of Culver Military Academy and Williams College. He served his Country during World War II as a Major in the US Army Signal Corps, then was employed as the Executive Vice-President and Director of Republic Pictures Corp., Chairman of Seaboard Associates Inc., Partner at White, Weld and Co., and Vice-President at Merrill Lynch. Doug was a Trustee of The Buckley School, and was a Trustee and Founder of The Episcopal School in New York City. He also served as a member of the Vestry of St. James Church and the International Center for the Disabled, was a Trustee of the Hospital Chaplaincy and The General Theological Seminary, and was Chairman of the Board of Foreign Parishes of The Episcopal Church. He was a long-time Trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital, and was Chairman of The United Hospital Fund and Vice-Chairman of The Greater New York Fund of United Way. Doug was a Knight Hospitaller of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, and was proud to have received The United Hospital Distinguished Director Award for 28 years of Distinguished Service to Hospitals and the United Hospital Distinguished Trustee Award for Extraordinary Service to Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, NYC, Southward Ho C.C., Bay Shore, NY, and Gasparilla Inn Golf Club, Boca Grande, FL. A Memorial Service at St. James Church will be held at 11:00am on September 12, 2014. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street or The Episcopal School in New York City, 35 East 69th Street. Interment will be private.
