ROBBINS--Irving Milton. Irving Milton Robbins, a mechanical engineer, who built a New York City engineering firm that has been a fixture in high rise residential and commercial real estate development in New York City for the last 57 years, died on August 31, 2014 at his home in New Rochelle, New York after a valient struggle with Merkel Cell Carcinoma. He was 88. Mr. Robbins was the founder of I.M. Robbins, PC engineering firm in Manhattan and was President of the business for over five decades. He worked with most of New York City's top architects and real estate developers, and was trusted and respected by everyone he knew. There is hardly a part of the New York City skyline that has not been touched by his firm. Coming from humble beginnings, Irv was born in 1926 to Bertha and Michael Robbins and grew up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn during the depression. He knew from a very young age that he wanted to get out from where he was and focused on being a good student. Upon skipping a number of grades in school, he was accepted to City College of New York at the age of 16. In the middle of his college years, he was drafted to serve in WWII and enlisted in the US Marine Corps. He was in the 4th division and fought in the Pacific theater at Iwo Jima and was awarded the purple heart. He was always very proud of his service to his country. Upon completing his tour of duty, Irv then reenrolled at City College and eventually completed his Masters in Mechanical Engineering thanks to the support of the GI bill. He was always grateful for the education he received at City College. Later in life, he established a scholarship program for the engineering school and was awarded membership to the Lavender Hill Mob. After graduating, recognizing the need for engineering expertise in the real estate industry, he started his consulting firm, which initially had clients throughout the country. In 1952, he married his wife Esther, who he first met at the age of 15 years at McKibben Street Park in Brooklyn. They just celebrated their 62nd wedding anniversary. Irv's knowledge and experience was highly regarded in the real estate industry. He was licensed in 12 states, was a member of the National Society of Professional Engineers, American Society of Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning, American Society of Mechanical Engineers, New York State Society of Professional Engineers, Professional Engineers in Private Practice and American Arbitration Association. As his business grew, the firm concentrated its work in New York City where he was a member of the Mayor's Task Force on Fire Safety, and recently a Member of the Mayor's task force for revision of the 2014 Mechanical Code. Irv was always generous with his time and served for many years on the Board of his condominium in Long Boat Key, Florida. He loved his Florida home and his one regret was that he did not retire early enough to spend more time there with his wife Esther. Up until the last days of his life, he continued to provide advice to his condominium Board on engineering and building issues. Irv enjoyed traveling, golf and reading, but most of all he loved spending time with his family. He is survived by his beloved wife, Esther, his loving children Susan, Marc and daughter-in-law Rise, David and daughter-in-law Joyce and Carol and son-in-law Richard. He also leaves behind his adoring grandchildren, Danielle, Jennifer, Oliver, Daniel, Samantha, Amy, Sarah, Michael, Matthew and Isabel. Services were held on September 1st at the Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY 10710. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in Irv's memory to CCNY Grove School of Engineering, 160 Convent Avenue, Shepard Hall, New York, NY 10031.

ODLUM--Norman W.,New York, 91, died on August 27, 2014 in New York City. A native of Bristol Connecticut (BHS 40). Norman served the United States Navy during World War II. After the war he moved to New York City to study, under the auspices of the G.I. Bill of rights at New York University where he received his BA in 1949. In January 1950 he joined the SESAC, the music licensing organization, and was employed there except for a leave of absence to serve again in the Navy return the Korean War, until his retirement and early 1990s as a vice president. He is survived by nieces and nephews and cousins. He is pre-deceased by his life long companion Xavier Sanlier-Lamark. A Mass of Christian Burial and Military Honors will be celebrated at 11:00am on September 6, 2014 at St. Joseph Church 33 Queen St. Bristol, CT 06010. A celebration of Life for Norman Odlum and Xavier Sanlier-Lamark will be held on Sunday, October 5, 2014 at 1:00pm to 3:00pm at 27 West 55th Street New York, New York. A special thank you to Altria, Margaret, Michelle, Thomasine and Val his wonderful care givers. In lieu of Flowers, please make a contribution to a charity of your choice or do a good deed. Dunn Funeral Home 191 West St. Bristol is in charge of services. http://www.dunnfh.com/

MULA--Lilia. 15 years ago, we moved to a cul de sac on East 52nd Street. Only one person in a co-op of five buildings encompassing 400 apartments sent Myrna and me a welcome note. Then she sent a welcome gift. Then she sent an invitation to come visit her. She made us feel welcome and embraced and she oozed likeability and trustability and was caring and generous of spirit (all under a platinum bee hive). When Christmas came, she was like a child, examining every ornament, every decoration and then contributing her own, overwhelming us with silly, frivolous and whimsical follies of wind-up toys. We became playmates. She came to see what we planted on the terrace, tasted of the pesto made from the roof-grown basil and embraced each dog we owned during the period we lived in the building with her and oohed and aahed over Sherpa's doggy calendars. Lila was never happy with the way the employees of our building who served us and who took care of us were treated by the "management'. She made sure they had extra food, water, soft drinks and fruit. They became her extended family. She was hyper-vigilant to heavy snow storms, flooded subways, called their families, gave them pillows, chairs, blankets. She was Florence Nightingale on East 52nd Street. She was what has been characterized by a wise man as a "perfect foul-weather friend". Although she was a lady and never revealed anything indiscreet, she was encyclopedic in her knowledge of Emory Roth, the architectural background of our building, every neighbor who had been in the building and the unwritten building history. She knew, she shared and she never complained. Because of that, we never knew that she was terribly ill. She asked us to call her Mrs. Goldberg. She signed her letters to us as Mrs. Goldberg. And so, goodnight, Mrs. Goldberg. May you be in peace. You were a terrific friend, neighbor and left the earth a better place for having been on it. We will miss you. Myrna Freddie & Buddy Gershon

MARKEWICH--Iris Alexandra, 87, died peacefully at home on August 30, 2014. Born in New York City, daughter of Milton and Anna Grass, Iris was preceded in death by the love of her life, her soul-mate and husband of sixty-two years, Robert Markewich. Iris will be missed, and lovingly remembered, by her five children and their spouses: Deborah Lazarus, Judith Stuchiner (Robert), Ida Lawrence (Geoffrey), Jeremiah Markewich (Deborah), and Eve Rachel Markewich, her seven grandchildren and their spouses: David Lazarus (Susan Verni), Matthew Lazarus (Mariecel Pilapil), Jacob and Emily Stuchiner, Andrew Lawrence, and Chloe and Tessa Markewich, and her baby great grandson James Richard Lazarus. Iris graduated from Wellesley College and, while raising her family, earned a masters degree from Teachers College and a doctorate degree at NYU, at the age of 60. Iris worked for many years as a rehabilitation counselor and administrator at the Post Graduate Center for Mental Health. Later in life, Iris taught numerous courses in psychology at Mercy College and at NYU. She was an inspiration to all, as an example of being able to have it all a spectacular family life and a fulfilling professional career. For funeral services, call Plaza Funeral Home, 212-769-4400.

LANGSDORF--John Jeffrey, 85, died on August 30, 2014 in New York City. John was the the loving husband of Constance K. Berman, adored father of Robin B. Langsdorf and Holly L. Hatch and her husband Andrew Hatch, and beloved "Bapa" of granddaughters Kelsey and Sophie Hatch. His brother, Roger, and his wife Juel Janus will dearly miss him, as will several nieces and nephews. John was the devoted stepfather of Patricia (Greg Koerper), Anthony (Jill Remaly), Anne and Donald (Meredith Moss) Berman and the cherished step grandfather of eight. Born September 12, 1928, John attended Horace Mann School and Oberlin College. After proudly serving in the US Army, he worked in Philadelphia at WCAU-TV, an early CBS affiliate where he met his late wife, Doris Magnus. They lived in Montclair, NJ for forty years. John worked for many years at American Sponge & Chamois Co. and then Church and Dwight Co. before retiring and moving back to Manhattan, his birthplace. He traveled extensively, volunteered tirelessly and enjoyed the outdoors; especially his bike rides around Central Park. John was a lifelong supporter of the arts, and generously shared his love of music and theater with family and countless friends. He will be remembered as a gentle, kind, and thoughtful man who always put his family first. A memorial service will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture (NYSEC), 2 West 64th St., New York, NY 10023 on Saturday, September 6, 2014 at 2pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the NYSEC (www.nysec.org) or to the Squam Lakes Association, PO Box 204, Holderness, NH 03245 (www.squamlakes.org).

LANDAU--W. Loeber, died peacefully in his sleep at home on September 1. Loeber was a graduate of the Newman School in New Orleans, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Princeton University where he was valedictorian of his class, and a summa cum laude graduate of the Harvard Law School where he was the Developments Editor of the Law Review. After his service in the Office of the General Council of the Air Force he joined Sullivan & Cromwell where he spent his entire career and served on the managing committee. He served on several corporate boards but also made time to serve on the boards of many non-profit organizations. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Barbara Gordon Landau, son Gordon Loeber Landau, daughters Blair Trippe and Donna Hardiman and her husband John, and his adored grandchildren, Katherine and Elizabeth Hardiman and Victoria and Brian Trippe. The family will be receiving visitors at home on Thursday evening from 6-8pm. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Chapel Haven, a school for the developmentally disabled (1040 Whalley Ave., New Haven, CT 06510), Harvard Law School, or the charity of your choice.

LANDAU--W. Loeber, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member Loeber Landau our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President

KENDALL--George B.,died in Floreffe Belgium on August 27, 2014 at age 89. Born in Tasnad (modern Romania) in 1925 moved to New York City in 1951. Studied in Cluj, Sorbonne and Bocconi; worked in finance at FM Mayer, DB Marron before founding Economic Strategies, Inc. A lover of food and wine, The New York Times crosswords and the Mets; member of the Metropolitan Club and Sleepy Hollow Country Club. In 1954 married Linda Preminger (died in 2005); in 2006 married Myriam Bolland moved to Belgium in 2011. Survivors include two sons from his first marriage, Coleman Kendall of Washington, DC and Joshua Kendall of Boston and step daughter Sophie Koves. Contributions may be made to the Institute for World Politics www.iwp.edu. Cole Kendall

KALINOWSKY-LAXMETER--Frances, died on August 31, 2014. To our beloved and adored mother and grandmother, with whom we laughed, learned and sparred during her 94* years. Survived by her daughters and their families Ann and Gary, Nancy and Stewart, Sue and Neil, step-son Rabbi Michael and her grandchildren, Halee, Spencer, Franklin, Elyse, Seth, Joel, Miriam and Eli. Her smile and spirit will forever be with us. Memorial contributions in her memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

JORQUERA--Humberto, 88, an electrical engineer whose career was principally focused on Latin America, died in Southampton, NY on August 16, 2014. Mr. Jorquera, a longtime resident of Greenwich, CT., was born in Santiago, Chile to the late Olga and Humberto Jorquera of Santiago. Mr. Jorquera was predeceased by his wife, Mary, and his brothers, Sergio Jorquera and Jaime Jorquera, both of Santiago, Chile. He is survived by his daughters, Christine Vickery of New York, New York and Sarah Jorquera of Pound Ridge, New York, his sons in law, Alan Vickery and David Kulowiec, his five grandchildren, William, Sarah and James Vickery, and Catherine and Peter Kulowiec, and his sister and brother in-law, Sylvia and Jaime Riquelme of Clemmons, North Carolina. Mr. Jorquera graduated from the Instituto Nacional in Santiago, Chile and the Universidad de Chile, Santiago, Chile from which he received his degrees in electrical engineering. Upon completion of his university education Mr. Jorquera was accepted into an electrical engineering internship program in Boston sponsored by the General Electric Company and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While in the internship program, he met his future bride Mary O'Malley and was married in 1955. The couple lived in Santiago, Chile for several years during which time Mr. Jorquera worked for the Compania Chilena de Electricidad, at that time a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company (EBASCO.) Mr. Jorquera was then asked to relocate to the United States to work for EBASCO International, headquartered in Manhattan, where he served as a vice president of EBASCO International and various subsidiary utilities in Latin America. Many years later, following the acquisition of EBASCO International by Boise Cascade Corporation, Mr. Jorquera joined EBASCO Services, the consulting arm of EBASCO. At the time of his retirement he was manager of international rates and client services of EBASCO Services. Following his retirement from EBASCO, he worked as an independent consultant to U.S., Latin American and Caribbean utilities. A Funeral Mass was held on August 23, 2014, at St. Mary's Church in Greenwich, CT.
HIRSCHFELD--Allison B. July 22, 1931-August 30, 2014. In loving memory from her family.

HERMAN--James Windley died on September 1, 2014 in New Bern, NC, age 65, following a long battle with cancer. Jimmy, as he was known, was a graduate of Wagner College (1970) and Brooklyn Law School (1973). He served as an Assistant District Attorney in New York County in the 1970s and, thereafter for many years, as an Assistant United States Attorney in the US Dept. of Justice Organized Crime Strike Force office in Miami, FL. He is survived by his brother, Peter, of Scarsdale, NY and by two cousins, Susan Windley Eames and Nancy Windley Shelton, each of New Bern, NC. Memorial to be private, at a later date.

HALES--Peter Bacon. (November 13, 1950 August 26, 2014), an acclaimed American cultural historian, photographer and author, and a joyous musician, died in a tragic bicycling accident near his home in Stone Ridge, New York. Born in Pasadena, California, Peter grew up in Guilford, Connecticut. He graduated from Haverford College in 1972. At the University of Texas at Austin, he earned his MA in Photography and American Studies in 1976 and his PhD in American Civilization in 1980 under the mentorships of Garry Winogrand and Dr. William H. Goetzman, respectively. His early academic career led him to the University of Illinois at Chicago in 1980 where he became Professor of Art History, Chair of the Art History Department (2006-2010), and Director of the Study of the U.S. Institute for Scholars (formerly American Studies Institute). He retired in 2010, was named Professor Emeritus, and continued to teach until 2012. Peter and his wife Maureen relocated from Chicago to their home in Stone Ridge, NY in 2012, where he focused on research and writing. When his most recent book Outside The Gates of Eden - The Dream of America from Hiroshima to Now was published in April, he was immersed in new projects, including a photographic and cultural study of the American freeway. Earlier books include Atomic Spaces: Living on the Manhattan Project (1997); William Henry Jackson and the Transformation of the American Landscape (1988); and Silver Cities: The Photography of American Urbanization, 1839-1915 (1984; revised and published in 2005); as well as numerous essays and articles, the spectrum of which reflect his broad areas of interest and expertise. A natural community builder, Peter embraced life in the Hudson Valley with his treasured wife Maureen, developing strong friendships and a conservationist's sense of place. As an accomplished guitarist and songwriter, Peter sought out and found friendship, collaboration and community with musicians wherever he lived. As a passionate cyclist, Peter often rode over 200 miles a week with a team, a partner or solo. Beloved husband, dedicated father, loving brother and uncle, mentor and friend to many, Peter is survived by his wife Maureen Pskowski, son Taylor Hales, daughter Molly Hales, sisters, Susan Hales and Marty Hales. He is predeceased by his parents, Milton Reynolds Hales and Harriet Bacon Hales. Donations may be made in honor of Peter Hales to the Rondout Esopus Land Conservancy, where he served on the board. RELC - Peter Hales, PO Box 144, Accord, NY 12404 All are invited to share memories and photographs at: www.peterbhales.squarespace.com

GOLDBERG--Stanley, 85, of White Plains and Boca Raton, passed away unexpectedly on September 1, 2014. His family meant the world to him. Beloved husband of Doris for 64 years, brother of Melvin, father of Steve, Sandy, Meryl, Pam, Lanie, and Gary. Grandfather of Scott, Neil, Lacey, Martie, Alexa, Zack, Erin and Graham. Great-grandfather of Mia Rose. Dad, we will miss you every day for the rest of our lives!

FREDA--Domenico. The Lauder family and The Estee Lauder Companies express their condolences on the passing of Domenico Freda, father of our President and Chief Executive Officer, Fabrizio Freda. Domenico passed away on September 2, 2014. A beloved husband, father and dear friend of many, Domenico will be greatly missed. Domenico had an illustrious career, founding and managing a global construction company that operated throughout Italy, Eastern Europe and the Middle East. His passion for his family, his friends and his career will continue to be an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. Our sincerest thoughts and prayers are with Fabrizio and his family at this time.

FELL--Theodore A.,94, of Stuart, Florida and Westhampton Beach, NY died peacefully on August 31st. He was predeceased by his wife Elizabeth Durham. He is survived by his son, John Keith (Mary Ellen) and his daughter, Sabina Fell McCarthy (Joseph Sherman). Also survived by eight grandchildren, Sam and Teddy McCarthy, Elizabeth Karl (Bradford), Alexandra, Evan, Keith, Katherine and Charlie Fell. He was born in New York City on February 13, 1920 and graduated Stuyvesant High School. After school he worked for Arthur Murray as a dance instructor. He joined the Aviation Cadet Program and served heroically as a pilot and intelligence officer in the U.S. Air Force. After the war, he began a long and illustrious career in the apparel industry. In 1966 he became President and a partner with Sidney Gould in the It's Pure Gould Co. which was later acquired by Interco. Ted served as CEO and became a member of the Operating Board of Directors until 1985. Ted was a long time member of the Cherry Valley Club (Garden City), Westhampton Country Club and Mariner Sands Country Club (Stuart, FL). A memorial and celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, September 6th, 2014 at 4:30pm at the Westhampton Country Club. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Center for Discovery, Harris, NY and Little Flower Children's Services, Wading River, NY.

DUBIN--Helen L. Helen L. Dubin, once again is holding hands with her beloved Ralph. She passed away peacefully on August 23, 2014. We, her family, her sister, Clara Creditor; her nephews and nieces, Ruby Eisenberg-Creditor and Gary Creditor; Bruce and Susan Creditor; her great and great-great nieces and nephews will deeply miss this inspirational lady who so brought color and spice to all she touched. Her niece, Ruby, was a loving organizer of the devoted caregivers who enabled her to fulfill all her wishes with dignity, love, organic food and dance, and providing compassionate end-of life care with MJHS Hospice. Our beautiful centenarian activist was mentor to all, modeled powerful advocacy and personal and civic minded duty for generations. Her Social Work encompassed Adoption Advocacy, Juvenile Justice and championed the Aging Community of New York City, while always protecting her Westbeth Artist Community, of which she was the oldest resident. Memorial donations may be made to Westbeth Beautification Committee or MJHS Hospice.

BABBIN--Chester H.,83, of Somers, NY on Monday, September 1, 2014. Mr. Babbin was born January 8, 1931 in NYC. He was a retired LT in the US Navy serving during the Korean Conflict. Chester was an Executive Vice President for Merrill Lynch in NYC for over 50 years. He was twice president of the Katonah Rotary Club. He was predeceased by his late wife, Susan Schwarz Babbin. Chester is the beloved husband of Kathleen Roberts Babbin for over 36 years and is the loving father of Elizabeth (Nicholas) Tucker, Douglas (Elizabeth) Babbin and Barbara (Timothy) Mulvey. He is the adored grandfather of eight. He is the brother of Norma Horowitz and the late Malcolm Babbin. The funeral will be held 10:00am on Wednesday, September 3 at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY. Burial will follow at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla.

AIELLO--Dominick J. August 31, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Mary. Devoted father of Vincent, Rosann, Dominick and the late Raymond. Dear grandfather of Riccardo, Serena, Daniel and Jon-Michael. Great-grandfather of Yusuf, Gianna Rose, Miriam, Henry and Francesca. Loving Brother of Anthony, Peter, Orlando and Susan. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York City, Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10:30am, St. Anthony's Church. Entombment Trinity Church Mausoleum. Friends may call Wednesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Prostate Cancer Foundation, www.pcf.org, would be appreciated. YATES--Douglas T.,of New York City, on August 16, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Titus Yates, devoted father of Douglas T. Yates, Jr. (Mary Caryl) of New Haven, CT, Timothy T. Yates (Kay) of Rye, NY, and L. Randall Yates (the late Hope Lloyd) and Margaret Yates Thorne (Nate), of New York City. Adored grandfather of Nate and Nicholas Thorne, and Hope Starr, Lawrence Jr., Tim (Alexis), Chris (Angela), Ted, Katie, Doug (Kerri), Brian (Marci) and Scott (Mackenzie) Yates. Loving great-grandfather of Max, Charlie, Campbell, Jade, Summer, Dougie, Eddie, Gaby, Oscar and Lydia Yates. Doug was a graduate of Culver Military Academy and Williams College. He served his Country during World War II as a Major in the US Army Signal Corps, then was employed as the Executive Vice-President and Director of Republic Pictures Corp., Chairman of Seaboard Associates Inc., Partner at White, Weld and Co., and Vice-President at Merrill Lynch. Doug was a Trustee of The Buckley School, and was a Trustee and Founder of The Episcopal School in New York City. He also served as a member of the Vestry of St. James Church and the International Center for the Disabled, was a Trustee of the Hospital Chaplaincy and The General Theological Seminary, and was Chairman of the Board of Foreign Parishes of The Episcopal Church. He was a long-time Trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital, and was Chairman of The United Hospital Fund and Vice-Chairman of The Greater New York Fund of United Way. Doug was a Knight Hospitaller of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, and was proud to have received The United Hospital Distinguished Director Award for 28 years of Distinguished Service to Hospitals and the United Hospital Distinguished Trustee Award for Extraordinary Service to Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, NYC, Southward Ho C.C., Bay Shore, NY, and Gasparilla Inn Golf Club, Boca Grande, FL. A Memorial Service at St. James Church will be held at 11:00am on September 12, 2014. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street or The Episcopal School in New York City, 35 East 69th Street. Interment will be private.

SOMMER--Leonard, of Teaneck, NJ and formerly of North Massapequa, NY died on August 15, 2014 at the age of 93. The oldest son of Fay and Solomon Sommer, he was born in New York City and raised in the Bronx where he attended DeWitt Clinton High School. After being graduated from City College of New York he served as a naval officer commanding landing craft in the Pacific Theater during World War II. Following his War service he attended Harvard Law School where he became an editor on the "Law Review." His legal career of 60 years was spent at the law firm Milbank Tweed Hadley and McCloy where he was an associate and later of counsel specializing in securities law. While he found the practice of law and mentoring lawyers to be both stimulating and satisfying he especially enjoyed his four decade involvement in the annual shows at the firm which were performed by the Milkweed Mighty Arts Players. Mr. Sommer married the former Dr. Beatrice Scott in 1950 and together they raised their sons Richard and Charles until her death in 1991. He enjoyed reading, bridge, and music, particularly show tunes and standards. One of his most enjoyable activities in the past year was performing in the chorus at Five Star Residence in Teaneck where he lived. He was a lifetime supporter of his synagogue, Temple B'nai Torah of Wantagh, NY and its predecessor Temple Judea of Massapequa, NY. He is survived by his sons Richard of Glen Rock, NJ, Charles of Derry, NH; daughters-in-law Amy and Nancie; brother Ted; sister-in-law Yole, sister-in-law Janne; grandchildren Sharon, Sarah, Rebekah, and Hannah, and numerous nieces, nephews, and cousins. He was predeceased by his brother Jerry. Charitable contributions may be made in his memory to Temple B'nai Torah, 2900 Jerusalem Ave, Wantagh, NY 11793.

SLOANE--Virginia. Jazz at Lincoln Center celebrates the life of Virginia Sloane, a lively and feisty woman, with enormous gratitude for her many contributions, her love of Jazz, and the arts. Robert J. Appel, Wynton Marsalis and the JALC Family

RUBIN--Judith. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Judith Rubin, and extend sincere condolences to her family. James Dreyfus, President

MULA--Lilia. 15 years ago, we moved to a cul de sac on East 52nd Street. Only one person in a co-op of five buildings encompassing 400 apartments sent Myrna and me a welcome note. Then she sent a welcome gift. Then she sent an invitation to come visit her. She made us feel welcome and embraced and she oozed likeability and trustability and was caring and generous of spirit (all under a platinum bee hive). When Christmas came, she was like a child, examining every ornament, every decoration and then contributing her own, overwhelming us with silly, frivolous and whimsical follies of wind-up toys. We became playmates. She came to see what we planted on the terrace, tasted of the pesto made from the roof-grown basil and embraced each dog we owned during the period we lived in the building with her and oohed and aahed over Sherpa's doggy calendars. Lila was never happy with the way the employees of our building who served us and who took care of us were treated by the "management'. She made sure they had extra food, water, soft drinks and fruit. They became her extended family. She was hyper-vigilant to heavy snow storms, flooded subways, called their families, gave them pillows, chairs, blankets. She was Florence Nightingale on East 52nd Street. She was what has been characterized by a wise man as a "perfect foul-weather friend". Although she was a lady and never revealed anything indiscreet, she was encyclopedic in her knowledge of Emory Roth, the architectural background of our building, every neighbor who had been in the building and the unwritten building history. She knew, she shared and she never complained. Because of that, we never knew that she was terribly ill. She asked us to call her Mrs. Goldberg. She signed her letters to us as Mrs. Goldberg. And so, goodnight, Mrs. Goldberg. May you be in peace. You were a terrific friend, neighbor and left the earth a better place for having been on it. We will miss you. Myrna Freddie & Buddy Gershon

LANDAU--W. Loeber. The Board of Directors, Shareholders and Staff of 510 Park Avenue mourn the death of long time resident, W. Loeber Landau. Until recently, Loeber served as a dedicated Officer and Board Member lending his formidable knowledge and judgment in the discharge of his positions on the Board. Deepest condolences to his wife Barbara and their children.

LANDAU--W. Loeber, died peacefully in his sleep at home on September 1. Loeber was a graduate of the Newman School in New Orleans, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Princeton University where he was valedictorian of his class, and a summa cum laude graduate of the Harvard Law School where he was the Developments Editor of the Law Review. After his service in the Office of the General Council of the Air Force he joined Sullivan & Cromwell where he spent his entire career and served on the managing committee. He served on several corporate boards but also made time to serve on the boards of many non-profit organizations. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Barbara Gordon Landau, son Gordon Loeber Landau, daughters Blair Trippe and Donna Hardiman and her husband John, and his adored grandchildren, Katherine and Elizabeth Hardiman and Victoria and Brian Trippe. The family will be receiving visitors at home on Thursday evening from 6-8pm. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Chapel Haven, a school for the developmentally disabled (1040 Whalley Ave., New Haven, CT 06510), Harvard Law School, or the charity of your choice.

LANDAU--W. Loeber. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Loeber Landau, a distinguished member of the Met's board since 1992. On behalf of everyone in the company, we extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Barbara, and to their family. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Kevin W. Kennedy, President & CEO Mrs. Walter J. Laughery, Jr., Major Gifts Chairman Peter Gelb, General Manager

KURSHAN--Jerome, of Princeton, NJ, on September 3rd, 2014, at age 95. Beloved husband of the late Phyllis Kurshan. Loving father of Neil (Alisa) Kurshan and Rachel Kurshan. Grandfather of five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Funeral September 4th, at 10:30am, at the Jewish Center, 435 Nassau Street, Princeton, NJ.

JACOBSON--Pauline F.,98, died peacefully at home on September 2. Survived by her son Howard (Kathryn Wolfson), brother Joseph Feld (Mairuth) and grandchildren Stefanie London (Jonathan Reich), Jennifer Jacobson (William Yang), Adam Hoffman, Erica Jacobson (Andrew Fishman) and Joshua Jacobson, as well as seven great-grandchildren. Predeceased by husband Paul, daughter Edith Hoffman and sisters Sarah Boxer and Fanny Joseph. Services Friday, September 5, 10am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

HOFRICHTER--Lawrence Steven (May 22, 1947 - September 2, 2014) was a dedicated attorney for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from 1971 until his retirement in 2012. He was a graduate of NYU and NYU School of Law. He served as Deputy General Counsel and Assistant Secretary of the Port Authority. He was honored to administer the Port Authority's World Trade Center Memorial Fund. Larry is survived by his wife, Frima Fox Hofrichter, his sons, Michael (Hannah) and Lee, his granddaughter, Razele, and his sisters, Beverly Dann (Jeffrey), and Frances Hofrichter. The Funeral will be at Highland Park Conservative Temple - Congregation Anshe Emeth, 201 South Third Avenue, Highland Park, NJ on Thursday, September 4th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to JewishGen, Inc.: www.jewishgen.org

GUTMANN--Ilse, beloved wife of the late Otto, devoted mother of Linda Kaplan, Benjamin Gutmann, Harold Gutmann and Hedy Collins. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Service at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC, today at 1:15pm.

GOLDBERG--Stanley M.,88, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of North Bellmore, NY, passed away peacefully on August 29, 2014. Stanley was raised in Borough Park, Brooklyn, and graduated from CCNY ('47) and Columbia Law School ('49). He served as an officer in the US Army in WWII and the Korean War, and was awarded the Purple Heart. Stanley was predeceased by his first wife, Ada (Lublin), his second wife, Renee (Bennett), and his daughter, Helene Goldberg. He is survived by his son, Lawrence A. Goldberg, daughter-in-law, Lisa C. Barnett, and granddaughter, Julia A. Goldberg, all of New York, NY. He was a brilliant, funny, loving, optimistic, outgoing man, and will remain in our hearts forever.

FREEMAN--Richard H. The Trustees of the Brooklyn Benevolent Society mourn the passing of our friend and colleague. As President, he acted with charity and great patience as his wit and graciousness enriched us. Our condolences to Isobel and the Freeman family. Thank you, Dick. James J. Daly, Vice President

ERMAN--Carl M.,a prominent medical malpractice defense attorney in the New York metropolitan area died on September 2, 2014 after a seven month battle with Amyloidosis. Mr. Erman of New York City and Boca Raton, Florida was 69 years old. He received his Undergraduate Degree from Rutgers University in 1967 and graduated from Brooklyn Law School where he received his J.D. in 1971. In 1982 he co-founded Amabile & Erman, P.C. with offices in New York and New Jersey. He was a member of the New York State Bar Association, New Jersey State Bar Association, Richmond County Bar Association, New York State Trial Lawyers Association, Defense Association of New York and New York Medical Defense Bar Association. During his more than 40 year legal career, Mr. Erman had tried to verdict over 100 cases in both State and Federal Courts involving high exposure medical malpractice claims in which he defended the interests of doctors and hospitals. Aside from his extensive knowledge of medicine, Mr. Erman was known for his pointed cross examinations of plaintiffs' expert witnesses during trial and his ability to reduce the most complex medical case to its simplest terms which could be easily understood by his juries. In addition to his law practice, Carl Erman was a man of many and varied interests. From African safaris, to the peaks of Machu Pichu, and skiing the Alps with his family, he loved to travel. A real New Yorker at heart, he made Manhattan his home and took advantage of all the city has to offer. A die-hard New Jersey Devils fan, his biggest love was for his family and all the special times he shared with them. Mr. Erman is survived by his wife Linda, his children Jonathan, Neal, Wendy, their spouses Pia, Lisa, Jonathan, six grandchildren, and his brother Harold. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother and friend. He will be greatly missed. Services will be held 11:00am Thursday, September 4, 2014 at the Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, Livingston, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Dr. Heather Landau Amyloid Fund, 633 3rd Ave, 28th Floor, NY, NY 10017 or the Amyloidosis Foundation.

COLLINS--Gertrude "Trudy" T, age 88, of Rochester, NH died peacefully on August 27. Visitation will be today from 5 to 7pm at the Elliott, Woodworth & Rogers Funeral Home, 35 Green Street, Newburyport, MA 01950. Mrs. Collins was born in Brooklyn, NY. She was the devoted wife of John J. Collins and the loving mother of the late Patrick J. Collins. She is survived by five children, John, Maureen, Michael, Daniel, Kevin, and eleven grandchildren. She will always be a profound part of our lives. "In death there is little I leave behind except my love for all of you."

CLARK--Mary, RSCJ died September 1st in Albany. She taught at Manhattanville College for more than 30 years. The author/editor of nine books and countless scholarly articles, her research and writing were primarily on Augustine and Thomas Aquinas. She served as visiting professor at St. John Neumann Seminary for more than 20 years. Her numerous honors included honorary degrees from Manhattanville and Villanova University, Outstanding Educator of America, the Aquinas Medal for Eminence in Philosophy and the Interracial Justice Award. Visit www.rscj.org. Born in Philadelphia October 23, 1913, to Francis S. and Regina Holland Twibill Clark, her brothers George A. and Rev. James D. Clark, and sister, Regina (Mrs. James P.) McGranery, predeceased her. She is survived by nieces and nephews and their children and grandchildren. Services: Funeral at 11:00 A.M. Saturday, September 6 in the chapel at Teresian House, Albany. Visitation one hour prior to the funeral. Memorial at Manhattanville Sunday, October 26, time and location TBD.

CARCELLE--Yves. The board of trustees and staff of amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, mourn the loss of Yves Carcelle, the former chairman and CEO of Louis Vuitton. At the instigation of Mr. Carcelle, Louis Vuitton has been a major supporter of amfAR and the fight against AIDS for many years. Through its generous contributions and donation of the proceeds from a custom line of vanity cases, specially designed by amfAR Global Fundraising Chairman Sharon Stone, Louis Vuitton has contributed millions of dollars to the Foundation. In recognition of his philanthropic efforts, amfAR honored Mr. Carcelle with its Award of Courage in 2010. His kindness and generosity of spirit will be remembered with gratitude. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Kenneth Cole, Chairman of the Board Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chairman Kevin Robert Frost, Chief Executive Officer

SULLIVAN--Eugene. The St. John's University family celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Eugene Sullivan, '42C, '73HON, distinguished and accomplished alumnus, extraordinarily generous benefactor, and first lay chair of the University's Board of Trustees. For almost three-quarters of a century, he blessed us with his wise counsel, loyal friendship, and dedicated service, given with a noble and humble heart. Amidst a busy and successful career, he found time to share his knowledge and corporate experience with generations of students as a professor in the School of Business. He evidenced his devotion to alma mater in a myriad of ways, including through the gift of Sullivan Hall on the Queens campus, which will remain as a permanent memorial to his vision and values. Our University is stronger and better because he has been a part of it. St. John's extends its prayers and its deepest sympathy to the Sullivan family in this time of sorrow and joins them in thanking God for the gift of this truly remarkable man. Peter P. D'Angelo, Chair, Board of Trustees Conrado M. Gempesaw, Ph.D., President

SULLIVAN--Eugene J. The administration, trustees, and staff of St. Francis Hospital, The Heart Center in Roslyn, New York, mourn the passing of Eugene J. Sullivan, longtime friend, benefactor, and board member. Mr. Sullivan served on the St. Francis Board of Trustees for 28 years, beginning in 1974, and he was Chairman of the Board from 1978 to 1981, a pivotal time in the hospital's history. It was during Mr. Sullivan's tenure that St. Francis consolidated its focus on the delivery of specialized cardiac services, and the Hospital became the first and only specialty designated cardiac center in New York State. He put his considerable talent and expertise as a successful corporate executive to work for a cause he loved, and during this time, St. Francis witnessed the dramatic growth of its facilities and services and its national and international reputation. While we mourn his passing, we also celebrate Mr. Sullivan as the warmest of friends and most dedicated of supporters. His leadership, generosity, and kindness will always be remembered by the St. Francis community. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Sullivan family during this sad time.

RIVERS--Joan. The officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Joan Rivers. A trailblazer in comedy, she opened the doors for female comedians to be who they want to bebold, beautiful and funny! We will miss the sass but we cherish the memories.

MURPHY--Walter Joseph, devoted husband of the late Veronica (Ronnie) and loving father of Dr. Brian Murphy, passed away after a long illness on August 21, 2014 in Newport Beach, California at the age of 87. A native New Yorker, Walter was a Navy veteran of the WWII Pacific theater and spent his career at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. from which he retired in the early 90's. A graduate of St. Francis College in NYC, Walter was an avid photographer, supporter of Jesuit education, and animal rights/ care programs. Contributions in his memory may be made to Fordham Preparatory School, 441 East Fordham Road, Bronx, NY 10458.

Donations in her honor may be made to the VH1 Save the Music Foundation.

Loeber Landau. We will miss his generous heart, counsel and love of the theatre. We extend our heart-felt condolences to Loeber's wife Barbara and their family.

JACOBSON--Pauline F.,98, died peacefully at home on September 2. Survived by her son Howard (Kathryn Wolfson), brother Joseph Feld (Mairuth) and grandchildren Stefanie London (Jonathan Reich), Jennifer Jacobson (William Yang), Adam Hoffman, Erica Jacobson (Andrew Fishman) and Joshua Jacobson, as well as seven great-grandchildren. Predeceased by husband Paul, daughter Edith Hoffman and sisters Sarah Boxer and Fanny Joseph. Services Friday, September 5, 10am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

HOFRICHTER--Lawrence Steven (May 22, 1947 - September 2, 2014) was a dedicated attorney for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from 1971 until his retirement in 2012. He was a graduate of NYU and NYU School of Law. He served as Deputy General Counsel and Assistant Secretary of the Port Authority. He was honored to administer the Port Authority's World Trade Center Memorial Fund. Larry is survived by his wife, Frima Fox Hofrichter, his sons, Michael (Hannah) and Lee, his granddaughter, Razele, and his sisters, Beverly Dann (Jeffrey), and Frances Hofrichter. The Funeral will be at Highland Park Conservative Temple - Congregation Anshe Emeth, 201 South Third Avenue, Highland Park, NJ on Thursday, September 4th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to JewishGen, Inc.: www.jewishgen.org

FISH--Judith. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Judith (nee Chinks) Fish of Montreal, the beloved wife of Morris Fish, the former Hon. Justice of the Supreme Court of Canada, an honorary alumnus of Yeshiva University who actively participated in programs of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Justice Morris Fish, their children, grandchildren, his sister-in-law Havie and the late Marvin Walker, Mattie and Gerri Chinks, Mal and the late Miriam Coven, nieces and nephews and aunt and uncle Avi and Dora Morrow. May the entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

EWING--Kenneth A.,MD, on September 1, 2014 of Sands Point, NY. Loving husband of Pauline. Devoted father of P.K. Ewing. Also survived by two brothers and one sister. Calling hours at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY on Saturday from l-5pm and Sunday 1-2pm, with services at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Dr. Ewing's memory may be made to: ASPCA.org/donate

ELISH--Helen Siegel. Beloved wife of the late Marvin and loving companion of the late Harold Meltzer. Devoted mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. Graveside service Monday, September 8, 10:45am, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

DUNKLE--Ruth Passweg, died peacefully on September 4, 2014. Born in Lyon, France in 1938 she escaped the Nazi holocaust and arrived in America with her family on New Year's Eve in 1940. She grew up in Manhattan and moved to Edison, NJ when she married. Ruth graduated from Mount Holyoke in 1960, received a PhD in Classics from NYU and taught Latin and ancient history at the high school and college level. After leaving academia, she had a successful career in real estate where her cards read, "Ask Dr. Ruth." Ruth was a woman of wide and varied interests, which included horseback riding, tennis, classical music, and her vacation house in North Carolina where she used her considerable photography skills to capture the beauty of the Outer Banks. She was a passionate Scrabble player, competing in online competitions and tournaments. Predeceased by her older sister, Eva, Ruth is survived and mourned by her younger sister, Judith Podell, a niece, Julia Bard, great niece Sasha Bard, three nephews, Philip Bard, Daniel Podell, and Adam Podell, and her husband of 44 years, Roger. Loyal and generous, she maintained lifelong relationships with friends from her childhood days at Camp Wenonah in Maine. Ruth will be sorely missed by many who remember her unselfishness, intelligence and wit. A memorial service is planned for a future date. Donations in honor of Ruth may be made to a charity of choice.

DIX--Stuart. The Hochfelder, Lerner and Cohen families are so sad today. Pop Stu was a fixture in our family meals, trips and memories. His beautiful, humble, sweet way and smile is something that we will all miss and remember forever. Judy, our hearts go out to you - your relationship with Stu was beautiful. Farrel, you are the epitome of what a loving daughter should be and your Dad was very proud of you. Steven, Brian, Andrew and Stef we are so sorry for this tremendous loss. We love you all.

COLGATE--Marlene Strobel, mother, grandmother, thinker. BA Smith, MA Yale, MA NYU. Memorial service: September 7, 2014 at 2:30pm, House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95, NYC, NY. Donations: democracynow.org/donate (in memory) with a note to: kidsofmarlene@gmail.com

CLARK--Mary, RSCJ died September 1st in Albany. She taught at Manhattanville College for more than 30 years. The author/editor of nine books and countless scholarly articles, her research and writing were primarily on Augustine and Thomas Aquinas. She served as visiting professor at St. John Neumann Seminary for more than 20 years. Her numerous honors included honorary degrees from Manhattanville and Villanova University, Outstanding Educator of America, the Aquinas Medal for Eminence in Philosophy and the Interracial Justice Award. Visit www.rscj.org. Born in Philadelphia October 23, 1913, to Francis S. and Regina Holland Twibill Clark, her brothers George A. and Rev. James D. Clark, and sister, Regina (Mrs. James P.) McGranery, predeceased her. She is survived by nieces and nephews and their children and grandchildren. Services: Funeral at 11:00 A.M. Saturday, September 6 in the chapel at Teresian House, Albany. Visitation one hour prior to the funeral. Memorial at Manhattanville Sunday, October 26, time and location TBD.

BRESSMAN--Bernice. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Bernice Bressman. Bernice leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Bernice's son and daughter-in-law, Robert and Amy, and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

RIVERS--Joan. The Barnard College community is saddened by the death of Joan Rivers, proud alumna of the Class of 1954, who made us laugh for many decades. RIVERS--Joan. The Board, staff, volunteers and clients of God's Love We Deliver are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved Board member, Joan Rivers. Joan was a profoundly compassionate friend of God's Love for over 25 years. She will be sorely missed for her brilliant humor and insightful view on life, but most especially for the kindness, joy and generosity she brought to everything she did for God's Love and our clients. Joan was one of a kind and irreplaceable. Joan's remarkable impact on God's Love will be remembered always. We send our deepest condolences to Melissa and Cooper.

MURPHY--Walter Joseph, devoted husband of the late Veronica (Ronnie) and loving father of Dr. Brian Murphy, passed away after a long illness on August 21, 2014 in Newport Beach, California at the age of 87. A native New Yorker, Walter was a Navy veteran of the WWII Pacific theater and spent his career at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. from which he retired in the early 90's. A graduate of St. Francis College in NYC, Walter was an avid photographer, supporter of Jesuit education, and animal rights/ care programs. Contributions in his memory may be made to Fordham Preparatory School, 441 East Fordham Road, Bronx, NY 10458.

LEVINE--Albert B.,age 92, from Brooklyn, Long Island and New Jersey, World War II combat veteran Normandy invasion. CASTLEMAN--Riva. The Foundation for Art and Preservation in Embassies is profoundly saddened by the death of Riva Castleman. As the founder of FAPE's Professional Fine Arts Committee, she shaped our longest running program, the Original Print Collection. Her brilliance attracted many of the greatest American artists, forming lasting relationships, and achieving what no one else could, as no would dare say no to her. Her contributions to the world of art history constitute a great legacy, and her impact will not soon be forgotten. We send our deepest sympathy to her family. Jo Carole Lauder, Chairman Eden Rafshoon, President Darren Walker, Vice President Elizabeth Pozen, Secretary Robert Storr, Chairman, FAPE's Professional Fine Arts Committee and Dean, Yale School of Art Jennifer A. Duncan, Director

CASTLEMAN--Riva. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of Riva Castleman, legendary print curator, who worked at the Museum from 1963 to 1995. Riva first joined MoMA's Department of Prints and Illustrated Books as a cataloger; in 1976 she became Director of Prints and Illustrated Books, and in 1986 she was named Deputy Director of Curatorial Affairs, a position she held in addition to her work as Director of Prints and Illustrated Books until she retired in June 1995. Recognizing the significance of prints and illustrated books as important expressions of modern art, Riva organized dozens of exhibitions and catalogues that helped to advance scholarship in the field and convey the importance of these mediums to a wider audience. Her efforts resulted in many landmark publications that remain standard references today, including Prints of the Twentieth Century: A History (1976), Printed Art: A View of Two Decades (1980), Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec (1985), Jasper Johns: A Print Retrospective (1987), and A Century of Artists Books (1994). Her work inspired a generation of curators and collectors, and her passion and dedication ensured that MoMA's collection of prints and illustrated books would remain the premier collection of its kind in the world. Her legacy is also reflected in two innovative initiatives that continue to provide support to the Museum and that have influenced other museums around the world. In 1975 she organized the Print Associates, the first collectors' group affiliated with a curatorial department at the Museum. She conceived of an endowment earmarked for the acquisition of prints and illustrated books, also a first for a curatorial department at the Museum. Her astute intelligence, sharp eye, and exacting standards left a mark on all who had the good fortune to know or work with her, and she will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to Riva's niece, Kristen DeVoe, and her family. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Art

CASTLEMAN--Riva. It is with deep sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the passing of its beloved honorary member Riva Castleman, who became an honorary member after her retirement from the MoMA staff in 1995. Among her many projects for the Museum's International Program was the comprehensive survey Modern Art in Prints that was exhibited in 23 cities in Australia, New Zealand, India, Iran, and Japan. She also directed other important traveling exhibitions including Latin American Prints, American Prints 1913-1963, and Modern Artists as Illustrators, which had extensive tours in Latin America, the Far East, and Europe. Riva will be long remembered by her many friends and colleagues throughout the world for her unerring eye, her keen intelligence, and her very sharp wit. We send our deepest sympathies to her family. Agnes Gund, Chair; Brian Urquhart, H.R.H. Duke Franz von Bayern, Chairs Emeriti; Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President; Jo Carole Lauder, Joann K. Phillips, Jeanne C. Thayer, Presidents Emeritae; Lewis B. Cullman, Beatrix Medinger, Vice Chairs; William L. Bernhard, Secretary. The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

Japan is a longtime donor to the Center for Strategic and International Studies, which has a program devoted to defining a strategic agenda for United States-Japan relations. The research group has organized events in cooperation with Japan government interests, bringing together members of Congress, as well as trade officials from the United States and Japan, to discuss issues important to both countries.

The United Arab Emirates has a longstanding relationship with the Center for Strategic and International Studies through which it sponsors a series of talks at the center about issues related to the Persian Gulf, papers about the region and trips that C.S.I.S. organizes that involve American security experts, to learn more about the region.

Norway made another contribution to the Atlantic Council — about $115,000 in 2007 — -to fund a program that would prepare advice for United States officials and other global leaders on how to create more peaceful relations between Turkey and the Kurds, who for much of the last decade have controlled the northern part of Iraq.

Norway signed agreements with both the Center for Strategic and International Studies and Brookings asking the think tanks to conduct research focusing on issues related to the Arctic Circle and climate change. Norway has long been a global leader in pushing for action to combat climate change. Its state-owned oil company, Statoil, is also preparing to begin oil exploration work in the area, where large-scale melting in recent years has been attributed to climate change and global warming.

The government of Norway has had a longstanding partnership through which Norway funds a broad array of research at the Brookings Institution, on topics as varied as Iran’s role in conflicts in Afghanistan and combating climate change.

The government of Azerbaijan hired a Washington-based public relations and lobbying firm in 2012 with the explicit purpose of expanding its relationships with think tanks here to try to reinforce public opinion in the United States and to make it clear that this Central Asian nation is an important security partner. It is a campaign that produced real results.

The Atlantic Council, which has experienced explosive growth in recent years, has negotiated a number of important, and lucrative, deals with the government of Norway. Here is a look at the ties between the two.

Norway entered into an agreement with the Center for Global Development, a Washington-based think tank that focuses on “how policies and actions of the rich and powerful affect poor people in the developing world.” The center was to work with Climate Advisers, a consulting firm, to persuade policy makers in the United States and other countries to increase funding for forest-protection programs, a top foreign policy priority of Norway. Such programs are known by the acronym REDD, for “reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation.”

Foreign governments are a major source of money for think tanks in Washington, making donations, in many cases, with a goal of trying to influence United States foreign policy. The think tanks offer the donor governments special access to United States government officials, at times in exchange for the financial support. Here is a look at these ties.

SIEBERT--Muriel F. It has been a year since you left us. The path you paved for women in finance has become a road to the future for many. We will always be grateful for your courage. The Muriel F. Siebert Foundation
SCHWARTZMAN--Dr. Isidore 9/6/20 - 8/14/13 Dear Dad: Happy 94th Birthday! We miss you very much.
POWELL--Maxwell Marshall. 21 years without you. Always in our hearts. Missing you now and always. No greater love.

KLEIER--Jonathan. Dear Jonathan, Even after five years it is still impossible to imagine this world without you. Your time with us was too heartbreakingly short but while we had you, your teddy bear laughter, your incredibly strong spirit, your infectious smile, and your eternally hopeful love of life were so abundant everywhere. We all carry you in our hearts every day. You were always voted by The Family as the one we'd want with us on a desert island. Now you are there, ready to hug the rest of us when we come. In the meantime, always be our Guardian Angel. We love you and miss you more than anything forever and ever and ever. Love you, The Family

GOLDBERG--William Eric. Jan. 2, 1971 - Sept. 7, 2000. Billy, it has been 14 years since you left us. You are in our thoughts and hearts every day. You are our angel. Please watch over us! Love, Mom and Heather.
CURCIO--Frank. Daddy, miss you every day. Watch over us. Help us to heal. Love, Paola
COHEN--Edward Baron. Five sad years without your wisdom, guidance and love. Andrew and Richard

ZUCKERT-COWLES-- Adrienne, died August 30, 2014, 75 years old of West Cornwall, CT. Born in New York City to Eugene M. Zuckert, former Secretary of Air Force, and Kathleen Barnes Zuckert of Salt Lake City. Graduate of University of Michigan l961. Writer/Producer NBC, awarded Emmy 1968 for contributions to documentary "Summer '67: What we learned." Formerly married to Chandler Cowles and Robert Mulholland. Survived by loving brother and sister: Robert B. Zuckert, and Genie Z. Farris, both of Phoenix, AZ, nephews, niece and grandnephews, grandnieces. Beloved by many for her quick sometimes irreverent wit, keen intelligence, zany sense of humor, absolute love for all animals, her dogs and stray cats, natural musical ability and gentle and generous ways. At her request, no services. Memories to Robert B. Zuckert, Box B, Keene, NH 03431.

WUSTER--Edward J. Retired from SIAC/NYSE, died September 2, 2014, born September 2, 1937. Beloved husband and father of three Sons and seven grandchildren. Memorial September 13, 2014, Coral Ridge Funeral Home, Cape Coral, FL, 239-283-0540

WEISHOFF--Bernice, beloved wife of Henry Weishoff (deceased), passed away peacefully on September 5th, 2014 in New York at the age of 89. Bernice Weishoff was born Bernice Schiffrin in New York City in 1925. She married Henry Weishoff in 1950 and they had two sons, Steven and Daniel. An aspiring singer/actress, Bernice Saunders, which was her stage name, performed in a number of major Broadway shows. Among the most notable were "South Pacific", "Sound of Music," "Jennie," "Annie Get Your Gun" and "Do I Hear a Waltz." (Original cast for all.) She was also frequently called upon by Rogers and Hammerstein to try out new songs they had written. She is survived by her sons, Steven (Marla), Daniel (Chrissy), and her stepson, Robert (Carol) as well as her eight beloved grandchildren, Diana, Danielle, Rachel, Nicole, Andrea, Barton, George and Christina. Bernice is also survived by her brother, Michael Schiffrin. The funeral service will be held on Monday, September 8th, 2014 at 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023.
STERN--Judith, 78, of Boynton Beach, FL, passed peacefully on August 25, 2014 in Lee, MA. Funeral was at Cedar Park Cemetery, NJ. Memorial service will be held in Florida. Details to be determined.

SOMMER--Leonard, of Teaneck, NJ and formerly of North Massapequa, NY died on August 15, 2014 at the age of 93. The oldest son of Fay and Solomon Sommer, he was born in New York City and raised in the Bronx where he attended DeWitt Clinton High School. After being graduated from City College of New York he served as a naval officer commanding landing craft in the Pacific Theater during World War II. Following his War service he attended Harvard Law School where he became an editor on the "Law Review." His legal career of 60 years was spent at the law firm Milbank Tweed Hadley and McCloy where he was an associate and later of counsel specializing in securities law. While he found the practice of law and mentoring lawyers to be both stimulating and satisfying he especially enjoyed his four decade involvement in the annual shows at the firm which were performed by the Milkweed Mighty Arts Players. Mr. Sommer married the former Dr. Beatrice Scott in 1950 and together they raised their sons Richard and Charles until her death in 1991. He enjoyed reading, bridge, and music, particularly show tunes and standards. One of his most enjoyable activities in the past year was performing in the chorus at Five Star Residence in Teaneck where he lived. He was a lifetime supporter of his synagogue, Temple B'nai Torah of Wantagh, NY and its predecessor Temple Judea of Massapequa, NY. He is survived by his sons Richard of Glen Rock, NJ, Charles of Derry, NH; daughters-in-law Amy and Nancie; brother Ted; sister-in-law Yole, sister-in-law Janne; grandchildren Sharon, Sarah, Rebekah, and Hannah, and numerous nieces, nephews, and cousins. He was predeceased by his brother Jerry. Charitable contributions may be made in his memory to Temple B'nai Torah, 2900 Jerusalem Ave, Wantagh, NY 11793.
SHARE--Edward, of Fort Lee, NJ (Longtime owner of Lou G. Siegel's Restaurant, NYC) For information "Eden memorial chapels" 1-888-700-3336.

SHAHON--Dr. Donald B.,90, adored husband of the late Selma Shahon, passed away peacefully surrounded by his family August 30, 2014. Dr. Shahon was a distinguished physician, accomplished surgeon and clinical instructor of surgery at Harvard and Tufts Medical Schools. He received undergraduate and medical degrees from Tufts University and a PhD in surgery from the University of Minnesota where he trained under world-renowned surgeon Dr. Owen Wangensteen, along with Drs. Christiaan Barnard and Norman Shumway. He was a pioneer and innovator in the early detection and surgical management of stomach cancer. Dr. Shahon will be greatly missed by his five children, seventeen grandchildren and great-grandchild.

ROSENTHAL--Hilda Davis, born on March 24, 1923, passed away September 1, 2014, at age 91, widow of George Rosenthal. Loving mother of Beth Rosenthal Finkel and son-in-law, Shelly Finkel; adoring grandmother of Genny Finkel, William and Wendy Perlmutter Finkel, and Steven and Lee Finkel Goldberg; great-grandmother of Ashley, Henry and Hannah; and devoted sister of Marilyn Davis Levine. Hildy gave her all for family, friends and community. For her official nieces and nephews and her 'adopted' ones, she truly loved you all. Donations may be made to the New York Common Pantry: nycommonpantry.org. Funeral to be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street, Manhattan on Tuesday, September 2, at 1pm. The family will be sitting shiva at the home of Beth and Shelly Finkel through Sunday. Remember her smiling on the dance floor....

RIVERS--Joan. The Board, staff, volunteers and clients of God's Love We Deliver are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved Board member, Joan Rivers. Joan was a profoundly compassionate friend of God's Love for over 25 years. She will be sorely missed for her brilliant humor and insightful view on life, but most especially for the kindness, joy and generosity she brought to everything she did for God's Love and our clients. Joan was one of a kind and irreplaceable. Joan's remarkable impact on God's Love will be remembered always. We send our deepest condolences to Melissa and Cooper.

MITCHELL--Paul, 78, died on September 2 from Alzheimer's Disease. He was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated with a BS in accounting from the Baruch School of Business of CCNY (now CUNY). Following graduation, he entered the USCG Officers' Candidate School, and was posted to the Port of New Orleans for three years where, according to Lt. Paul, "We didn't lose a foot of the coast on my watch!" There, he met "Linda the Lovely" his wife of 52 years. In 1962, he joined Pricewater House & Co., and earned his CPA. In 1972 he joined Ogilvie and Mather Advertising, subsequently moving to Foote Cone and Belding for several years, while raising a family in Fair Haven, NJ. In 1987, he accepted the position of Chief Financial Officer for Edelman Worldwide, an international public relations firm headquartered in Chicago. As CFO, he traveled to Europe, Asia and the Far East to oversee acquisitions for Edelman. Linda and Paul loved Chicago and remained for 22 years making lifelong friends. After his retirement, Paul served as treasurer of the Joseph Jefferson committee (Chicago theater awards) for nine years, enjoying the perks of nonstop theater-going. In 2007, they returned to New Jersey, residing in Shrewsbury. Paul was a gentle, kind, and extremely honorable man; a wonderful husband and father, much loved by his family and friends. He was predeceased by his eldest daughter, Mary Mitchell formerly of New York City. Besides his wife, he is survived by daughter Patricia Gallagher (Joe) of Fair Haven, NJ; son James Mitchell (Kristin) of Baltimore, MD; and grandchildren Clare, Kevin, and Grace Gallagher. Also surviving are his brother Thomas Mitchell (Joan) of Holmdel, NJ and brother Peter Mitchell (Frances) of Staten Island, NY and 18 nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will he held at a later date. Donations may be made to Girls' Prep, LES at Public-Prep, 291 Broadway, Ste. 1202, NYC 10007 or online at: www.PublicPrep.org.

NORDEN--Irving, 87. A friend of over 75 years. A gentleman of the highest integrity. His honesty and kindness will be missed by all who knew him. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Norden family. Maurice & Margie Slater

MARSHALL--Robert Bamber Sr.,June 11, 1918, died August 7, 2014. He was beloved husband of Traudy father of two, grandpa of twins. No donations. Silver Star WWII Veteran BlackCat Recon pilot. In honor to God and Country, Amen

LICHTENSTEIN--Marjorie R. The officers, brokers and staff at Brown Harris Stevens will miss our beloved colleague, who was a well-respected member of the Real Estate Community for decades. She will be remembered for her professionalism, intelligence, and her support of her colleagues. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her family and friends.

LEVINE--Lilian, on June 24, 2014. Owner Lilian Rowan Exercise Studio. Survived by her husband Melvin. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, September 9, 2014, 3pm at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LEVINE--Albert B.,age 92, from Brooklyn, Long Island and New Jersey, World War II combat veteran Normandy invasion. Her brilliant music and energy made the world sparkle and will be greatly missed. She is survived by her husband, Stanley, her children, Edward and Allison, and her sister, Rochelle. Donations in her honor may be made to the VH1 Save the Music Foundation.

LARIMER--Bob. Friends and colleagues in the theater community are deeply saddened by the recent passing of composer/lyricist, Bob Larimer. From his teenage years at Langley High School in Pittsburgh, PA, where he was Valedictorian of his class, Bob played piano in the school band showing an early passion for music. On scholarship at Carnegie Mellon University, he created musicals for their Scotch & Soda productions. In New York, his work includes the Broadway musical "But Never Jam Today" and Off-Broadway productions "King of the Whole Damn World", "Jack & Jill" and "Blue Roads". Two of Bob's jazz musicals, "Maxie's" and "999 BC", were performed recently at the York Theatre Company. Our warmest condolences to his wife, Riki Kane Larimer. The Board and Staff of The York Theatre Company. James Morgan, Producing Artistic Director Andrew Levine, Executive Director W. David McCoy, Chairman.

KLEINMAN--Ann Bailinson, of New York passed away gracefully on September 1 following a long battle with ALS. She is survived by her daughter Jill Kleinman Halberg, son-in-law Ken Halberg, granddaughter Zoe Halberg, brothers Frank Bailinson (Jann Dickerson) and Jim Bailinson (Nancy Gibson), several loving nieces and nephews and a countless number of friends and family who adored her. Born August 14, 1949 in Manhattan to Jean and Frank Bailinson, Ann was raised in Brooklyn and graduated from the Berkeley Institute (now Berkeley Carroll School). She was a member of the Class of 1971 at Carnegie Mellon University, ultimately earning her degree from the University of Pittsburgh. She fought ALS with courage, dignity and strength and will be remembered for her generous heart, loyal friendship, amazing memory and sense of humor. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Donations can be made in her memory to the MDA/ALS Manhattan District www2.mda.org/annsmemory or The ALS Association Greater NY. www.als-ny.org

KENIGSBERG--Herbert Stuart, DDS (Colonel Retired, US Army) on May 19, 2014, age 75, from complications of total right knee replacement. Beloved husband of Norma Kay Schuker for over 49 years. Cherished father of Spencer Lee and Matthew Mark. Devoted son of the late Dr. Louis Kenigsberg and Sophie Weinreb Kenigsberg. Graduate of Columbia University College of Pharmacy, NYU College of Dentistry, and the US Army War College. Herbert earned the dental FAGD, MAGD and ABGD. He served at various continental US Army posts and also in Berlin, West Germany. After military retirement, he was Director, Clinical Affairs and Disease Intervention of the Oral Health Program for the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Services 9:00am Tuesday, October 28, 2014 at Arlington National Cemetery, with full military honors. Donations in his memory may be made to the Disabled American Veterans.

HOWARD--Trudy Mulcahy, 91, on Labor Day, peacefully with family, of Cambridge, MA (formerly Scarsdale/Bronxville, NY) and Nantucket, wife of Leonard F. Howard (deceased). Beloved mother of Thomas, Susanne, James and Daniel and grandmother of Aidan, Carter and Preston. HEWITT--Charles C. Jr.,94, died peacefully at his Naples, FL home on August 31. Pre-deceased by his beloved wife of 68 years, Mary Irene (McDermott). Dear father of Charles C. Hewitt III (Mary), Patricia (Dale Christensen) and Brian (Anita Gonzalez). Proud grandfather of Michael and Stephen Hewitt, Erik and Peter Christensen and Laura Beardsley. Loving great-grandfather of Natalie, Andrew, Emily, Noah and Maya Hewitt and Austin Beardsley. Treasured brother of Robert G. Hewitt. Born in Trenton, NJ, to Charles C. Hewitt Sr. and Elisabeth Schwab, he graduated from Princeton University in 1940 at age 19. During WWII he was a weather officer in Untied States Army Air Corps, rising to Captain and serving in the U.S. and Shanghai, China. He was a career actuary employed by several insurance companies, retiring in 1985 as President & CEO of Metropolitan Reinsurance Co., which he helped found. He was also prominent in the actuarial profession, serving as President of the Casualty Actuarial Society and Vice-President of the American Academy of Actuaries. Donations may be made to Moorings Park Foundation, 120 Moorings Park Drive, Naples, FL 34105.

HALES--Peter Bacon. (November 13, 1950 August 26, 2014), an acclaimed American cultural historian, photographer and author, and a joyous musician, died in a tragic bicycling accident near his home in Stone Ridge, New York. Born in Pasadena, California, Peter grew up in Guilford, Connecticut. He graduated from Haverford College in 1972. At the University of Texas at Austin, he earned his MA in Photography and American Studies in 1976 and his PhD in American Civilization in 1980 under the mentorships of Garry Winogrand and Dr. William H. Goetzman, respectively. His early academic career led him to the University of Illinois at Chicago in 1980 where he became Professor of Art History, Chair of the Art History Department (2006-2010), and Director of the Study of the U.S. Institute for Scholars (formerly American Studies Institute). He retired in 2010, was named Professor Emeritus, and continued to teach until 2012. Peter and his wife Maureen relocated from Chicago to their home in Stone Ridge, NY in 2012, where he focused on research and writing. When his most recent book Outside The Gates of Eden - The Dream of America from Hiroshima to Now was published in April, he was immersed in new projects, including a photographic and cultural study of the American freeway. Earlier books include Atomic Spaces: Living on the Manhattan Project (1997); William Henry Jackson and the Transformation of the American Landscape (1988); and Silver Cities: The Photography of American Urbanization, 1839-1915 (1984; revised and published in 2005); as well as numerous essays and articles, the spectrum of which reflect his broad areas of interest and expertise. A natural community builder, Peter embraced life in the Hudson Valley with his treasured wife Maureen, developing strong friendships and a conservationist's sense of place. As an accomplished guitarist and songwriter, Peter sought out and found friendship, collaboration and community with musicians wherever he lived. As a passionate cyclist, Peter often rode over 200 miles a week with a team, a partner or solo. Beloved husband, dedicated father, loving brother and uncle, mentor and friend to many, Peter is survived by his wife Maureen Pskowski, son Taylor Hales, daughter Molly Hales, sisters, Susan Hales and Marty Hales. He is predeceased by his parents, Milton Reynolds Hales and Harriet Bacon Hales. Donations may be made in honor of Peter Hales to the Rondout Esopus Land Conservancy, where he served on the board. RELC - Peter Hales, PO Box 144, Accord, NY 12404 All are invited to share memories and photographs at: www.peterbhales.squarespace.com
