Mickey, as she was affectionately known, organized and oversaw internationally acclaimed exhibitions, publications, and public programs that celebrated the best in contemporary art, architecture, and design. The Walker extends its deepest condolences to her husband Martin, daughters Lise, Ceil, and Zoe, and extended family and friends. The Board of Trustees & Staff of the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis, MN.

FINE--Arnold, passed away on September 5, 2014 at the age of 90. Dear husband of the late Edith. Beloved father of Jay (Cindy), Brian (Dina), and Marty (Janet). Adoring grandfather of Eric, Daniel, Sarah, Joan, Max and Adam. Dear great-grandfather of Ella and Eve. Graveside service Monday, 1:30pm at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

FIELD--Dr. Michael. Dr. Michael Field, of New York died of an acute illness in the Eastern Maine Medical Center in Bangor on Saturday evening, August 23. He had been taken there earlier in the week from his summer home in Lamoine and comforted during his last days by his wife and sons who were at his side, along with other family members, at the moment of his passing. He was 81. Dr. Field was born in London, England on July 20, 1933 to Hans Hirschfeld, a business man, and Miriam Lewinson, a physician born in Russia. For the first five years of his life he resided in Hamburg Germany from which the family fled on November 8th, 1938, the day before Kristallnacht. They travelled via Rotterdam to the United States, arriving on Thanksgiving. The family ate hot dogs as their first American meal, consumed somewhere on the Upper West Side. This past year, Dr. Field reclaimed his German citizenship to reconnect with his birthright and heritage. Mike, as he was known to his family and acquaintances, obtained his BA from the University of Chicago in 1953 and his MD from Boston University in 1959. He did his residency at Cleveland Metropolitan General Hospital, and fulfilled his military service in the United States Public Health Service in Bethesda, MD. In 1964, he joined the Biophysical Laboratory at Harvard Medical School as a postdoctoral fellow pursuing research into intracellular mechanisms. It would be his life's work, continuing it as Associate Professor, Harvard Medical School and then as Professor of Medicine and Physiology at the University of Chicago (1977-1984), and Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons (1984-2001), where he also served as Director of the Division of Gastroenterology at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center (1984-1999). He retired as Emeritus Professor of Medicine and Physiology & Cellular Biophysics in 2001. In 1984 Dr. Field was co-recipient of the King Faisal International Prize in Medicine for research into diarrheal disease, in particular cholera. His work demonstrated how cholera and other pathogenic bacteria toxins interfere with the body's salt regulation, a discovery that is now taught to medical students in biochemistry courses throughout the world and which enabled effective diarrheal treatment to be developed for a disease that had killed millions in the developing world. Dr. Field was the first Jewish recipient of the Prize. He was also the author of numerous scholarly papers, editor of a book on diarrheal disease, and the recipient of many honors from his colleagues and peers, including the American Gastroenterological Association (AGA) Distinguished Achievement Award in 1984, the Lifetime Achievement in Digestive Sciences Award from Janssen Pharmaceuticals in 2000 and the AGA's Distinguished Mentorship Award in 2008. His pleasure in the accomplishments of students and younger colleagues whom he shepherded at critical stages in their careers gave him great satisfaction. In addition to his professional accomplishments and his unwavering devotion to his family, Dr. Field battled devastating illness throughout his life. He was diagnosed with hepatitis in 1961, underwent a portacaval shunt (liver bypass) operation in Atlanta in 1979, received a liver transplant at the University of Nebraska Medical Center in February 1990 and had a kidney transplant at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in 2004 with his wife as donor. His memoir of his life as a physician and patient, which he had substantially completed at the time of his passing, will be edited by his wife. A global community of relatives, colleagues, friends and mentees thought he would live forever, so resolutely did he meet each medical challenge that came his way. He is survived by his wife, Linda Seidel; sons John B.A., Ezra S., and Benjamin H.; their wives Kristen Bearse, Marlene Field, and Viktoriya Torchinsky-Field; grandchildren Helen and Thomas Field; Gabriella, Lillian and Abigail Field; Isaac Torchinsky-Field; brother-in-law Irwin List, niece Allison List Hutner, nephew Steven S. List, and cousins in San Francisco, Israel and South Africa. A memorial is being planned for later in the fall. In his honor, his family asks that you consider registering as an Organ Donor. Donations may be sent to the Center for Liver Disease and Transplantation, Columbia University Medical Center; the Transplant Center at the Nebraska Medical Center, Omaha; and/or the Mt. Desert Island Biological Laboratory, Salisbury Cove, ME.

DUNKLE--Ruth Passweg, died peacefully on September 4, 2014. Born in Lyon, France in 1938 she escaped the Nazi holocaust and arrived in America with her family on New Year's Eve in 1940. She grew up in Manhattan and moved to Edison, NJ when she married. Ruth graduated from Mount Holyoke in 1960, received a PhD in Classics from NYU and taught Latin and ancient history at the high school and college level. After leaving academia, she had a successful career in real estate where her cards read, "Ask Dr. Ruth." Ruth was a woman of wide and varied interests, which included horseback riding, tennis, classical music, and her vacation house in North Carolina where she used her considerable photography skills to capture the beauty of the Outer Banks. She was a passionate Scrabble player, competing in online competitions and tournaments. Predeceased by her older sister, Eva, Ruth is survived and mourned by her younger sister, Judith Podell, a niece, Julia Bard, great niece Sasha Bard, three nephews, Philip Bard, Daniel Podell, and Adam Podell, and her husband of 44 years, Roger. Loyal and generous, she maintained lifelong relationships with friends from her childhood days at Camp Wenonah in Maine. Ruth will be sorely missed by many who remember her unselfishness, intelligence and wit. A memorial service is planned for a future date. Donations in honor of Ruth may be made to a charity of choice.
DIX--Stuart. A compassionate, caring, life long friend. Our Love to the Dix and Starker families. Barbara and Peter Seideman Cyvia and Barry Cohen
DIX--Stuart. We met over 47 years ago and our lives were never the same and all for the better. Pop Stu, you will be forever loved and never forgotten. The Lazar and Musoff family

DIX--Stuart Howard, 72 of White Plains, NY died Thursday, September 4, 2014 at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City. He leaves his wife of 50 years, Judith Ann Dix; his daughter and her spouse, Farrel and Steven Starker and three grandchildren; Brian, Andrew and Stefanie Starker; his brothers Lawrence and Gary and their families, and many close friends. Born and raised in the Bronx, the son of Herbert and Dorothy, he was a long time resident of Forest Hills, Queens and most recently lived in White Plains, NY. In his early years Mr. Dix started his own company with Judy called Just Management. He met his wife, Judith in 1963 and they were married in 1964 in New York City. He and Judith enjoyed traveling--getting away to their summer home in the Berkshires And winter home in Boca Raton, FL. An avid golfer, he was a longtime member of Fresh Meadows Country Club in Great Neck and also belonged to Old Kinderhook Country Club and Columbia Golf Club in the Berkshires. He held very close to his heart the works of Blythedale Children's Hospital, where he was the co-founder of their annual Golf Tournament. Mr. Dix was a man filled with joy and passion for his family and always had a special spark. He was a true mensch to all that knew him. A funeral service was held September 5 at JCC of Harrison, with private burial. Donations in Stuart's memory can be made to: Blythedale Children's Hospital- Stuart H Dix Memorial Golf Outing, Development Department, 95 Bradhurst Avenue, Valhalla, NY 10595.

DAVID--Frederick L.,longtime resident of Deerfield Beach, FL, died peacefully at his home on August 28, 2014. Mr. David was well known internationally during his long career in the fashion industry as President and Designer of Chris Craft Footwear headquartered in NYC. He then launched his own successful outdoor apparel line, East Egg, continuing to build on his unique reinterpretation of classic design. In 1988 family matters brought Mr. David to Ft. Lauderdale, FL. where he made his new home and began a second fulfilling career, returning to his longstanding affinity for economics and law. He was recognized by the Supreme Court of Florida as a Certified Civil Court Mediator. He created Frederick David and Associates, Inc. assisting people with banking and financial concerns for more than two decades. Mr. David is survived by his wife, Karen Golembeski-David, his sister, Stephanie David, nieces Katharine and Natasha and many friends and colleagues. We were lucky to have him.

CASTLEMAN--Riva. From an early age, Riva Castleman (1930-2014) seemed fated to work in the world of prints. As a child, she enjoyed visits with her father, a printer and autodidact, who instilled in her a love of art and the print process. She was a loyal sister to my mother, a devoted friend to many, champion of artists and a fierce lioness of an aunt to our family. She loved music, walks in Central Park with her Norfolk Terriers especially Winnie, her closest companion in these last years. She could be witty, playful and serious, by turns and her laugh could light up a room. She is survived by nephews, John and Nicholas Skedgell, niece Kristen DeVoe and Kristen's children, Matthew James Dougherty and Katharine Lee Dougherty, first cousins, Frances Burton of New York City, Judith Neumann of Boulder, CO and Bob Rubenstein of Dallas, TX. Riva instructed that there be no memorial service. Her family would appreciate any donations to the Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration for further research into this debilitating dementia that stole Riva's last vibrant years. www.theaftd.org.

CASTLEMAN--Riva. It is with deep sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the passing of its beloved honorary member Riva Castleman, who became an honorary member after her retirement from the MoMA staff in 1995. Among her many projects for the Museum's International Program was the comprehensive survey Modern Art in Prints that was exhibited in 23 cities in Australia, New Zealand, India, Iran, and Japan. She also directed other important traveling exhibitions including Latin American Prints, American Prints 1913-1963, and Modern Artists as Illustrators, which had extensive tours in Latin America, the Far East, and Europe. Riva will be long remembered by her many friends and colleagues throughout the world for her unerring eye, her keen intelligence, and her very sharp wit. We send our deepest sympathies to her family. Agnes Gund, Chair; Brian Urquhart, H.R.H. Duke Franz von Bayern, Chairs Emeriti; Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President; Jo Carole Lauder, Joann K. Phillips, Jeanne C. Thayer, Presidents Emeritae; Lewis B. Cullman, Beatrix Medinger, Vice Chairs; William L. Bernhard, Secretary. The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

CASTLEMAN--Riva. The Foundation for Art and Preservation in Embassies is profoundly saddened by the death of Riva Castleman. As the founder of FAPE's Professional Fine Arts Committee, she shaped our longest running program, the Original Print Collection. Her brilliance attracted many of the greatest American artists, forming lasting relationships, and achieving what no one else could, as no would dare say no to her. Her contributions to the world of art history constitute a great legacy, and her impact will not soon be forgotten. We send our deepest sympathy to her family. Jo Carole Lauder, Chairman Eden Rafshoon, President Darren Walker, Vice President Elizabeth Pozen, Secretary Robert Storr, Chairman, FAPE's Professional Fine Arts Committee and Dean, Yale School of Art Jennifer A. Duncan, Director

BRAUN--Sonia Stan, of Boynton Beach, FL, passed away on June 21, 2014, at the age of 85. Beloved wife of 56 years to Harold Stuart Braun, loving father of David Stan Braun (Ricki), New York City, and Paul Braun (Alexandra) of Fairfield, CT, and grandmother of Sara. BOTT--Herman Peter, on September 4, 2014. Beloved husband of Bubbles. Devoted father of Nisha Chisena and her husband Aaron and Nikhil and his wife Katrina. BRADLEY--Bill (Wes). Of White Plains, NY, passed away on September 4, 2014 at the age of 91. Beloved husband of Cheryl Bradley and devoted father of Jon, Joelle and Adam, he was known in his community and among his friends as a most caring, honest, and principled man committed to making his part of the world a better place. Bill was born in Brooklyn, NY to Sam and Frieda Bradley on February 22, 1923. He was raised in Brooklyn and attended Bucknell University. At the age of 19, when the United States entered World War II, he enlisted in the U.S. Marines and served as an officer until the end of the war when he returned to Bucknell to finish his education. Upon graduation he met the love of his life, Cheryl Levy, and they were married in August 1947. The newlyweds moved to White Plains where they lived with their two young sons Lance and Jon until 1951 when Bill was again called up by the Marines to serve in the Korean War. Later having served for over 5 ++ years, Bill resigned from the Corps with the rank of Captain. He remained active in Veteran Organizations all throughout his life. Returning to White Plains with his family in 1953. Bill quickly became a civic leader, active in politics and community service. He joined the Democratic Party where he worked to ensure that it held true to the democratic values he believed in all his life. Ultimately, he became Chair of the Democratic Party. As Chairman, in 1969 he was the Democratic mayoral candidate standard bearer when they achieved a victory in their first election in over 50 years seating two Democratic White Plains City Councilmen. He remained actively involved and an advisor to many elected officials until recent years when his health began to decline. Bill dedicated his life to justice, community involvement and equal opportunity. Perhaps no work demonstrates this more clearly than his many years chairing the planning committee of the Brotherhood Breakfast where all faiths and members of the community were invited to come together to share their common values and hopes for the future. Indeed, when Bill Bradley was awarded the Brotherhood Award by his peers in 1966, it was said that the only reason he did not receive it sooner was that he always chaired the committee. Cub Scout Master, founder of a neighborhood Association, Captain of the Community Chest, Vice President of the White Plains lodge of B'nai Brith, and Chairman of the White Plains Anti-Defamation League, were just some of the many ways he was committed to the community in which he lived. Bill and Cheryl were the greatest example of love, devotion and family commitment for over 67 years. Besides his wife, Cheryl, he is survived by his children and grandchildren all of whom are grateful for the example he set for them as a man committed in life to making this world a better place. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY on September 8, 2014 at 10am.

BOALT--Bruce. With great sadness we announce the death of Bruce (Brucie) Rial Boalt on Friday, August 29, 2014 in Southampton, NY. A resident of New York City and Southampton, Brucie was for many years a residential real estate broker with Sotheby's International Realty in New York. Brucie was born in 1932 in Pittsburgh, PA and graduated from the Ethel Walker School in 1950 before attending Vassar College. Brucie is survived by her four sons, Michael, Kelly, David and Ted, and twelve grandchildren. Throughout her life, Brucie was a devoted sportswoman who played golf and tennis for many years. In accordance with Brucie's wishes, there will be no funeral services. Friends and family are welcome to donate to The Shinnecock Hills Educational Fund, 200 Tuckahoe Road, Southampton, NY 11968.

She was a sociologist, professor and child development advocate. She is greatly missed by of three living sisters Gladys, Yolaine and Jacqueline as well as from her nieces Judith and Vania. She is alive in our prayers. Yannick and Thierry Grenier

ROSENBERG--Helen U.,of Hallandale, FL., passed peacefully on September 6, 2014 at the age of 98. Beloved mother of Steven Finger and Susan Kasen Summer, grandmother to Scott Kasen, Wendy Fishman, Mellissa and Sarah Finger and proud great-grandmother to Ariel, Duke and Jake Fishman. Born in Long Branch, New Jersey to Morris and Yetta Weinstein, she is survived by her brother John Weinstein. A friend to many and active member of her community she will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be planned at a later date in Long Branch, New Jersey.

ALBANESE--Licia. A public Memorial Service is scheduled for 2pm, Sunday, 14 September 2014, at St Jean Baptiste Catholic Church (184 East 76th St., New York City). In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Puccini Foundation, 8 East 69th St, NY, NY 10021. Let her legacy continue.

LEVINE--Lilian, on June 24, 2014. Owner Lilian Rowan Exercise Studio. Survived by her husband Melvin. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, September 9, 2014, 3pm at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LEFF--Eleanor, on September 6, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Martin J. Leff. Devoted mother of Richard Schwartz and the late Andrew Schwartz and mother-in-law of Tina. Loving grandmother of Jake, Alison, and Daisy. Services Tuesday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

LARIMER--Bob. Friends and colleagues in the theater community are deeply saddened by the recent passing of composer/lyricist, Bob Larimer. From his teenage years at Langley High School in Pittsburgh, PA, where he was Valedictorian of his class, Bob played piano in the school band showing an early passion for music. On scholarship at Carnegie Mellon University, he created musicals for their Scotch & Soda productions. In New York, his work includes the Broadway musical "But Never Jam Today" and Off-Broadway productions "King of the Whole Damn World", "Jack & Jill" and "Blue Roads". Two of Bob's jazz musicals, "Maxie's" and "999 BC", were performed recently at the York Theatre Company. Our warmest condolences to his wife, Riki Kane Larimer. The Board and Staff of The York Theatre Company. James Morgan, Producing Artistic Director Andrew Levine, Executive Director W. David McCoy, Chairman.

IRVING--Anne, 93, formerly of Wantagh, LI, peacefully on September 5. Devoted wife of Joe Irving for 65 years until his death in 2009. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of Francie Irving Ben-David of blessed memory and her husband Yair, and of Andrew Irving and his wife Evelyn Sucher, and proud grandmother of Jesse Jacoby Sucher and Toby Rae Irving.

FRIEDMAN--Mildred. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Walker Art Center mourn the passing of their former design curator whose exceptional eye, intelligent care, and sincere passion for the Walker touched all of us. Mickey, as she was affectionately known, organized and oversaw internationally acclaimed exhibitions, publications, and public programs that celebrated the best in contemporary art, architecture, and design. The Walker extends its deepest condolences to her husband Martin, daughters Lise, Ceil, and Zoe, and extended family and friends. The Board of Trustees & Staff of the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis, MN.
DIX--Stuart. We met over 47 years ago and our lives were never the same and all for the better. Pop Stu, you will be forever loved and never forgotten. The Lazar and Musoff family

FINE--Arnold, passed away on September 5, 2014 at the age of 90. Dear husband of the late Edith. Beloved father of Jay (Cindy), Brian (Dina), and Marty (Janet). Adoring grandfather of Eric, Daniel, Sarah, Joan, Max and Adam. Dear great-grandfather of Ella and Eve. Graveside service Monday, 1:30pm at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

CANNELL--H. Scott, 79, of Purchase, NY, passed away on August 21, 2014 following a brief illness. He graduated from Yale University, where he was a member of the Elihu Club, and later earned an MBA from University of California Berkeley. Scott headed his own TV production company and co-founded the Center for the Media Arts in New York City. He is survived by his wife Julie; sons Ian of Pasadena, CA; Nicholas of NY, NY; and Patrick of Brooklyn, NY; a sister, Nancy Carter of Sea Ranch, CA; and step-brothers Richard Deutsch of Woodcliff Lakes, NJ and Doug Deutsch of N. Fort Myers, FL. He was pre-deceased by his first wife Marcia. A celebration of Scott's life will be held at Rye Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY 10580 on Saturday, September 20 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Rye Presbyterian Church.

BOTT--Herman Peter, on September 4, 2014. Beloved husband of Bubbles. Devoted father of Nisha Chisena and her husband Aaron and Nikhil and his wife Katrina. Cherished grandfather of Caden, Lyla and Giuliana. Loving brother of Donald H. Bott and the late William Bott. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Wednesday, September 10, 2014, 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. Contributions in lieu of flowers will be gratefully accepted in memory of Herman Bott to support Dr. Maeve Lowery at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

BOALT--Bruce. With great sadness we announce the death of Bruce (Brucie) Rial Boalt on Friday, August 29, 2014 in Southampton, NY. A resident of New York City and Southampton, Brucie was for many years a residential real estate broker with Sotheby's International Realty in New York. Brucie was born in 1932 in Pittsburgh, PA and graduated from the Ethel Walker School in 1950 before attending Vassar College. Brucie is survived by her four sons, Michael, Kelly, David and Ted, and twelve grandchildren. Throughout her life, Brucie was a devoted sportswoman who played golf and tennis for many years. In accordance with Brucie's wishes, there will be no funeral services. Friends and family are welcome to donate to The Shinnecock Hills Educational Fund, 200 Tuckahoe Road, Southampton, NY 11968.

ARTON--Patrick, D.O.,79, died August 16, 2014 in Croton-on-Hudson, NY after a long illness. Born in Birmingham, England, he lived many years in South Africa, which he loved. He served as editor of Travel Trade and ASTA Travel News, and was a member of the New York Travel Writers. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Wounded Warrior Project. Services will be private.

SOYBEL--Arthur Isaac. The son of Ukrainian immigrants who were active in business, education and philanthropy, Arthur Soybel was born in Brooklyn on June 16, 1925, and died at home on September 6, 2014. He attended the Little Red Schoolhouse and Erasmus High School before enlisting in the V-12 Navy College Training Program at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1943. He served as an ensign on a minesweeper in the Pacific and then returned to UNC where he graduated in 1947 as a political science major. An accomplished pianist, he graduated from the Manhattan School of Music in 1949 and played professionally, but settled on a legal career after graduating from New York Law School in 1954. He specialized in real estate and artistic intellectual property contracts from 1954 until his retirement in 2012. Throughout his professional life, he served on the boards of multiple organizations, including the W. Eugene Smith Memorial Fund, the Rudolf Steiner School, Manhattan Community Board 7, the Westside Chamber of Commerce, and the Foundation for Religion and Mental Health. His passion for gardening at his mountain home in Shady, NY, was matched by his love for the nature and rich culture of the American Southwest and for his wife's hometown of Berlin. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Renate Elise Haake Soybel, his daughter, Carol Ann Soybel Bartges, both of New York City, his daughter-in-law, Virginia Earll Soybel, of Boston, by three grandchildren Max Bartges, Sarah Bartges Ohana, and Anna Soybel and by two great-granddaughters. His son, Thomas W. Soybel, died in 2010. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Central Park Conservancy.

STEWART--Martin, 91, died peacefully on September 7th. He is survived by his adoring wife of 47 years, Harriet. Beloved father to Marla and son-in-law Glenn Seidman and to Lowell and daughter-in-law Nancy Stewart. Cherised brother to Ruth Block. Remembered with the greatest fondness by his grandchildren Nina, Zachary, and Grady Stewart and Maxwell Seidman. Served in the Army during WWII and returned to New York City where he went to Brooklyn Law School. He then practiced as an attorney for over 50 years. He was a Trial Lawyer par Excellance. He was truly loved by his family and will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapel located at 180 West 76th Street on Wednesday, September 10, 2014 at 11:30am. Burial to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Queens.

SAWYER--Stanley S. Stanley S. Sawyer, of Newton MA, on September 5, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Corinne (Clare) Sawyer. Dear son of the late Morris and Lillian Schultz. Devoted father of Howard Sawyer and his wife Linda, Arnie Sawyer and his wife Yuri, and Betsy Gold and her husband David. Dear grandfather of Evan, Graham, Marika and her husband Matt, Sara, Hannah, Jesse, and Benjamin. Loving brother of Sydell and Ed Masterman. Formerly married to Sheila Feingold Sawyer. Brother-in-law of Angela Clare. Services were held in Sharon, MA on Sunday, September 7, 2014. Stanley was known as "The Man of a Thousand Voices" in Boston radio before going on to New York to become one of the premiere TV commercial voiceover artists. He was also an avid painter and sculptor who created a number of busts, most notably of Martin Luther King Jr that were dedicated in parks in Harlem, NY and Rahway, NJ. His larger-than-life presence will be missed by all of us.

RUDANSKY--Sheldon, M.D. The Orienta Synagogue mourns the passing of Sheldon Rudansky, M.D., the esteemed and beloved father of our Rabbi, Charles Rudansky. We will always remember Dr. Rudansky's kind words, the twinkle in his eye, and warm smile. May G-d comfort the family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Board of Trustees.

RASMUSSEN--Joann Spain, 90 years old, died on September 4th 2014 at home, atop rolling farmlands in Walton, NY, surrounded by love. Born in Queens, NY, April 10 1924, a graduate of Smith College '46, Joann worked at IBM and was married for 60 years to Arthur Rasmussen, who predeceased her in 2008. Joann lived a dynamic life of generous-spirited activism. While raising four children in Montclair, NJ, in the 1950s and 60s, Joann engaged actively in Planned Parenthood and Fair Housing (a community campaign to integrate white suburban enclaves). She also became a certified teacher and tutored illiterate adults. Upon moving to Chicago in 1968, she was active in the Reading is Fundamental literacy program and Executive Service Corps (ESC), a nationwide nonprofit service that pairs retired executives with struggling community start-ups. Upon retirement to the Catskill Region of Upstate New York in 1990, she launched an ESC agency in Oneonta, NY and served on the boards of WSKG, the Catskill Symphony Orchestra and Franklin Stage Company. A vigorous advocate of the disenfranchised, and a gracious, altruistic soul, Joann's life motto was "never resist a generous impulse." She is survived by her four children; Mark and Will of London, and Kim and Ann of NYC and Montclair, NJ respectively. Additionally she is survived by six grandchildren; Emma, Mark, Nathan, Leah, Will and Luke. Services will be held in Franklin, NY at The Franklin Stage Company, Sunday, October 26th 2014, with reception to follow at Erna McReynold's and Tom Morgan's home. Services are under the direction of the Courtney Funeral Home, 25 Townsend Street, Walton. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to William Ogden Library, 42 Gardiner Pl., Walton, NY 13856. Condolences to the family may be made online by visiting: www.courtneyfh.com

PERSICO--Joseph E.,on August 30, 2014. Any review of Joseph Persico's life should reveal the work of a great historian-an historian whose writings will, in the future, be greatly utilized by scholars and educators. Tom Singleton

PATENT--Shirley M.,passed away peacefully on September 7, 2014. Predeceased by Samuel R. (Pat), her beloved husband of 64 years, she is survived by her loving children, Susan Gregge and Robert and Patricia Patent, her dear brother and sister-in- law, Gerald and Jacqueline Munitz, her adoring grandchildren Lauren and Russell Anmuth, Alison and Barry Medintz, Leslie and Ben Rubin, and Michael Patent, and her five cherished great-grandchildren, Sydney, Chloe, Lily, Drew and Samuel. Love was the essence of Shirley's life, equalled only by the kindness and warmth she brought to others. She was devoted to the happiness and success of both her family and her many friends, all of whom brought her great joy. Generous and charitable, with a gentle manner, a seasoned view of the world and a lack of pretension, she had an extraordinarily profound influence on her entire family and all who had the pleasure of sharing her friendship. As a family, we have been blessed to have had Pat and Shirley with us for so long. Their legacy will be felt by three generations who will miss them dearly every day. Services will be private.

PATENT--Shirley M.,Gram: Our shining star and the love of our lives, you will forever be in our hearts and countless memories etched in our minds. Straightforward, with your quick wit and razor-sharp memory, you were always a constant source of love and support. We are thankful for every moment that we had with you and we will miss you every single day. The best GG in the whole world, our children were blessed to briefly see what we have known forever. We are all comforted knowing that you and Poppa are back together, as you should be. You made us proud to be yours. Lauren, Russell, Ali, Barry, Leslie, Ben, Michael, Sydney, Chloe, Lily, Drew, and Sam.
PASZTOR--Ita G.,97, passed away peacefully on September 1, surrounded by her loving family. Her long career with the United Nations included the Human Rights Commission, with Eleanor Roosevelt.

MEYER--Gloria Gettinger. Most devoted mother, sister, aunt, great-aunt and friend to many. She will missed by all. Services Wednesday 11:15am, on September 10, at "The Riverside", 76th Street, and Amsterdam Avenue. Peter Gettinger Meyer and Martin Gettinger and Family.
KORNBLAU--Jules H.,"And if I ever lost you, how much would I cry? How deep is the ocean? How high is the sky?"

KORNBLAU--Jules H.,of New York City, Fair Harbor, Fire Island, and Palm Beach, died peacefully at his home on September 7, 2014. He leaves his cherished wife of sixty years, Helen Weinreb Kornblau, his beloved four children, David, Kenneth, Eric, and Katherine, and their spouses, Amy, Lisa, Stacy, and Matt Susskind. He was the proud and devoted grandfather of Joel (Jaime), Michelle (Josh), Jennifer, Daniel, Jonathan, Sam, and Sofia, adoring great-grandfather of Zoey, and loving uncle of Lisa and Craig Spear. Born in Atlantic City, NJ, Jules graduated from Eastern District High School, where he was President of the G.O., Baruch College (The City University of New York), and Columbia Law School. He practiced law in New York City for more than forty years, most recently in the law firm of Kornblau & Kornblau, P.C., with his son and partner, Eric. Jules was an avid New York sports fan, world traveler, athlete, great enthusiast of history, literature, and the arts, and thoroughly enjoyed everything that life had to offer. But his greatest source of joy was the time he spent with his family and friends. Jules made lifelong friends easily. He loved his friends from public school, high school, college, law school, Rockville Centre, Fire Island, and his pinochle and bridge cronies; they loved and respected him in return. Jules was a big, strong, generous man with a very tender heart and soul who expressed no regrets, just an appreciation for his life and the family that is his legacy. Patriarch extraordinaire -- we will carry you in our hearts forever and endeavor always to live by your shining example. "Now cracks a noble heart. Good night sweet prince: And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!" Donations in memory of Jules may be made to the Jules H. Kornblau Memorial Scholarship Fund at Baruch College.
KATZ--Lyber. Engineer, writer, and social activist led a full life to age 92. Funeral private. Memorial at a later date. Donations to Camp Kinderland, Jewish Currents, or Workmen's Circle.

HICKS--Martin Richard 1929 - 2014. It is with sadness that we share the loss of Martin Richard Hicks on September 6, 2014. Beloved son of Victor and Doris Hicks, he will be greatly missed by his three children Daniel, Catherine (Robert) and James (Barbara), as well as his sisters Joy (Ken) and Carol, and grandchildren Aidan, Isaac, Meg, Phoebe and William. Predeceased by his wives Peggy (nee Simpson) and Diane (nee Jones). Born in Calgary on February 22, 1929, and following various jobs ranging from cattle ranch hand to working on a Mackenzie River sternwheeler, Marty started his career in the Financial Industry first with Tanner & Co in Edmonton, and subsequently with A.E. Ames & Co. During his time with Ames, he lived in Victoria, Vancouver and Toronto, as well as being appointed president, A.E. Ames in New York City. Following his successful efforts at Ames, which included overseeing the financing of the James Bay Hydroelectric Project for Quebec and the re-introduction of British Columbia to world bond markets, Marty joined Bache and Co. as President in Canada before retiring in 1998 as Vice Chairman. Following his retirement he remained active in business serving on numerous boards. Marty loved the time he spent travelling both in Canada and around the world to see his family and friends. Whether on a salmon river with a fly rod in his hands, hunting at The Goodwood Club, of which he was a founding member, or summers spent at Lake Simcoe or Lake of Bays, Marty relished his time outdoors. He also savoured the finer things in life and was renowned by friends and family alike for his prowess in the kitchen coupled with his innate ability to find the best place to dine on almost any continent. "Pressing on regardless", Marty lived a full and satisfying life which will be celebrated at Grace Chruch on-the-Hill, 300 Lonsdale Road, Toronto on Thursday, September 11th at 2:00pm followed by a reception in the Parish Hall. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Canadian Cancer Society, or a charity of your choice. Online condolences at: www.morleybedford.ca

HELFGOTT--Dr. Andrew Wayne, born in Bennington, VT on October 24, 1957, entered into rest on September 7, 2014 surrounded by his family. Andy fought a courageous battle against pancreatic cancer, and always remained positive and hopeful, a true warrior. He grew up on Long Island, attended Hun School of Princeton, Washington & Jefferson College majoring in biology. He earned his medical degree from the Universidad Autonoma de Guadalajara, Mexico and a master's degree in health policy administration from University North Carolina Chapel Hill. He completed a residency in Obstetrics & Gynecology at Brooklyn Hospital in New York and a fellowship in maternal-fetal medicine at the University of Miami School of Medicine. He attended Chabad of Augusta. An active member and on the board of many professional organizations, Andy was employed by University of South Carolina Columbia as a Professor and Director of Maternal Fetal Health. Andy is survived by his parents, Claire and Saul; siblings Bennet (Laura), Michele (Rodney); his wife, Gabrielle and his three children Alexandra, Jonathan and William, extended family members, including his niece and three nephews. Our tie-dying wearing, Miami Hurricanes loving, avid Boy Scout fan, Andy was bigger than life. He shall be greatly missed by his family and all of those whose lives he touched during the 56 years God granted him on Earth. Funeral service today at 1pm at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.
HALL--Ron, on September 6, 2014. Ageless. A lovely man with a quick wit, a curious mind and an open heart. We miss you, Ronnie. Love, your many friends at the Art Students League.

GOLDSTEIN--Susan. With great sadness we announce the passing of Susan Beth Goldstein on September 7th. Susan passed peacefully after a brave and difficult fight against Cancer. Susan was an outstanding mother, daughter, relative and friend, always thinking of others, always there to help, advise and teach. Susan is survived by her beloved children Zoe and Alec Parower her devoted father Joseph Goldstein and many cherished relatives and friends, Susan was pre-deceased by her mother Lynette Goldstein and sister Jodi Sproul. Funeral services Wednesday, September 10th at 11:30am at Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NY, NY. Rhonnie and Charles Goldstein

FINKENSTAEDT--Rose Lindsay Harvey. Died on August 30, 2014, in Paris in her 88th year. Mrs. Finkenstaedt, who was born in Baltimore, MD, was educated at Miss Hall's School in Pittsfield, MA, Vassar College for two years, then transferred to Columbia University where she received her BA, MA and PhD. She married James Clements Finkenstaedt in 1947 and spent the next year in Paris where she studied at the Sorbonne and began her love of the French cuisine. While in New York, she was a Civil Rights activist and wrote and served on the editorial board of The Liberator, a black revolutionary magazine. From 1965-1967, she taught Comparative Literature at Hofstra University. Following this, she moved to Paris with her family, where she continued her writing career which included an extensive number of books best categorized as Histoires des Idees with a focus on American history, literature, economics, race, and the black struggle. She also wrote two novels and occasionally translated cookbooks. She continued her love of the French cuisine and befriended some of France's most noted chefs. She rode her bicycle throughout France, enjoyed swimming, and was an avid supporter of tennis. She is survived by her daughter Isabel Finkenstaedt Schelameur; her grandchildren, Catherine, Rose Lindsay, James III, Thomas Finkenstaedt, Pierre, William Luke and Rose Schelameur; her sisters Mrs. Ellen H. Kelly and Dr. Jean H. Baker; her brothers Robert H. Harvey and Alexander Harvey all of Baltimore, MD.
FERNANDEZ--Jesus. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Jesus Fernandex, associated with The New York Times from February 14, 1978 until retiring on September 1, 1994.

DYCKMAN--Samuel A.,CPA, J.D., LL.M., on September 7, 2014. Beloved husband of Florence. Loving father of Donna and Larry Lefkowitz and Richard and Beth Dyckman. Cherished grandfather of Jodi, Amy, Rebecca, Rachel and Gabe. He was a Professor Emeritus of Taxation and Accounting at Baruch College and nationally recognized tax lecturer." He was also a World War II Veteran

DIX--Stuart. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Stuart Dix. Stuart leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Stuart's beloved wife, Judy; his daughter and son-in-law, Farrel and Steven; his grandchildren; and entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO
DAVIS--Roy, at home on September 8, 2014, at the age of 91. Survived by his wife Cecily Langdale Davis; nephews, great-nephews and great- nieces, and cousins. A memorial service will be announced.

CAPLOW--Mildred (Rosner), on September 8, 2014. Daughter of the late Anna and Leo Rosner, wife of the late Alvin (Cappy). Beloved mother of Stacy Caplow (Gene Cerruti) and Amy Chan (Bob), cherished grandmother of Jordan (Rebecca), Daniel, Adam and Carlo. Millie celebrated her birthday in August with her close family in Seaview, Fire Island where she and Cappy spent so many happy summers with dear friends. A voracious reader, gambler and traveler, feisty and independent to the end, she declined suddenly but died peacefully. She will be missed.

BURDICK--Edward Hyde, of Rye, NY died September 5th. Born in Chicago in 1935, Mr. Burdick lived in Larchmont for 47 years as well as Philadelphia, Detroit, Brooklyn and Wilmington, North Carolina. Mr. Burdick graduated from Mamaroneck High School in 1953 and from Cornell in 1957 with a BS in mechanical engineering. A distinguished military student, he served in the US Army Reserve. In 1964 Mr. Burdick graduated from Harvard Business School with an MBA. Mr. Burdick briefly worked for the Air Reduction Company. In 1968 he began a 28-year career working for the Rockefeller family office, retiring in 1995 as president of its Wayfarer Ketch Corporation. Mr. Burdick is survived by his wife, Margaret MacCallum Burdick, sons Andy (Sarah) and Ted (Aileen), sisters Barbara Gallagher and Jane Burdick and seven grandchildren. A daughter, Betsy, predeceased Mr. Burdick. Contributions can be made to St. John's Episcopal Church, 4 Fountain Square, Larchmont, NY 10538 or Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.

ARTON--Patrick, D.O.,79, died August 16, 2014 in Croton-on-Hudson, NY after a long illness. Born in Birmingham, England, he lived many years in South Africa, which he loved. He served as editor of Travel Trade and ASTA Travel News, and was a member of the New York Travel Writers. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Wounded Warrior Project. Services will be private.

REEVES--Martha Seymour, beloved wife of Richard Stone Reeves; devoted mother to her children Nina Stone Reeves and Richard Stone Reeves, Jr. Martha passed away peacefully on September 8, 2014 after a long and debilitating illness. RASMUSSEN--Joann Spain, 90 years old, died on September 4th 2014 at home, atop rolling farmlands in Walton, NY, surrounded by love. Born in Queens, NY, April 10 1924, a graduate of Smith College '46, Joann worked at IBM and was married for 60 years to Arthur Rasmussen, who predeceased her in 2008. Joann lived a dynamic life of generous-spirited activism. While raising four children in Montclair, NJ, in the 1950s and 60s, Joann engaged actively in Planned Parenthood and Fair Housing (a community campaign to integrate white suburban enclaves). She also became a certified teacher and tutored illiterate adults. Upon moving to Chicago in 1968, she was active in the Reading is Fundamental literacy program and Executive Service Corps (ESC), a nationwide nonprofit service that pairs retired executives with struggling community start-ups. Upon retirement to the Catskill Region of Upstate New York in 1990, she launched an ESC agency in Oneonta, NY and served on the boards of WSKG, the Catskill Symphony Orchestra and Franklin Stage Company. A vigorous advocate of the disenfranchised, and a gracious, altruistic soul, Joann's life motto was "never resist a generous impulse." She is survived by her four children; Mark and Will of London, and Kim and Ann of NYC and Montclair, NJ respectively. Additionally she is survived by six grandchildren; Emma, Mark, Nathan, Leah, Will and Luke. Services will be held in Franklin, NY at The Franklin Stage Company, Sunday, October 26th 2014, with reception to follow at Erna McReynold's and Tom Morgan's home. Services are under the direction of the Courtney Funeral Home, 25 Townsend Street, Walton. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to William Ogden Library, 42 Gardiner Pl., Walton, NY 13856. Condolences to the family may be made online by visiting: www.courtneyfh.com

PATENT--Shirley M.,Gram: Our shining star and the love of our lives, you will forever be in our hearts and countless memories etched in our minds. Straightforward, with your quick wit and razor-sharp memory, you were always a constant source of love and support. We are thankful for every moment that we had with you and we will miss you every single day. The best GG in the whole world, our children were blessed to briefly see what we have known forever. We are all comforted knowing that you and Poppa are back together, as you should be. You made us proud to be yours. Lauren, Russell, Ali, Barry, Leslie, Ben, Michael, Sydney, Chloe, Lily, Drew, and Sam.

PATENT--Shirley. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our dear friend Shirley, whose late husband, Samuel R., was a member of the Einstein Board of Overseers for 20 years. Samuel and Shirley were generous supporters of the College; their commitment to Einstein's medical research and education spanned more than three decades. Their son, Robert, is a past Chairman of our Men's Division and his wife, Patti, served on the Women's Division National Board and is a former President of its Westchester/ Fairfield Chapter. To Robert, Patti and the entire family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

PATENT--Shirley M.,passed away peacefully on September 7, 2014. Predeceased by Samuel R. (Pat), her beloved husband of 64 years, she is survived by her loving children, Susan Gregge and Robert and Patricia Patent, her dear brother and sister-in- law, Gerald and Jacqueline Munitz, her adoring grandchildren Lauren and Russell Anmuth, Alison and Barry Medintz, Leslie and Ben Rubin, and Michael Patent, and her five cherished great-grandchildren, Sydney, Chloe, Lily, Drew and Samuel. Love was the essence of Shirley's life, equalled only by the kindness and warmth she brought to others. She was devoted to the happiness and success of both her family and her many friends, all of whom brought her great joy. Generous and charitable, with a gentle manner, a seasoned view of the world and a lack of pretension, she had an extraordinarily profound influence on her entire family and all who had the pleasure of sharing her friendship. As a family, we have been blessed to have had Pat and Shirley with us for so long. Their legacy will be felt by three generations who will miss them dearly every day. Services will be private.

MINKIN--Helen Siegel. Died August 26, 2014 at age 91. She was the beloved wife of George Minkin (deceased). She was the daughter of Louis Siegel and Ellen Storch Siegel. She was sibling to Selma Katzen (surviving) of Cincinnati, Ohio and aunt to Nancy Riedel, Marsha Jackson, and Larry Jackson (surviving) and Len Jackson (deceased). She received a B.A. (1943) from Barnard College and an LL.B. (1947) from Columbia University. She had practiced law in New York City since 1948. Over her long career, she earned the trust and respect of clients and colleagues alike. A memorial reception for George and Helen Minkin is planned at the Harvard Club of New York City on October 9 at 6:00pm.

LEVINE--Sid. Age 97, Beloved husband of the late Natalie. Adored father of Paul, Mindy, Arthur (Harris). Loving grandfather of Rebecca and Nathan. Adored by family, friends, and neighbors. Services Sinai Chapel, September 10th. Call: 718-445-0300.

LEVICK--Mark. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Mark Levick and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

LEFF--Eleanor. The congregation of Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her son Richard Schwartz and the Schwartz families. May her memory be for blessing. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch Michael Starr, President

HERSHCOPF--Gerald. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Mr. Gerald Hershcopf and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

HERSHCOPF--Gerald Thea. Devoted husband, father and grandfather died peacefully after a very brief illness on September 8 at age 92. A mentor to many younger lawyers, he retired from practice in 2006. Following graduation from Columbia University in 1943, he served as a medic during the liberation of France, Belgium, Holland and Germany. He remained in France after VE day to study at the Sorbonne, earning a certificate in French Civilization, and retained a life-long love of the country; its culture and language and its food and wines. Upon his return, he attended Harvard Law School on the GI Bill, graduating with a JD in 1949. He practiced with Marshall, Bratter, Seligson & Klein before striking out on his own as a partner in several firms including: Starr & Hershcopf; Hershcopf, Stevenson, Tannenbaum, San Filippo, Donovan & Korn; and Eisen, Hershcopf & Schulman. Throughout a successful career, his focus was always on his family. He was home for dinner nearly every night. He served as the Chairman of the North American Planning Corp. and was president of the Consortium of Metropolitan Law Schools. From 1997-98 he served on the board of the New York division of the American Cancer Society. In 1950, he married the former Elaine Yeckes, the love of his life a marriage that lasted 57 years until her death in 2009. The couple loved to travel to France, particularly Paris. In 2000, to celebrate their 50th anniversary, they shared Paris with their daughter, son-in-law and grandson. A charming, intellectually curious and handsome man; he was well respected in his field and cherished as an especially steadfast friend. He was also an avid golfer and tennis player who read this paper every day until his death. Fellow members of the Harvard Club, the New York Athletic Club, Doubles and Central Synagogue will remember watching him share jokes with family and friends at dinner. He is survived by his daughter and son-in-law, Jane and Don Schreck, his grandson, Sam Schreck, his sister, Judith Banki and his niece, Susan Banki. Services will be held on Wednesday, September 10, at 1pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Ave. Donations can be made in his name to the American Cancer Society.

GRUBMAN--Sara, passed away at home on September 9, 2014. She was loved and will be sadly missed by her family and friends. DAVIS--Roy, at home on September 8, 2014, at the age of 91. Survived by his wife Cecily Langdale Davis; nephews, great-nephews and great- nieces, and cousins. A memorial service will be announced.

COLE--Frances Ann, of New York City's Upper West Side, died on August 29, 2014 after a long illness. Ms. Cole was 76 years old. A graduate of MacMurray College, Ms. Cole received an MFA in costume design from Northwestern University. At Northwestern, Ms. Cole met her husband Barry Cole. Ms. Cole designed costumes for the Madeira School, Interlochen Center for the Arts, and Pulse Ensemble Theatre, among others. Ms. Cole was also an accomplished pianist. Ms. Cole is survived by her two children, Tracy Cole Barker of Bronxville, New York and Kelly Cole Dobson of Glen Echo, Maryland, and her four grandchildren: Allison Barker, Megan Barker, Katharine Dobson and Liam Dobson. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 13 at 11am at Christ Church Bronxville, Bronxville, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to The Doe Fund: Ready, Willing and Able (www.doe.org/help.cfm).

COHEN--Bette Reid, died peacefully at home on September 8 at the age of 92. Originally from Michigan, Bette came to New York in her 20's as a dancer; she fell in love with both the city and with Bill Cohen, and they married in 1945. Bill and Bette were among the original tenants of Peter Cooper Village, and Bette loved walking from East 23rd to her work. Her long professional career began as office manager for her father in law's lumber business near Union Square. Her next job was in retail as Bette's people skills won her the position of handling customer relations at B.Altman's Department Store. When the store closed, Bette was hired by the administrative offices at the Veteran's Hospital, where she worked well into her 80's. An accomplished cook and conversationalist, Bette loved hosting friends for dinner-- her guests enjoyed both her delicious food and sharp wit. Always elegant, Bette went regularly to theater, music and museums-walking there in order to take in every detail of her beloved New York. Contributions may be made in her honor to the Metropolitan Museum .

BRAUN--Sonia Stan, of Boynton Beach, FL, passed away on June 21, 2014, at the age of 85. Beloved wife of 56 years to Harold Stuart Braun, loving father of David Stan Braun (Ricki), New York City, and Paul Braun (Alexandra) of Fairfield, CT, and grandmother of Sara. Survived by sister Mary Waslen and brother Michael Stan. Born in Winthorpe, Saskatchewan, she was the youngest of ten children of Onufrey and Rose Stan. She graduated Nursing School in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan and emigrated to the U.S. shortly afterward. She worked as a nurse in California and Hawaii, then moved to New York where she continued nursing, married, and raised her family. After a brief semi-retirement in North Carolina, she retired to Florida where she enjoyed a full and active life. Sonia was loved by family and friends and will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

PINTO--Joseph J. Died peacefully on September 9th at his home in South Salem surrounded by people who love him. Born on April 24th, 1933 in Casablanca, Morocco to Jacques M. Pinto and Lunita Toledano Pinto, he was one of the last of the Sephardic Pinto family to be born in Morocco. In September 1939, at age six, he and his family arrived in New York harbor the day Hitler invaded Poland. After several years in Manhattan, the family settled in Greenwich, CT where Joe attended Bruns- wick Academy and then went on to The Lawrenceville School, from which he graduated in 1950. After graduating from Yale University in 1954, he moved back to Casablanca to work for the family tea importing business. Following Morocco's independence in 1956, he returned to New York and soon after met and married Pauline Badham Pinto. They moved to Paris where, with his brother and cousin, he formed Pinto & Cia., a merchant banking business investing in both operating businesses and real estate. In 1963 he moved to Madrid, where his parents resided, and continued his merchant banking activities and made many deep and lasting personal and business relationships. In 1968 he moved to New York to begin his life-long wish to become an American citizen, which he attained in 1980. Over the 1970's he was Instrumental in the formation and development of Sea Containers Ltd, an early entrant in the container leasing industry, and led their capital raising efforts over many years as the Chairman of the Finance Committee and a Board member. After Sea Containers, with one of his lifelong friends from Spain, he formed and led a team directing the investment in a number of private companies in the United States, including Loehmann's, Lehrer McGovern and a handful of other businesses in various industries. To those who knew him personally or in business, Joe was a man of clean reasoning and deep intellect, who was never afraid to ask the simplest of questions, as he was confident, though devoid of ego. He went on to become a private investor and in the early 1990's formed Hinsdale LLC, the Pinto family's investment partnership. Alongside his successful business career, his overriding focus was the care and support of his immediate and extended family. He was thoughtful, kind and dignified cherished by his many friends and family members for his generosity, caring and for his desire to lend support. Complementing his disciplined investing, caring support for his family and his many deep friendships, was his passion for horses, especially eventing and fox-hunting. He was a long time member of the Golden's Bridge Hounds and resident of North Salem, where over many years he and his wife, Linda, enjoyed life at their "gentleman's farm," Salem Sunshine Farm. He is survived by his wife of 31 years, Linda B. Pinto, his two sons and step-son, Paul and John Pinto and Alger B. Chapman, and his four grandchildren, Emma, Sarah, Jacob and Owen. He also leaves behind his older sister, Ena Abensur, his loving cousin and "little sister," Marina Pinto Kaufman, his close cousin, Maurice E. Pinto, his sister-in-law, Camila Pinto, widow of his brother Morris J. Pinto and many cousins, nieces and nephews whom he loved dearly. We will miss him, but know that his presence will live long in our hearts and actions. A service is planned for 10am on Friday, September 12th, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chappell in Manhattan.

MINKIN--Helen Siegel. Died August 26, 2014 at age 91. She was the beloved wife of George Minkin (deceased). She was the daughter of Louis Siegel and Ellen Storch Siegel. She was sibling to Selma Katzen (surviving) of Cincinnati, Ohio and aunt to Nancy Riedel, Marsha Jackson, and Larry Jackson (surviving) and Len Jackson (deceased). She received a B.A. (1943) from Barnard College and an LL.B. (1947) from Columbia University. She had practiced law in New York City since 1948. Over her long career, she earned the trust and respect of clients and colleagues alike. A memorial reception for George and Helen Minkin is planned at the Harvard Club of New York City on October 9 at 6:00pm.

MARCUS--Shirley, born October 14, 1923 on East 94th St., Manhattan, died at her home on on East 66th St. on September 9, 2014. The daughter of Abraham and Rose Marcus, immigrants from Romania who became shop owners in New York, Shirley was for decades a financial executive at Longines Watch Co., and subsequently at the Iron Workers Locals 40, 361 and 417. Shirley was briefly married to Arthur Liebowitz, DDS. Shirley's sardonic wit and lively stories of mistakes, doom, marriage, and money management made her a memorable and much-loved character in the Marcus family. Her devotion to Jewish causes, world traveling, and New York diners were notable. She is predeceased by her siblings Anne Marcus, Carl Marcus, and Ruth Bendiner. Her many nieces and nephews will miss her deeply, and are grateful for the care provided to Shirley in her later years by Doreen Hayes and her colleagues.

LEVY--Dr. Philip H.,91, of Delray Beach, FL and Torrington, CT; formerly of Long Island, NY, passed away on September 2nd. He was a renowned orthodontist, lecturer and had taught at NYU Dental School for many years. He is survived by his wife, Rita, of 66 years; sons Richard (Janice), Steven (Thomasina) and Dr. Lawrence (Joan) and seven sparkling grandchildren.

EPSTEIN--Lawrence, PhD, 88. Our beloved father passed away on September 9. Dr. Epstein was an esteemed colleague, author, friend and mentor to many as well as a training and supervisory analyst and member of the faculty at the William Alanson White Institute. Dr Epstein is survived by his wife Roslyn his children, David and Andrea and four grandchildren. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Memorial donations may be made in Larry's name to a charity of your choice or the AHA. A memorial and viewing is scheduled for Saturday, September 13 from 2-4pm at the John Krtil Funeral Home 1297 1st Ave. New York, NY 10021. 212-744-3084.

DAVIS--Roy. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague. He founded Davis Galleries in 1952 which later became Davis and Langdale Company, Inc. Our sympathy and condolences go out to his wife, Cecily Langdale Davis, and family. Dorsey Waxter, President Linda Blumberg, Executive Director

COLE--Frances Ann, of New York City's Upper West Side, died on August 29, 2014 after a long illness. Ms. Cole was 76 years old. A graduate of MacMurray College, Ms. Cole received an MFA in costume design from Northwestern University. At Northwestern, Ms. Cole met her husband Barry Cole. Ms. Cole designed costumes for the Madeira School, Interlochen Center for the Arts, and Pulse Ensemble Theatre, among others. Ms. Cole was also an accomplished pianist. Ms. Cole is survived by her two children, Tracy Cole Barker of Bronxville, New York and Kelly Cole Dobson of Glen Echo, Maryland, and her four grandchildren: Allison Barker, Megan Barker, Katharine Dobson and Liam Dobson. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 13 at 11am at Christ Church Bronxville, Bronxville, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to The Doe Fund: Ready, Willing and Able (www.doe.org/help.cfm).

CAPLOW--Mildred. The Board of Trustees of The Fire Island Synagogue mourn the passing of Mildred Caplow, long-time friend, neighbor and supporter of our congregation. Our deepest condolences to Stacey and Amy and their families. Shaul Magid, Rabbi Basya Schechter, Cantor

BRADLEY--Frederick W.,Jr., 87, passed away peacefully on Friday, August 29, 2014 at Center for Hope Hospice in Scotch Plains, NJ. Born and raised in Trenton, NJ, he was a graduate of Trenton Central High School in 1945. In the spring of his senior year, he enlisted in the United States Naval Reserve Corps serving as a Pharmacist Mate at the National Naval Medical Center. Mr. Bradley was a member of the Colgate University Class of 1950, where he received his Bachelor of Arts Degree in Political Science. He went on to earn a Master's Degree in Business Administration from Harvard Business School in 1955. Mr. Bradley had a long and influential career as one of the premier financiers and advisers to the airline and aero-space industry working closely with airframe and engine manufacturers as well as airlines across the world. Mr. Bradley began his career at W.R. Grace & Co. in its South American passenger transportation businesses and later worked as a consultant focused in the aeronautical industry. He joined The First National City Bank of New York in 1958 and rose to become a Senior Vice President of Citibank, N.A. (as the First National City Bank was renamed) in charge of the bank's global airline and aerospace business. While at Citibank, Mr. Bradley pioneered many of the innovative financing strategies used by the global airline industry today to acquire aircraft that often cost into the billions of dollars including structured financings utilizing global debt capital markets, leveraged tax-motivated lease financing, operating lease approaches, and asset-based, aircraft portfolio lease securitizations. He was well regarded throughout the industry for his ability to solve problems in what was often a cyclical, troubled industry by finding innovative but credible solutions and by supporting his clients through their difficult financial periods. He was the lead banker for many of the industry's principal companies, among these The Boeing Company, United Technologies, Pan Am and SAS. After retiring from Citibank in the early 1990's, Mr. Bradley joined various Boards of Directors including America West Airlines, Inc. (a predecessor company of American Airlines) where he served for seven years until 1999. He also served as the Chairman of the Board of ALPS 92-1 and 94-1, as Chairman of the Board of AerCo Limited and as a senior aviation industry adviser to the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan. Mr. Bradley was also a Director of First Citicorp Life Insurance Co., and the Institute of Air Transport Paris, France and was president of the International Air Transport Association's (IATA) International Airline Training Fund of the United States. He was predeceased by his wife, Elizabeth White Bradley, who died in 2012. He is survived by his daughters, Margaret Olivia Bradley and Anne Elizabeth Bradley. A Memorial Visitation will be held on Tuesday, September 16 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm with services beginning at 8pm at Memorial Funeral Home, 155 South Ave., Fanwood, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Colgate University (www.colgate.edu) or to the U.S.O. (www.uso.org). For additional information, or to express condolences, please visit www.fanwoodmemorial.com.

WICKERSHAM--Theodore Savage, 75, on September 8, 2014 after a long battle with prostate cancer. Survived by loved wife, Norma; sons Tod and Walter; stepdaughters Noelinda and Jeanan, and seven grandchildren and step-grandchildren. Retired law partner of McLaughlin & Stern. Member Union Club, Anglers' Club, The Church Club of NY, North Woods Club, St. Nicolas Society, Pilgrims, and Colonial Wars. Former President of Adirondack Landowners Association and North Woods Club, former Board Member of the Arthritis Foundation of New York. Great-grandson of Attorney General George W. Wickersham, grandson of General Cornelius W. Wickersham, son of Cornelius W. Wickersham, Jr., Esq and Elizabeth Savage Wickersham. Memorial service: Church of Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave. and 90th St. on September 19 at 2pm. Memorial contributions to Legal Aid Society of New York, 199 Water St., New York, NY 10038 or Adirondack Foundation: The Community Fund for the Gore Mountain Region, P.O. Box 217, North Creek, NY 12851 would be appropriate.

Swain--Jean Gerstner, passed away on August 25, 2014. A long-time resident of New York City, she was pre-deceased by her husband, John "Mark" Swain. Service to be held on September 13, 2014 at 10:30am at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, NJ.
SOLSTEIN--Marvin. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Marvin Solstein, associated with The New York Times from April 1, 1963 until retiring on September 1, 1987.

ROTHSTEIN--Joel B, on September 9, 2014 at age 89. Beloved husband of Iris for 56 years. Loving father of Lisa and Robin. Dear father-in-law of Jim Benson. Devoted brother of Dr. Marshall Rothstein. Treasured uncle and brother-in-law.

ROSEN--David, age 99, of Riverdale, NY passed away peacefully on September 9, 2014. Loving husband of Ruth (deceased) and devoted father of Bonnie Fry and Karen Morse (Clifford). He was a WWII Veteran and a lover of golf. A sweet and gentle man that will be missed by all who knew him.

MINKIN--Helen Siegel. Died August 26, 2014 at age 91. She was the beloved wife of George Minkin (deceased). She was the daughter of Louis Siegel and Ellen Storch Siegel. She was sibling to Selma Katzen (surviving) of Cincinnati, Ohio and aunt to Nancy Riedel, Marsha Jackson, and Larry Jackson (surviving) and Len Jackson (deceased). She received a B.A. (1943) from Barnard College and an LL.B. (1947) from Columbia University. She had practiced law in New York City since 1948. Over her long career, she earned the trust and respect of clients and colleagues alike. A memorial reception for George and Helen Minkin is planned at the Harvard Club of New York City on October 9 at 6:00pm.

KONECKY--Bill. It is with sorrow that we announce the passing of Bill Konecky, beloved father of Sean and his wife Sibylle, Evan, and Regan, brother-in-law of Isobel, uncle of Bob and Jennifer Wheelock and honorary grandfather to Tim and Matt. Bill was born in Brooklyn on January 8, 1918. He started his career in printing and publishing in 1936 and formally retired 75 years later at the 2011 Barnes & Noble Christmas Party. In that time he became friends with most of the leading figures in the New York publishing industry. In 1980 he started his own publishing company bringing out beautiful art books, and an authoritative library of books on the American Civil War and military history. Bill went into the army in 1939 as a private, graduated from OCS, served in the European Theater as a captain and then a major. At the end of the war he served in SHAEF, (Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force). At war's end, along with the Czech journalist and author Hans Habe, he ran Die Neue Zeitung, the German language newspaper published by the U.S. armed forces in the American Occupation Zone. In 1949 he married Patricia Haim. Their marriage lasted 49 years until Pat's death in 2004. Together they traveled the world, but were most at home in France where Bill's love and knowledge of French wine (Burgundy, not Bordeaux) and Pat's fluent French won them lifelong friendships. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel. Friday September 12 at 1:30pm.

EPSTEIN--Lawrence, Ph.D. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute & Society mourn the loss of our esteemed and beloved colleague, teacher, psychoanalyst, and friend. Training and Supervising Analyst and faculty member, Larry served the Institute devotedly for five decades. Consummate clinician, loyal friend, creative and imaginative contributor to the field of psychoanalysis, his wise, playful, and deeply honest spirit inspires us. Jay S. Kwawer, Ph.D., Director, White Institute Nicholas Samstag, Ph.D., President, White Society Christopher N. Young, President, Board of Trustees

EPSTEIN--Lawrence, PhD, 88. Our beloved father passed away on September 9. Dr. Epstein was an esteemed colleague, author, friend and mentor to many as well as a training and supervisory analyst and member of the faculty at the William Alanson White Institute. Dr Epstein is survived by his wife Roslyn his children, David and Andrea and four grandchildren. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Memorial donations may be made in Larry's name to a charity of your choice or the AHA. A memorial and viewing is scheduled for Saturday, September 13 from 2-4pm at the John Krtil Funeral Home 1297 1st Ave. New York, NY 10021. 212-744-3084.
DAVIS--Roy, at home on September 8, 2014, at the age of 91. Survived by his wife Cecily Langdale Davis; nephews, great-nephews and great- nieces, and cousins. A memorial service will be announced.

BREEN--Rev. Msgr. Edward J.,entered into eternal life on September 8, 2014 at Immaculate Conception Center, Douglaston, NY. Pastor Emeritus of Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church, East Elmhurst, NY. Beloved brother of Irene A. Breen, and the late Most Reverend Bishop Vincent De Paul Breen. In repose at Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights on Friday, 2-5pm. Vigil Mass Friday, 7:30pm, Our Lady of Fatima RCC, East Elmhurst. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10:30am, Our Lady of Fatima RCC. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

KAUFMAN--Bel. A memorial service for Bel Kaufman will take place on Wednesday, September 17th, at 4pm, at Hunter College's Kaye Playhouse, entrance on East 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

TOMASHOFF--Chelsy Blake. It is with great sorrow that we announce the passing of our beloved daughter on September 11. Loving sister, granddaughter, niece and friend to all who knew her. Chelsy strived to make a difference in the world by changing how people with disabilities are seen and treated. Funeral Sunday 10:30am, The Hampton Synagogue, 154 Sunset Ave. Westhampton Beach, NY. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale NY.

MINKIN--Helen Siegel. Died August 26, 2014 at age 91. She was the beloved wife of George Minkin (deceased). She was the daughter of Louis Siegel and Ellen Storch Siegel. She was sibling to Selma Katzen (surviving) of Cincinnati, Ohio and aunt to Nancy Riedel, Marsha Jackson, and Larry Jackson (surviving) and Len Jackson (deceased). She received a B.A. (1943) from Barnard College and an LL.B. (1947) from Columbia University. She had practiced law in New York City since 1948. Over her long career, she earned the trust and respect of clients and colleagues alike. A memorial reception for George and Helen Minkin is planned at the Harvard Club of New York City on October 9 at 6:00pm.

McLEE--Martin D. The New York Annual Conference of the United Methodist Church mourns the death of its beloved Bishop Martin D. McLee, who joined the Church Triumphant on September 6, 2014. A service celebrating Bishop McLee's life and our resurrection faith will be held on Monday, September 15th at 11:00am, at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY. A viewing will be held in the Riverside Church Christ Chapel from 8:30-10:30am.

KENNY--Thomas F.,92, on September 10th. He was Vice President at the Credit & Management Association. Ran an editorial business and former director of The Publicity Club of New York. Survived by his beloved wife Catherine Puleo. Memorial Services at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave (81st St) on Sunday 3pm to 5pm.

GOLDBERG--Eugene, of New York City and Wellington, FL. Son of Shirley and Abraham Goldberg of Brooklyn, NY, died at the age of 89 on Thursday, September 11, 2014. Attended NYU and graduated from the New York Maritime Academy, Ft. Schuyler, NY with the rank of Ensign USNR in 1944. He enlisted in the Merchant Marine as a Third Mate and was stationed on ships that supplied the Atlantic and Mediterranean areas during WWII. Eugene finished his tour in 1946 with the rank of Second Mate, Lt. Jr. Grade USNR. Upon leaving the service he joined the family business, THC Systems, Inc., a distributor of domestic chinaware, flatware, glassware and sundries to restaurant and hotel chains. Eugene as CEO, in 1969 changed the company's direction and became the first company of its kind to import hotel ware for the use in the airline industry. Together with his brother Robert they transformed THC Systems into a differentiated multinational firm that served leading companies in the foodservice, restaurant, airline and hospitality industries, among others. As a complement to his corporate activities, Eugene was a world-traveler, noted connoisseur with wide-ranging expertise in wine and art, and an ardent supporter of many charitable societies and foundations, and served on the boards of the Palm Beach Symphony, Morikami Museum, Fort Schuyler Maritime Foundation and Croquet Foundation of America. He is survived by his beautiful and loving wife of 67 years Eleanor Goldberg; his sister-in-law Joan Goldberg; his devoted daughter Celia; his beloved grandchildren Jimmy, Peter, George, Killian and Lauren and four great-grandchildren. Friends may visit at the funeral home from 6pm to 9pm Sunday, September 14, 2014. Funeral Services 11am, Monday, September 15, 2014 at Palms West Funeral Home, 110 Business Park Way, Royal Palm Beach, FL 33411.

HOOD--Linda Mason Died suddenly September 13, 2012. Daniel, her loving husband of 44 years, and adored son, Michael, continue to mourn her loss. Music performance was the joy of her life. Linda earned a BA cum laude in flute from Brooklyn College. She performed with the Washington Square Harp and Shamrock Orchestra. Linda was an International Project Manager for Thomson-Reuters and Board Chair of Menno House. In 2011 Linda performed "Waltz Me Around Again Willie" as a vocal solo on the charity CD, "In Partnership with the Poor," and live with WSHSO at Symphony Space. Hundreds gathered on 9/22/12 to share testimony in both word and music to Linda's sweet spirit of generosity and ebullient embrace of life. Her ashes will be mingled with Dan's, then scattered in rural Ireland. Visit her blog http://truffles-turtles-tunes. blogspot.com

KAUFMAN--Bel. A memorial service for Bel Kaufman will take place on Wednesday, September 17th, at 4pm, at Hunter College's Kaye Playhouse, entrance on East 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

YOUNG--David, 76, Cortlandt Manor, NY, died August 18, 2014. Born in Butler, PA, David graduated from NYU and served in the Army. A Mensa member, he worked for many years at Time and most recently the Somers Central School District. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sharon, and by his five children, David, Jennifer, Jessica, Brian and Owen. David played hockey all his life and competed in track and field at the Empire State Games. He passed down his love of New York sports to his children and grandchildren. At his request, no service was held.

WOLLMAN--Paul, fantastic father, husband and grandfather passed away on July 30, 2014. Married 52 years, he was predeceased in 2003 by the love of his life, Anne Gittleman Wollman. Paul leaves his children Eric and Karen, daughter-in-law Emily, son-in-law Kenneth and granddaughters Melanie and Jane. Born in New York City on August 4, 1929, Paul was an illustrator for the United States Army and an art director in the advertising industry. At DDB in the 1960's he was on the creative team that developed the iconic ads for Volkswagen - including the Snow Plow and the Egg ads. He continued at Y&R, Carl Ally and Romano & Wollman, creating ads for Jaguar, Fiat and British Leyland. An award winning member of the Art Directors Club of New York, his work is at MOMA. As an illustrator he conceived ads for Cole Hahn, Hickey Freeman and the PGA. A lifelong painter, Paul taught watercolor workshops aboard the Queen Elizabeth and on land at the James Lenox House in NY. His career took the family to Dusseldorf, London, Paris and Marbella, ultimately returning to his beloved New York City. Please consider donations to the James Lenox House Association, 49 East 73rd Street, New York, NY 10021. Paul Wollman's soul and spirit will be missed forever.

WITTENBERG--Ann. Our family is saddened by the passing of Ms. Wittenberg. Your particular elegance, boundless wisdom, and affectionate friendship will be missed. Thanks for all of our wonderful times together. The Kalick's
