WAHLE--Harold Lawrence (Larry), on September 12, 2014. Knocking on the door of 90, truly one of the "Greatest Generation". Son of the late Benjamin and Ethel Wahle. Beloved husband of Renee for 64 years. Devoted father of Elliott (Helene) and Gail (Rick Taffer). Loving grandfather of Melissa, Aaron, Elyse and Sam. Proud great-grandfather of Ryan and Leora. Dear brother of Muriel Engel, the late Mildred Rosenkranz and Daniel Wahle. A distinguished WWII veteran who proudly served in the US Navy. Larry was a man of integrity and strength who truly loved his family, playing golf and a good book. Services today 11:30am "Sinai Chapels", 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY 11365.

SOYBEL--Arthur Isaac. The son of Ukrainian immigrants who were active in business, education and philanthropy, Arthur Soybel was born in Brooklyn on June 16, 1925, and died at home on September 6, 2014. He attended the Little Red Schoolhouse and Erasmus High School before enlisting in the V-12 Navy College Training Program at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1943. He served as an ensign on a minesweeper in the Pacific and then returned to UNC where he graduated in 1947 as a political science major. An accomplished pianist, he graduated from the Manhattan School of Music in 1949 and played professionally, but settled on a legal career after graduating from New York Law School in 1954. He specialized in real estate and artistic intellectual property contracts from 1954 until his retirement in 2012. Throughout his professional life, he served on the boards of multiple organizations, including the W. Eugene Smith Memorial Fund, the Rudolf Steiner School, Manhattan Community Board 7, the Westside Chamber of Commerce, and the Foundation for Religion and Mental Health. His passion for gardening at his mountain home in Shady, NY, was matched by his love for the nature and rich culture of the American Southwest and for his wife's hometown of Berlin. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Renate Elise Haake Soybel, his daughter, Carol Ann Soybel Bartges, both of New York City, his daughter-in-law, Virginia Earll Soybel, of Boston, by three grandchildren Max Bartges, Sarah Bartges Ohana, and Anna Soybel and by two great-granddaughters. His son, Thomas W. Soybel, died in 2010. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Central Park Conservancy.

SMITH--Julia Scarsten, on September 6, 2014. Loving wife of the late Arthur T. Smith. Cherished daughter of the late Dr. Christian P. and Emma Scarsten. Interment with her family in Green-Wood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Please make donations in her name to: Norwegian Christian Home Foundation 1250 67th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11219.

SHANLEY--Grace Ross, age 87, of Rowayton, CT beloved wife of William Carleton Shanley III, passed away at her home on Monday, September 8, 2014 with her loving family by her side. Grace was born on March 24, 1927, in New York City, daughter of the late Henry and Evelyn (Timothy) Ross. She married William (Bill) C. Shanley III of Roslyn, NY, in 1954 and recently celebrated their 60th anniversary on May 1st of this year. Grace was the proud mother of six children and 15 grandchildren, as well as an accomplished artist, creative force, and founder of the Center for Contemporary Print Making (CCP). She, along with her husband, Bill, founded the Center in 1995, as a printmaking facility whose mission is to support, preserve, and advance the art of original prints. Grace had a passion for art and a love for people and family. Her infectious creativity, kindness, loyalty, honesty, and joyful laugh will be missed by each person who was privileged to know her. She was an energetic force that touched everyone around her and always saw the best in everything. "Grandma" grew up in Jackson Heights, NY where she attended Garden Country Day school and went on to graduate from Manhattanville College with a BS in mathematics. She also studied at the Parsons School of Design, Baltimore Institute and Art Students League. She began her career with the McCann-Erickson advertising agency in NYC before pursuing her creative and artistic passions full time. Moving from Manhasset, NY to New Canaan, CT in 1975, Grace continued her illustrious career in the arts, as an artist, art director and visionary art center founder. For almost 20 years until 1995 she served as the Executive Director of the Silvermine Guild. From 1995 when she founded CCP through her death Grace served as Chairman or Chairman Emeritus of the Board. She also sat on the board of The Shanley Family Foundation, which contributes to education and the arts, and was a Board Member of the Vermont Studio Center. Through her career Grace received awards for her own art, and was written up in the New York Times and numerous other newspapers, art magazines and journals. She was also a member of the Pastel Society of America, and had many exhibits throughout the NY/NE area. Recent shows include, "Circle of Life Then and Now", at the Silvermine Art Center in New Canaan CT and "Recurrence of Memory" , at the Center for Contemporary Printmaking, in Norwalk, CT. Her talents included oil painting, pastel, charcoal, watercolor, printmaking, and multidiscipline artistry which incorporated photography, computer graphics, and traditional art mediums. She was a highly talented portrait artist, whose subjects where typically her children and grandchildren. Additionally, she was president of the Manhattanville Club, director of the Woman's Club of Nassau/Suffolk, and board member of too many artistic endeavors to count. She was an accomplished tennis player, golfer, and was known to occasionally beat her husband at Skeet Shooting. But in her soul, she was the life force that kept her broad family close. Survivors include her husband of 60 years William C. Shanley III, her children, Sharon S. Sniffen, William C. Shanley IV, Thomas R. Shanley, Mary Evelyn S. Malloy, Timothy K. Shanley and Patrick M. Shanley. Grace was predeceased by a brother Thomas B. Ross. A Funeral Service will take place on September 20, 2014, at 11am at the Church of the Good Shepard in Blooming Grove, PA. A lunch and celebration will follow at the Blooming Grove Club. A "Celebration of Life" will take place at the Center for Contemporary Printmaking on October 12th (time TBD). The Shanley Family has asked that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made, in Grace's honor, to the Grace Shanley Memorial Scholarship Fund for aspiring artists at the Center for Contemporary Printmaking (on line donations at http://www.contemprints.org/; checks can be made out/ mailed to Center for Contemporary Printmaking, Mathews Park, 299 West Avenue. Norwalk, CT 06850). To leave an online condolence, please go to, www.magnerfuneralhome. com

MARCUS--Shirley, born October 14, 1923 on East 94th St., Manhattan, died at her home on on East 66th St. on September 9, 2014. The daughter of Abraham and Rose Marcus, immigrants from Romania who became shop owners in New York, Shirley was for decades a financial executive at Longines Watch Co., and subsequently at the Iron Workers Locals 40, 361 and 417. Shirley was briefly married to Arthur Liebowitz, DDS. Shirley's sardonic wit and lively stories of mistakes, doom, marriage, and money management made her a memorable and much-loved character in the Marcus family. Her devotion to Jewish causes, world traveling, and New York diners were notable. She is predeceased by her siblings Anne Marcus, Carl Marcus, and Ruth Bendiner. Her many nieces and nephews will miss her deeply, and are grateful for the care provided to Shirley in her later years by Doreen Hayes and her colleagues.

MACOMBER--Phyllis B.,90, of Nantucket, MA, died on September 3, 2014. A 1945 graduate of Simmons College, she worked as a stenographer at Sullivan and Cromwell in New York and shortly thereafter for John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, as personal assistant in managing his office, and later for Dean Rusk, U.S. Secretary of State. This was a complex and demanding job that she handled with enormous skill and dedication. She married William B. Macomber, who worked in the State Department for five Presidents. They lived in Jordan and Turkey when he was Ambassador. Upon Mr. Macomber's retirement they moved to New York where he became the President of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The couple settled in Nantucket where both were deeply involved in various organizations, including the Nantucket Historical Association and the Nantucket Garden Club. She is survived by her sister, Edna Allen and her brother-in-law John D. Macomber and five nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Offshore Animal Hospital of Nantucket or the Alzheimer's Association.

LEIBOWITZ--Ellen. Always there with us. Best sister, sister-in-law and aunt. We will miss you. Robinson/Helfman Family

KORNBLAU--Jules H.,"And if I ever lost you, how much would I cry? How deep is the ocean? How high is the sky?"

KORNBLAU--Jules H.,of New York City, Fair Harbor, Fire Island, and Palm Beach, died peacefully at his home on September 7, 2014. He leaves his cherished wife of sixty years, Helen Weinreb Kornblau, his beloved four children, David, Kenneth, Eric, and Katherine, and their spouses, Amy, Lisa, Stacy, and Matt Susskind. He was the proud and devoted grandfather of Joel (Jaime), Michelle (Josh), Jennifer, Daniel, Jonathan, Sam, and Sofia, adoring great-grandfather of Zoey, and loving uncle of Lisa and Craig Spear. Born in Atlantic City, NJ, Jules graduated from Eastern District High School, where he was President of the G.O., Baruch College (The City University of New York), and Columbia Law School. He practiced law in New York City for more than forty years, most recently in the law firm of Kornblau & Kornblau, P.C., with his son and partner, Eric. Jules was an avid New York sports fan, world traveler, athlete, great enthusiast of history, literature, and the arts, and thoroughly enjoyed everything that life had to offer. But his greatest source of joy was the time he spent with his family and friends. Jules made lifelong friends easily. He loved his friends from public school, high school, college, law school, Rockville Centre, Fire Island, and his pinochle and bridge cronies; they loved and respected him in return. Jules was a big, strong, generous man with a very tender heart and soul who expressed no regrets, just an appreciation for his life and the family that is his legacy. Patriarch extraordinaire -- we will carry you in our hearts forever and endeavor always to live by your shining example. "Now cracks a noble heart. Good night sweet prince: And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!" Donations in memory of Jules may be made to the Jules H. Kornblau Memorial Scholarship Fund at Baruch College.

KING--Thomas M.,on September 13, 2014 at age 59. Beloved husband of Victoria (nee Sheridan). Loving father of Thomas and Tracey. Adored son of Thomas and Shelia King. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The American Cancer Society or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

KIMMELMAN--Judge Irwin I.,84, passed away on Friday, September 12, 2014. He is survived by his loving wife of 60 years, Margaret, and his children Joan and Douglas and their spouses Edward and Carol. He was the proud grandfather of Lauren, Julia, Annie, Robert, Tommy and Scottie. Born in Newark, New Jersey, Judge Kimmelman graduated from the Rutgers School of Business Administration in 1952 and from Harvard Law School in 1955. He pursued a distinguished career in law and public service for 45 years. He was a partner at the law firms of Hannoch, Weisman and Kimmelman, Wolff and Samson. He was elected to the New Jersey General Assembly in 1963 and served as Essex County General Counsel from 1968 to 1970. In 1982, Judge Kimmelman was appointed by New Jersey Governor Thomas H. Kean to serve as Attorney General, a position he held until 1986. He was a Judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey, Chancery Division, from 1970 to 1976, and again from 1989 to 1994, at which point he was appointed to the Appellate Division, where he served until his retirement in 2000. An avid boater and fisherman, Judge Kimmelman spent his happiest moments with his family at his summer home on the Jersey shore.

KASS--Bernice Diane Karp, passed away on August 20, in Coral Springs Florida. She was 83. She leaves behind her loving children; daughter Arden Kass (Juan), son Marshall Kass (Nicole) and grandchildren Izzi, Jillian, Leo and Gaby. Peace, BC.

JANDA--Irene Elizabeth, 55, on September 10th, after 13 years of grace, poise, and ever compassionate persistence in the face of ovarian cancer. Kindest and most admired friend, niece, cousin, aunt, daughter and sister. An ardent lover of animals, music and a fine fabrics expert. A lifelong devout Catholic, she believed we were all brothers and sisters. In that spirit, she is survived by all of us. She will be missed by all who knew her and by those who never had the chance. The world is compromised by her absence. Contributions to Ovarian Cancer Research Fund. Services: Thursday, September 18 at 10:30am, American Martyrs Church, 79 43 Bell Boulevard, Bayside.
HINSON--Harry Lee. Mentor and friend. Remembered warmly and always. My condolences to Tripp March. Rest in Peace. PAS

HINSON--Harry Lee, III, a leading figure in the home furnishings industry, died in Manhattan on September 4, 2014. Hinson was born on March 30, 1938 in Rocky Mount, NC. After attending local schools, he went on to graduate from the Richmond Professional Institute of the Colleges of William and Mary in 1962. Immediately upon graduation, he joined the Executive Training Program at Bloomingdale's where he focused his interest on interior design and became assistant to the firm's widely acclaimed interior designer, Barbara Darcy. Following his successful launch into the international world of interior design, Hinson joined the illustrious retailer Bonwit Teller where he worked with the renowned store president Mildred Custin. Bonwit's, as the store was known, specialized in high-end apparel, catering to an elite "carriage trade." Hinson designed branch stores in the burgeoning suburbs of Westchester County, Long Island and major cities across the country and served as director of interior design for all of the Bonwit Teller stores. While still at Bonwit's, he and three other men opened the wallpaper and fabric firm, Quadrille, which continues to be a major supplier today. In 1971, Hinson inaugurated Hinson & Co., Ltd. It soon became the leading wallpaper and fabric firm in the United States. After Hinson's retirement the firm was acquired by Brunschwig & Fils and has subsequently closed. A lifelong member of the Episcopal Church, Hinson was active in both St. Bartholomew's and St. Thomas parishes in New York City. He was Commander in the Order of St. John of Jerusalem. In 1982, Hinson was chosen to design wallpapers and fabrics for the New American Wing Collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He was selected in 1985 to design the Wildflowers of America fabric and wallpaper collection for Lady Bird Johnson's National Wildflowers Collection. He was a member of the board of trustees of the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club and served for thirty-three years to organize the Kips Bay Decorator Show House and also as its chairman for many years. He was a member of the board of directors of the Decorative Fabrics Association and a member of the American Society of Interior Designers. In addition to his apartment in New York City, Hinson was a longtime resident of East Hampton, Long Island, New York. At his request, there will be no burial or memorial service. His remains will be interred in the columbarium of the Chapel of The Resurrection at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue, New York City. Harry Hinson is survived by his spouse Tripp March. Hinson and March were companions for twenty-eight years. They were married on June 6, 2013. Memorial contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan- Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065.

HERZSTEIN--Laine, died peacefully September 9, 2014. Daughter of the late Morris F. and Helen Murphy Herzstein. Sister of the late Morris J. Herzstein and Jayne Kepner. Survived by her sister Constance of Jenkintown and brothers Rev. Joseph, C.S.S.P. of Tanzania and John of Harleysville. Also survived by a niece and five nephews, grandnieces and nephews and great-grandnieces and nephews. Interment was private. Memorial donations may be made to Congregation of the Holy Spirit, 6230 Brush Run Rd., Bethel Park, PA 15102. Services by FitzPatrick Funeral Home, Abington. www.fitzpatrickabington.com

GOLDSTEIN--Mark N.,MD A compassionate and brilliant physician who placed the well-being of his patients above all else, was taken too soon. Our friendship spanned nearly 50 years during which time we had many wonderful experiences and adventures together. But of greatest importance is the fact that each of us knew we could count on the other in times of need. I am honored to have known him and to have counted him among my very best friends. I mourn his loss and will miss him dearly. My wife, Jane, and I extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife and son. Ernest J. Dellheim, DMD

GOLDBERG--Eugene, of New York City and Wellington, FL, son of Shirley and Abraham Goldberg of Brooklyn, NY, died at the age of 89 on Thursday, September 11, 2014. Attended NYU and graduated from the New York Maritime Academy, Ft. Schuyler, NY with the rank of Ensign USNR in 1944. He enlisted in the Merchant Marine as a Third Mate and was stationed on ships that supplied the Atlantic and Mediterranean areas during WWII. Eugene finished his tour in 1946 with the rank of Second Mate, Lt. Jr. Grade USNR. Upon leaving the service he joined the family business, THC Systems, Inc., a distributor of domestic chinaware, flatware, glassware and sundries to restaurant and hotel chains. Eugene as CEO, in 1969 changed the company's direction and became the first company of its kind to import hotel ware for the use in the airline industry. Together with his brother Robert they transformed THC Systems into a differentiated multinational firm that served leading companies in the foodservice, restaurant, airline and hospitality industries, among others. As a complement to his corporate activities, Eugene was a world-traveler, noted connoisseur with wide-ranging expertise in wine and art, and an ardent supporter of many charitable societies and foundations, and served on the boards of the Palm Beach Symphony, Morikami Museum, Fort Schuyler Maritime Foundation and Croquet Foundation of America. He is survived by his beautiful and loving wife of 67 years Eleanor Goldberg; his sister-in-law Joan Goldberg; his devoted daughter Celia Zahringer; his beloved grandchildren Dr. James Kessler, Major Peter B. Marks USMC, George J. Zahringer IV, Killian Combs Zahringer and Lauren Turner Zahringer and four great-grandchildren. Friends may visit at the Funeral Home from 06:00 to 09:00pm Sunday, September 14, 2014. Funeral Services 11:00am. Monday, September 15, 2014 at Palms West Funeral Home, 110 Business Park Way, Royal Palm Beach, FL 33411.

FULTON--Maurice 1919-2014 It is with great sorrow that we mourn the passing of Maurice Fulton of Highland Park, IL and Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Glencoe, IL. Fulton, past president and chairman of the board of the Fantus Company, died August 31st in Highland Park, Illinois, at age 94. The Fantus Company (previously, the Fantus Factory Locating Service) was the oldest and largest consulting firm dedicated to factory site selection. The Fantus Company evolved from a three-person business started by Felix Fantus and his two sons-in-law Maurice Fulton and Leonard C. Yaseen of New York, into the premier authority on plant location, pioneering research in economic geography. During his tenure at the Fantus Company, Fulton was consultant to governors of 11 states, and to the White House under Presidents Nixon and Carter. The company was sold to Dunn & Bradstreet, and is now a division of Deloitte & Touche. Fulton lectured widely, authored books and articles, and taught a course on industrial location at his alma mater, the University of Chicago. Son of William and Sadie Fedotin, younger brother of the late Lionel, Maurice Fulton was raised on Chicago's West Side. At age 13, he began working at Mailing Shoes for $2eek. Halfway through his senior year of high school, Fulton entered the University of Chicago. He graduated in five years with combined bachelors and JD degrees, and served as editor of the Law Review. At the University of Chicago, Maurice met fellow student and love of his life, Muriel Fantus. Fulton graduated with his uniform and orders under his graduation robe and he entered the Navy as an officer. Fulton fought in and around the Solomon Islands in the South Pacific, and later the Central Pacific. He participated in the invasions of Guam and Leyte, often coordinating movement of Landing Ship Tanks. Fulton received the Navy's commendation and the Presidential Unit Citation for "outstanding heroism." While on brief leave from the war in 1944, Maurice married Muriel, before returning to active service. Maurice Fulton served as president of the Glencoe (Illinois) School Board, was a member of Rotary, practiced arbitration in the Chicago court systems, and served as a Trustee of the Art Institute of Chicago. He committed many hours to boards and committees of a number of non-profits, including his beloved University of Chicago, Ravinia Music Festival, Boca Raton Museum of Art, Morikami Museum, and the Chicago Botanic Garden. A lecture series at the University of Chicago on the History of Law is named for Maurice and Muriel Fulton. His family knew him first and foremost as a romantic, whose primary concern was always his beloved Muriel. Her presence was all he required for his happiness. He persuaded the University of Chicago to put a plaque in the location on campus where he and Muriel first met in 1938. Fulton is survived by Muriel, to whom he was married for nearly 70 years, two daughters, Barbara Sideman and Jane Alt (Howard), and son Paul (Cathy), 11 grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. His oldest daughter, Peggy Heller (Steven) predeceased him in 2012. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September, 14 at 10:00am at Lake Shore Country Club, 1255 Sheridan Rd. Glencoe, IL. Contributions can be made to the charity of your choice in Maurice's memory.

FONG--Dr. Bobby. The Board of Trustees, along with the students, parents, faculty, staff, and alumni of Ursinus College in Collegeville, PA, mourn the untimely passing of Dr. Bobby Fong, 15th President of Ursinus College, who died unexpectedly on September 8, 2014. As President of Ursinus since July 2011, he established himself as a leader with integrity, vision, humor, and passion, hailed for his role as a national leader on the stage of higher education, especially in the liberal arts. He continued to enhance the Ursinus College model for liberal education where students learn to think critically, communicate effectively, work cooperatively, and act ethically. He was committed to the values that lead not only to graduates making a living, but also making lives of purpose. Dr. Fong led the campus in creating "Transformative Education," a seven-year strategic plan for Ursinus, and in establishing two interdisciplinary centers: the Center for Science and the Common Good and the U-Imagine! Center for Integrative and Entrepreneurial Studies. He recently led efforts that resulted in the third largest incoming class, which surpassed enrollment goals, and the best fundraising year in the history of the College. He made connections with Chinese universities, the local and greater Philadelphia communities, and a wide range of individuals across the country. The son of Chinese immigrants, Dr. Fong grew up in Chinatown in Oakland, CA, where he developed a lifelong passion for baseball. He earned a scholarship to Harvard and received his doctorate in English Literature from the University of California - Los Angeles. He was an internationally known scholar of Oscar Wilde and the editor of the Oxford edition of Wilde's poetry. His academic career took him from Berea College, to Dean of Arts and Humanities at Hope College, to Dean of Hamilton College. In 2001 he became President of Butler University, where he served for a decade and was a beloved leader. During his tenure, the men's basketball team twice reached the NCAA Final Four championship game. Dr. Fong was past Chair of the Board of the Association of American Colleges and Universities, and served on the Presidents' Council of the Association of Governing Boards. He also served on the boards of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, the Council for Higher Education Accreditation, the Council for Independent Colleges/Network for Vocation in Undergraduate Education, the Lingnan University Foundation, Project Pericles, the Annapolis Group, and the Greater Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce. We extend our deepest condolences to Suzanne Fong and sons Jonathan and Nicholas (Colin). A memorial service will take place September 20, 2014, at 11am on the Ursinus College campus in Bomberger Hall. Memorial contributions can be made in support of the planned Innovation and Discovery Center, which was one of Dr. Fong's highest priorities for his presidency. Contributions can be mailed to Ursinus College; Attn: Advancement Office; 601 E. Main Street; Collegeville, PA 19426, with checks made payable to "Ursinus College" and noting tribute to Dr. Fong. Memorial gifts may also be made online at www.ursinus.edu/makegift/.
FLEISIG--Jerry. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Jerry. Our hearts go out to Mona, Jodi, Pamela and Jonathan and the rest of his family. We loved him, we will miss him. Wilma and Lou Perlman

FLEISIG--Gerald. It is with broken hearts that we announce the death of our great husband, father and grandfather Jerry Fleisig. He died Saturday, September 13th at 8:25am. He died peacefully and comfortably in his home. Jerry is survived by the love of his life for 56 years, Mona and their children, Jodi Fleisig Gabay and Moti Gabay, Pamela and Bruce Azus a Jonathan Fleisig. Papa was loved dearly by his five grandchildren Zachary, Jake, Kody, Ari and Brynn. He will be missed by his brothers Alvin Poskar and Robert FIeisig, sister Barbara Spitzer. Jerry is the son of Murray and Sally Fleisig and son-in-Iaw of Harry and Pauline Poskar. Jerry was an amazing, honest, loyal man who was loved by his family and friends in New York and Florida. He was a great golfer, tennis player and card player. The men's card room at Addison Reserve will never be the same. He's now joining his late sister Joan and best friends Harvey and Louie for a gin game. Funeral Services will be held Monday at 12:00pm at Gutterman's Funeral Home on Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, NY. Shiva will be observed at the home of his daughter, Pamela Azus, at 9 Bensin Drive in Melville, NY. Papa, you were the best daddy and grandpa ever. We will miss you so much!

FINKENSTAEDT--Rose Lindsay Harvey. Died on August 30, 2014, in Paris in her 88th year. Mrs. Finkenstaedt, who was born in Baltimore, MD, was educated at Miss Hall's School in Pittsfield, MA, Vassar College for two years, then transferred to Columbia University where she received her BA, MA and PhD. She married James Clements Finkenstaedt in 1947 and spent the next year in Paris where she studied at the Sorbonne and began her love of the French cuisine. While in New York, she was a Civil Rights activist and wrote and served on the editorial board of The Liberator, a black revolutionary magazine. From 1965-1967, she taught Comparative Literature at Hofstra University. Following this, she moved to Paris with her family, where she continued her writing career which included an extensive number of books best categorized as Histoires des Idees with a focus on American history, literature, economics, race, and the black struggle. She also wrote two novels and occasionally translated cookbooks. She continued her love of the French cuisine and befriended some of France's most noted chefs. She rode her bicycle throughout France, enjoyed swimming, and was an avid supporter of tennis. She is survived by her daughter Isabel Finkenstaedt Schelameur; her grandchildren, Catherine, Rose Lindsay, James III, Thomas Finkenstaedt, Pierre, William Luke and Rose Schelameur; her sisters Mrs. Ellen H. Kelly and Dr. Jean H. Baker; her brothers Robert H. Harvey and Alexander Harvey all of Baltimore, MD.

DENMARK--Jerome, died September 8, 2014. Born in New York City February 8, 1921, a member of the Greatest Generation, he gave his all and asked for nothing. Jerry voluntarily interrupted his education at City College of New York in 1942 to enlist in the United States Army. Served in Battery B 904th Field Artillery Battalion in Europe; liberated a Polish concentration camp and received four medals before his 1945 discharge. After marrying and moving to Westchester County, Jerry founded White Plains Electrical Supply Co. in 1955 and retired in 1988. Jerry will be greatly missed by his wife Frieda, children Frances (Alan Feld) and William (Carol Sack) and four grandchildren, Daniel and Rebecca Feld and Andrea and Julie Denmark. Memorial donations can be sent to www.USO.org.
DAVIS--Roy, at home on September 8, 2014, at the age of 91. Survived by his wife Cecily Langdale Davis; nephews, great-nephews and great- nieces, and cousins. A memorial service will be announced.

CREWE--Bob. Known for writing hit songs from the 1950's through the 1970's, including "Can't Take My Eyes Off Of You," "Rag Doll," "Walk Like A Man," "Lady Marmalade," "My Eyes Adored You," "The Sun Ain't Gonna Shine Anymore," and as the lyricist of the hit Broadway show "Jersey Boys," died peacefully, with his brother Dan Crewe by his side, on Thursday, September 11, 2014 in Scarborough, ME. Crewe was a dynamic, innovative record producer, producing such recording artists as The Four Seasons, Mitch Ryder & The Detroit Wheels, Oliver, Lesley Gore, Frankie Valli and Bobby Darin. He was also mentor to songwriters Kenny Nolan, L. Russell Brown, Desmond Child and Cindy Bullens. Born in Newark, NJ, Bob Crewe spent his formative years in Belleville, NJ. He moved to New York City to attend Parsons School of Design with the desire to become an architect. After a year, Bob left Parsons to embark on a musical career singing on recording demos and writing songs with his first writing partner Frank C. Slay. Together they wrote "La Dee Dah," "Bells Bells Bells" and "Lucky Ladybug" for Billy & Lillie. Bob's lyrics in the hit song, "Silhouettes," by The Rays, showcased early on his lyrical storytelling. Crewe and Slay also wrote hits for Freddie Cannon including "Way Down Yonder In New Orleans" and "Tallahassee Lassie." In 1961, Bob Crewe turned to his singing talents on Warwick Records, with "The Whiffenpoof Song," "Water Boy," and "Voglio Cantare." Bob's dynamic character and striking good looks triggered teen idol status, landing him on the cover of 16 Magazine and on early 1960's national talent shows. Earlier, he had been a successful fashion model, appearing as the face of Coca-Cola in 1957. During the flurry of music activity in the early Sixties, Bob discovered a young vocal group from New Jersey, hiring them to sing backup on recording demos and singles. With the addition of a young songwriter to the group, Bob Gaudio, Crewe renamed the group The Four Seasons. The songwriting collaboration of Bob Crewe and Bob Gaudio garnered many hits for The Four Seasons including "Rag Doll," "Walk Like A Man," "Can't Take My Eyes Off You," "Big Man In Town" and "Bye Bye Baby (Baby Goodbye)." In 1967, Bob heard a jingle on the radio for a Diet Pepsi commercial and rushed into the studio to record it as a single. "Music To Watch Girls By" spawned the Bob Crewe Generation and was a major hit. Bob Crewe innovated the concept of independent record production, creating his own label, DynoVoice Records. The Crewe Group of Companies, a complex of several companies that included three publishing houses, Saturday Music, Tomorrow's Tunes, and Genius Music was formed and administered by his brother Dan Crewe. Bob's musical talent discoveries included an undeniable list of heavyweights. After The Four Seasons, Bob found raw talent in a young band from Detroit and renamed them Mitch Ryder & The Detroit Wheels. The collaboration spawned three Top 10 hits, "Jenny Take A Ride," "Sock It To Me," and "Devil In A Blue Dress." Having moved from New York to Los Angeles in the mid 1970's, Bob Crewe's music success continued with young songwriter Kenny Nolan, penning the hit, "My Eyes Adored You," for Frankie Valli's solo effort. In 1974, with continued writing collaboration, Bob and Kenny wrote the Number 1 hit, "Lady Marmalade," which Allen Toussaint recorded with LaBelle. In the 1980's, Bob Crewe renewed his focus on his passion for painting and sculpture. Bob had successful showings at Earl McGrath Gallery, Tom Solomon'S Garage, and Jan Baum Gallery, all in Los Angeles. Nearly every song written by Bob Crewe with his collaborators charted in Billboard's top 20. In 1992, Bob was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame. He was also feted by BMI in 2000, with a Millennium award for the third most played song on the radio, "Can't Take My Eyes Off Of You." Bob's compositions have been heard in numerous films and television shows and include the score for the soundtrack of the cult classic film Barbarella, written with Charlie Fox. In 2011, Bob and Dan Crewe established the Bob Crewe Foundation. The mission of the Foundation is to support scholarships in the fields of art and music. It also supports LGBTQ issues. The Foundation recently granted the Maine College of Art $3 million to establish the Bob Crewe Program for Art and Music. The program introduces, for the first time, a music program at a college of Art. Bob Crewe is survived by his brother, Dan Crewe of Cumberland, ME; niece Reid Bullens Crewe of Portland, ME, and Cidny Bullens of Portland, ME. He is also survived by niece Therese Crewe of Newton, NJ, nephew Thomas C. Crewe of Hewitt, NJ, and many close friends and colleagues. Bob was very proud of his sobriety as a member of Alcoholics Anonymous for 37 years. Bob will be missed, but not forgotten - every twenty minutes a Bob Crewe song is playing somewhere in the world. Donations can be made in Bob's name to the Maine College of Art Scholarship Fund, the University of Southern Maine School of Music Scholarship Fund, or The Frannie Peabody Center, Portland, ME. To share memories and condolences with the family, please go to www.athutchins.com. Services by A.T. Hutchins Funeral Home, 660 Brighton Avenue, Portland, ME.

COHEN--Bette Reid, died peacefully at home on September 8 at the age of 92. Originally from Michigan, Bette came to New York in her 20's as a dancer; she fell in love with both the city and with Bill Cohen, and they married in 1945. Bill and Bette were among the original tenants of Peter Cooper Village, and Bette loved walking from East 23rd to her work. Her long professional career began as office manager for her father in law's lumber business near Union Square. Her next job was in retail as Bette's people skills won her the position of handling customer relations at B.Altman's Department Store. When the store closed, Bette was hired by the administrative offices at the Veteran's Hospital, where she worked well into her 80's. An accomplished cook and conversationalist, Bette loved hosting friends for dinner-- her guests enjoyed both her delicious food and sharp wit. Always elegant, Bette went regularly to theater, music and museums-walking there in order to take in every detail of her beloved New York. Contributions may be made in her honor to the Metropolitan Museum .

CAULKINS--Virginia Backus. January 11th, 1922 September 4th, 2014. Virginia Backus Caulkins died peacefully at her home in Hobe Sound, FL on September 4th, 2014 at the age of 92. Born in Detroit, Michigan to Standish and Lotta Boyer Backus, she attended the Ethel Walker School and graduated in 1940. In 1941 she married Alfred "Budd" Marks and brought up their five children in Grosse Pointe. After divorcing in 1975, she married Edward Burns Caulkins of Detroit and lived in Grosse Pointe, Hobe Sound and Gloucester, MA. She is survived by her four sons Robin, Randolph, Standish, Timothy and daughter Shelley Marks along with their wives, husband and two grandchildren. Virgie excelled at skiing, tennis, golf, shooting, and bridge and will always be remembered by her loving family for her irreverent wit and fun-loving nature. The family asks that you consider a contribution in Virgie's memory to a charity of your choosing.

CARROLL--Thomas H.,Age 82, passed away on September 8th, at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 52 years. A private service will be held at the burial site in Manchester, VT.

CAMPBELL--Virginia Warren. Age 92, died peacefully on June 25, 2014, in Port Washington, NY. Virginia was born in Yankton, SD, on March 7, 1922. On August 12, 1942 she was married to David Arthur Campbell of Great Neck, NY. Virginia is survived by her three children, David Arthur Campbell, Jr., Jeanne Campbell Sedgwick of Woodside, CA, and Carol Edmunds Campbell of New York City. Virginia was an active mental health advocate and was appointed to the New York State Board of Visitors. She also was also a member of Christ Church of Manhasset, NY, the Junior League of the North Shore of Long Island, and P.E.O. We will all miss her ready laugh and her beautiful green eyes and raven hair (even at age 92). Donations in Virginia's name would be welcomed by the Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd., Suite 2, Woodbury NY 11797-2946; 800-405-6731. Notes of condolence to the family can be sent to: caroledmundscampbell @gmail.com

BURDICK--Edward Hyde, of Rye, NY died September 5th. Born in Chicago in 1935, Mr. Burdick lived in Larchmont for 47 years as well as Philadelphia, Detroit, Brooklyn and Wilmington, North Carolina. Mr. Burdick graduated from Mamaroneck High School in 1953 and from Cornell in 1957 with a BS in mechanical engineering. A distinguished military student, he served in the US Army Reserve. In 1964 Mr. Burdick graduated from Harvard Business School with an MBA. Mr. Burdick briefly worked for the Air Reduction Company. In 1968 he began a 28-year career working for the Rockefeller family office, retiring in 1995 as president of its Wayfarer Ketch Corporation. Mr. Burdick is survived by his wife, Margaret MacCallum Burdick, sons Andy (Sarah) and Ted (Aileen), sisters Barbara Gallagher and Jane Burdick and seven grandchildren. A daughter, Betsy, predeceased Mr. Burdick. Contributions can be made to St. John's Episcopal Church, 4 Fountain Square, Larchmont, NY 10538 or Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.

BIBEN--James H. A dedicated husband, father and grandfather, passed away on September 6, 2014, his 22nd wedding anniversary, at age 78. He was predeceased by his parents, Joseph and Augusta Biben; sister, Elaine Boehm; brother, Robert Biben and nephew Stephen. He is survived by his loving wife, Gail; devoted children Matthew (Ellen) and Douglas Biben; step-children Lara and Marc (Amy) Badain; three grandchildren and three step-grandchildren; brother, Dr. Lewis (Beverly) H. Biben; nieces Barbara and Susan Boehm and Candy Scherer; and nephews Jeffrey, Gregory, and Bradley Biben. He was a proud graduate of Cornell University and the Cornell Law School, and an attorney in private practice in Rochester, NY for over 50 years. A lifelong Rochesterian, he supported numerous local area charities and civic organizations. He was a lawyer's lawyer; a dedicated husband and father; and a man of unwavering integrity and generosity who will be missed greatly. Funeral Services were held in Rochester, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to: www.giving.cornell.edu

BARKER--Robert (Bob) M.,age 84, of Sands Point, on September 11, 2014. Devoted husband of Barbara (pre-deceased), loving father of Robin and Wendy (pre-deceased), step-sons Jeffrey and Van Stogner, grandchildren Zachary Bridges, Meghan Bridges FeIder, Antonin and Amadeus Durchanek, and step grandchildren Paul, Thomas, Jonathan, Alexander; and Bradford Stogner. Bob began his career as a securities analyst and became a premier stock broker for Kidder Peabody, Walston & Co., Dean Witter Reynolds, Solomon Smith Barney, and Morgan Stanley on Long Island from 1950 until he retired in 2011. Born and raised in Douglaston, he attended Buckley Country Day School as a youngster, and graduated from Colgate University in 1950. Bob was a published author of a novel entitled "Love Forty", published in hardcover and was an accomplished artist with works of art including oil on canvas, charcoal and metal sculptures. His true passion was playing tennis, competing in the men's draw at the U.S. Open until he was 35, won national titles (the USTA 35 and 45 Clay Courts), and set Eastern USTA records for 35 years. In 1961, Bob played Arthur Ashe in the finals of the Eastern Clay Court Championships at the Oritani Field Club in Hackensack, NJ. He was in the second group of inductees into the Eastern Tennis Association Hall of Fame in 1988. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home 128 Main St., Port Washington, Monday, September 15 from 3:30 to 7:30pm. Interment on Tuesday, September 16 at Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens at 10:30am. Donations may be made to St. Jude's Children's Hospital in lieu of flowers at www.stjude.org.

BALLENTINE--Susan Miller, died Tuesday, September 2, 2014 at her home in Palm Beach. She was 76. Mrs. Ballentine, known as "Susie", was born on April 2, 1938, in Chicago to Creighton S. Miller and his wife Jane R. Miller. She was a graduate of New Trier High School (1956) and Wheaton College in Massachusetts (1960). She married James M. Ballentine Jr. in 1962 and lived in New York City; Richmond, VA; Laguna Niguel, CA; Wayzata, MN and Ho-ho-kus, NJ. She was a permanent resident of Palm Beach for 15 years. Mrs. Ballentine was a prolific painter and was active in The Garden Club of Palm Beach, The National Society of Colonial Dames and Opportunity Inc, where she taught art to underprivileged children. In addition to her husband of 51 years, she is survived by her son, James M. Ballentine III and his wife Jeannie of Darien, CT; three daughters, Molly B. Scott and her husband Alex of New Canaan, CT; Julia B. Peter and her husband Chris of New Canaan; and Laura B. Ferris and her husband Jeffrey of New York City; a brother, Craig Miller and his wife Sharon, of Pasadena, CA, and 10 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held later in the fall. Memorial contributions may be made to The Garden Club of Palm Beach, Box 2791, Palm Beach, FL 33480 or to Opportunity Inc., 1713 Quail Drive, West Palm Beach, FL 33409.

ANDERSON--Margaret "Margot" Peet, 68, of Johns Island, SC, passed on September 11, 2014. Born in New York City, she was the daughter of the late Charles D Peet and Margaret Louise Sherman and wife of John B. Anderson. A graduate of Westover School and Vassar College, she was a Vice President of JP Morgan. Margot is survived by her husband John, sons Robert, Paul and grandson Garrett and by her brother Charles D Peet Jr. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Roper St. Francis Foundation, Charleston SC. www.rsfhfoundation.org

ADAMS--Mark C. With a heavy heart we announce the passing of Mark C. Adams on September 5, 2014, in his home surrounded by loved ones. Born on March 23, 1930 and raised in Great Neck, NY, Mark had a long and successful career working for IBM. After he took early retirement, he, his wife and sister-in-law started Hotel de Filosoof in Amsterdam, The Netherlands. Mark had a zest for life and a passion for sports and travelling the world. After a long and courageous battle with Parkinson's Syndrome, he is at peace. Mark is dearly missed by his loved ones -- wife Alie; daughters Leslie, Diane and Nancy; six grandchildren; seven great-grandchildren; sister-in-law Ida; family and friends. Interment services were held in private. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hospice by the Sea, Palm Beach County, FL.

ALTIERI--Marcelle P.,88, of Watertown, MA, died on September 2nd. Memorial service October 8, 11:30am, at Christ Church Pelham, 1415 Pelhamdale Ave., Pelham, NY 10802. Please consider memorial donations to the Mertz Library, New York Botanical Garden: www.nybg.org/support--the-- garden/gifts/. MINDICH--Daniel Benjamin, 48. It is with great sadness that we share the news that Dan Mindich, extraordinary husband and father, beloved son, brother and friend, died of a presumed cardiac event on September 1 while swimming in an open water race near his home in Honolulu, Hawaii. Dan graduated from Vassar College, where he met the love of his life, the amazing Shilpa Patel. After spending a year teaching in rural Kenya, Dan graduated from Stanford's STEP program with a master's in education. He went on to teach in northern California, Vermont and finally at the Punahou School, in Honolulu where he taught English and History. He returned to Stanford to earn a doctorate in educational policy before rejoining the Punahou faculty in 2011 where, in addition to teaching, he served as the director of its Academy Summer School. Dan was a remarkable teacher, known for his humor, energy and ability to inspire excellence in his students. He had a huge heart, which had room for so many people and he was loved by so many. He loved to eat, tell stories and to laugh until he cried. Dan is survived by Shilpa and their three children, Satya, Asha and Vida; his parents, Leonard and Margot Zucker Mindich; his brothers, David and Jeremy; his sister-in law, Amy Smith; the Patel family; his extended family and friends. We need to continue to tell Daniel stories, remember his irrepressible joy, perform random acts of kindness as he did and remember his love and pass it on. A memorial service will be held later in the year. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Punahou School for the Daniel Mindich Endowed Financial Aid Fund. 1601 Punahou Street Honolulu, HI 96822.

LEEB--Joseph, 69. Born in Brooklyn, he spent the last 36 years in Northern New Jersey. Survived by best friend and wife, Mary-Ann (Ballenberg), sons Daniel and Michael (Julie) and granddaughter, Aleah. He will be greatly missed.

JAFFE--Jeff H. Jeff H. Jaffe, Chairman and President of The Chunky Corporation and President and CEO of Ward Foods Candy, Ward Foods Branded Foods Group, Schrafft Candy Company and Bernan Foods, died of natural causes at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida on July 27, 2014. He was 93 years old. In 1950, Mr. Jaffe leveraged the purchase of a small bankrupt candy company in Brooklyn known for a chocolate bar called CHUNKY. Due to his marketing skills and ability to take risks and win, he built Chunky into a major player in the candy industry. Through the years, Mr. Jaffe acquired other candy companies. In 1951, he reached an agreement with Rowntree & Company of York, England to import Kit Kat, the famous chocolate covered sugar wafer candy bar, and shortly nationwide distribution was successfully achieved. Shutter Candy Company, manufacturer of Bit-O-Honey and Old Nick, was purchased in 1958, and Klotz Confection Company in 1960. In 1965, he bought Chocolate Sponge from Heide Candy Company and produced it in the Shutter plant in Chicago. He added Oh Henry!, purchased from the Williams Candy Company, to Shutter in 1971. Jeff Jaffe, well respected by the candy industry, received two prestigious awards among many. The Association of Manufacturers of Candy and Chocolate presented their award to him at a testimonial dinner attended by over 400 industry members in 1964. He was the youngest executive, at age forty-four, to be honored in this fashion. In 1971 he received the 26th Kettle Award and was named "Candy Man of the Year" by Candy Industry Magazine, who recognized him for his "endless efforts on behalf of his industry and his community..." Two noteworthy accomplishments were the Chunky exhibit at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair and the Harvard Business School case study on Chunky. The World's Fair exhibit, an actual manufacturing plant, automatically coated with chocolate, wrapped and packaged Old Nick candy bars. It also contained the "Sculpture Continuum" that served as an art form and a functional children's playground and an area where company products were sold. The cost per thousand was many times less than that of companies like IBM and GM. It was proclaimed that the Chunky exhibit "could not help but benefit the entire candy industry." Harvard Business School's Midway Series was used by nearly 1,000 MBA participants in the Executive Education Programs each year. A landmark in case writing, the study was used by more than fifty universities at home and abroad and dozens of Fortune 50 companies. For sixteen years, Mr. Jaffe lectured on the study to hundreds of HBS students and in 1977 was ceremoniously honored "for his important service to Harvard Business School." Mr. Jaffe served on many Boards (including Young Presidents' Organization) and contributed to various communities throughout his life. In later years, he was President of Sailfish Point of Stuart, Florida and helped transfer ownership from the developer, Mobil Oil, to the residents. In 2001, he brought Sir John Templeton's "Laws of Life" essay contest to Martin County, Florida. Reaching students of all backgrounds, the contest inspired them to focus on their principles and ideals. Mr. Jaffe, himself, valued integrity above all. Jeff Jaffe was born Irwin Hugh Jaffe on December 25, 1920 in Washington, DC. Nicknamed "Jeff" at Virginia Polytechnic Institute where he received a degree in Architectural Engineering, he legally changed his name shortly after 2001. Unhappy as an architectural engineer, he left his family painting and construction business and moved to Manhattan in April, 1945. There he met his wife, Natalie, on a blind date. They were married six months later. Jeff Jaffe is survived by Natalie, his wife of 68 years, his two daughters Bonnie Berens and Holly Jaffe, four grandsons and three great-grandsons. They all said, "Make it flat. You'll never get a nickel for that funny-looking, not-quite-square, truncated something or other. Make it flat like a Hershey bar. Then you'll have something to sell." He took that chunk of chocolate and made history. As he entitled his book, "How Sweet It Is." A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, September 30, 2014 at 5:00pm at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022.

CAMPBELL--Virginia Warren. Age 92, died peacefully on June 25, 2014, in Port Washington, NY. Virginia was born in Yankton, SD, on March 7, 1922. On August 12, 1942 she was married to David Arthur Campbell of Great Neck, NY. Virginia is survived by her three children, David Arthur Campbell, Jr., Jeanne Campbell Sedgwick of Woodside, CA, and Carol Edmunds Campbell of New York City. Virginia was an active mental health advocate and was appointed to the New York State Board of Visitors. She also was also a member of Christ Church of Manhasset, NY, the Junior League of the North Shore of Long Island, and P.E.O. We will all miss her ready laugh and her beautiful green eyes and raven hair (even at age 92). Donations in Virginia's name would be welcomed by the Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd., Suite 2, Woodbury NY 11797-2946; 800-405-6731. Notes of condolence to the family can be sent to: caroledmundscampbell @gmail.com

WOLF--Ellen L.,loving wife, mother, and grandmother, passed away on September 12, 2014. Ellen's concern with others extended beyond her family, inspiring her to volunteer to tutor children and assist the disabled. She enjoyed an exceptionally close marriage to her husband, Donald Wolf, who devoted himself to her care until her death.

WATKINS--David, 1958-2014, was born in Piermont, NY. He went to NYU School of the Arts where he formed many lifelong friendships. He achieved acclaim as an interpreter of Sam Shepard's works, in particular his 1978 Club 57 production of Geography of a Horse Dreamer. David loved baseball, the Mets and the East River Rats softball team. David celebrated life; presiding for 26 years over a monthly dinner at various Indian restaurants in the East Village, where his braying laughter would bring pedestrians in from the street just to have a look, and hosting numerous celebrations of the summer solstice on his roof top. Founder of Bootleg Theater, David wrote and directed Ban Republican Marriage, Dialog of Insects, The Devil and Walter Cronkite, and Moon Saloon, A Play in 9 Innings. His final play, Not Dead Yet, has ironically not yet been produced. He is survived by his family of friends in New York, his sisters Elizabeth and Mary, his nephews Arin and Matthew, and niece Alaina.

WALLACE--Justin, passed away peacefully on September 14 in Wallingford, PA. He was 89. He is survived by his loving children; daughters Erika Kors (Alan) and Nina Wallace (Dan Gutman), grandchildren Samantha, Brian, Sam, and Emma; and five great-granddaughters. We love you Dad, rest in peace.

THOMSON--John B. Jr. Former Owner/Chairman of Thomson Industries & Pillar of the sailing community passes away at 70. The sailing community lost one of its best owner/drivers and a pillar of the sport when John B. Thomson, Jr., of Sands Point, NY, passed away in the evening of Wednesday, September 10, surrounded by family and loved ones after succumbing to the effects of ALS. Thomson Jr. was a beloved figure in his hometown and around the world. Husband to wife Adrienne, father to three children and grandfather to more, he was also the steady and kindhearted owner of the Infinity yacht racing team, which won many regattas around the world through the course of 40 years of buoy and ocean racing, spanning from the early 1970s into the 21st century. Mr. Thomson was born May 31, 1944, in Mineola, NY, the son of Louise Magoon Thomson and John B. Thomson, Sr. He attended the New York Institute of Technology where he earned an engineering degree. Upon graduation, he joined Thomson Industries, the company founded by his father, who, in the early 1940's, invented the linear motion ball bushing bearing. Thomson Jr. rose to become chief executive officer and chairman of the company, and contributed many patents to the company's line of proprietary technology. Aviation was always a cornerstone of the Thomson family, starting with Thomson Sr.'s invention of the linear bushing bearing, which gave birth to the first variable pitch propeller. This tradition continued with Thomson Jr. becoming a skilled pilot, who flew his helicopters. His ability as a pilot is a key legacy of his business and personal life. Thomson Jr. also had great effect in the sailing community. He began sailing at the age of eight and later in life would go on to own a series of yachts named Infinity. His welcoming nature and hearty laugh were readily recognized at the many regattas he won, including the Kenwood Cup, SORC, Block Island Race Week, Key West Race Week, Antigua Race Week, and the Around Long Island Race. Thomson was a member of the New York Yacht Club, Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, Royal Cork Yacht Club, and the Storm Trysail Club, for which he served as commodore. He was past director of the U.S. Naval Academy-Fales Committee, and one of the benefactors that helped the New York Yacht Club purchase its satellite clubhouse in Newport, RI. He also was very active in owners' associations for classes such as the International 50-Foot Association and the Farr 40 Class Association, and also enjoyed a skeet membership at the Sands Point Golf Club. Thomson founded one of Long Island Sound's greatest regattas, the Manhasset Bay Fall Series. Founded in 1979, the regatta is a premier event on the East Coast and used by crews as a final tune-up before heading to the winter racing season in Florida. The overall trophy is named in honor of his father, John B. Thomson, Sr. With his wife and family at his side, Thomson always steered his yachts and believed in an amateur crew, which often included lifelong friends. In his honor, the New York Yacht Club and Storm Trysail Club together formed the John B. Thomson Award for Campaign Excellence. Thomson Jr. was a staunch supporter of his community. He was a Trustee at the North-Shore-LIJ Health System in Manhasset, NY, and served for many years as a Trustee at the South Street Seaport Museum, in New York City. Through his family's charitable foundation, Thomson Jr. supported many local fundraising efforts, always choosing to keep his charitable giving "close to home." Thomson is survived by his wife Adrienne Thomson, of Sands Point, NY, children John B. Thomson, III, of Sands Point, NY, Victoria Thomson, of Sands Point, NY, Scott Thomson, of New York, NY, and three grandchildren. A tribute and celebration of John's life will be held on Friday, September 26th, at Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in Port Washington, New York, from 3-8 p.m. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations in John's honor be sent to The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter, 42 Broadway, Suite 1724, New York, NY 10004, or online: www.als.org.

STEINLAUF--Joy (nee Wallis) on September 14, 2014 at N. Bergen, NJ. Loving wife, mother, grandmother. Super teacher, handicrafter and world traveler. Service at Menorah Chapel of Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union (Vauxhall) NJ at 10am, Wednesday, September 17.

SCHUAL--Dr. Roger Samuel, of Westport, CT passed on September 14, 2014. Beloved husband of Laurie Morris Schual and loving father of Mia Schual, Jessica and Ron Berenblat, Gordon and Claudia Novod. Cherished grandfather of Asher, Cooper, Samantha, and Alexandra. Brother of Daniel Schual-Berke. Son of Lillian Schual and the late Dr. Aron Schual. Son-in-law of Dr. Iris Morris and the late Dr. Robert Morris. Charitable donations may be made in Dr. Schual's memory to The Esophageal Cancer Education Foundation (www.fightec.org). Burial and shiva information is available upon request to gnovod@hotmail.com.

ROBBINS--Michael David. Congregation Emanu-EI of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Michael David Robbins. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John Streicker, President

ROBBINS--Michael David, died at home on September 13th. He graduated from Princeton University in 1955, was a member and Director of the NYSE, and served as President of the Alliance of Floor Brokers. Post "retirement" Mike was employed as a reporter and historian at Bloomberg News. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Lois Otten Robbins; daughters Juli Greenwald (Daniel), Jil Pollock (John) and Polly White (Bracken); grandchildren Alix and Oliver Greenwald, Stewart and Clayre Pollock, and Andrew and Colin White; and brother Benedict. Mike had a passionate love of opera and history, and served on numerous boards including The Princeton Alumni Corps, The Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library and Friends of the Princeton University Library. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 21 at 11:00am at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Princeton University.

RAINIS--Jane Micucci, passed away on September 12, 2014 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She was 73. Born in Jersey City, she lived in Staten Island, NY and Randolph, NJ before moving to Mendham, NJ, 40 years ago. She also maintained residences in York Harbor, ME and Palm City, FL. Jane was an accomplished author. She was awarded a B.A., Magna Cum Laude, from the College of St. Elizabeth. She received her doctorate from Drew University in 2012. She served on the Boards of Drew University and the College of St. Elizabeth. She also served on the Board of the Library Foundation of Martin County, FL. She was an active equestrienne and a competitive dressage rider. Jane was an authority on the American author Willa Cather. She presented scholarly papers on Ms. Cather's works in the United States and in Europe. She is survived by her husband Eugene Rainis; two sons, Mark Rainis (Amy) of Palm City, FL and David Rainis (Melissa) of Mendham, NJ; one daughter Ellen Rainis Peters (Rev. Michael) of the Villages, FL; one brother, Nicholas Micucci of Deal, NJ and one sister Mary Beth Micucci Savage of Maywood, NJ. She is also survived by her four cherished grandchildren, Alexandra, Victoria, Molly and Nathaniel Rainis. Visitation will be held on Wednesday and Thursday, September 17 and 18 from 2-4pm and 6-8pm at the Bailey Funeral Home, 8 Hilltop Rd., Mendham. Funeral Liturgy, Friday, 11am at St. Joseph Church, Mendham. Interment private. For those desiring, donations may be made to the Gregorian University Foundation, New York, NY or the College of St. Elizabeth, Convent Station, NJ in her memory. www.baileyfuneral.com

NAUMBURG--George W.,Jr, M.D. died peacefully on September 14, 2014 at age 96. Dr. Naumburg was a psychiatrist and later in life a vintner. In addition to private practice, he worked and taught Adolescent Psychiatry at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York. A pioneer, he founded a psychiatric hospital for adolescents in Manhattan that operated in the 1960's; and he also created North Salem Vineyard, the first winery in northern Westchester County that ran for over 40 years, closing on his retirement at age 88. For 50 winters, he and his wife built a community in their beloved Barbados. Survived by his wife of 53 years, Michelle R. Naumburg. He is the father of four children: Peter Naumburg, Eric Naumburg, M.D., Janet Naumburg (deceased), Elizabeth Naumburg, M.D. He has eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. We remember him for his wit, his sage counsel and his exploratory spirit. Instead of flowers, please send donations to the Children's Defense Fund or Planned Parenthood of New York.

MULLER--Patricia Sheridan. Born March 17, 1932 to the late Agnes Reid Sheridan and Thomas J. Sheridan. She was a life long New York City Resident and New York Yankees Fan. She devoted her life to the field of education in the New York City Schools System, first as a teacher in grades K-6, then as an assistant principal for many years at PS 34. She was predeceased by her husband of 54 years, the Hon. Charles Muller, and her son Roger S. Muller, Esq. She is survived by her son, Reid Muller, MD, his wife Shelley Gilroy MD, their children, Aislinn and Reid, daughter-in-law Margaret Nussey and numerous nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to VNSNY Hospice and Palliative Care at VNSNY.org

MINDICH--Daniel Benjamin, 48. It is with great sadness that we share the news that Dan Mindich, extraordinary husband and father, beloved son, brother and friend, died of a presumed cardiac event on September 1 while swimming in an open water race near his home in Honolulu, Hawaii. Dan graduated from Vassar College, where he met the love of his life, the amazing Shilpa Patel. After spending a year teaching in rural Kenya, Dan graduated from Stanford's STEP program with a master's in education. He went on to teach in northern California, Vermont and finally at the Punahou School, in Honolulu where he taught English and History. He returned to Stanford to earn a doctorate in educational policy before rejoining the Punahou faculty in 2011 where, in addition to teaching, he served as the director of its Academy Summer School. Dan was a remarkable teacher, known for his humor, energy and ability to inspire excellence in his students. He had a huge heart, which had room for so many people and he was loved by so many. He loved to eat, tell stories and to laugh until he cried. Dan is survived by Shilpa and their three children, Satya, Asha and Vida; his parents, Leonard and Margot Zucker Mindich; his brothers, David and Jeremy; his sister-in law, Amy Smith; the Patel family; his extended family and friends. We need to continue to tell Daniel stories, remember his irrepressible joy, perform random acts of kindness as he did and remember his love and pass it on. A memorial service will be held later in the year. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Punahou School for the Daniel Mindich Endowed Financial Aid Fund. 1601 Punahou Street Honolulu, HI 96822.

MARINACCI--Nicola, Rev. Msgr.,on September 13, 2014, at age 103. Born in Abruzzi, Italy on December 4, 1910 and ordained a priest on April 3, 1938. Graduated from the University of Rome in 1941 and obtained a degree in Natural Sciences. He taught in Rome at Collegio Nazereno. In 1949, Cardinal Spellman accepted him into the Archdiocese of New York. He was appointed associate pastor at Church of the Holy Family, where he served until 1965 and subsequently named pastor of Our Lady of Peace Church. While serving at Our Lady of Peace he was elevated to the rank of Monsignor. In October 1970, His Eminence, Cardinal Cook requested that he serve at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral. Monsignor retired in 1985. He is survived by his community of faith. Visitation Wednesday, September 17th from 1 to 9pm at The Basilica of St. Patrick's Old Cathedral. A parish Mass will be celebrated at 7pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be concelebrated by His Eminence, Cardinal Dolan on Thursday, September 18, 2014, 10am. Monsignor will be interred in the cathedral's catacomb. Friends may visit "Monsignor Nicola Marinacci" on facebook to share memories and photos. For condolences: green wichvillagefuneralhome.com.

LERNER--Frances Ann nee Levine, on September 13, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Stephen D. Lerner. Born November 21, 1937 in Wilmington to Hilda and Joseph Levine. Loving sister of Dorothy (Melvin) Gerstein and the late Arnold (Anne) Levine. Devoted mother of Jeffrey, Hilary (Peter) and Terri. Cherished grandmother of Jasmine, Spencer and Audrey. Loving aunt. Funeral 1pm Today at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains. Contributions will be appreciated by Congregation Kol Ami/Religious School Fund or Pediatric Cancer Foundation.

LEEB--Joseph, 69. Born in Brooklyn, he spent the last 36 years in Northern New Jersey. Survived by best friend and wife, Mary-Ann (Ballenberg), sons Daniel and Michael (Julie) and granddaughter, Aleah. He will be greatly missed.

KING--Thomas M.,on September 13, 2014 at age 59. Beloved husband of Victoria (nee Sheridan). Loving father of Thomas and Tracey. Adored son of Thomas and Shelia King. Dear brother of Clarc, Doreen (Gerard), Kathleen (Peter), Aileen (Guido) and Kevin (Alexandra). Devoted nephew, uncle, cousin and friend. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, NYC, Monday and Tuesday, 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday 11am at Epiphany Church, 22nd Street and 2nd Avenue, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The American Cancer Society or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.
KALLEN--Claire. We remember with love our dear friend Claire Kallen. The Bloom Family

HOYOS--Ana Mercedes, Colombian artist, and long time resident of New York City, passed away September 4 in Bogota, Colombia. Hoyos, painter and sculptor, was one of the most important exponents of the art of Colombia for the last five decades. She depicted a Colombian version of realism containing both pop art but also the irony of modern day Colombia. She is survived by her husband architect Jacques Mosseri, her daughter artist Ana Mosseri and two grandchildren.
HINSON--Harry. Former employees of the New York showroom of Hinson & Company mourn the loss of Harry Hinson, visionary founder of Hinson & Company and legend in the design world.

GOLDBERG--Eugene, Congregation Emanu-EI of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Eugene Goldberg. With his family, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President
FLEISIG--Jerry. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Jerry. Our hearts go out to Mona, Jodi, Pamela and Jonathan and the rest of his family. We loved him, we will miss him. Wilma and Lou Perlman

FLEISIG--Gerald. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Gerald Fleisig. Gerald leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Gerald's beloved wife, Mona; his children, Jodi Fleisig Gabay (Moti), Pamela Azus (Bruce), and Jonathan; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

DAUBER--Harriet, on September 13, 2014, at 90, of Southbury, CT. Beloved wife of Edwin; loving mother, and devoted grandmother. Donations in her memory may be made to Michael J. Fox Research Foundation or Hadassah.

CREWE--Bob. Bob, you were always one of those "there's no one quite like you" kind of guys. There were plenty of talented people in the music business of the 60's and the 70's and in the visual arts and just about everything you touched and did was artistic. You not only had a golden ear; you had a golden eye. I remember my first tour of the Crewe Triplex Penthouse on Fifth Avenue which jutted out as if it were part of Central Park. You were so proud of the fact that you had outbid Walt Disney for exotic wood panelings inside which came from the Indonesian Pavilion of the World's Fair of the 60's. I had never seen a real fur spread thrown over a Hollywood King-sized bed. I had never been to an apartment with its own full gymnasium. I had never known anyone in real life to look like a movie star or live like one. You were outre, outrageous and sui generis. Your work ethic was not by the book. You worked by gut. I don't think you had any musical training of significance but you knew what you liked and were relentless with fortitude and resilience. You kept pushing forward and set an example for a new definition of talent. It takes more than "talent". You demonstrated how to kick doors open, to stick your foot in a door that's being slammed and change your persona to make yourself so seductive that no one could say "no" to Bob Crewe. I recall your convincing me to meet your astrologer, Augusta Willy, who lived on Bank Street in the Village for astrological clearance and a transaction involving a singer who went by the name of Eddie Jason and whose real name was Edward Germano, later a mogul of recording studios, the most elegant recording studios, the "money is no object" studios and things he learned from you. Apparently, my moon was in the right position to proceed and I was given "clearance" by Mrs. Willy. I told you that I found the experience disconcerting. You laughed. When I told you I needed the agreed advance paid to my client (Eddie) in single dollar bills because he wanted to surprise his wife and roll on the bed with tens and tens of thousands of dollars of money which was his advance against royalties, you found it delightfully refreshing, romantic and laughed again. The only thing close to a goodbye we had was when brother Dan confirmed your fall a few years ago. I wrote you a long letter of Proustian memories of times gone by and recollections of the good ole days. I then spoke with Dan and he told me that for a few hours, you were able to relive and remember all of that world of Camelot when you were king. Bob, trust me when I say "oh pretty baby" because you were the best looking of them all and you were "just too good to be true" and I thank God you were alive and you always will be alive in my memories and in the songs you wrote. You'll be right at home with all of the angels, Bob, because stars belong in Heaven. You'll still shine and sparkle very brightly with your flawless nose/jaw/chiseled angelic face. Freddie & Myrna Gershon (with smiles and tears)

BRENT--Lt. Colonel Walter I. Christopher, Retired, age 89, formerly of Manhattan passed away at his home in Sewickley, PA. Survived by his wife Nancy Carr Brent; predeceased by his wives; Ursula Gosselck and Liane Beebe. Interment in Arlington National Cemetery with full honors will take place at a later date.

SICHEL--Alexandra. The Memorial Service on September 20 will start at 2pm at the Lafayette Ave. Presbyterian Church , 85 So. Oxford St., Bklyn.
WHELAN--Elizabeth M. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Elizabeth M. Whelan, and send condolences to her family.

WEIN--MaryLouise Barker. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are saddened by the loss of MaryLouise Barker Wein, M.D., of Bethesda, Md. Together with her late husband Dr. Arthur Wein, she was a Technion Guardian, a designation for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. The Weins supported numerous Technion projects, including the Dr. Arthur & Mary Lou Wein Dormitory in the Eastern Village and the Samuel and Miriam Wein Academic Lectureship in Medicine. To her son Daryl Barker Wein, daughter Cynthia Ellen Wein Lett, and the entire Wein family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President

WARD--James (Jim) W. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with its officers and employees, wish to express our deep sense of loss at the passing of our colleague and friend, Jim Ward, who served as Senior Field Vice President of Mutual of America's Marketing Division. Mr. Ward joined Mutual of America in 1997. Throughout his years with the Company, he inspired those who worked with him with his energy, humor, unflagging optimism and dedication to service. We will deeply miss his exuberant presence in our lives. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Cindy, their children and families, and their many friends and loved ones. Thomas J. Moran Chairman, President and CEO William J. Flynn Chairman Emeritus

TENBEKJIAN--Jack, 74, Wall Street Sales Trader for over 45 years, passed away peacefully, Monday, September 15th. He is survived by his wife Nevere, two daughters Nicole Jundanian, Tiffany Minnetian, and a son Richard Tenbekjian, and nine grandchildren. He will be remembered in the business world as a man of uncompromising integrity, respected by his co-workers, clients and competitors alike. He was a loyal and trusted friend to us and our family, whose powerful presence and hearty laugh will be missed. May you be at peace dear Jack. In our prayers always, Mary Jane and Peter DaPuzzo.
STERN--Melvin, 89 years old, died on September 15th, 2014. Beloved father, grandfather, great-grandfather and brother. He will always be remembered.

ROEHDER--Robert Alexander, died in England on August 22, 2014. Born in Troy, NY, December 19, 1936, Mr. Roehder was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Cornell University. Following graduation, he moved to Germany where he founded ROADCOAT GmbH, a world-wide industrial coatings organization with headquarters in Germany. Mr. Roehder also resided in Absorkee, MT where he enjoyed outdoor activities on his ranch. He was an adventurer at heart and possessed a unique sense of humor that will be missed. He is survived by his sisters Valerie R. Florstedt and Wendy E. Roehder and their families. Donations may be made in his memory to an orphanage close to his heart "The Littlest Lamb," PO Box 592, Rye, NY 10580.
