SOBEL--Rhea 82. September 16th, 2014. Beloved wife of Harold for sixty years.; treasured mother and best friend of Suzanne and Stacey; loving sister of Ira; loving sister-in-law of Elaine and Morris; cherished aunt to her nieces and nephews; grandmother to her number one grand-dog Joey. Rhea lived life to the fullest, and was a true friend to those she liked. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Thursday September 18th, at 11:15 a.m.

ROBBINS--Michael David, died at home on September 13th. He graduated from Princeton University in 1955, was a member and Director of the NYSE, and served as President of the Alliance of Floor Brokers. Post "retirement" Mike was employed as a reporter and historian at Bloomberg News. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Lois Otten Robbins; daughters Juli Greenwald (Daniel), Jil Pollock (John) and Polly White (Bracken); grandchildren Alix and Oliver Greenwald, Stewart and Clayre Pollock, and Andrew and Colin White; and brother Benedict. Mike had a passionate love of opera and history, and served on numerous boards including The Princeton Alumni Corps, The Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library and Friends of the Princeton University Library. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 21 at 11:00am at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Princeton University.

MULLER--Patricia Sheridan. Born March 17, 1932 to the late Agnes Reid Sheridan and Thomas J. Sheridan. She was a life long New York City Resident and New York Yankees Fan. She devoted her life to the field of education in the New York City Schools System, first as a teacher in grades K-6, then as an assistant principal for many years at PS 34. She was predeceased by her husband of 54 years, the Hon. Charles Muller, and her son Roger S. Muller, Esq. She is survived by her son, Reid Muller, MD, his wife Shelley Gilroy MD, their children, Aislinn and Reid, daughter-in-law Margaret Nussey and numerous nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to VNSNY Hospice and Palliative Care at VNSNY.org

LERNER--Frances Ann nee Levine, on September 13, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Stephen D. Lerner. Born November 21, 1937 in Wilmington to Hilda and Joseph Levine. Loving sister of Dorothy (Melvin) Gerstein and the late Arnold (Anne) Levine. Devoted mother of Jeffrey, Hilary (Peter) and Terri. Cherished grandmother of Jasmine, Spencer and Audrey. Loving aunt. Funeral 1pm Today at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains. Contributions will be appreciated by Congregation Kol Ami/Religious School Fund or Pediatric Cancer Foundation.

LEMPERT--Ruth, 93. Artist, singer, actor and designer extraordinaire. Loving mother to Brad, Melody, Suzanne (deceased) and Christina. Grandma to Coby, Samantha, Alexandra, Jacqueline and Madeline. We will miss you Mama Roux.

LEHMAN--Joan. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Joan Lehman. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Joseph and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary
LEHMAN--Joan. Rest in peace my beloved friend. We shared beautiful memories. Audrey Goodman

LEHMAN--Joan Sontag, passed away peacefully on September 16th in Palm Beach after battling the effects of a massive stroke. She was born (June 23, 1929) and raised in Brooklyn. Joan attended Syracuse University before settling in Manhattan and focusing on philanthropic work, including serving for years as Co-Chairman of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation Promise Ball. She enjoyed her many friends, travel, concerts, card games, and golf, but mostly her family ... beloved husband Joe of 56 years, late son Michael, son Jeff and daughter-in-law Tami, granddaughters Arielle and Jocelyn, late brother Rollin, niece Cathy, and many other nieces, nephews, and in-laws. Joan lived a wonderful life and will be dearly missed. There will be a private graveside funeral.

KREIZEL--Gloria. The Board of Governors and the members of The Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our long time member Gloria Kreizel. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her family. Paul Kotcher, President

KREIZEL--Gloria, 89, on September 15, 2014. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of James, Susan and the late Steven. Mother-in-law of Dion Kreizel and William Weintraub. Loving grandmother to Jennifer, Brian, Keith, Ashley and Nicole. Cherished sister of Inez Simens. Funeral service will be held l0am, Thursday, September 18, 2014 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway Hewlett, NY 11557.

HOYOS--Ana Mercedes, Colombian artist, and long time resident of New York City, passed away September 4 in Bogota, Colombia. Hoyos, painter and sculptor, was one of the most important exponents of the art of Colombia for the last five decades. She depicted a Colombian version of realism containing both pop art but also the irony of modern day Colombia. She is survived by her husband architect Jacques Mosseri, her daughter artist Ana Mosseri and two grandchildren.
FLEISIG--Jerry. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Jerry. Our hearts go out to Mona, Jodi, Pamela and Jonathan and the rest of his family. We loved him, we will miss him. Wilma and Lou Perlman

DENMARK--Jerry. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed honorary life member, Jerry Denmark and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Fritzi and her family. Barry N. Winograd, President Donald Capelin, Secretary

CREWE--Bob. Bob, you were always one of those "there's no one quite like you" kind of guys. There were plenty of talented people in the music business of the 60's and the 70's and in the visual arts and just about everything you touched and did was artistic. You not only had a golden ear; you had a golden eye. I remember my first tour of the Crewe Triplex Penthouse on Fifth Avenue which jutted out as if it were part of Central Park. You were so proud of the fact that you had outbid Walt Disney for exotic wood panelings inside which came from the Indonesian Pavilion of the World's Fair of the 60's. I had never seen a real fur spread thrown over a Hollywood King-sized bed. I had never been to an apartment with its own full gymnasium. I had never known anyone in real life to look like a movie star or live like one. You were outre, outrageous and sui generis. Your work ethic was not by the book. You worked by gut. I don't think you had any musical training of significance but you knew what you liked and were relentless with fortitude and resilience. You kept pushing forward and set an example for a new definition of talent. It takes more than "talent". You demonstrated how to kick doors open, to stick your foot in a door that's being slammed and change your persona to make yourself so seductive that no one could say "no" to Bob Crewe. I recall your convincing me to meet your astrologer, Augusta Willy, who lived on Bank Street in the Village for astrological clearance and a transaction involving a singer who went by the name of Eddie Jason and whose real name was Edward Germano, later a mogul of recording studios, the most elegant recording studios, the "money is no object" studios and things he learned from you. Apparently, my moon was in the right position to proceed and I was given "clearance" by Mrs. Willy. I told you that I found the experience disconcerting. You laughed. When I told you I needed the agreed advance paid to my client (Eddie) in single dollar bills because he wanted to surprise his wife and roll on the bed with tens and tens of thousands of dollars of money which was his advance against royalties, you found it delightfully refreshing, romantic and laughed again. The only thing close to a goodbye we had was when brother Dan confirmed your fall a few years ago. I wrote you a long letter of Proustian memories of times gone by and recollections of the good ole days. I then spoke with Dan and he told me that for a few hours, you were able to relive and remember all of that world of Camelot when you were king. Bob, trust me when I say "oh pretty baby" because you were the best looking of them all and you were "just too good to be true" and I thank God you were alive and you always will be alive in my memories and in the songs you wrote. You'll be right at home with all of the angels, Bob, because stars belong in Heaven. You'll still shine and sparkle very brightly with your flawless nose/jaw/chiseled angelic face. Freddie & Myrna Gershon (with smiles and tears)
CLARK--Lenny. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Lenny Clark. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

BRENT--Lt. Colonel Walter I. Christopher, Retired, age 89, formerly of Manhattan passed away at his home in Sewickley, PA. Survived by his wife Nancy Carr Brent; predeceased by his wives; Ursula Gosselck and Liane Beebe. Interment in Arlington National Cemetery with full honors will take place at a later date.

BREEMAN--Walter Peter. Walter Peter Breeman was born on February 23, 1995, and died on September 7, 2014. During his short life, Walter was deeply loved and cherished for his natural warmth and openness, and an easy going charm that offered humor, acceptance, wisdom and joy to everyone he met. His handsome presence, his sense of style and his beautiful smile lit up every room he entered. He leaves behind a heartbroken family that includes his mother and father, Pam and Barry Breeman, his sister, Marion, his cousin, Andrew Perrelle, his aunts and uncles, Randi Perrelle, Judy Jacobson, Joseph Chin, Steven Fabrizio, Mike and Veronica Nolla, his loving caregiver since childhood, Irene McKeown, and his lifelong friend, Matthew Rametta. In the spirit of Walter's exuberance and love of the performance arts, his family is creating an endowment fund that will be used for theater production at the school that Walter attended, loved and was loved at, North Country School. Please consider making a donation in his name and memory, The Walter P. Breeman Endowment Fund at North Country School, 4382 Cascade Road, Lake Placid, New York 12946 northcountryschool. org. Services for Walter were privately held at Lazear-Smith & Vander Plaat Memorial Home, Warwick, NY. To send an online condolence, see www.lsvpmemorialhome.com

ZLOTNICK--Dov. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the loss of Professor Emeritus Dov Zlotnick (z"l), who taught Rabbinic Literature at JTS for approximately half a century. He will be remembered for his writings on the Mishnah, close ties to Saul Lieberman, and lifelong dedication as a teacher. May his wife, Alice, and his extended family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

WHELAN--Elizabeth M. The American Council on Science and Health's Board of Trustees, Board of Scientific Advisors, and staff mourn the loss of our beloved founder and president Dr. Elizabeth Whelan who departed this life September 11, 2014. We extend condolences to her family. Her legacy will live on through ACSH.

TENBEKJIAN--Jack, 74, Wall Street Sales Trader for over 45 years, passed away peacefully, Monday, September 15th. He is survived by his wife Nevere, two daughters Nicole Jundanian, Tiffany Minnetian, and a son Richard Tenbekjian, and nine grandchildren. He will be remembered in the business world as a man of uncompromising integrity, respected by his co-workers, clients and competitors alike. He was a loyal and trusted friend to us and our family, whose powerful presence and hearty laugh will be missed. May you be at peace dear Jack. In our prayers always, Mary Jane and Peter DaPuzzo.

STEIN--Philip, on Wednesday September 17, 2014, Philip Stein, affectionately known to all as Phil, got his lifelong wish to die peacefully and comfortably in his Malverne, New York home of over 60 years. Phil is survived by his devoted son David, David's longtime girlfriend Barbara Pastore, his sister Roslyn Storch and by enumerable other loving nieces, nephews and cousins who all called him "Uncle." Phil was predeceased by his beloved wife Margaret (Margie) and his youngest son Jeffrey. Phil was a titan and legend of the women's garment apparel industry, having founded such highly successful companies such as Allyson Frocks, Nassau Miss and Afterdark. Coupled with his entrepreneurial successes was Phil's deep commitment to charitable and philanthropic causes, many of which were responsible for fostering the growth of Jewish culture on Long Island from Nassau County all the way out to the Hamptons. Such endeavors included being a founder of the Malverne Jewish Center, a cofounder of the Hamptons Synagogue and for many years one of the Journal Chairpersons for the incredibly successful Hampton's Synagogue's annual fund raising events. Phil was also a staunch supporter of the State of Israel cofounding the Alan King Diagnostic Center in Jerusalem. Phil will be most remembered for his smile, the twinkle in his eye, his wit, his charm and infectious sense of humor. Funeral services for Phil will be held on Friday September 19, 2014 at 1:00pm at the Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. Shivah will be observed at the home of David Stein, 70 Morris Avenue, Malverne, New York, from sundown Saturday September 20, 2014 until the morning of Wednesday September 23, 2104.

SOBEL--RHEA, 82, on September 16th, 2014. Beloved wife of Harold for sixty years.; treasured mother and best friend of Suzanne and Stacey; loving sister of Ira; loving sister-in-law of Elaine and Morris; cherished aunt to her nieces and nephews; grandmother to her number one grand-dog Joey. Rhea lived life to the fullest, and was a true friend to those she liked. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Thursday, September 18th, at 11:15am. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Rhea's name to a charity of your choice.

SOBEL--Rhea. We are stunned and saddened by the sudden loss of Rhea. Loved and cherished for her natural warmth and charm. We will miss you so. Sincere condolences to the entire Sobel family. Jane and Larry David

SHARKEY--Dr. Irwin. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Dr. Irwin Sharkey and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

SHARKEY--Irwin, MD. Graduate of Durfee High School in Fall River, MA, Columbia College and NYU School of Medicine. He was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, AOA and he was a proud Eagle Scout. His professional career was spent at NYU Medical Center and he was Chief of Medicine at Beekman Downtown Hospital. Happily married to Betty for 55 years. Loving father to Wendy Aronow, Jonathan Sharkey, Jennifer Sharkey Ull, the late Marcy Sharkey Farkas and seven perfect grandchildren. Funeral services at Frank E Campbell 1076 Madison Ave (81st St) on Friday September 19 at 11:30am.
SAWYER--Stan. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Stan Sawyer. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.
ROTHSCHILD--Walter, Esq.,86, of Old Field, Long Island, on September 9, 2014. Memorial Visitation Saturday, 4-6pm, Clark Funeral Home, Inc., Yorktown Hts; clarkfh.com

MELNICK--Channe (Anna). Died at age 99 in Massachusetts September 16. Married to Penn for 68 years. Survived by three sons and their wives, one of the first Head Start teachers -- lover of Yiddish. Member of AFT and 3 Arrows. Donations to Workmen's Circle Division ORT. Funeral September 19 Cargain Funeral Home Mahopac.

LOW--Richard H. Richard H. Low, 87, died at his home on September 15 after a long and debilitating illness. He lived in Manhattan and for many years had summer homes in Fair Harbor and Saltaire, Fire Island. He is survived by his companion of 45 years, Barbara Bonn; his best beloved daughter, Jennifer Low, PhD; her husband, Mark Scroggins, PhD; their daughters, Philippa and Daphne, and his former wife, Stephanie Taubman Low. A graduate of the University of Michigan, University of California at Berkeley and Columbia University Law School, he was a pioneer in the television industry, helping to shape the Golden Age of Television at CBS News and as Executive Vice President and Director of Broadcast Programming and Planning at the Young & Rubicam advertising agency. After retirement, he was licensed to teach history to at-risk students in the New York City high schools, and continued a lifetime of learning, taking graduate seminars in art, literature and philosophy at Columbia. He served in the U.S. Army in World War II. He was the son of Regina and Irving Low, immigrants who raised their family "over the store" in West New York, N.J. Proud of this heritage, he served as a founding trustee of the American Museum of Immigration at the Statue of Liberty, which celebrated the contributions of newcomers from all nations. He was also a Life Trustee of The Town Hall, a board member of the Air and Space Bicentennial and a member of the Advisory Committee for the League of Women Voters' Presidential Debates. He was an active participant in the battles for civil rights and gender equality. He will be remembered for his absolute integrity, formidable intelligence, generosity, profound love of art and music, and his passion for justice. A memorial gathering will be held Sunday, September 21, 11:15am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, followed by burial at Westchester Hills Cemetery. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to the VNSNY Hospice and Palliative Care Program or any organization that promotes education for immigrants to the U.S. The family wishes to thank his team of dedicated caregivers, who improved his quality of life immeasurably over the past seven years: Evelyn Chevalier, Yvonne Dacosta, Jennifer Hylton, Blossom Mitchell, Rose Paul and Sybil Scott.

LEHMAN--Joan. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, Joan Lehman. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her entire family. Benjamin Kirschenbaum, President

LEHMAN--Joan Sontag, passed away peacefully on September 16th in Palm Beach after battling the effects of a massive stroke. She was born (June 23, 1929) and raised in Brooklyn. Joan attended Syracuse University before settling in Manhattan and focusing on philanthropic work, including serving for years as Co-Chairman of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation Promise Ball. She enjoyed her many friends, travel, concerts, card games, and golf, but mostly her family ... beloved husband Joe of 56 years, late son Michael, son Jeff and daughter-in-law Tami, granddaughters Arielle and Jocelyn, late brother Rollin, niece Cathy, and many other nieces, nephews, and in-laws. Joan lived a wonderful life and will be dearly missed. There will be a private graveside funeral.

KREIZEL--Gloria, 89, on September 15, 2014. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of James, Susan and the late Steven. Mother-in-law of Dion Kreizel and William Weintraub. Loving grandmother to Jennifer, Brian, Keith, Ashley and Nicole. Cherished sister of Inez Simens. Funeral service will be held l0am, Thursday, September 18, 2014 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway Hewlett, NY 11557.

HOYOS--Ana Mercedes, Colombian artist, and long time resident of New York City, passed away September 4 in Bogota, Colombia. Hoyos, painter and sculptor, was one of the most important exponents of the art of Colombia for the last five decades. She depicted a Colombian version of realism containing both pop art but also the irony of modern day Colombia. She is survived by her husband architect Jacques Mosseri, her daughter artist Ana Mosseri and two grandchildren.

GORDON--Robert S.,passed away peacefully at home in Manhattan on September 17, 2014. He was born on October 28, 1925, in Michigan City, Indiana, and raised in Helena, Arkansas. He was an accomplished musician and played on a Mississippi riverboat. He attended the University of Michigan, where he was a drum major. He attended graduate school at New York University and Columbia University. After working as an editor for Forbes, he became a highly successful stock broker and financial wizard. He is survived by his adoring wife of 57 years, Ida, his daughter, Roberta, and step-son, Michael, his son-in-law, Rick, his daughter-in-law, Anne, and his grandchildren, Adrian, Eli, and Zoe. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic at www.pphp.org.

GOLDSTEIN--Connie. It is with deep regret and sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members & staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club mourn the loss of our member, Connie. Mr. and Mrs. Goldstein have been members of Fresh Meadow for 53 years. We extend our sincerest condolences to her husband, Allen J. Goldstein, her daughters Nancy Wasserman, Susan Kushner and the entire family. Michael Lamoretti, President David Finkelstein, Secretary
FLEISIG--Jerry. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Jerry. Our hearts go out to Mona, Jodi, Pamela and Jonathan and the rest of his family. We loved him, we will miss him. Wilma and Lou Perlman

CHENDER--Selda, died Sunday in New York City. She was born in Sokal, Poland in 1923, and was predeceased by her husband Yuli. Selda was a loving mother to Michael and Robert, grandmother to Claudia, Lauren, Julian, Evan, and Isabel, and great-grandmother to four (soon to be five). The family will hold a private ceremony and requests that donations be made in memory of Selda to the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, hias.org/donate, which cared for Selda when she was a refugee in this country.

BRYANT--Flora, 76, at home surrounded by family, on September 16. Lifelong New York City resident, devoted wife, mother, grandmother, teacher and singer. Survived by husband Ted, brother John, daughter Amy, son-in-law Gary, and her two beloved grandchildren, Sam and Lily. Services Thursday, September 18 12:45pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Gilda's Club, www.gildasclubnyc.org.

ARNSTEIN--Daniel Noah, was born on August 9, 1987 and died on September 9, 2014. Beloved son of Marjorie Saltzberg and Ellis Arnstein; brother to Ariel and Davi Carsen; cherished cousin, uncle, grandson, and nephew. His friends and colleagues at Riverdale Country School (graduated 2005), Haverford College (graduated 2009) and Max Planck Institute in Tuebingen, Germany (neuroscience PhD candidate) wil always remember his warmth, intelligence, humor and perspectives on life. The funeral and week of mourning took place in Tuebingen. A day of Shiva will be held on Sunday, September 21, Noon - 6pm at our home in the Bronx, NY.

WOLF--Elaine. The entire Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Rebbetzin Elaine Wolf, z'l, the beloved wife of the late revered Rabbi Dr. Ephraim R. Wolf, who with her beloved husband served the Great Neck Synagogue from 1956-1988. They were among the founders of the North Shore Hebrew Academy among many other projects in which they provided leadership such as the establishment of the Ritualarium (Mikveh) in Great Neck. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her children, YU Guardians, Rabbi Shimon (and Hennie Lesin) Wolf; and Dr. Dahvid (and Leah Becker) Wolf, and her eleven grandchildren and thirty-nine great grandchildren. May their entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Prof. Richard M. Joel, President Rabbi Dr. Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

THOMSON--John B. Jr.,The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of Honorary Trustee John B. Thomson, Jr., a dedicated supporter of North Shore-LIJ and North Shore University Hospital (NSUH). John's generosity enabled NSUH to upgrade and renovate its Emergency Department to provide the highest level of quality care to patients. His dedication to the health system helped North Shore-LIJ become a regional and national leader in healthcare. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Adrienne; children John B. Thomson, III, Scott Thomson and Victoria Thomson; and grandchildren. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System

SOBEL--Rhea. Our heartfelt condolences to the Sobel family on the passing of Rhea Sobel, beloved mother, wife and friend. May she rest in peace. The Cuomo and Cole Families

SOBEL--Rhea. Our deep sadness and sympathy to the family of Rhea Sobel. She was a beloved and revered mother who shared her wonder with her children Suzanne, Stacey and her husband Harold. The Goldfield Family

SHARKEY--Irwin, MD. Graduate of Durfee High School in Fall River, MA, Columbia College and NYU School of Medicine. He was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, AOA and he was a proud Eagle Scout. His professional career was spent at NYU Medical Center and he was Chief of Medicine at Beekman Downtown Hospital. Happily married to Betty for 55 years. Loving father to Wendy Aronow, Jonathan Sharkey, Jennifer Sharkey Ull, the late Marcy Sharkey Farkas and seven perfect grandchildren. Funeral services at Frank E Campbell 1076 Madison Ave (81st St) on Friday September 19 at 11:30am.

SALISBURY--John Francis, 83, of Stamford, CT, died there on September 7, 2014 of natural causes. The son of Dr. Edward I. Salisbury and Kathleen O'Sullivan, John was born in Limon, Costa Rica, living there for 12 years, then was raised in Manhasset, NY. He was educated at Chaminade High School, Villanova and University of Pennsylvania Law School. As a Lieutenant in the United States Navy, he served aboard the U.S. McGinty during the Korean conflict. John began his brilliant career at Breed, Abbott and Morgan then spent 30 years at National Distillers and Chemical Corp, where he retired as Vice President and General Counsel. In 1996 John founded National Distillers Products Company and as its Chairman, launched Teton Glacier Vodka, a premium potato vodka, proudly marketed as "The Best Vodka in the World and It's Made in America!" John was a devoted member of St. John's Catholic Church. John is survived by his beloved wife of 54 years, Nancy Furlong Salisbury; daughters Adrienne, Philippa, Anne and Gay; his son-in-law Terrence Cole and his granddaughter, Elizabeth Salisbury Cole. He is also survived by his brothers Edward and Kevin Salisbury, 11 nieces and nephews and his devoted pug Phoebe. There will be a memorial service on Saturday, September 27th at 12:30pm at St. Frances Church, 503 Old Long Ridge Road, Stamford, CT with interment at Long Ridge Union Cemetery, 154 Erskine Road.

MAY--Todd, passed away on September 17, 2014 at 88 years of age. Dear husband of the late Peggy Masback May. He will be greatly missed by his daughter Peggy May Ordway and stepdaughter Martha Pelligrino. He is survived by his son Todd Gifford May. Stepfather of Deb and Nick. Grandfather of six. He was retired as the Chief Economist of Fortune Magazine.

MARLOWE--Francine. The Millinger family mourns the passing of Francine Marlowe, beloved sister, sister-in-law, and aunt. We will miss her smile, her energy, and her ability to find joy in every day. Contributions in Fran's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

LOW--Richard H. Richard H. Low, 87, died at his home on September 15 after a long and debilitating illness. He lived in Manhattan and for many years had summer homes in Fair Harbor and Saltaire, Fire Island. He is survived by his companion of 45 years, Barbara Bonn; his best beloved daughter, Jennifer Low, PhD; her husband, Mark Scroggins, PhD; their daughters, Philippa and Daphne, and his former wife, Stephanie Taubman Low. A graduate of the University of Michigan, University of California at Berkeley and Columbia University Law School, he was a pioneer in the television industry, helping to shape the Golden Age of Television at CBS News and as Executive Vice President and Director of Broadcast Programming and Planning at the Young & Rubicam advertising agency. After retirement, he was licensed to teach history to at-risk students in the New York City high schools, and continued a lifetime of learning, taking graduate seminars in art, literature and philosophy at Columbia. He served in the U.S. Army in World War II. He was the son of Regina and Irving Low, immigrants who raised their family "over the store" in West New York, N.J. Proud of this heritage, he served as a founding trustee of the American Museum of Immigration at the Statue of Liberty, which celebrated the contributions of newcomers from all nations. He was also a Life Trustee of The Town Hall, a board member of the Air and Space Bicentennial and a member of the Advisory Committee for the League of Women Voters' Presidential Debates. He was an active participant in the battles for civil rights and gender equality. He will be remembered for his absolute integrity, formidable intelligence, generosity, profound love of art and music, and his passion for justice. A memorial gathering will be held Sunday, September 21, 11:15am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, followed by burial at Westchester Hills Cemetery. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to the VNSNY Hospice and Palliative Care Program or any organization that promotes education for immigrants to the U.S. The family wishes to thank his team of dedicated caregivers, who improved his quality of life immeasurably over the past seven years: Evelyn Chevalier, Yvonne Dacosta, Jennifer Hylton, Blossom Mitchell, Rose Paul and Sybil Scott.

LeBLANC--Nancy E.,died pe-acefully September 15, 2014. Founding director MFY Legal Services and North Country Legal Services. Admired by clients, colleagues and judges throughout her brilliant career in public and private practice. Her husband, Scott Avery, her family and those whose lives she touched will remember her true grit and indomitable spirit. Memorial, Whiteface Community Church, Wilmington, NY, 11am Saturday, September 27. Gifts to Essex County Bar Ass'n Scholarship Fund, Schroon Lake, NY gratefully accepted.

GREIFER--Ira, M.D.,on September 17, 2014. World renowned pediatric nephrologist and Professor Emeritus of Pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Beloved husband of Carol, devoted father of Shelly Greifer, Lori Greifer Kaufman and Glenn Kaufman, and Julie and Michael Swidler. Cherished grandfather of Hannah and Benjamin Kaufman and Hallie, Nora and Sam Swidler. Dear brother of the late Naomi Weiss and David Greifer. Also survived by family members Edward Sachs, Merle Greifer, Dedee and Stephen Lovell and many beloved nieces and nephews. Service: Friday, September 19, 2014, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

GORDON--Robert S.,passed away peacefully at home in Manhattan on September 17, 2014. He was born on October 28, 1925, in Michigan City, Indiana, and raised in Helena, Arkansas. He was an accomplished musician and played on a Mississippi riverboat. He attended the University of Michigan, where he was a drum major. He attended graduate school at New York University and Columbia University. After working as an editor for Forbes, he became a highly successful stock broker and financial wizard. He is survived by his adoring wife of 57 years, Ida, his daughter, Roberta, and step-son, Michael, his son-in-law, Rick, his daughter-in-law, Anne, and his grandchildren, Adrian, Eli, and Zoe. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic at www.pphp.org.
GOLDSTEIN--Connie. We mourn the loss of our dear friend of over 40 years. Our hearts go out to Allen, Nancy and Susan. Vivian and Ira Merritt
GOLDSTEIN--Connie. Our hearts are broken. We will miss you. Honey, Lynne, Thea, Sonny and Maryanne

GOLDSTEIN--Connie. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst mourns the passing of our longtime member Connie Goldstein. We extend condolences to her husband Allen and the Goldstein Family. Matthew Futterman, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

GLAUBINGER--Lawrence D. Beloved husband of Lucienne Glaubinger, died of natural causes on September 16 at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88. A respected entrepreneur and philanthropist, Larry was chief executive for several textile companies throughout his 40-year career, most recently of Stern and Stern Industries, from which he retired. Larry served in the Coast Guard, stationed in the South Pacific, in the final days of World War II. Benefitting from the GI Bill, Larry graduated from Indiana University in 1949, and later attended Columbia Business School during a hiatus from executive duties, graduating in 1977. Forever grateful for the opportunity to further his own education, he supported hundreds of student scholarships at both alma maters--including the establishment of an endowment in his name for student athletes in non-revenue-generating sports at IU. He stayed in touch with many scholarship recipients for decades, gratified to learn about the careers in education, business, law and medicine he had helped to launch. A private funeral service was held on September 18 at Beth David Cemetery in Kenilworth , New Jersey. The family suggests that in lieu of flowers a gift in remembrance of Lawrence Glaubinger to benefit student athlete scholarships in the Glaubinger Endowment Fund be sent to: IU Foundation, P.O. Box 500, Bloomington, IN, 47402.

EPSTEIN--Norman M.,age 80, died at his home after a long illness. His family was by his side. He is survived by his loving wife, Mari, adoring sister, Cookie and devoted family and friends. Norman was Executive Vice President of E.F. Hutton & Company. One of Norman's greatest successes was his gift for mentoring and inspiring young people. Services will be held Sunday 3pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in Norman's memory may be made to American Bird Conservancy, P.O. Box 249, 4249 Loudoun Ave, The Plains, VA 20198 or NYC Coalition Against Hunger, 50 Broad Street, Ste 1520, NYC 10004.

DOMB--Stanley, of Fort Lee, beloved husband of Doris, devoted father of Susan and Leonard Fuld, Mindy Domb and Matthew Sadof, dear brother of Edward Domb, loving and adored grandfather of six grandchildren, beloved uncle and great-uncle. DICKER--Grayce W.,93. Longtime resident of Hewlett, NY, passed away peacefully in her sleep at home on September 17, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Lee Dicker. Loving mother of Rodd (Ilene), Philip (Dar), Richard (Ellen) and James (Anna). Cherished grandmother of Margot, Lawrence, Kit, Ben, and Ian. Graveside service will be held at 11am, Sunday, September 21, 2014 at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

CHENDER--Selda, died Sunday in New York City. She was born in Sokal, Poland in 1923, and was predeceased by her husband Yuli. Selda was a loving mother to Michael and Robert, grandmother to Claudia, Lauren, Julian, Evan, and Isabel, and great-grandmother to four (soon to be five). The family will hold a private ceremony and requests that donations be made in memory of Selda to the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, hias.org/donate, which cared for Selda when she was a refugee in this country.

CELENTANO--Marian, passed away after a brief illness September 17 in New York City surrounded by family. She was delivered by poet and pediatrician William Carlos Williams on January 12, 1935; grew up in Wood Ridge, NJ and spent her adult years in Clifton and Montclair, NJ; New York City and Palm Beach. She was the beloved wife of John A. Celentano, Jr., cherished mother of SueAnne (Robert), Mark (Susanna), Kerry, and Gregory (Heather) Celentano. Predeceased by son John A III, son-in-law Brian Frawley and brother A Edward DiMiceli. Loving Nonna to Hayley, Patrick, Matthew, Michela, Ian, Luke, Lucy and Lily. Let's not forget her Westies Molly and Talulah. Contributions in her memory may be made to Camp Kesem (campkesem.org/msu/ donate) and The Doe Fund. Friends may call Friday, September 19, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell. 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. (212) 288-3500. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, September 20th-10:30am, St Thomas More Church: 65 East 89th Street, NYC. Interment will be private.

BROWN--Elvira, "Ellie" (nee DiMiceli), on September 12, 2014. Loving wife, mother, and proud New Yorker who returned to her roots after many years of living and travel abroad as the wife of an American diplomat. She was a gifted linguist, gracious hostess, and keen observer. She worked unstintingly to promote the interests of the United States abroad, as well as her husband's career. That husband, Carroll, and her two children David Brown and Suzanne Fitzpatrick will miss her terribly.

BOGART--Robert, a former resident of Roslyn, NY, passed away on September 8, 2014 in Sarasota, FL at the age of 91. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Corinne, his sister Roslyn, three children, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. The funeral was September 11, 2014 at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Family would appreciate donations to CCFA or JDRF in his memory.

ANISMAN--Dore, of New York City and Sarasota, Florida, died peacefully on September 18, 2014, at age 91, after a short illness. Born in Romania, in transit from Russia, as an infant he emigrated to New York City with his parents, Julius and Yetta. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II and was a graduate of Washington University in St. Louis. Trained as a civil engineer, he had a career as a developer and builder, primarily in Rockland County New York, and was president of MAK Development Corp. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Annette, his son Paul, daughter Debra, daughter-in-law Shari Anisman, son-in-law Paul Milmed, and grandchildren Laura and Julia Milmed and Emma Anisman. His younger brother, Lou, predeceased him. He loved and was beloved by his family and will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, on Sunday at 10:00am. Memorial contributions may be made to the Mount Sinai Medical Center Palliative Care Unit, One Gustave Levy Place, Box 1070, New York, NY 10029, or https://philanthropy. mountsinai.org/hertzberg.

ALI--Amina Grace Cullen, age 5, passed away suddenly September 17, 2014. Cherished daughter of Munawar and Maura Cullen Ali; loving sister of Nabil and Emma; beloved granddaughter of Khorshed and Monowara Ali and Frank and Marilyn Cullen; dearest niece and cousin of many. Amina will always be remembered for her love of life, strength, free spirit, angelic smile, dancing, hugs and love of Pirate's Booty. She touched the hearts of all who had the opportunity to spend time with her. We miss our sassy girl and will carry her in our hearts forever. Salat al-Janazah be held on Sunday, September 21, at 1:30pm at the Muslim Community Center (MCC), 8601 N. Menard Ave., Morton Grove. Visitation will be during 4-9pm on Sunday at Smith-Corcoran Funeral Home, 6150 N. KAPELL--William. Dear Willy, you would have been 92 today. I always think of you and miss you. You were my protector every day of your short life. Your loving brother, Bobby

STEWART--Jason Mathew Psy.D. Beloved husband of Theresa (nee Donnelly), loving brother of Patricia Jr and Matthew (and his wife Rosemary and their children Ramsey and Mary Elizabeth) and adored nephew of Judy Moseley. Cherished son of James and Patricia. Dr Stewart, 39, was a clinical psychologist with a practice in Garden City and previous work at LIJ and Mercy First on Long Island and was the editor/author of a definitive work published last month "Mindfulness, Acceptance and the Psychodynamic Evolution." An avid surfer and cyclist, Jason's great professional pride was enriching the lives of patients and others. Contributions can be made in Jason's name to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Swartz Center for Neuroscience cshl.edu or to St. John's Church of Cold Spring Harbor stjohnscoldspringharbor.org

McNAMEE--Lillian E. (nee McCarthy) September 19, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Edmund J. Loving mother of Maureen (Frank), Michele and Monica and the late Margaret Ellen. Cherished grandmother of Kiera and Bridget. Beloved aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. Friends may call Saturday 7-9pm and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, September 22nd, 10:30am at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St.

KOLLEENY--Steven J. On September 18, 2014. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of Steven J. Kolleeny, an accomplished litigator whose career was marked by a singular dedication to public service. Steve was 58. Over the past 33 years, Steve played a key role in numerous significant litigation matters, advising clients in a diverse array of securities and commercial cases in state and federal court, including numerous contests for corporate control. However, Steve was perhaps best known for, and most proud of, his extraordinary dedication to serving individuals seeking political asylum. For more than 25 years, he headed Skadden's pro bono asylum program. Steve personally secured asylum for more than 40 individuals and supervised another 300 cases, providing invaluable assistance to our attorneys at every step of the process. The many honors he received for his pro bono efforts include Human Rights First's Frankel Award and the New York State Bar Association's Empire State Counsel Award. This year, the New York Law Journal selected Steve as one of its "Lawyers Who Lead by Example". We join Steve's wife, Eva, and daughters Elizabeth and Natalie in honoring Steve's memory.

KOLLEENY--Steven J.,passed away on September 18, 2014 at the age of 58. Beloved husband of Eva. Loving father of Natalie and Liz (Scott). Dear brother of Debra (Richard) and Helena (Jaromir). Uncle of Adam (Marlene) and their son Trent, Brooke (Brad) and their sons Blake and Brady. He will be remembered as a thoughtful, intelligent and dedicated attorney especially in his pro bono work. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the NYU/Perlmutter Cancer Center. Services Sunday, 9:45am at "The Riverside," West 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

KLEIN--Sam H.,89, passed away peacefully at home in Purchase, NY with his family at his side on Friday, September 19, 2014. Sam was born in Yonkers, NY on June 18, 1925 to the late Bernard and Gussie (nee Ziegler) Klein. He joined his family's business, Crown Products in Yonkers and rose to the positions of Vice President, President and ultimately Chairman. A World War II Veteran, he served in the China-Burma-India Theater. Discharged honorably in 1946, he returned to Yonkers to begin his working life. In 1952 he married his beloved Lucy, formerly Lucille Herbst, who predeceased him last year. They were true partners in every sense of the word. He leaves behind his loving children Richard, Edith (Marc) and Margaret (Eric) and two delicious grandchildren Mark and Alexandra. Funeral Service will be Sunday, September 21, 2pm at Congregation Emanu-el of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave., East, Rye, NY 10580. 914-967-4382. Family will receive condolences directly following the service until 9pm at the Klein home in Purchase, NY. 914-997-7424. Shiva will be observed Monday, September 22, 5-9pm and Tuesday, September 23, 5-9pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Sam's memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

GROPIUS JOHANSEN--Beate. December 19, 1925 - September 7, 2014. Last surviving child of Bauhaus founder Walter Gropius and protege of Josef Albers at Black Mountain College. Artist, graphic designer, children's book illustrator and international educator on the principles of modern design. Widow of renowned architect John Johansen. She is celebrated, loved, and deeply missed by her daughter Erika, her grandsons Matias and Lukas, and her many friends.

EPSTEIN--Norman M.,age 80, died at his home after a long illness. His family was by his side. He is survived by his loving wife, Mari, adoring sister, Cookie and devoted family and friends. Norman was Executive Vice President of E.F. Hutton & Company. One of Norman's greatest successes was his gift for mentoring and inspiring young people. Services will be held Sunday 3pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in Norman's memory may be made to American Bird Conservancy, P.O. Box 249, 4249 Loudoun Ave, The Plains, VA 20198 or NYC Coalition Against Hunger, 50 Broad Street, Ste 1520, NYC 10004.

CELENTANO--Marian, passed away after a brief illness September 17 in New York City surrounded by family. She was delivered by poet and pediatrician William Carlos Williams on January 12, 1935; grew up in Wood Ridge, NJ and spent her adult years in Clifton and Montclair, NJ; New York City and Palm Beach. She was the beloved wife of John A. Celentano, Jr., cherished mother of SueAnne (Robert), Mark (Susanna), Kerry, and Gregory (Heather) Celentano. Predeceased by son John A III, son-in-law Brian Frawley and brother A Edward DiMiceli. Loving Nonna to Hayley, Patrick, Matthew, Michela, Ian, Luke, Lucy and Lily. Let's not forget her Westies Molly and Talulah. Contributions in her memory may be made to Camp Kesem (campkesem.org/msu/ donate) and The Doe Fund. Friends may call Friday, September 19, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell. 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. (212) 288-3500. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, September 20th-10:30am, St Thomas More Church: 65 East 89th Street, NYC. Interment will be private.

ANISMAN--Dore. The congregation of Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of Dore Anisman, husband of Annette and father of Debra. Heartfelt condolences are extended to them and the entire Anisman family. May his memory be for blessing. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch Michael Starr, President

ANISMAN--Dore, of New York City and Sarasota, Florida, died peacefully on September 18, 2014, at age 91, after a short illness. Born in Romania, in transit from Russia, as an infant he emigrated to New York City with his parents, Julius and Yetta. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II and was a graduate of Washington University in St. Louis. Trained as a civil engineer, he had a career as a developer and builder, primarily in Rockland County New York, and was president of MAK Development Corp. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Annette, his son Paul, daughter Debra, daughter-in-law Shari Anisman, son-in-law Paul Milmed, and grandchildren Laura and Julia Milmed and Emma Anisman. KRIM--Arthur B. April 4, 1910 - September 21, 1994 Arthur B. Krim passed away twenty years ago today. We, his family, mark this day by commemorating him and celebrating his life well-lived. He was born in his paternal grandfather's house in Harlem, NY, the son of two young Jewish immigrants from Russia. His father, Morris Krim, had immigrated to the United States at the age of 15, from the Ukrainian shtetl of Borispol, first supporting himself with a fruit and vegetable stand on a street corner in New York City's Lower East Side. His mother was Rose Ocko, a seamstress. She too had emigrated from Russia as a teen. Growing up first in New York City, then in Lakewood, NJ and Mount Vernon, NY, he received his first catcher's mitt from his father when he was eight years old, beginning a life-long love of baseball. With a bugle he received from his uncle, he played reveille each morning at summer camp and later the trumpet in high school, and in his college band. With a deep love of reading and learning, he thrived at Columbia College, immersing himself and excelling in his studies of philosophy, history, and English literature and where he was captain of the debating team. He attended Columbia Law School where he became Editor-in-Chief of the Law Review and from which he graduated first in his class. During WWII, he served for three years as a U.S. Army attorney in the Pacific. As special assistant to the Undersecretary of War, he earned the praises of his superiors for providing effective assistance to business and industry working to increase military aircraft and equipment production and resolving critical manpower issues. He achieved the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. In his early legal career in New York City, he joined the law firm of Phillips & Nizer and represented many theater artists and writers. He spent time with members of New York's Group Theater and this period became the harbinger of his empathy for and understanding of, the creative community. Within a few years of such involvement and representation, he and his law partner Robert Benjamin were transferred ownership of a troubled United Artists and led it from near bankruptcy to profitability, followed by many years of success. As chief executive of United Artists, he and his team developed and adopted the innovative and successful practice of financing the films of independent producers, directors, actors, and writers, some of whom had been blacklisted in the McCarthy era, while providing them with unprecedented levels of creative autonomy. He became known for investing in the unique and little known producer, director or writer who did not, or could not, fit the Hollywood mold, but who had an important story to tell. At Orion Pictures, he and his team continued the same successful approach. Ultimately, he was the force and direction behind the financing and distribution of more than 1,000 films over a 40-year period. Many of his films earned Academy Award recognition. Fourteen received Academy Awards in the "Best Picture" category, the most of any studio head in the film industry. He was deeply committed to numerous humanitarian causes, most notably, the struggles for civil rights, civil liberties, and against apartheid in Zimbabwe and South Africa; efforts toward improved international relations and for nuclear disarmament; and the struggle for gay rights. He served on the Board of Governors of Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science; the Board of Trustees of his beloved Columbia University, including five years as its chairman; as a Life Trustee of the African-American Institute; and on the Boards of the John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson Library Foundations. Having lived through the Depression and the Jim Crow era and believing that a civilized, compassionate society had a moral responsibility to provide education, economic opportunity, and protection to the weak, the economically disadvantaged, and those against whom it had discriminated, he devoted decades of personal service and financial support to the Democratic Party. And, he proudly yet privately served as trusted personal advisor to three Presidents: John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson, and Jimmy Carter. Along with the considerable achievements and contributions of his lifetime, from which so many have benefited and will continue to benefit, he was a modest, self-effacing man of the highest integrity, of impeccable honesty, an exceedingly generous and loyal friend, a role model to every member of our family and of our extended family, and a loving, patient, accepting, and supportive husband, father, and grandfather. Today, as always, we remember him with much gratitude and love. Mathilde Krim, Daphna Krim & Sergio Kapfer, Amanda Crotty, Robert & Mayra Crotty, Maria Jonzier, and Marc & Renee Jonzier.

WILENSKY--Harold, 91, died in San Francisco on August 31, 2014. Predeceased by his wife Sabina Margolin Wilensky. He taught psychology at CCNY from 1963-1990. Survived by daughters Sharon, Laura, and Debra (Wilensky), their husbands, four grandchildren and two step-grandchildren.

WELLIN--Keith S. Noted Charleston philanthropist and retired Wall Street executive Keith S. Wellin died Sunday at age 88 following a long illness, surrounded by his beloved wife Wendy, loving family and friends. Wellin was born in Grand Rapids, Michigan on August 13, 1926 and was raised in Chicago, Illinois. After graduating from New Trier High School in Winnetka, Illinois, he attended the Citadel and was stationed as an officer in Seoul, Korea. Following his Army service, Mr. Wellin returned to Hamilton College in Clinton, New York, where he received a degree in Philosophy and English literature, then went on to earn an MBA from Harvard Business School in 1952. During his career on Wall Street, Wellin served as president and vice chairman of E.F. Hutton, president of Reynolds Securities, and then chairman of DW Intercapital and vice chairman of Dean Witter Reynolds. He also served as chairman of Moorco International, Inc., a Houston-based energy equipment company. Always remembering those less fortunate, Keith was particularly generous to those in need. From his early days, he was a significant supporter of the Bowery Mission in New York City. In memory of his niece Ruth, who was killed in the terrorist attacks on September 11, 2001, he supported a space dedicated to women in need at the Bowery. Wellin served as a life trustee of Hamilton College, where he was first elected to the board in 1969 and served as chairman of the college's Investment Committee. Together with his wife Wendy, Mr. Wellin was a significant benefactor of Hamilton, supporting special endowment projects and making transformative gifts to create spaces named in their honor for music, athletics and the sciences. In 2007, the Wellins made the single largest gift in the history of Hamilton College. Their $10 million lead gift to the arts funded the Ruth and Elmer Wellin Museum named in memory of his parents, which was dedicated in 2012. The Wellins' great love for Hamilton and Charleston is reflected in joint exhibitions which have since been co-curated with the Wellin and Halsey Museums. The Wellins returned to Charleston in 2005, where they quickly became engaged citizens and have been actively involved in local philanthropic efforts. In addition to supporting generously many local organizations, the Wellins have made significant gifts to the Medical University of South Carolina and to the Roper St. Francis Hospital. In recognition of their support, construction will begin in November on the Wendy and Keith Wellin Head and Neck Clinic at MUSC and plans are underway for construction of the Wellin Stroke Center at Roper St. Francis. In lieu of flowers, please consider gifts in Keith's memory to the Wendy and Keith Wellin Head and Neck Clinic MSC550 (135 Rutledge Avenue, Charleston, SC 29425) or to the Roper St. Francis Foundation/Wellin Stroke Center (125 Doughty Street, Suite 790, Charleston, SC 29403). A memorial message may be written to the family by visiting our website at www.jhenrystuhr.com.

TRIGLEDAS--Peter J.,teacher, tutor, mentor, community activist and tenant leader, died September 10, 2014 at home, age 72. Over 47 years, Peter educated thousands of public and private school students. He was a great host, wit, and avid opera lover. Born October 9, 1941 in Cambridge, MA, son of Nicholas Trigledas and Claire (nee) Murphy, Peter was predeceased by his brother Paul. He is survived by his spouse, Felix M. Roldan. We celebrate his presence in our lives. He made you think. He made you feel special. No one could hold a candle to him.

THOMSON--John B. Jr. Former Owner/Chairman of Thomson Industries & Pillar of the sailing community passes away at 70. The sailing community lost one of its best owner/drivers and a pillar of the sport when John B. Thomson, Jr., of Sands Point, NY, passed away in the evening of Wednesday, September 10, surrounded by family and loved ones after succumbing to the effects of ALS. Thomson Jr. was a beloved figure in his hometown and around the world. Husband to wife Adrienne, father to three children and grandfather to more, he was also the steady and kindhearted owner of the Infinity yacht racing team, which won many regattas around the world through the course of 40 years of buoy and ocean racing, spanning from the early 1970s into the 21st century. Mr. Thomson was born May 31, 1944, in Mineola, NY, the son of Louise Magoon Thomson and John B. Thomson, Sr. He attended the New York Institute of Technology where he earned an engineering degree. Upon graduation, he joined Thomson Industries, the company founded by his father, who, in the early 1940's, invented the linear motion ball bushing bearing. Thomson Jr. rose to become chief executive officer and chairman of the company, and contributed many patents to the company's line of proprietary technology. Aviation was always a cornerstone of the Thomson family, starting with Thomson Sr.'s invention of the linear bushing bearing, which gave birth to the first variable pitch propeller. This tradition continued with Thomson Jr. becoming a skilled pilot, who flew his helicopters. His ability as a pilot is a key legacy of his business and personal life. Thomson Jr. also had great effect in the sailing community. He began sailing at the age of eight and later in life would go on to own a series of yachts named Infinity. His welcoming nature and hearty laugh were readily recognized at the many regattas he won, including the Kenwood Cup, SORC, Block Island Race Week, Key West Race Week, Antigua Race Week, and the Around Long Island Race. Thomson was a member of the New York Yacht Club, Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, Royal Cork Yacht Club, and the Storm Trysail Club, for which he served as commodore. He was past director of the U.S. Naval Academy-Fales Committee, and one of the benefactors that helped the New York Yacht Club purchase its satellite clubhouse in Newport, RI. He also was very active in owners' associations for classes such as the International 50-Foot Association and the Farr 40 Class Association, and also enjoyed a skeet membership at the Sands Point Golf Club. Thomson founded one of Long Island Sound's greatest regattas, the Manhasset Bay Fall Series. Founded in 1979, the regatta is a premier event on the East Coast and used by crews as a final tune-up before heading to the winter racing season in Florida. The overall trophy is named in honor of his father, John B. Thomson, Sr. With his wife and family at his side, Thomson always steered his yachts and believed in an amateur crew, which often included lifelong friends. In his honor, the New York Yacht Club and Storm Trysail Club together formed the John B. Thomson Award for Campaign Excellence. Thomson Jr. was a staunch supporter of his community. He was a Trustee at the North-Shore-LIJ Health System in Manhasset, NY, and served for many years as a Trustee at the South Street Seaport Museum, in New York City. Through his family's charitable foundation, Thomson Jr. supported many local fundraising efforts, always choosing to keep his charitable giving "close to home." Thomson is survived by his wife Adrienne Thomson, of Sands Point, NY, children John B. Thomson, III, of Sands Point, NY, Victoria Thomson, of Sands Point, NY, Scott Thomson, of New York, NY, and three grandchildren. A tribute and celebration of John's life will be held on Friday, September 26th, at Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in Port Washington, New York, from 3-8 p.m. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations in John's honor be sent to The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter, 42 Broadway, Suite 1724, New York, NY 10004, or online: www.als.org.

TAYLOR--Dr. Andrea, died of early Alzheimer's disease on September 17, 2014. Born August 20, 1946, and raised in Middle Village, Queens, Andrea (Mestel) graduated from Queens College in 1967 and, after earning perfect 800 scores on her MCAT's, went on to graduate from Albert Einstein College of Medicine, one of two women in her class of 1971. She became an accomplished internist and endocrinologist, practicing in Charlottesville, VA, for over 25 years, and then Northern California, before retiring. Andrea was a brilliant physician whose hard work and dedication to her patients (she estimated as many as 2000 at one point) helped pave the way for all women interested in the practice of medicine. Andrea was fortunate to have two sons who survive her, Peter and Matthew, whose love and respect were of great comfort to her in her decline. In addition, she is survived by her twin sister Karen, sister Lynn, mother Shirley and loving partner Armando. Memorial services will be in Northern California on September 29, 2014. St. Justin's Catholic Church, Santa Clara, CA (408) 296-1193.

STEIN--Philip, on Wednesday September 17, 2014, Philip Stein, affectionately known to all as Phil, got his lifelong wish to die peacefully and comfortably in his Malverne, New York home of over 60 years. Phil is survived by his devoted son David, David's longtime girlfriend Barbara Pastore, his sister Roslyn Storch and by enumerable other loving nieces, nephews and cousins who all called him "Uncle." Phil was predeceased by his beloved wife Margaret (Margie) and his youngest son Jeffrey. Phil was a titan and legend of the women's garment apparel industry, having founded such highly successful companies such as Allyson Frocks, Nassau Miss and Afterdark. Coupled with his entrepreneurial successes was Phil's deep commitment to charitable and philanthropic causes, many of which were responsible for fostering the growth of Jewish culture on Long Island from Nassau County all the way out to the Hamptons. Such endeavors included being a founder of the Malverne Jewish Center, a cofounder of the Hamptons Synagogue and for many years one of the Journal Chairpersons for the incredibly successful Hamptons Synagogue's annual fund raising events. Phil was also a staunch supporter of the State of Israel cofounding the Alan King Diagnostic Center in Jerusalem. Phil will be most remembered for his smile, the twinkle in his eye, his wit, his charm and infectious sense of humor. Funeral services for Phil will be held on Friday September 19, 2014 at 1:00pm at the Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. Shivah will be observed at the home of David Stein, 70 Morris Avenue, Malverne, New York, from sundown Saturday September 20, 2014 until the morning of Wednesday September 23, 2104.

SALISBURY--John Francis, 83, of Stamford, CT, died there on September 7, 2014 of natural causes. The son of Dr. Edward I. Salisbury and Kathleen O'Sullivan, John was born in Limon, Costa Rica, living there for 12 years, then was raised in Manhasset, NY. He was educated at Chaminade High School, Villanova and University of Pennsylvania Law School. As a Lieutenant in the United States Navy, he served aboard the U.S. McGinty during the Korean conflict. John began his career at Breed, Abbott and Morgan then spent 30 years at National Distillers and Chemical Corp, where he retired as Vice President and General Counsel. In 1996 John founded National Distillers Products Company and as its Chairman, launched Teton Glacier Vodka, a premium potato vodka, proudly marketed as "The Best Vodka in the World and It's Made in America!" John was a devoted member of St. John's Catholic Church. John is survived by his beloved wife of 54 years, Nancy Furlong Salisbury; daughters Adrienne, Philippa, Anne and Gay; his son-in-law Terrence Cole, stepgrandsons Henry andDesmond Cole, and his granddaughter, Elizabeth Salisbury Cole. He is also survived by his brothers Edward and Kevin Salisbury, 11 nieces and nephews and his devoted pug Phoebe. There will be a memorial service on Saturday, September 27th at 12:30pm at St. Frances Church, 503 Old Long Ridge Road, Stamford, CT with interment at Long Ridge Union Cemetery, 154 Erskine Road.

ROEHDER--Robert Alexander, died in England on August 22, 2014. Born in Troy, NY, December 19, 1936, Mr. Roehder was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Cornell University. Following graduation, he moved to Germany where he founded ROADCOAT GmbH, a world-wide industrial coatings organization with headquarters in Germany. Mr. Roehder also resided in Absorkee, MT where he enjoyed outdoor activities on his ranch. He was an adventurer at heart and possessed a unique sense of humor that will be missed. He is survived by his sisters Valerie R. Florstedt and Wendy E. Roehder and their families. Donations may be made in his memory to an orphanage close to his heart "The Littlest Lamb," PO Box 592, Rye, NY 10580.

NICKLIN--Katherine (nee Aronson), social worker, inspirational leader of Quaker organizations, and loving wife, mother, aunt, and grandmother to three generations of Nicklins and Berners, died peacefully on August 19, at the age of 90, at her beloved home on Shelter Island, NY, where her extended family had gathered to care for her and each other. Characterized throughout her life by integrity, courage, and luminous intelligence, Kate dedicated her formidable capacities to caring for others: for her mother, Emma Aronson, and young sister, Ruth, through the Depression, for her husband, Dr. George L. Nicklin through 56 years of marriage until his death in 2007, for her beloved children and grandchildren, who were the light of her life, for young children and struggling families in her professional life as a social worker, and for her friends and those with whom she partnered as a joyful volunteer in the serious work of Quaker organizations. Kate's special gifts for spiritual leadership and clear vision were recognized in the community of Friends (Quakers), and she was tapped to serve first as Clerk of Westbury Meeting and then Clerk of New York Yearly Meeting, from 1974-77. Kate also served the American Friends Service Committee for many years, during two terms as the Clerk of the New York Metropolitan Regional Office, as a member of the Board from 1979-2001 and leader in the work of its committees, and as the Treasurer of AFSC from 1994-2000. Next to her devotion to her family and children, her commitment to Friends, and especially to AFSC, was central to her life's work and allowed her talents to bloom and inspire many others. She was extraordinarily gifted as a clerk who could find the sense of a meeting and lead a group of Friends through contentious waters to a shared vision. Her loss is keenly felt by her dearly loved children, Emily Nicklin, David Nicklin (Amy Kietzman), Jane Nicklin Olsen (Bob Olsen), and Sarah Nicklin (Jim Moreno), her cherished grandchildren, Max Schleusener (Meg Hammond), Luke, and Anna Schleusener, Kate, Megan, and Sarafina Kietzman-Nicklin, Emma and Elizabeth Olsen, Molly Olsen Lewen (Mike Lewen), and Graham, Clara, and Olivia Moreno, her dear brother-in-law, Jerry Berner, and beloved nieces and nephew and grand niece and grand nephews. To her very last day, she was the soul and mainstay of her large family, caring deeply and with tender kindness and wisdom for each one. Memorial Services will be held at Fifteenth Street Friends Meeting in New York City at 11am on Saturday, November 8, 2014. In lieu of flowers, the family would gratefully accept donations to: The George and Kate Nicklin Medical Research Fellowship Fund at the University of Chicago, Make checks payable to The University of Chicago with Nicklin Fellowship on the memo line Attention: Paul Seeley, Executive Director, Regional Major Gifts University of Chicago, 7th Floor, 5235 South Harper Court, Chicago, IL 60615 Or American Friends Service Committee, AFSC Development, 1501 Cherry St., Philadelphia, PA 19102.

KOLLEENY--Steven J. On September 18, 2014. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of Steven J. Kolleeny, an accomplished litigator whose career was marked by a singular dedication to public service. Steve was 58. Over the past 33 years, Steve played a key role in numerous significant litigation matters, advising clients in a diverse array of securities and commercial cases in state and federal court, including numerous contests for corporate control. However, Steve was perhaps best known for, and most proud of, his extraordinary dedication to serving individuals seeking political asylum. For more than 25 years, he headed Skadden's pro bono asylum program. Steve personally secured asylum for more than 40 individuals and supervised another 300 cases, providing invaluable assistance to our attorneys at every step of the process. The many honors he received for his pro bono efforts include Human Rights First's Frankel Award and the New York State Bar Association's Empire State Counsel Award. This year, the New York Law Journal selected Steve as one of its "Lawyers Who Lead by Example". We join Steve's wife, Eva, and daughters Elizabeth and Natalie in honoring Steve's memory.
