JAFFE--Jeff H. Jeff H. Jaffe, Chairman and President of The Chunky Corporation and President and CEO of Ward Foods Candy, Ward Foods Branded Foods Group, Schrafft Candy Company and Bernan Foods, died of natural causes at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida on July 27, 2014. He was 93 years old. In 1950, Mr. Jaffe leveraged the purchase of a small bankrupt candy company in Brooklyn known for a chocolate bar called CHUNKY. Due to his marketing skills and ability to take risks and win, he built Chunky into a major player in the candy industry. Through the years, Mr. Jaffe acquired other candy companies. In 1951, he reached an agreement with Rowntree & Company of York, England to import Kit Kat, the famous chocolate covered sugar wafer candy bar, and shortly nationwide distribution was successfully achieved. Shutter Candy Company, manufacturer of Bit-O-Honey and Old Nick, was purchased in 1958, and Klotz Confection Company in 1960. In 1965, he bought Chocolate Sponge from Heide Candy Company and produced it in the Shutter plant in Chicago. He added Oh Henry!, purchased from the Williams Candy Company, to Shutter in 1971. Jeff Jaffe, well respected by the candy industry, received two prestigious awards among many. The Association of Manufacturers of Candy and Chocolate presented their award to him at a testimonial dinner attended by over 400 industry members in 1964. He was the youngest executive, at age forty-four, to be honored in this fashion. In 1971 he received the 26th Kettle Award and was named "Candy Man of the Year" by Candy Industry Magazine, who recognized him for his "endless efforts on behalf of his industry and his community..." Two noteworthy accomplishments were the Chunky exhibit at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair and the Harvard Business School case study on Chunky. The World's Fair exhibit, an actual manufacturing plant, automatically coated with chocolate, wrapped and packaged Old Nick candy bars. It also contained the "Sculpture Continuum" that served as an art form and a functional children's playground and an area where company products were sold. The cost per thousand was many times less than that of companies like IBM and GM. It was proclaimed that the Chunky exhibit "could not help but benefit the entire candy industry." Harvard Business School's Midway Series was used by nearly 1,000 MBA participants in the Executive Education Programs each year. A landmark in case writing, the study was used by more than fifty universities at home and abroad and dozens of Fortune 50 companies. For sixteen years, Mr. Jaffe lectured on the study to hundreds of HBS students and in 1977 was ceremoniously honored "for his important service to Harvard Business School." Mr. Jaffe served on many Boards (including Young Presidents' Organization) and contributed to various communities throughout his life. In later years, he was President of Sailfish Point of Stuart, Florida and helped transfer ownership from the developer, Mobil Oil, to the residents. In 2001, he brought Sir John Templeton's "Laws of Life" essay contest to Martin County, Florida. Reaching students of all backgrounds, the contest inspired them to focus on their principles and ideals. Mr. Jaffe, himself, valued integrity above all. Jeff Jaffe was born Irwin Hugh Jaffe on December 25, 1920 in Washington, DC. Nicknamed "Jeff" at Virginia Polytechnic Institute where he received a degree in Architectural Engineering, he legally changed his name shortly after 2001. Unhappy as an architectural engineer, he left his family painting and construction business and moved to Manhattan in April, 1945. There he met his wife, Natalie, on a blind date. They were married six months later. Jeff Jaffe is survived by Natalie, his wife of 68 years, his two daughters Bonnie Berens and Holly Jaffe, four grandsons and three great-grandsons. They all said, "Make it flat. You'll never get a nickel for that funny-looking, not-quite-square, truncated something or other. Make it flat like a Hershey bar. Then you'll have something to sell." He took that chunk of chocolate and made history. As he entitled his book, "How Sweet It Is." A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, September 30, 2014 at 5:00pm at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022.

HINSON--Harry. The Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club family and Board of Trustees express their deepest sympathy on the passing of long-time Trustee Harry L. Hinson a loss for all who knew him, for two generations of Kips Bay children, especially Mr. Tripp March, most of all. Harry will forever be associated with the Decorator Show House, our signature event. He led a committed core group who were the champions of the Show House. We are indebted and grateful to them all. The Show House is what it is today in large part because of Mr. Hinson's dedication to Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club. James P. Druckman, Chairman and Daniel Quintero, Executive Director

HAURY--Agnese Nelms passed away on March 20, 2014, in Tucson, AZ, at the age of 90. Born in Houston, Texas, on May 17, 1923, she is preceded in death by her husband, twin sister, and brother. Survivors include a niece and nephews. Early in her life, Mrs. Haury acquired an interest in helping individuals struggling with language barriers to receive justice in the courtroom. She also assisted organizations and individuals working to effect social change by providing funding to expand influential ideas and programs. Mrs. Haury was educated at the College de Jeunes Filles in Fontainebleau, France, and at Rosemary Hall in Greenwich, Conn. She received a B.A. degree in history from Bryn Mawr College in 1946. She was married to Manice deForest Lockwood III (1950-1976), Denver Lindley (1978-1982) and Emil W. Haury (1990-1992); all predeceased her. Mrs. Haury's professional career included work as an editor at the United Nations. While employed by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, she traveled to Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Libya, and Burma making surveys and writing treatises on economic and social problems in those countries as well as economic development possibilities. In 1964-1965 she processed and catalogued artifacts recovered from the Snaketown Archaeological Project in central Arizona, which was directed by Emil W. Haury. Through her work at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Mrs. Haury formed a lifelong friendship with its president, Alger Hiss. Over a 60-year period, Mrs. Haury supported a series of activities aimed at clearing Mr. Hiss of charges leveled against him by Whittaker Chambers and Richard Nixon. In honor of Mr. Hiss, she established the Alger Hiss Distinguished Professorship at Bard College and provided financial support for the Emergency Civil Liberties Foundation and The Nation Institute. She also provided funding to individuals engaged in legal research and writing about Mr. Hiss and supported the National Security Archive, an independent nonprofit repository of declassified U.S. government documents. She also helped establish New York University's Center for the United States and the Cold War as well as the Alger Hiss Papers Project at NYU's Tamiment Library. Personal friends of Mrs. Haury speak of her intelligence and unpretentious nature. She rarely spent money on herself except to fill her home with beloved collections of Native American rugs, pottery, and artwork. Her true enthusiasm was always for people, and her philanthropy extended from the preservation of cultural artifacts to support of human rights for both immigrant and Native American populations. From 1981-1990 Mrs. Haury was president of the Agnese N. Lindley Foundation, which funded projects concerning social and humanitarian problems, civil and human rights issues, the arts, the environment, and scientific research. The foundation also supported journalism, civic affairs, and economic advancement in less-developed countries. More than 200 projects received funding through the foundation including the following: preservation of more than 100,000 photographs of the conflict in El Salvador, the start-up of an Inter-American Environmental Policy Center, a project to help increase the number of Indian groups gaining federal tribal recognition, and research on the rapidly disappearing Native American languages of Yaqui and Samish. The foundation also provided grants for archaeological excavations; scholarships in the fields of art conservation; and an intern program for The Nation magazine, which provided young journalists an opportunity to learn about political and social reporting. With her support, the University of Arizona established the Agnese N. Haury Institute of Court Interpretation (a certification program for teachers across the country who train court interpreters). Mrs. Haury also supported endowments for anthropology graduate students; dendrochronological research; the construction of the Agnese and Emil Haury Southwest Native Nations Pottery Vault; and the Bryant Bannister Tree-Ring Building, which houses the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research and its irreplaceable collection of tree-ring specimens from around the world. The University of Arizona gave Mrs. Haury an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree in 1999 and a Citizen of the Year Award in 2001. In 2007 the Arizona Archaeological and Historical Society gave her the Victor R. Stoner Award. In keeping with Mrs. Haury's lifelong use of her financial resources to support scholarly work and advance human rights on an international scale, her love of the Arizona-Sonoran desert region and its peoples, and her desire to address serious issues in a meaningful way, her estate will provide more than $50 million to the University of Arizona Foundation to create the Agnese Nelms Haury Program in Environment and Social Justice at the University of Arizona and will fund other programs consistent with her philanthropic objectives.

HADLEY--Peggy. Theatre's Peggy Hadley left life's stage recently at the age of 83. Born in Kentucky, she graduated from Smith College. After graduation she hurried to Manhattan to pursue a life in the theatre. She toured with Harry Belafonte in "Sing, Man, Sing," and appeared on TV in commercials and comedic series. She wowed cabaret lovers at the Bon Soir, and London's Churchill. Later, she managed Fannie Flagg and Marcia Rodd and opened her own theatrical agency until recently retiring. Her dearest friends in Manhattan and on Long Islands's North Fork will miss her madly. A memorial will be held at the theatrical hideaway, Joe Allen.

GROPIUS JOHANSEN--Beate. December 19, 1925 - September 7, 2014. Last surviving child of Bauhaus founder Walter Gropius and protege of Josef Albers at Black Mountain College. Artist, graphic designer, children's book illustrator and international educator on the principles of modern design. Widow of renowned architect John Johansen. She is celebrated, loved, and deeply missed by her daughter Erika, her grandsons Matias and Lukas, and her many friends.

GREIFER--Ira. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center and the entire Montefiore family are deeply saddened by the passing of our great friend and statesman for children, Ira Greifer, M.D. An internationally recognized pioneer in pediatric kidney failure, Dr. Greifer helped establish the first Pediatric Dialysis Center in the nation at Montefiore. Dr. Greifer was always a strong advocate for Montefiore and supported important new initiatives, most notably The Children's Hospital at Montefiore's Ira Greifer Children's Kidney Center. We have lost a fierce advocate for children's needs, an inspiring mentor and colleague, and dear friend. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Greifer family. Steven M. Safyer, M.D., President and CEO, David A. Tanner, Chairman Board of Trustees

GRANT--Dr. John Phillips, Jr.,an accomplished NYC urologist, died September 15th, 2014 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital of complications from a stroke. He was 82. At his bedside at the time of death were his four children and his wife, Jane. Dr. Grant practiced urology for over 40 years in New York City. He was a member of the surgical team that performed the first renal transplant done at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in 1969. After working early in his career at Columbia, he became a staff surgeon at Roosevelt Hospital in 1969 and continued to work there as an attending physician until his retirement in 2005. Dr. Grant was born on January 30, 1932 in Greenwich, Connecticut. He graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1950 and Amherst College in 1954. He served two years in the Marine Corps and was honorably discharged in 1956. He entered Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1958, graduating in 1962. He completed his residency in urology at Columbia. He served as a volunteer surgeon for three months during the Vietnam war at Rach Hyah Hospital in Saigon. Dr. Grant completed a six-month fellowship in pediatric urology at Great Ormond Street Hospital in London in 1969 before beginning his formal affiliation with Roosevelt Hospital. He volunteered throughout his early career at Hopital Albert Schweitzer, in Deschapelles, Haiti, the hospital founded by the parents of his first wife, Jenifer Grant. John, who was known as Jerry to his family and early friends, was a founding member of the Zumbyes singing group at Amherst College. He sang with the University Glee Club of NYC for over 20 years. Besides his love for singing, he enjoyed cooking, bridge, opera, political discourse, travel and, most of all, time with his family. His family years were spent in Englewood, New Jersey. He moved to NYC in 1980 where he remained until his death. His favorite vacation spot was a family camp in Belgrade Lakes, Maine where he annually gathered with his children and grandchildren. Dr. Grant is survived by his wife, Jane Robb Grant, his two sisters, Mary Grant of Greenwich, Connecticut and Priscilla Grant of Cape Elizabeth, Maine, along with his children, Dr. Gwendolyn Grant of Durango, Colorado, Dr. John Phillips Grant III of Berkeley, California, Susannah Grant of Santa Monica, California, and Kate Grant Kellogg of Boulder, Colorado, along with 13 grandchildren. Services will be held at The New York Society for Ethical Culture on October 11th, 2014 at 4pm. Memorial contributions may be made to Maine Lakes Resource Center, PO Box 431, Belgrade Lakes, ME 04918.
GOLDSTEIN--Connie. We mourn the loss of our dear friend of over 40 years. Our hearts go out to Allen, Nancy and Susan. Vivian and Ira Merritt

GOLDSTEIN--Connie, passed away suddenly on September 16th. Devoted and beloved wife of 60 years of Allen J. Goldstein. Loving mother to Susan (Scott) Kushner and Nancy (Mark) Wasserman, proud grandmother of Max Kushner, Jessica z"l, and Melissa and Andrew Wasserman. GLAUBINGER--Lawrence D. Beloved husband of Lucienne Glaubinger, died of natural causes on September 16 at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88. A respected entrepreneur and philanthropist, Larry was chief executive for several textile companies throughout his 40-year career, most recently of Stern and Stern Industries, from which he retired. Larry served in the Coast Guard, stationed in the South Pacific, in the final days of World War II. Benefitting from the GI Bill, Larry graduated from Indiana University in 1949, and later attended Columbia Business School during a hiatus from executive duties, graduating in 1977. Forever grateful for the opportunity to further his own education, he supported hundreds of student scholarships at both alma maters--including the establishment of an endowment in his name for student athletes in non-revenue-generating sports at IU. He stayed in touch with many scholarship recipients for decades, gratified to learn about the careers in education, business, law and medicine he had helped to launch. A private funeral service was held on September 18 at Beth David Cemetery in Kenilworth , New Jersey. The family suggests that in lieu of flowers a gift in remembrance of Lawrence Glaubinger to benefit student athlete scholarships in the Glaubinger Endowment Fund be sent to: IU Foundation, P.O. Box 500, Bloomington, IN, 47402.

FRENCH--Frederica Ripley, on September 17th, 2014 at age 92. Wife of Seth B. Jr., six children, thirty one grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Service at St. John's Church of Cold Spring Harbor on September 24th, 2014 at 12:15pm. Donations may be made to Charlottesville Albermarle SPCA (https://caspca.org/).

DUPRE--Clare E.,89, died peacefully on August 24. She was pre-deceased by her husband, Tristan. She is survived by her daughters Andrea and her children, Adrianna and Michael Riolo, Madelyn and her son, Harris. Also by her sons Richard and his daughter, Christina, and Alan, his wife, Ann, and their children Max, Suzanne, and Elizabeth. Born in Bridgeport, CT on December 23, 1924 to Joseph and Mary Berecz, she and her sister, Charlotte, attended the Black Rock School and Fairfield High School. Clare graduated salutatorian and soon left for Greenwich Village where she worked as a secretary and met and married Tris Dupre, a financial advisor. After giving birth to two children, they bought the house in Flushing, Queens where they lived until both their deaths. Clare set high standards for herself and her family academically, politically, and ethically. She had a healthy competitive spirit that instilled a life-long drive for success in each of her children. She loved backgammon, canasta, puzzles and every week completed the Sunday Times crossword in 30 minutes. She enjoyed travel, tennis, Hank Williams and Eddy Arnold. Clare worked for many years at Saks Fifth Avenue in NYC. She had a critical eye for style and fashion and was always the best-dressed woman at any gathering. She was a meticulous needle worker whose completed artwork is prized by her children. In her later years, Clare remained independent in thought and action and memories of her witticisms and sense of humor continue to spark laughter in her children and grandchildren. She was a loving and devoted wife to her husband of 62 years and an inspiration all of us. She will be sorely missed, but will live forever in our hearts.

COTTER--James J. On September 13, 2014, James Joseph Cotter, 76, passed away after a heroic battle with prostate cancer surrounded by his loving family. He was born on February 10, 1938 in the Bronx section of New York City to James Joseph and Marie Wynne Cotter. In 1955, he graduated from New York City's Xavier High School, and then attended Georgetown University and Georgetown University Law Center. After graduation, he studied tax law at New York University. Mr. Cotter was a prominent and innovative businessman and known as one of the early activist shareholders. He was the driving force behind the often sited Technicolor decision in Delaware, a case that set out many of the standards for director conduct. He backed the management of Stater Bros. Markets, a California supermarket chain, in an early leveraged buy-out that lead to his ownership of half that company. He was instrumental in saving what was then known as the Fidelity Federal Bank. In the early 1980s, Mr. Cotter gained control of the company that owned the Reading Railroad of Monopoly gameboard fame and one of the oldest companies in America, which traced its roots back to the mid-1830s. Over the next thirty years, as Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of Reading International, Inc. (NASDAQ: RDI), Mr. Cotter oversaw the Company's growth to become one the world's leading theatrical exhibition companies and growing real estate company, with cinema, live theater and real estate assets in the United States, Australia and New Zealand. The Angelika Film Centers, the Union Square Theater building in New York City and Reading Cinemas in Australia and New Zealand (one of the largest exhibitors in each of those countries) are among the assets now controlled by Reading. Mr. Cotter started his involvement in the movie exhibition and real estate industries in 1969 when he worked for William Forman, the founder of Pacific Theaters, which, at the time, was a chain of drive-in movie theaters. Mr. Cotter continued to work for Pacific, its affiliates and the Forman family for over 40 years Mr. Cotter became a personal investor in California agricultural businesses in the 1970s. He owned Cecelia Packing Corporation and formed JJ Cotter Orchards. Mr. Cotter's agricultural business currently controls approximately 2,000 acres of orange groves in the San Joaquin Valley. Cecelia Packing Corporation is considered amongst the finest citrus companies in the industry. Outside of his love for business, Jim was an avid handball player, which he began playing at age 23. Shortly before his passing, Jim continued to play handball several times per week. Much of his life revolved around his handball games played at the Los Angeles Athletic Club, New York Athletic Club and University Athletic Club, at each of which he was a devoted member. Jim is survived by Mary Ellen Cotter and their three children, Ellen Marie Cotter, Ann Margaret Cotter and James Joseph Cotter, their five grandchildren, Duffy, Margot, Sophia, Brooke, James, his brother, Gerard W. Cotter, and his daughter-in-law, Gina Taylor. A Memorial Mass Celebration will be held at 2:00pm on Friday, September 26, 2014 at St. Paul the Apostle Church located at 1536 Selby Avenue, Los Angeles, California 90024. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to The Prostate Cancer Foundation in Mr. Cotter's name: www.pcf.org/JamesCotter.

COLEMAN--Robert J. Beloved husband and proud father of five children and fourteen grandchildren, died peacefully at home on September 14, 2014 following complications from cancer. He was born in New York City on September 24, 1935 and raised by his parents, William and Gertrude, in Irvington, NY. His father was a Partner at Adler Coleman and Company of New York. A competitive college racquets player and social science major, he earned his undergraduate degree from Fordham University in 1956. After serving his country as a First Lieutenant in the United States Army, he worked as a General Partner with Carlisle and Jacqueline and then with Allen and Company as a Vice President. In 1985, he founded his own firm, West Corner Corporation, where his keen insight and adept business entrepreneurship enabled him to specialize in private equity and real estate. In addition to his business career of over thirty-five years, he was passionate about 19th and 20th century American paintings and furniture, he served on the Board of Trustees for the New York Historical Society, and he was deeply proud of his Irish heritage. He loved his homes in both Grafton, VT and on Fishers Island, NY where his gardens and architectural restorations there provided a welcome outlet for his creativity. Most importantly, his faith and family were his foundation. He loved and doted on each of his grandchildren and they affectionately referred to him as "Poppy". Predeceased by both his brothers William and Peter, he is survived by his wife of 54 years, Suzanne Stepan Coleman of Chicago Illinois and New York City, his children Robert J. Coleman of Charlottesville, VA, Suzanne Coleman Bancroft of Mill Neck, NY, James P. Coleman of Bedford, NY, Jennifer Coleman Creel of New York City, Kevin C. Coleman of New York City, a sister, Carol Coleman Buckner Manning of Palm Beach, FL and fourteen grandchildren. Private burial services have been held, and a memorial service will take place at the Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola on Thursday, October 9th at 11am.

BROWN--Elvira, "Ellie" (nee DiMiceli), on September 12, 2014. Loving wife, mother, and proud New Yorker who returned to her roots after many years of living and travel abroad as the wife of an American diplomat. She was a gifted linguist, gracious hostess, and keen observer. She worked unstintingly to promote the interests of the United States abroad, as well as her husband's career. That husband, Carroll, and her two children David Brown and Suzanne Fitzpatrick will miss her terribly.

BOYD--Karen Anne, AIA, LEED AP, of New Haven, CT, formerly of New York City, August 29, 2014. Daughter of Dr. Arthur D. Boyd and Joan Fischer Boyd of Lexington, MA, formerly of Mamaroneck, NY. Sister of Dr. Kimberly Boyd and her husband Dr. Christopher Lovett of Newton Centre, MA and Arthur D. Boyd, Jr. and his wife Griet Dehandschutter of Acton, MA. Aunt of Alexander, Romie, and Nicholas Boyd and Ian and Matt Lovett. Graduate of Smith College, class of 1981; Graduate of the University of Virginia School of Architecture, class of 1986; Major Projects Planner at Yale University. Friends and family are invited to a memorial service on Sunday, September 28th at 1:00pm at the Marquand Chapel in the Sterling Divinity Quadrangle at Yale University, 409 Prospect Street, New Haven, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the T Cell Lymphoma Foundation at Yale University School of Medicine. Douglass Funeral Home Lexington 781-862-1800 www.douglassfh.com

ALI--Amina Grace Cullen, age 5, passed away suddenly September 17, 2014. Cherished daughter of Munawar and Maura Cullen Ali; loving sister of Nabil and Emma; beloved granddaughter of Khorshed and Monowara Ali and Frank and Marilyn Cullen; dearest niece and cousin of many. Amina will always be remembered for her love of life, strength, free spirit, angelic smile, dancing, hugs and love of Pirate's Booty. She touched the hearts of all who had the opportunity to spend time with her. We miss our sassy girl and will carry her in our hearts forever. Salat al-Janazah be held on Sunday, September 21, at 1:30pm at the Muslim Community Center (MCC), 8601 N. Menard Ave., Morton Grove. Visitation will be during 4-9pm on Sunday at Smith-Corcoran Funeral Home, 6150 N. Cicero Ave., Chicago and on 10:30 a.m. Monday until time of Funeral Mass at 11:00 a.m. at St. Cornelius Church, 5430 W. Foster Ave., Chicago. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Amina Grace Memorial Fund, c/o BMO Private Bank, 503 N. Washington Ave., Naperville, IL 60563. Funds will be directed to Amina's favorite organizations such as Misericordia and Gigi's Playhouse.

SAM AND DAVE DIG A HOLE By Mac Barnett. Illustrated by Jon Klassen. 36 pp. Candlewick. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 8) 
 
Two brothers are determined to find “something spectacular” in this clever second collaboration between Barnett and Klassen (after “Extra Yarn,” a Caldecott Honor book). As Sam and Dave apply shovels to dirt, their hole grows and grows, but their goal keeps eluding them. The prose is deadpan; the joke’s all in Klassen’s winsomely smudgy illustrations: There are gigantic jewels buried everywhere, except in the paths the boys dig. The dog, meanwhile, is after a prize of his own.

WELZER--Irv. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Irv Welzer. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

TAYLOR--Dr. Andrea, died of early Alzheimer's disease on September 17, 2014. Born August 20, 1946, and raised in Middle Village, Queens, Andrea (Mestel) graduated from Queens College in 1967 and, after earning perfect 800 scores on her MCAT's, went on to graduate from Albert Einstein College of Medicine, one of two women in her class of 1971. She became an accomplished internist and endocrinologist, practicing in Charlottesville, VA, for over 25 years, and then Northern California, before retiring. Andrea was a brilliant physician whose hard work and dedication to her patients (she estimated as many as 2000 at one point) helped pave the way for all women interested in the practice of medicine. Andrea was fortunate to have two sons who survive her, Peter and Matthew, whose love and respect were of great comfort to her in her decline. In addition, she is survived by her twin sister Karen, sister Lynn, mother Shirley and loving partner Armando. Memorial services will be in Northern California on September 29, 2014. St. Justin's Catholic Church, Santa Clara, CA (408) 296-1193.

SPIEGEL--Judy. Beloved Judy Blair Spiegel passed away peacefully in her home Saturday night. Treasured mother and mother-in-law to two adult sons, Mitchell and Greg and their wives Bonnie and Tara; cherished "Mema" to six adoring grandchildren, Nelson, James, Mia, Stella, Scarlett and Ford; sister, confidant and best friend to Cynthia Rose; inspirational aunt to two adult nieces Tristen and Courtney; dearest partner to Roy ("Ray Ray") Muro. Judy's passion, dedication and commitment to her family and friends was unparalleled. Her strength, braveness and resolve was an inspiration to all who knew her. Judy touched all those that were lucky enough to be part of her life. She will be greatly missed but live on forever in our hearts and memories. We love you. In lieu of flowers, donations in Judy's honor may be sent to The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter, 42 Broadway, New York, NY 10004 or online at www.als.org. Memorial service to be annouced at a later date

LIKWORNIK--Harry, 86, after a long life well lived. Adoring father of Andrea (David Weiss) and grandfather of Jake. Sweet and gentle, kind and generous, funny and wise no wonder everyone was wild about Harry. Much beloved, sorely missed, and forever and ever in our hearts. Service on Tuesday, 9:45am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

LENGYEL--Gretchen Hunicke, was born on April 28th, 1944 and passed away on Wednesday, September 17th, 2014 at the age of 70. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, Peter, daughters Monica Karlson and Cricket Lengyel, son Roger Lengyel, grandchildren Sebastian, Jasper, Hugo, Malcolm, Griffin and Ryan, brother James Hunicke and sister Deborah Manion. She co-founded The Madison Playgroup in 1981, and with great pleasure, educated more than twelve hundred two- and three-year-olds during her career. After a New England childhood she became a Manhattan dweller and an expert and lecturer on various aspects of raising and educating children in New York City. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1966 with a major in Medieval English History and Literature, and could rarely be found without at least two books-in-progress, a warm, welcoming smile, her many adored friends and/or a grandchild in tow. She exuded goodness and kindness, and as one friend amusingly wrote, was quite a "gifted people person." She will be missed so deeply by so many. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest on Tuesday, September 30th at noon. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for donations made in Gretchen's memory to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

KOLLEENY--Steven J. The Board and staff of Human Rights First mourn the loss of Steven J. Kolleeny, a member of our Board of Advocates and pro bono colleague. Through his pro bono legal work and mentoring of other volunteer attorneys, Steve helped hundreds of people who faced persecution secure safety in the United States. These former refugees and their children are now rebuilding their lives, free from violence and harm, in this country. It was an honor to work with him and we will miss him greatly.

JOSEPH--Arthur, 94 of Monroe Twp.,NJ on September 20, 2014. Beloved husband of Claire for almost 72 years. Leaves behind two children Joan and Michael, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School. Private services were held at B'nai Abraham Cemetery, Union, NJ.

GWATHMEY--William "Willie". Gaines. Beloved son of Gaines Gwathmey and Rose Harvey; devoted brother of Katie Gwathmey; passed away on September 19th, in Washington, D.C. He was 20. The 6'2," freckle-faced New York native, with a big smile and an even bigger heart, lived life to the fullest. He was known for his easy charm, boundless energy and infectious enthusiasm. A 2012 graduate of Collegiate High School, in New York, Willie excelled both in the classroom and on the court. During his junior and senior year, he helped lead the school's varsity basketball team, the "Mighty Dutchmen," to back-to-back state championships. He was also an avid tennis player. Willie was a junior at George Washington University (GW), pursuing a degree in Finance and Economics at its School of Business, at the time of his passing. In addition to his parents and older sister, Willie is survived by an extended family of relations and friends from every walk of life. A service to commemorate Willie's life will be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, located at 1157 Lexington Ave, New York, at 11am on Wednesday, September 24th. Anyone wishing to make a contribution in Willie's memory might consider a donation to the Collegiate School's Athletic Fund.

GRANT--Dr. John Phillips, Jr.,an accomplished NYC urologist, died September 15th, 2014 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital of complications from a stroke. He was 82. At his bedside at the time of death were his four children and his wife, Jane. Dr. Grant practiced urology for over 40 years in New York City. He was a member of the surgical team that performed the first renal transplant done at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in 1969. After working early in his career at Columbia, he became a staff surgeon at Roosevelt Hospital in 1969 and continued to work there as an attending physician until his retirement in 2005. Dr. Grant was born on January 30, 1932 in Greenwich, Connecticut. He graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1950 and Amherst College in 1954. He served two years in the Marine Corps and was honorably discharged in 1956. He entered Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1958, graduating in 1962. He completed his residency in urology at Columbia. He served as a volunteer surgeon for three months during the Vietnam war at Rach Hyah Hospital in Saigon. Dr. Grant completed a six-month fellowship in pediatric urology at Great Ormond Street Hospital in London in 1969 before beginning his formal affiliation with Roosevelt Hospital. He volunteered throughout his early career at Hopital Albert Schweitzer, in Deschapelles, Haiti, the hospital founded by the parents of his first wife, Jenifer Grant. John, who was known as Jerry to his family and early friends, was a founding member of the Zumbyes singing group at Amherst College. He sang with the University Glee Club of NYC for over 20 years. Besides his love for singing, he enjoyed cooking, bridge, opera, political discourse, travel and, most of all, time with his family. His family years were spent in Englewood, New Jersey. He moved to NYC in 1980 where he remained until his death. His favorite vacation spot was a family camp in Belgrade Lakes, Maine where he annually gathered with his children and grandchildren. Dr. Grant is survived by his wife, Jane Robb Grant, his two sisters, Mary Grant of Greenwich, Connecticut and Priscilla Grant of Cape Elizabeth, Maine, along with his children, Dr. Gwendolyn Grant of Durango, Colorado, Dr. John Phillips Grant III of Berkeley, California, Susannah Grant of Santa Monica, California, and Kate Grant Kellogg of Boulder, Colorado, along with 13 grandchildren. Services will be held at The New York Society for Ethical Culture on October 11th, 2014 at 4pm. Memorial contributions may be made to Maine Lakes Resource Center, PO Box 431, Belgrade Lakes, ME 04918.

DRISCOLL--Doris Tracy, of Rockville Centre, Brooklyn, and East Hampton died on September 20, 2014 at age 87. Daughter of the late James and Marguerite Heaney and the adopted daughter of the late Mrs. Thomas F. Tracy, wife of the late James Patrick Driscoll. Predeceased by five brothers, Thomas, James and Robert Heaney, Walter and William Tracy and three sisters, Helen Tracy Driscoll, Marie Tracy Murphy and Kathleen Tracy. She is survived by her children James, Doris, and David. Six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Doris attended St. Saviour Elementary and High School and was a graduate of the College of New Rochelle. Later, she became a faculty member at St. Saviour's High School. Doris will always be remembered for her humor, quick wit and unforgettable parties. Reposing Monday, 7-9pm and Tuesday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11215. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday at the Church of St. Saviour, 11am. Interment to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery.

BARRETT--Mary B.,100, of Goshen, NY on September 19, 2014. Devoted wife of late Arthur L. Barrett, loving mother of David and Assemblymember Didi Barrett, and adoring grandmother of Alec and Annabel. Born in Paterson, NJ, Mary served in WWII as Second Lieutenant, Womens Army Corps. Educated at Montclair State and Harvard, she began teaching English in 1934 and retired as Professor Emerita at SUNY Orange to travel, make quilts and write poetry.
